description:
Family of 4 on vacation in SF....did Saturday morning dim sum here.  f you would like white rice, I suggest you order it as soon as you sit down. The food was fantastic.   We had:

Green tea
Shrimp dumpling
Spicy shrimp dumpling 
Sweet shrimp
Duck
Fried noodles
Sesame chicken 
Greens
Pork skewers


We enjoyed everything.  No wait to be seated at 10:45.  Within 30 seconds of getting seated, carts were approaching the table.
Great service.  Great dim sum experience.  Highly recommend.

Cons:  had no idea what individual dishes cost.  Did not feel it was expensive, but felt like pricing was hidden.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Customer Service: 5/5
Recommend: Pan Fried Chive Dumplings

The most quintessential way to experience dim sum is at a restaurant where servers roll carts piled high with steamer baskets.  City View offers that service, as well as an English picture menu for you to order items you're too impatient to wait for.  This place is great for tourists and those who are intimidated by the frenzied pace of your typical Chinese restaurant.  The staff is friendly and professional, and the restaurant itself is very clean.  Although the servings are quite expensive for dim sum, I don't mind paying that extra money for the top-notch service.  Make sure to come before 1-2pm for a variety of dim sum options.  Also, there is street parking, but you will have to circle around quite a bit.  I'd recommend just parking in a structure.  There always seems to be a wait here, so I'd suggest making reservations, although I only waited 20 minutes on a Sunday noon.  For those who are beginner dim sum eaters, City View is a good starting point.
author: Charissa S.

description:
$67 (pre tip) for 10 items, I'm not sure of the breakdown of the costs, but it's categorized by small, medium, large, and specialty items.

BBQ Pork Buns - 4.5/5
Black Bean Spare Ribs - 3.5/5 
Chicken Feet - 4/5
Turnip Cake - 4/5 
Shrimp Dumpling - 3/5 
Shrimp Sui Mai - 4/5 
Shanghai Siu Long Bao - 5/5
Stuffed Crab Claw - 5/5
Tofu skin stuffed vermicelli and veggies - 3/5
Seafood Ball - 4.5/5 
Tea - 2.5/5

You don't order from a menu, but there are plenty of staff members circulating and bringing different items as well as bussers to come and remove the finished items. I can appreciate efficiency and would rather have that than friendly service.

We were there before they opened at 10 and were second to be seated. By the time we finished, there was a long wait already.
author: Cam C.

description:
Best dim sum!!! This was such a fabulous meal. If you like Dim Sum then you must try this fabulous restaurant.  Good food, fast service, tons of variety. 
Shrimp dumplings were my favorite and the duck was also delicious. Go early on the weekends or be prepared to wait for a table.
author: Alison B.

description:
There are many hangover curealls, and dim sum is one of them.

City View has a few locations in the SF area, and this one in particular is in/near Chinatown and the Financial District, meaning it's an ideal spot for a quick work lunch.

Our party of 2 was seated quickly - larger parties had a longer wait. But anyone who knows dim sum knows the more people, the merrier! You get to try more. 

I think our favorites were the shrimp & chive dumplings, soup dumplings, and crab claws. Skip the eggplant and tofu (eggplant was good, tofu was rubbery) and fried tarot root. 

Place is clean, carts are a plenty, closing out was fast - I'm a fan. Craving it right now, all the way from Houston, Texas.
author: Farrah A.

description:
Fantastic quality of dim sum.  Just back from China (granted, not Guangzhou, but still...) and I dare say the dim sum quality is better at City View.  Variety is spot on, and the wait wasn't too bad on a Saturday at 1pm - maybe just 10 minutes.

Must-haves are the turnip cake which is especially crispy and not too oily, the kung pao shrimp which is a nice take on a classic shrimp dumpling, and the crispy-top dessert buns (I didn't get a name) that was the absolute perfect dim sum dessert for a sweet tooth that also likes a bit of substance.

The only miss is the price.  Dim sum for 3 ran us $90 with only a pot of tea to drink.  Ok ok, this is SF, but it's DIM SUM.  It's cheaper in London and NYC, two other pricey cities.  Tho fine, it's really good food.  But still...you only get my 5 stars when I don't feel a bit poorer just for going to dim sum.
author: Nathan B.

description:
Soooo good. They close at 2:30pm so you really have to time it correctly as there is usually a huge line of people on Saturdays waiting for a table, and the hostess is running around with a legal pad filled with names operating on a system that will make zero sense to you. Just take a seat on the curb and be patient. 

It's a white table cloth restaurant but it's not fancy- you'll get a mix of locals and tourists, families, hungover USF students, and Chinatown regulars who have been coming for years. They are one of the last dim sum restaurants in the city I believe who still have the carts, but they also have a menu you can order off of which I prefer because you know what you're getting is hot and fresh (out the kitchen). 

My favorites are the shrimp and chive dumplings, shrimp siu mai, xiao long bao, char siu bao, and the eggplant and tofu. The hot tea is also really nice. For 3 people who eat A LOT with a couple of beers, we usually get out of there for about $80.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Best place in the city for dim sum! When it's only open for a few hours each day and yelp sometimes has a warning for unclean business practice yenno you're in for a real treat! There's almost always a wait and plenty of Chinese patrons so you know it's the spot! 

My most recent experience went like this: my coworker and I arrived a few minutes after 12 which was pushing the lunch rush. Since we were only 2, there was no wait! Lucky us! When we arrived it looked as though every table was full except for the one we were seated at. 

My coworker and I have both spent time (a year for me in Shanghai & 5 years in Beijing for my coworker) so we know what to expect dining in a Chinese place but They had great service. Waiters were attentive and all the carts were filled with variety. 

My coworker does not eat pork so we let the waiters know and they had great options for us. A few highlights of the food: onion pancake, scallop& shrimp dumplings, chicken shui mai, deep fried shrimp egg rolls w sweet chili sauce, and my own personal pork dishes of Shanghai soup dumplings & bbq pork pastries which were my absolutely favorite! For dessert we shared the sesame balls that were filled w red bean. 

This was enough for the two of us to even have a few things leftover for to go. Our bill came to $55 which also included one coke (no tea). 

special tips: never go close to closing as they won't have carts anymore and will have the regular menu which isn't the full dim sum experience. If you're entertaining people visiting the area or have a large party they have plenty of large tables to accommodate but definitely will have a wait especially on weekends. If it's too crowded R& G lounge up on Kearney is a great replacement.
author: Jazmine S.

description: Yes this place is touristy and yes the crowds are huge but the dim sum is still pretty good! We came around 11 so we avoided the bulk of the crowds and thank god we did, when we left there were masses of people outside in the alley. The food here was pretty good and they are fast and have a wide selection with your usual dim sum fare and some additional ones like Peking duck.
author: Jen L.

description:
Amazing food here. This place is so good. I wish that the food in Vegas could be as good. I ate so much food. My favorites are their Shao Long Bao's and their Sticky Rice. They had carts moving the entire time and I couldn't help but keep grabbing for more food.  

Right when we walked in, I had 3 cart pushers asking me if I wanted food. I told them I needed to still put my coat down but I appreciate the eagerness to stuff me with ginormous amounts of food.  We had a group of 9 people with us and the kids even loved the food here. Big plus!!   

All the noodles were made fresh. That's what makes the place so good. I've been to so many places where noodles are stale or dry. Nope this place is NOT!!

Please open this in Las Vegas!!!!!!
author: Annie E.

description: Came here for dim sum on a Saturday with my gf and my mom and we were seated right away around 1pm for a party of 3.  They have decent service here but the dim sum is good.  They aren't too pricey either compared to a lot of other dim sum restaurants in the city.  This might be one of my to go spots for dim sum whenever I am craving it.  Street parking is pretty hard to find since it is in the Chinatown but there is a parking lot right across this alleyway that you can park in and there is usually parking inside there.  They do close after 2:30 but they do re-open later for dinner. It is one of the nicer dim sum joints in the city as well compared to Koi Palace and Dragon Beaux (same owners) but those two are more pricier.
author: Ben Z.

description: For SF dim sum without a journey this is as good as I've had.  On a weekday you can get in and out under an hour.  Amaze
author: Sparrow S.

description:
I rolled up solo around 11AM on a Sunday and was immediately seated.  The hot tea came out quick, and I quickly started my aggressive positioning for dumplings, bbq pork noodles, fried taro, chinese broccoli, some siu mai/har gao hybrid, fried turnip cake, and pork and shrimp siu mai.  The BBQ pork noodles were by far and away the stand out on the menu.  I was underwhelmed by the siu mai (they seemed overcooked), and I prefer a greasier, more gelatinous filling.  The fried taro wasn't as greasy as I'm used to, which is not a bad thing!  

The service was impressive for an Asian joint, but I'm surprised that six dishes totalled more than $40 for lil ole me.  Over $6 per dish is a bit steep for dim sum, but I'll come back to this place b/c there was no wait, the service was very attentive, and the small handful of dim sum gems that were executed very well.
author: Crystal C.

description:
City View is a very popular. By the time we got there around 10:30 am, a lot of the things that we wanted to try such as duck, and a couple of their more popular dumplings were sold out. 

The service was outstanding and much appreciated. Knowing that we couldn't get some of the dishes we came for, the management took extra special care to make some other things for us fresh. One stand out was the shrimp egg roll. It was so delicious when freshly fried. 

We also ordered: Pork and shrimp shu mai, har gow, some XLB, walnut shrimp, (which they made fresh, so good!), and crab claws. Crab claws are a must get; delicious shrimp meat surrounding a single crab claw, breaded and then fried. Absolutely delicious! No egg tarts, maybe next time. Everything was good.

I would definitely come back if I were ever in SF again, but I would come much earlier. Happy eating!
author: Kyung E.

description: So glad to find this place.  Our go-to dim sum place for years has declined in quality and we are so happy our concierge recommended this place.  First, it is immaculately clean.  We went on a Sunday morning and it was pretty crowded.  The hostess is super efficient and we were seated within 20 minutes.  The place was filled with lots of different people.  The servers were very efficient.  We had water, tea and food within 2 minutes of sitting down.  Everyone spoke English, which made it much easier.  If we didn't see what we wanted, we asked and someone went and brought it to us.  Very impressed with the service.  AND the food was awesome.  I ate way too much.  This is my new go-to place for dim sum.
author: Michael W.

description:
Packed when I went for my first time, not sure if that's a normal thing here. There were people waiting outside and inside, but not in a line. Randomly scattered every where. 

Go to the lady at the hostess stand/podium with a note pad (if you can spot her with everyone standing around) and get your name on the list ASAP. I didn't know until I spotted people walking in and going to her, she's pretty small and unnoticeable in the crowd.

You can stand inside or outside and she will call your name at both areas. She told us 20 min wait, but it was actually 30.

Food was worth it though, very very fresh!! They have hot oil if you ask a waiter/waitress. 
If you are looking for a certain item, and they don't come around on the cart with it, just ask a worker and they will grab it for you.

Slightly on the pricy side for dim sum, but worth it. Spend over $40 for a few plates for 2 people but it had fresh seafood.

Enjoy!
author: Teena N.

description: Came here with a family friend based on a recommendation and what a great experience! The dim sum was delicious and the service was great. We definitely over ordered. Highly recommended that you show up early as the place tends to get very busy on weekends.
author: Neda P.

description:
Pretty damn good, definitely exceeded my expectations. I honestly prefer this place over other not-to-be-named fancy dim sum places in the FiDi.

We came by on a Thursday right around lunch time. When we arrived there was a large crowd around the entrance. Don't be shy, get in there and put your name down with a lady who is holding a yellow notepad. If you're there when she calls your name you'll be seated right away. If not, your spot will be taken by someone who is ready and very willing.

We ended up waiting less than 10 minutes for this very reason. As soon as we were seated the dumplings we wanted passed by and we swooped in! We got: 

Har Gow: yummy, large pieces of shrimp with thin skin

Shu Mai: same commentary, a bit more greasy due to the pork. well executed

Walnut Prawns: could have been crispier but a nice balance of sauce with walnuts

Woo Kok (fried taro with pork & water chestnuts): nicely done! not greasy at all, despite being fried

Chicken Lettuce Wraps: I'll admit I've never had these at dim sum before, but they were super yummy. the filling was flavorful without being overly saucy

Stuffed Crab Claw: again, yummy! 

Overall, I was pleasantly surprised. I'll definitely come back to try some of my other favorites (turnip cake, etc.). It's not my favorite dim spot in the city but it is a good one, especially for the area.
author: Vanessa S.

description: Should of known better than to have eaten here when I had to chase down the hostess to get my name down on her list. The second warning would have been all the white folks. This place had SHIT for food. Worst dim sum I have ever eaten. DO NOT EAT HERE. Go somewhere else. There's plenty of other dim sum joints that'll treat you shitty but with better food
author: Angie K.

description: This so good , clean , service won't disappoint will be back !  A gem  !  Nice place to bring friends , family and most of all visitors !
author: Edita A.

description: Cleanest dim sum place you'll ever go to. The tables are not cramped, the dim sum cart pushers actually show you what's on their cart (catering to a potentially non-Chinese audience), and for these two reasons alone, I'd give it 4 stars. The upscale service justifies the higher prices. We came close to when it opened and they had a line out the door. Fear not, the hostess is good at keeping a waitlist and goes through the list very efficiently. Just make sure you stand close by because many of us missed it when she called our names.
author: Susan W.

description:
**** THEY CHARGE HOT TEA****

When you first sit down, servers ask if you want hot tea, but you have to pay Hot Tea. He will not say it will be charged. It doesn't taste very good, either. I don't recommend ordering tea if you don't really like it. You can pick up dishes, when servers walks around with diDimsum was generally delicious. I ate Sumai, shrimp dim sum and dimsum with pork soup, and sumai was the most delicious I had ever eatten. I had Beijing duck in a special dish, but it was soso. The egg tart for dessert was so small that it was hard to taste the egg. 

If they said tea would be charged, I would give 4 star for this restaurant.
author: Da Won L.

description:
City View is a complete and total gem of a place! From the outside it really does not look like anything special but to eat there is such an experience. They serve you tea on arrival and immediately a cart will come up to the table and it becomes a free for all. 

They have traditional "cart style" dim sum where the servers go around with different carts of delicious items and you get to make the choice of whether or not you want it. I would definitely go with friends this way you can get a variety of dishes and just split them all. The dumplings were fantastic as was the Chinese broccoli and some other "mystery" item we tried. 

Overall, eating at City View was an amazing experience and the dim sum is delicious. I will definitely be back there.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
This dim sum restaurant is like a lower quality Yank Sing. I forgot that I ate here before and had the same reaction.

Food is mediocre. However decor and service are better than other Chinatown places. It's clean and the clientele is more affluent than many other places. No pushy people waiting next to you for a table.

It feels like a nice restaurant so it's disappointing when the food is meh. We had mainly steamed dumplings and the flavors were not distinctive. Can't really recall anything good about them. Probably the best item was the fried sesame ball, which was still warm although the outer coating was too thick with very little filling. 

Three of us did not order very much and the bill was $60 so a little pricier than other places but less than Yank Sing.
author: Joanna S.

description: Dim sum was pretty decent.  I came here years ago living in fremont.
author: Johnny L.

description: Great dim sum!!! Try to get there a little earlier so you don't have to wait and make sure your full party is there! I loved the shrimp rice rolls
author: Errie S.

description:
I am not sure why there was a line out the door for this place. Quality of the food was poor. Service was meh. They charge $1.50 tea price per person, even though we ordered just hot water. We were NOT informed that we would need to pay for hot water... (we did have it fixed at the end and was not charged). A bit ridiculous for someone who did not know. 

I wonder if it was the dim sum carts that attracted people to come here. Or maybe because they think the food is reasonable priced? Ordered 8 things. We did not get full, paid $42.86 for 4 people. I thought the portions were a bit small. The only thing I really liked from there: Turnip Cake. Also, they do not have congee as a dim sum option. 

If you're all about the cart service, then go for it. By the way, they take AMEX (woohoo!)
author: Jenny Y.

description:
Good food.
Reasonable price.
Delicious.
Original Chinese dim sum.
I'm not sure if it's in china town or not but I can see lots of Chinese restaurant.
The place might be a little bit difficult to find. The place is spacious. They will serve food in cart and you can pick whatever you want. Price about 20-30 dollars for big lunch.
author: Meenarin P.

description:
City View has definitely ruined cheap dim sum for me.  The quality of the ingredients and the flavors are distinguishable from pick-up-and-go counters in Chinatown. I love a bargain, but it is definite worth the price of high quality dim sum here. 

This place is quite busy during weekday lunches, so come early or the tail-end of the lunch rush/peak time (~2pm). 

Dine-in service is decent. Carts roll through and you pick what you like. Anything you don't see, you ask a staff passing by.

To-go orders are awesome here. I came in around 1:30-2pm, order from the cashier/front desk, and wait about 15 minutes. Love their little containers for the dim sum! Everything comes our hot and delicious! $40 worth will feed 2 people.
author: Hmmm O K.

description:
This is one of those reviews where I distinguish between the food and the service -- the food was exactly what one would expect from dim sum and nothing extraordinary or particularly memorable. However, the service had significant opportunity for improvement. There was no significant waits for the dim sum carts and most servers were accommodating, but a couple of ours (males) seemed to be bothered by any request and even slammed down some glasses in what seemed to be frustration.

The restaurant was full and the cart service frequent. We most enjoyed the fried shrimp balls, the pot sticker dumplings, and the almond shrimp. We did note that many of our earlier carts were mostly carbohydrate dumplings etc. and some of the more substantive protein items arrived too late after we already were full. Having a more regular variety between the carb items and the proteins would have been great.

Overall, this was a fun experience, and our total bill came to $26 each including tip after sampling a lot of items.
author: Todd B.

description: Awesome place for dumplings and food alike. The food came out fast but make sure to ask for a menu. They come by with different dishes and will keep doing so until you say otherwise. If you want anything specific you have to order it.
author: Louis M.

description:
Their food was ok, but I have experienced better at other restaurants (2 stars). There were a couple of items I liked ok (e.g., Peking duck), but nothing wowed me. Particularly, I was looking forward to enjoying great xiaolongbao (a.k.a. soup dumplings), but I was completely disappointed!

As we had a reservation, we, a party of 9, were seated immediately. When we were leaving the restaurant, there were many people waiting even outside the restaurant. For one thing, I was not very impressed by the food. For another, there are many dim sum restaurants in Chinatown. So, it's hard for me to understand why this place is so popular. Anyway, if you must try, I recommend you make a reservation.

******************************
If you found something useful in my review, please hit "useful" so that I can improve my reviews. If you love food and traveling, follow me, or better yet, let's become friends on Yelp! Thank you and happy Yelping!
author: Masanori D.

description:
City View Dim Sum is located on the edge of the Financial District and Chinatown.  It serves a more diverse clientele than dim sum places deep in the Richmond.  Given that, the food caters to more Western tastes and when I went there yesterday was heavily dumpling based.

The food is acceptable and the decor of the restaurant is quite nice.  Unfortunately, I was quite disappointed with my experience.  The food just tasted less fresh and the prices were much more expensive than I remembered.

Dim Sum is hard in San Francisco - places like Yank Sing and Lai Hong are pretty over rated compared to places like Asian Pearl and Hong Kong Lounge.  Lines here can run long - was lucky to get seated immediately.
author: Mark C.

description: My coworkers and I frequent this place pretty regularly. Service is impersonal and the wait can be long if you come right at peak lunch. We've found you get the best experience if you come around 1:15 or so. They are still rolling around the good dim sum but aren't as stressed and you shouldn't have to wait for a table. Also, if they aren't still serving your favorite dish they'll be pretty fast to bring it fresh from the kitchen. Some favorites include the Xiao Long Bao, rice noodles in xo sauce, Peking duck, and scallop shumai. Don't bother with the veggies. We always forget how bland they are and order them anyway, only to have them sit there bland and uneaten.
author: Beth S.

description: This restaurant is so tasty and it's a fun dining experience. We were able to call ahead and make a reservation, but there were a lot of people waiting. I enjoyed my experience so much, I think it'd be fun to come weekly!
author: Turi F.

description: This is an awesome, convenient spot for dim sum in this area if you want a sit-down experience! The wait time can be long, so I recommend getting there earlier in the morning if possible. The service is a bit rushed but it's understandable with the amount of people who go here. I recommend any of the pork and shrimp dumplings. Shrimp and chives is my favorite. Honesty, I recommend trying as much as you can, it's all tasty!
author: Lupita D.

description: This is the second time we have come here in as many years, and two things are still the same...it is still crowded , and the food is still good. The prices have risen as they have all over, but still reasonable. The wrappers on the dumplings can be a little soggy and sticky due to being unable to breathe a bit in the carts, but letting them cool a bit helps. Yes, the have carts and that to me is part of the charm. Service is good, and if it takes a little time it actually is good so then you don't overstuff your face and regret it later. Selection is about average, and you must ask for the mustard. Still I will return.
author: Ifti K.

description: We had high expectations from the other reviews here, but our experience was very poor. The dim sum variety was very lacking -- missing many traditional items, had a lot of sweets and fried items instead. Some of the carts didn't bother going by our aisle of 2-people tables, so the food came around very slowly, BUT the waitress with glasses kept on asking us if there was anything she could get for us. I didn't know that that meant she would give us our check, but she did! We were really disappointed because we were planning to stay longer for more food to come around, but we were rushed out instead... even while we were still working on an item. Not coming back.
author: Lucy T.

description:
I visited City View with my parents who were in town and seeking an "authentic" dim sum experience in Chinatown, and it definitely provides that: white tablecloths, cart service, and most of the basic staples you'd expect to be served. 

Service is pretty good -- one thing I noticed was that a huge variety of stuff went around on the carts in the hour or so we were there. If you don't see a dish you're hoping for, just hold out and it'll come eventually!

The food is average compared to some of the "better" dim sum available in SF but it's definitely a cool tourist type experience, or a great option if you're looking to avoid dropping a ton of money or waiting on a long line. There was no wait to be seated around noon on a Saturday, which is a blessing in SF, and prices were excellent -- $25/pp (after tax and tip!) for a feast-worthy amount of food.
author: Christine G.

description:
Oh! Em! Gee!

This came up as a top spot for dim sum in San Fran. Yelpers were spot on with this!

I've never seen so many different yummy options before. It was never ending. I need to go back because I feel I only tasted a tiny selection of choices!  

City View only does lunch. And it's packed. So get there a tad early & be prepared for a wait (we lucked out & arrived just before the crowd). Also, it's a bit tricky to find, down a rather non-touristy street. Don't give up finding it. You'll be so glad you did!
author: Ekatarina V.

description:
More like 3.5...

Arrived at around noon on a Saturday. It was busy, but not too packed and we were seated right away. We ordered tea (guk boh - black & chrysanthemum tea! DELICIOUS!) and the carts started coming around pretty quickly. 

I enjoyed the food here...just not the usual dim sum. Generally, my go to is the shumai and hargow, and unfortunately, those were sub par! I did enjoy the soup dumplings, crab claw, lettuce wraps, honey walnut shrimp, and peking duck!  Sadly, most of those were premium prices, bringing our total to $75 for two people. Womp, womp. The chili also leaves a bit to be desired on the spice level. 

Overall, not bad if you're looking for more non-traditional dim sum, but prices are a bit on the high side. Oh, and there is no city view.
author: Jaymie Lynn S.

description:
One of the best dim sum restaurants I have ever been too, only competition is a place I know in Southern California but hands down, the best in the north. 

Authentic real Chinese dim sum. I don't have to describe every single dish because they were all good. The taro cake is already, a winner. Love this place. Only issue, we didn't get all the different types of dim sum to choose from so we got a limited choice to pick from. I would wish they would have everything pre prepped so customers can order them all. I asked for fried taro balls, shrimp dumplings, and other dishes but had to wait. The wait was too long.
author: Tom L.

description: Umm...  just go.  If you like dim sum, this place is it. Service was great and the food was better. You're going to pay more than most but you're getting a great dining experience for it. Just go. Did I write that already?
author: Robert F.

description:
Thank goodness for reservations! Came in a little after 12pm with my coworkers and this place was packed! Not sure if the downstairs is typically used during this time, but the place was fairly busy. The restaurant is more spacious than other dim sum spots, with a little more space in the aisles to walk by. The space looked clean and the inside was nice and bright. The place is located in Fidi/almost CT, so there are other dim sum options not too far from this place. 

We were seated immediately and the food carts came around quickly and pretty frequently, so we were always given more options before finishing what we had and waiting for more. That's the great thing about going with a larger group of people to dim sum is that you can taste a greater variety of dishes. 

I will say that the vegetarian dishes were really tasty! But my favorite was probably the xiao long bao. They had some dishes that are not typically offered at dim sum, like some chicken dishes. They even had green tea mousse as an option for dessert, different than the typical sweet buns you would order. The main dishes were pretty standard, but the food was still pretty tasty. The calamari had a better type of breading than I'm used to-more of a soy sauce taste which was a nice change. And you can't go wrong with sesame balls. I do wish they had a little more of the red bean paste, but I still enjoyed them.

Good dim sum spot for lunches with coworkers if you don't want to make the trip to another spot in CT.
author: Meghan J.

description:
BEST DIM SUM EVER. 
and I'm from NY.... this place really blew me away with their authentic dim sum. Everything was so fresh and SOOO GOOD. I left the place so full but hungry for more. I ended up coming back to pick up take out before I went back to NY cause I was craving it so much!! 

All their plates were so HOT and so FRESH and VERY LITTLE MSG. I didn't feel the need to have a nap afterwards, it was THAT GOOD. Everything was also not that salty which was just amazing. 

My party of 3 had about 9 dishes, 
Shrimp spring roll
Chive dumplings
Beef Rice Roll (cherng fun)
Chicken feet
Szechwan style dumplings
Fried Taro 'dumpling'
Shrimp dumpling
Fried Dumpling

Everything was just amazing.
author: Karina W.

description: I was shocked. I live so close to this restaurant and now I've finally tried it. This place is excellent. Great food and service. You will not be disappointed . Amazing dim sum!
author: Leman B.

description: This is the first place I'd ever tried Dim Sum before and now I'm hooked! Service was great. They bring the food around on carts so you can see what you're ordering.
author: Kristin M.

description: Great, traditional dim-sum.  Make sure to there at the open otherwise be ready to wait.
author: Plx S.

description:
-Not good for big parties. Portion sizes are more suited for 2-4 people. 
-Sunday afternoon the wait is fast compared to other dim sum spots, even faster if you have a small party. 
-Carts were not rolling out fast enough.
-Americanized dim sum, far off from the traditional. Don't bring traditional grandparents here, you'll disappoint them lol.
-Recommend for first time dim sum experience to serve as comparison.
author: Hui L.

description:
I came with a party of 6 and waited 30 minutes for a table around noon on Sunday. 

City View had offerings that I wasn't use to at other dim sum restaurants like their shrimp honey walnut, but they also had the usuals. 

My friends and I paid ~$30 per person at the end. I wouldn't plan on coming back here as the different dishes were hit or miss. It was convenient as the different carts would come around, and you could easily add food if you were still hungry. I brought some of my friends, and it was their first time to a dim sum restaurant. City View was nice as you could see what you may be interested in eating if you're unsure as to the names of the different dishes. However, walking out of the restaurant, I realized there were some carts that didn't make it by the table as there were some dishes that weren't offered to us. 

I'd be interested in looking for better dim sum around the city.
author: Lander L.

description: Very good cart service for tourists . Everyone speaks English here and the dim sum is decent enough .. they use pickled radish and vegetables in their dumplings if you're not used to that. Unfortunately they were missing my favorite rice shrimp rolls so knocked one star off for that . I also found it was a bit expensive @ over 30/person .
author: Thang S.

description:
Hot and fresh dim sum, the runners resupply the carts with delicious dim sum. 

The lava bar are so good as are the soup dumplings. The shu mai is terrific as is the ha gow. The scallop gow was awesome too. 

DD said their baked char shu bow was the best she'd had. 

Good service and pretty clean. I love it!
author: Cynthia W.

description:
For some of the best dim sum in San Francisco you should definitely try this place it's a little crowded and chaotic but the dim sum is totally good also thought I was a bit overpriced. They really bombard you with tons of selections of my girl really liked it so we wanted to try it I enjoy the atmosphere but it was like I said very chaotic.

The good thing about dim sum is once your full about an hour later you can eat some more so we brought some home for later which was still very tasty
author: Mirko N.

description: Really good dim sum. Lunch was $60 for two.  A lot cheaper than Hang Seng.  They have an upstairs and a downstairs.  It gets crowded early for lunch rush.  We sat at 1130 and there was a line when we left.
author: Jeff C.

description: Great dim sum, clean place. Good service with carts pushing around like traditional Chinese dim sum. Only downsides are not enough options and overpriced, as price is higher than kitchen and is not as good.
author: Kevin R.

description: Wanted some dim sum while we visited San Francisco and stumbled upon this place. We came right at opening right before it got packed. They had so many choices and service was really fast. The workers were all very friendly and the restaurant is very clean and well kept. Highly recommend this place.
author: Vinny W.

description:
Old-school Cantonese dim sum beautiful executed, very fresh, plump ingredients. Mid-level pricing, in comparison to San Francisco FiDi and SOMA. The dining room itself is a gem, bathed in natural light and with high ceilings.

Why the single star?

Unfortunately on my third visit in as many months, it was a very cold day and my guest and I were seated in a direct line of the front door. Customers coming and going would carelessly open the door and it would lock into an open position. As I had recommended City View for our lunch, I jumped out of my seat three times to close the door, my guest closed the door once. When I caught the eye of the floor manager to request that she close the door once again, she shrugged, said it's the customers' fault and walked away.

My guest and I finished the few steam baskets on our table and left for another restaurant.
author: Mutant O.

description:
Awesome food! You have to go.
We  planned to visit this restaurant on our recent trip to San Francisco. We were aware of the long queues on the street outside and the limited working hours of this place. So plan your visit wisely. 
We made it quite early and even then we had to wait for around 10-15mins. But good thing is the tables keep rotating pretty quickly so you don't have to wait very long. Once seated, they promptly get you the pot of that amazing jasmine tea, the dim sum carts start coming by. We opted for our usual favorites - the pork dumplings, BBQ buns, BBQ duck, Shanghai dumplings, sticky rice in lotus leaf and spare ribs. Everything was amazing! The duck was fabulous. It came with a bun and the combination was so perfect! All through our brunch, the line outside never ceased. However the staff handled it well and kept the guests moving! This place is very close to the Coit Tower, so makes a good place to drop by for breakfast/brunch. As we left, we took to go orders for the sticky rice in lotus leaf and the spare ribs to experience the delicious food later in the day. Definitely going on my list of to go places for my next trip in San Francisco.
author: Oly M.

description:
Took my friends from Japan here last week! Always a great Dim Sum experience! Clean, white table cloths, friendly and attentive service and delicious dim sum!

We had 3 adults and 1 - 6 yr old child and we ate a ton of yummy items! To name a few... Black Bean Spareribs, Shrimp Dumplings with Chives, BBQ Pork Cheurng Fun, Ni Wong Bows(similar to), Siu Loong Bow, and more. 

Always a delight to have Dim Sum here! Hope you try it soon!  :0)
author: Aaa T.

description:
Caution - Writer of this review is in a FOOD COMA !!!

Delicious, Lip smacking, mouthwatering and other great words are not enough to describe my experience of this place. OK ! Enough being dramatic, lets talk about the real thing. 
They have a cart system and a menu system. By cart system I mean the servers roam around on carts with food on them. If something appeals you, you can just pick that plate and start hogging. 
I went for the safe option, the Menu option. I picked three things from the menu walnut honey shrimp, chicken buns and chicken skewers. 

FOOD-

Walnut honey shrimp - Full size shrimps coated with a layer of creamy honey sauce with crispy walnuts accompanying it. Shrimps cooked perfectly, had a nice flavor to them. No one can stop on one :P 

Chicken Buns - Pan seared buns filled with spicy minced chicken filling. I am literally drooling even thinking about them. So soft, served hot and filling was just amazing. Great flavor !!!!!

Chicken skewers - Crispy yet tender chicken thigh on a skewer. Paired well with the spicy red sauce, enough for 2 people as you get only 2 skewers in a plate. 

Ambience and Service - It was packed when I went in, had to wait for 15 minutes to get a table. Service is pretty quick and the food is served hot. Also, it a huge restaurant with ample of sitting space, good for big groups and they serve green tea with food.
author: Simran K.

description:
This is a GREAT Dim Sum Restaurant in San Francisco. Great location. Park in the Portsmouth Square parking garage, it's close and cheap!

My family and I have been going here for years and for the states it is very good! It's classic, carts and all! A must if you like dim sum and are in the Bay!
author: Jonathan S.

description:
Great place for a dim sum lunch, especially around financial district. Not a lot of options if you have dietary restrictions (most things have meat/seafood), but fantastic if you eat everything. I personally stick to chicken and seafood, and had no issues trying a bunch of different items here. 

Make a reservation if you can, as it gets crowded during the week. Good for groups, and probably better if you come with more people as you can really try a lot of different things before you get full.
author: Alka M.

description:
The quality and assortment of dim sum at City View is right up there with Yank Sing. The atmosphere is pleasant and informal, but you still get cloth napkins. The service is very friendly and efficient. We chatted and joked with several of the women rolling the carts around--a first!

It's a very smoothly run operation. At Tuesday lunch, with lots of people coming and going, our group of five felt very much at ease and couldn't have been treated better.

Among our favorites were the Peking duck, deep-fried breaded crab, sticky rice, potstickers, and shumai. 

City View is on a nice street just around the corner from the Portsmouth Square city parking garage.
author: Will L.

description: This place came highly recommended as good dim sum around Chinatown. We were a bit traumatized from our $100+ dim sum for 2 at Yank Sing a while ago so we approached this place with a bit of reservation. Located in a cute quiet street off the main hustle and bustle of Chinatown. When we arrived on a Sat around prime brunch time, the wait for 2 was only 5-10 min. I loved the feel of white tablecloths and the large open space. Lots of carts were already rolling around with goodies to be selected. Upon being seated, our eyes quickly darted around and we had a good idea of what we wanted to order. We started with tea and the food arrived so quickly that I completely forgot I had wanted a beer to go with my meal haha. Yes they charge for hot tea but I'm not sure why that's such a big deal that you would dock off stars. The food quality, freshness  and selection is excellent here (not to mention pricing and efficient service). Chicken Siu mai and spinach dumpling were just ok; have had better elsewhere. Pan fried chive dumpling was good and i was surprised by the high quality of their XLB (they sit in cute foil holders so you can easily slurp up all the juices). My favorites were the rice noodles roll with shrimp and they also had a shrimp toast like dish. Overall, very good dim sum and given the short wait, will definitely be back for more.
author: Yin H.

description: The food was great and the service was amazing! My whole family loved it and we will defiantly return. A must if you are in San Fran.
author: Lauren B.

description: The food and service is amazing here! I wish that the dimsum back in the OC was as good. We were seated right away on a Friday morning and the carts came by right away. My favorite was the BBQ pork bun, fried shrimp ball and the fried pork dumpling. One of the managers noticed I was trying to get a server's attention that missed me, she chased him right down to grab the dish for me! Amazing service for a dimsum spot, I'll definitely come back to this place when I'm back in the Bay!
author: Julie P.

description: authentic & great service! the cart ladies are so nice and there is never a short supply of food
author: Madeline O.

description: I've been here twice, and both times were really solid. I can't say I have a favorite dish, although the Peking duck is pretty good. The first time I ate here was after a half marathon, and my best friend and I probably ate our weight in dim sum and noodles. The last time I went, I was part of a party of 4 and we ordered enough for us - and the bill only really ended up being around $60, which isn't bad at all! I'd be back for sure.
author: Amy L.

description: Good food, good service. We were able to enjoy Dim Sum. Crowded but easy to get in. Highly recommend.
author: Antonio J.

description:
This place definitely gets packed during lunchtime so plan ahead or you may be standing around for a good hour. Make sure you go inside and check in with the hostess to get your name on the list!

I've been here a couple of times with my colleagues because who doesn't love DIM SUM! If you're wondering, this is the type of dim sum place that actually has people going around with the items on the cart. Some places don't do this (which sucks) but this place does.  I get my typical orders of hargow, siu mai, taro dumpling, turnip cakes, and more! Every single item I got here was full of flavor and extremely fresh. 

If you are looking for a different dish that you aren't seeing on the carts, go ahead and stop one of the workers and they will order it in the kitchen for you. 

Service is pretty good. food is good. On the pricier side of dim sum but worth it!
author: Michelle Z.

description: My colleagues and I love this place. Dim sum where they serve small plates on carts can be hard to find. They have a great selection, describe what is in each dumpling or on the plate (but they talk fast and they move fast so listen closely and decide quickly!) And is fresh and still steaming hot.  If you miss something you like don't worry because they will be back. The soup dumplings are one of our favorites. They are very hot and will bring you if you're not careful. These can be hard to find so this is a treat. Save room for the dessert carts. This trip we had 9 people and it was fun to be able to order so many different dishes and see what you really like for next time.  We also ordered a crispy noodle dish and the total was only $22 per person. That is pretty reasonable to eat all you can eat in San Francisco.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Delish!! We had chicken shuimai, crunchy noodles with chicken, steamed buns...yummy!!
author: Michele W.

description: Reasonable dim sum. Was certainly a wait on the weekend. Consider dropping some of your party off to get on the waiting list while you find parking. BBQ pork dumplings were delish.
author: Chris D.

description: Can't believe it took me this long to try this place.  After eating at many other dim sum places in SF: Yank Sing, Dim Sum Club, Begoni, Great Eastern, Mama Ji's, Dumpling Time...CITY VIEW is the best one I've been to.  Service was incredible for the usual dim sum location.  Food was great.  Xiu Mai, Rice noodle rolls, and Turnip Cakes were all delicious.  Definitely my new go to Dim Sum place in SF.
author: Jay H.

description: Solid and reliable restaurant in a city that struggles with their Chinese food - dim sum in particular. It seems like some reviewers have a problem with service. For me, I grew up eating in Cantonese restaurants and the brusque yet efficient service feels comfortingly and culturally familiar.
author: Lei T.

description: This is a delicious Dim Sum house with many selections to choose from. I recommend the crab claws,  yummy. Everything we ordered was very good.
author: Dan A.

description: The best dim sum restaurant in SF, closest to the best dim sum restaurants in HK.  This restaurant has been here for decades and continues to be the best and always so busy so get there early. Vincent the owner is very hands on and ensures that quality is maintained.
author: Sheila S.

description: Are you serious? Are you for real? Really? Is this real life? What? Carrots on siu mai. Cold egg tarts. Flavorless cha siu. 2 stars if there weren't carrots on the siu mai. Come on people.
author: Johnson L.

description:
Many of the dishes that were pushed around were different from what I usually see and there were some dishes that I usually see that weren't there. 
I did learn that I like baked sho pao better than steamed. They had these shrimp egg rolls that were pretty good. I tried a turnip cake for the first time which was very tasty. The texture was different, but with some chili and soy sauce, it was addicting. Shu mai is shu mai, I don't taste the difference between other dim sum places. They had soup dumplings which was a bonus, but they weren't as good as the ones I had in NY at the dumpling house. Sadly, they didn't have my favorite - black bean spare ribs. I ordered their duck, but it wasn't as flavorful as the ones I had in SSF. 

Place is surprisingly packed on a weekday by 12pm! It's the first dim sum place I've been too that had relatively more Caucasians than Asians dining. Service was fast and friendly (shocker). I liked this place but it wasn't the best dim sum I've had.
author: Jenna T.

description: Came here for Dim Sum with a group of friends. Food was all on point. Would recommend. Service was very fast as well.
author: Kim A.

description: So bomb! Yummy, delicious, worth the price you pay! Everything you order will be great!
author: Vannessa L.

description:
There's no city view with this restaurant. 

Considered to be a high-end dim sum restaurant, we can all decipher that to be very Americanized dim sum.

Nothing was terrible, but nothing particularly stood out. Service was attentive. Despite ordering all of our favorite dim sum dishes (sans a few because they aren't offered here), we left slightly unsatisfied.

I did like that we were seated right away because it's located away from the hustle and bustle of downtown Chinatown, but hey, authenticity wise, City View is catering to a very different crowd.
author: Trung N.

description: One of the better and cleaner places in Chinatown. Service is fast and good. Lots to choose from and food comes out fast, but it's nothing special. Gets super busy after 11:30AM.
author: Karen H.

description:
Dim sum here was delicious and was served in carts at tables, which is my favorite way of having dim sum. The craftsmanship on the dumplings is pretty remarkable if you stop to look at the patterns on the dough before popping them in your mouth.

The bill can be a surprise because they use the stamp system. Approximate cost per size next to stamps: Smallest ($3.85) medium ($4.20) large ($5) special 1 ($6) special 2,3,4 (?)
author: Lindsay B.

description: OHMIGAWD, paradise!!! The carts, the trays, our table near the kitchen. Loved it all!! Food was great and we are eaters so they picked up on that and pretty soon our table was full. 42 bucks for a feast for two of homemade Chinese food. This is a must stop!!!
author: JoAnne P.

description:
WE GOT SICK FROM EATING HERE!

Several coworkers and I ate here last week on the Friday before the July 4th weekend and I'm still recovering from whatever pathogen I ingested here.  I know it was this place because I hadn't eaten anything before lunch and on the walk back from the restaurant I clearly felt nauseous and went home without eating anything else. As soon as I got home the nightmare began continuing on through a week later at this point.

It's so upsetting to get sick from a place you trust with your food. It just makes you wonder what pathogen you ingested to make you so sick.

I've eaten here several times with no concerns of food safety, but no more.  This place is off my safe restaurant list.
author: V J.

description: Amazing place! We visited after watching the Chinese new year mini parade. We got seated right away, and before we knew it servers were bringing carts of food over. No need to wait to order or wait for food, it just keeps coming!
author: Kate M.

description: Absolutely the best Meal I had in San Francisco, the dim sum was outstanding and the price was below average for SF.
author: R P.

description: Came for lunch today. The line was literally out the door. Even though it was long we were seated relatively quickly. We had the bok choy, scallion pancakes, ha gao, soup dumplings, some other dumplings (filled w/ veggies and shrimp), honey walnut shrimp, Lotus bean sesame balls, fruit cup and green tea pudding. Everything was delicious. We really liked the honey walnut shrimp, bok choy and green tea pudding. The ha gao was good, but definitely not the best that I have had. Overall it was a good lunch, but surprisingly pricey for a dim sum place. It came to about $80.
author: Neelu Y.

description: A little expensive but super tasty. Attentive wait staff and polite though it was the end of their day and they were about to close.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
It was decent and a good option for a weekday lunch during the workday!  

There were a bit more Americanized dishes than normal dim sum (think skewers, etc) - but it was all right.  Tasted fine and was super quick which is a plus.  A couple of the dishes were a bit odd (for example, the rolled noodles were fried, and the soup dumplings were stuck to the foil) but overall tasted fine.
author: Kay C.

description:
This is my office's go-to spot for dim sum in FiDi. It's not outstanding, but it does the job very well, no complaints.

I don't feel like boring people with a rundown of our orders, but the most typical items were fine. Har gow (shrimp dumpling) was round and juicy, with a thin, chewy skin. Lor mai gai (sticky rice with filling) was as it should be, with chicken, mushroom, and Chinese sausage wrapped inside. Chive dumplings had what Cantonese people call "wok hei," hard to describe in English, but basically that you can tell the oil was sizzling when food was cooked / mark of a good chef. Sesame balls looked normal. Tip: Xiao long bao isn't a normal dim sum dish, people.

I always lol a little bit when I see that Yelp warns me that the restaurant I'm reading about has poor food safety...unfortunately, I'd probably argue that the more authentic a Chinese spot is, the poorer the food handling (and yes I'm from Hong Kong).
author: Nicole H.

description: Great variety of dim sum--some kinds I've never seen. Great prices too! Two of us shared six plates and had a glass of wine and a beer for under $45! Definitely worth a repeat visit.
author: Ryan S.

description:
A nice respite from the hectic chaos of Downtown San Francisco is City View Restaurant.

I would never have found City View if it were not for my friends who recommended it; as it is tucked down an alley, Commercial I believe.

The restaurant itself is immaculate...as in super clean. For me this is always an indication of quality. Service was simple and succinct. Food was good not great but for the price to quality ratio....I am a huge fan now.

Dim sum carts galore with wonderful chicken feet ( so good), mini bao, great sauteed greens, and more. The only dish I did not care for or thought was mediocre were the pot stickers.

As for the debate on the restaurants name: It is in an alley with no view but they have a very large painting of the lovely Chinese city Guilin. My two cents.

Highly recommend
author: David G.

description: This is my 2nd time here. My boyfriend took me here for my first dim sum experience and it was amazing. Watching the carts come by and all the different choices. I was hooked. But you've got to pass yourself otherwise your just too full to try all the delectables. We had a party of seven on a crowded Saturday morning but we were still seated in less than 20 minutes. Each one of us were happy with the multiple choices we ordered. 7 people and drinks, food ,Tea and the experience all for under $170.00.  Believe me we were stuffed...
author: Leah a.

description:
ugh, so torn between three and four stars, but rounding up for the value. 

they don't take reservations so if you're not there early for lunch, expect a 20+ minute wait. but it's worth it. lots of dim sum choices, with carts. two people can eat a lot for less than $30 which is awesome. space is small but comfortable. everything we ate was very good. would rather come here than some of the better known dim sum places in FiDi/SoMa
author: Bob U.

description:
We're so close to Chinatown, it's almost wrong not to walk the extra few blocks for dim sum.  But, when you work nearby and are in a time-crunch, this place does fine.

As a dim sum place, they are fine.  They have all the staples you'd expect, and not much that you don't.  Their service is swift and efficient, without much friendliness, which is again par for the course.  

Writing this it's difficult to get excited about City View, but I never leave disappointed either.  Come here if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way for it.
author: Denis S.

description: Believe it or not, I've never REALLY had a full-blown Dim Sum experience yet, and I guess, leave it to San Francisco to hook it up. I had a blast. I always enjoy exploring this type of food but I kind of struggle with the menu and what to choose. They just roll a big ol' cart full of delicious stuff up to you and let you pick. I think I ate one of everything? So fun. Definitely order the Soup Dumplings - you have to be good at chopsticks a little, and somewhat surgical with the process. Don't tear them. I like working for it a little bit sometimes.
author: Brian S.

description: Food here is pretty good but prices are pretty insane. We only got a few items when my sister and I went and it was close to 70 bucks!
author: Jennifer G.

description:
Delish dim sum!  I actually like it slightly more than Lai Hong Lounge, as the quality seems a bit more refined, but it is also a bit more expensive.

There are many items to choose from and I haven't tried every dish, but my favorites were:
- Walnut shrimp
- Eggplant with shrimp
- Tofu skin wrapped shrimp
- Fried taro dish

I went with 4 people, we ordered about 15 dishes...total was $30 per person including tax/tip.
author: Mon T.

description: Fantastic find on our day in SF!  2 teenagers, 1 growing boy and myself, enjoyed a great variety for under $65.  That doesn't happen EVER when I'm searching for a good meal at a reasonable price.
author: Marsha L.

description:
I usually give five star reviews for places that I think have good service, atmosphere, and food quality that meets standards for the price you pay. This place definitely meets those expectations. I came around 11 AM, right before the lunch rush. The restaurant is located on a quieter street and is very clean (in comparison to other Chinese restaurants I've been to). The service is pretty fast at seating you and getting you water and tea. There are a decent amount of carts servicing around and they call make sure to stop at your table.

I will confess part of the reason I came here was became it seemed like the servers understood both English and Mandarin, and the most stressful parts about dimsum for me around this area is communicating what I want in mandarin - since I'm not particularly fluent. So, that was an added bonus to all this.

As for the food, I personally liked everything I ate. Which was part of the reason I didn't take any pictures this time unfortunately. But the food is all pretty good quality. I tried the egg tarts, almond jelly, ribs, Peking duck (I love duck), siu mai, lotus rice and shrimp dumplings. I will echo what everyone else says about not over ordering though. I was so full after all of this. 

Overall, I had a good experience and as someone who has been to quite a few dimsum places around here, this is one of my favorites :)
author: Michelle L.

description: Great value dim sum in Financial District.  Due to the popularity, be prepared for long lines.
author: Alfred C.

description:
I LOVE City View! I went with coworkers for a team lunch. The variety of food and service were great!

Food: 4/5. We ordered all kinds of dishes and all of them were great! The variety of dishes to try were versatile and we were so full, we almost needed to be rolled out. So good!

Atmosphere: 4/5. Coming from Charlotte, this place was much more authentic than ours back home. Small in size but was clean and quaint.

Service 4/5: Very attentive service. Staff was nice and friendly.

Overall: 4/5. Will definitely return when I am in town!
author: Sarah W.

description:
I am surprised at myself that I have never noticed this restaurant has good dim sum!  Located in an alley, it is quite an out of sight, out of mind spot.

Their shrimp and chives steamed dumplings are bomb.  Black bean pork ribs are steamed up nicely.  Fried eggplants with shrimp cake tofu braised in sauce, was scrumptious.

Ladies were pushing the piping hot carts around the place.

Yum, yum for dim sum at this discrete location.
author: Tiffany D.

description: For dim sum places in and around Chinatown, the staff here is quite friendly and the place is quite clean. Not sure why there are so many negative reviews. The one drawback is that the prices are pretty expensive for what you would expect from dim sum. But otherwise, I would recommend this place if you want some good dim sum.
author: Harnoor T.

description: They didn't bring all the carts around to our table, so we couldn't even try everything! Food wasn't amazing either!
author: Tanaya W.

description:
My friends and I came around 11:30am for dim sum on a Sunday morning and we definitely skipped the line because we got seated right away (table of 6) but we saw people waiting at the door within the next 10 minutes. 

I'm from Hong Kong, so honestly I cannot say the dim sum here is good at all but compared to the other dim sum places I've had in the US this place isn't the worst either...let's just say I'm sure they are better dim sum places in SF, but I guess this place is okay too...

The biggest problem I have with this place is how we had to wait 20 minutes for some siu mai (pork dumplings). Siu Mai and Ha Gau are two of the most popular dimsum dishes ever, so I can't understand why the restaurant took forever to bring those dishes out. You can't order dim sum individually, you have to wait for the carts to come by and hope that they have the items you want. Which wouldn't be a problem if the restaurant is good with coming out with the foods people want but it is clearly not the case for City View. 

We ate a solid amount and in the end it came out to around $22 per person (including tip)--reasonable. 

I don't think I'll come back again just because there are many better dim sum places in Chinatown.
author: Christy W.

description:
Location: Right near the entrance to China Town in an alley way it's easy to find. Since it's in an alleyway parking is scare if there is any so definitely walk if you're coming here. 

Price: Pricier than other dim sum places, but it makes sense for SF. 

Service: Come 15-30 minutes before the lunch rush if you're coming with a big group. I don't think they take reservations. When we've gone we still haven't had to wait long even with a group of 12. 

They do get a bit frazzled when there are tons of people and it does get hard to determine who's your actual waiter. My peeve with this place is that we had an order of peking duck left and while we were waiting for a waiter to bring us a box another waiter came to clean up our table quickly and threw it away. A WHOLE PEKING DUCK! :( After doing so, they acted like it wasn't really anything instead of compensating us or asking if they could do anything to make up for it. Such a waste.

Food: We get a large mix of everything so it's hard to list everything we've tasted here. They have a great selection of dumplings, desserts, and other items you can order ala carte so you never have to worry that there won't be something for you.
author: Keizzel C.

description: Great place for a real dim sum meal - cars with steamed dumplings and buns and desserts as well. Filled with some good local color - there was a line out the door by 1100. Meal for three people, nine plates total, was $60
author: Elizabeth R.

description:
We came here on a weekday afternoon at about 1.30pm and it was not too crowded. The place does not serve congee (my staple for dim sum), but what we had was decent:

Har gao (ok), siew mai (ok), xiao long bao (ok), chicken feet (preferred Good Luck Dim Sum's), liu sha bao (yummy), shrimp chee cheong fun (this version has vege in it), glutinous rice wrapped in lotus leaf (this version has clear segregation of rice and meat). Egg tarts were sold out so it could have been pretty good? 

Price was reasonable for a dim sum restaurant (cheaper than Yank Sing). Service was a little rushed, with the servers telling us to meet the 2pm last order deadline (but they seated a couple who walked in at 2pm. D'oh!)
author: Lindt C.

description:
City View Restaurant :

In search of the best dim sum.

Summary- City View is the best place in town for dim sum and deserves a higher rating than Yank Sing! Food: fresh, authentic, high quality. Decor: clean and classy. Service: excellent. Price:  Reasonable (for SanFran).

In the US, I've had delicious dim sum in NY and FL. City View's menu is eclectic and innovative in comparison to other restaurants in the U.S. (You can't compete with dim sum at Guangzhou.)

Decor: when you walk-in, you immediately feel like you made the right choice walking in. It's not your typical Chinese restaurant (in the U.S.) the colors are subtle and decor is modern but still Chinese.

Food: OMG. I took my mom, who is a tough critic (yes, more than I am); and she loved it! We ordered 10 plates and all were superb from ingredients to execution. Most memorable : Duck Bao, Wu gohk- taro root dumpling;Lorh bahk go- Pan fried turnip cake; sesame balls; fried crab. We would've ordered more but were so full so planning to go again everyday until the trip ends.

Price: well priced. Here is a comparison , we ordered 10 dishes and it costs $76; whereas the other place I mentioned above was $135 (almost $20 something just for the Siu luhng bao- steamed soup dumplings !!!). The other place was good (better than NY and FL dim sum), but City View left an impression on me (and family).

Service: when there are no empty plates because someone is always attending to your table and refilling your tea and does so discreetly , then that's excellent service!!!!

Whether you are a dim sum aficionado or rookie, you'll be more than pleased.
author: Ana W.

description: Was looking for a really good dim sum restaurant while in San Francisco. Prefer cart service. This place was in a good location, very clean, and the service was excellent. Food quality was A++. Would definitely go there again!
author: Ernie G.

description: Quality dim sum at a reasonable price.  Clean and nice space at a fraction of the price of yank sing.  Expect a short wait on weekends / during peak hours, but well worth it!
author: Brian S.

description: I have pork rip, xiao-long bao, ​and shrimp dumpling. Food is good here but you need to go before 11:00 to skip the line.
author: Kev W.

description: Awesome dim sum and great service.  Came hungry and left full! Yum!  Loved everything except pork bun.  Skip it and save room for other good stuff. :)
author: Rob K.

description: The best dim sum restaurant I ever had so far. One bad thing is need to wait for the waitress to serve the food depending on the type of dim sum is ready to serve. Queue is pretty long if you come during lunch time and have to leave as soon as you finish as many people is waiting for the table.
author: Fion L.

description:
I believe dim sum can only be enjoyed at a place that serves these delicious plates on push carts. This is one of the few places in the city that fulfill this requirement so we had to come when we visited San Francisco during the Memorial Day weekend. Compared to the mega dim sum places in LA, this place seemed to be in its infancy (even though it's been open for over 20 years). They had 1 hostess who spent most of her time time in the back, not attending or instructing new customers how to sign-in. Their dining area was tiny and definitely not suited for large parties. They have a downstairs dining area that was not used at all. Most ladies pushing the carts came through leisurely. I want to thank the lady with the shrill voice who helped us hunt down a few requested dishes. Guess that's how it's gotta be done!  

Pros:
-Has push carts
-Decent tasting food
-Serves peking duck, not available at all dim sum places
-Must try the Chinese donuts!!!

Cons:
-Long wait during the weekend
-Few tables for large parties
-Slow service
author: Teresa K.

description:
Thoroughly impressed with food,  ambient and service.... Especially the Food.  It was so delicious we are coming back today,  which is unusual since we are on a short trip and don't want to waste time repeating places and trying new things all the time. 

They even got me to love dishes I hated as a child. Oddly enough my always go-to favorite and universal dish for all,  the pan fried pork dumplings,  was just okay. 

I challenge everyone who visits San Francisco Bay area to try the crab pincers with sweet mayo sauce!!! It's the first one I have tried that actually had just REAL crab meat in its own pincer surrounded by shrimp.
author: Wai Y.

description: Best affordable dim sum place in the Financial District. Love their BBQ pork rice roll, green onion pancake, and crab claw.
author: Victoria T.

description:
We came to the restaurant and had dim sum at about 10:30am.  Fortunately we beat the rush, as it got fairly busy by 11.

I typically like to go to a hole in the wall restaurant, but it was a good experience here since the waiters were able to describe the food as they passed by.  I'm new to dim sum, so I wasn't familiar with the food; the waiters had no problem explaining the ingredients in the food.

There was constantly food coming out of the kitchen and being rolled in carts with a wide variety for the hour we were there.

My only negative is that it's a bit pricey.  But it was definitely worth it given the positive experience we had.

I would definitely recommend City View Restaurant for a newbie to dim sum.
author: John Q.

description:
This is a great spot for dimsum for those working in FiDi and wanting a quick dimsum fix.

I've come here a couple times with 1-2 friends each time, and we've always enjoyed the meal. Most recently I came right around noon on a Wed with a friend, and while I was afraid there would be a wait, we were able to get seated immediately. Throughout our meal I never saw a very long line up of people at the door, so I'm guessing it usually doesn't get too crowded here. 

This is one of the few dimsum places I've been to in the bay area (if not the only one actually...) that still pushes carts around. Because of this, you could pull off a very quick lunch here in 30 minutes or less. 

I really like the environment of the restaurant. It's very large and airy and clean, and the tables are spaced far apart enough where nothing feels cramped as you'll often find in Chinese restaurants.

The food here isn't the most amazing dimsum I've ever had, but it is pretty darn good. My friend only eats seafood and shrimp but no pork, and City View had a great selection of dimsum items for her, even these steamed dumplings with ground chicken that I haven't seen elsewhere.

Given its location between FiDi and Chinatown, it definitely is pricier at around $20 pp, but I think it's worth it for an authentic dimsum experience!
author: Dianna H.

description: The dim sums are awesome. I love they're exquisite, and I can taste every kind. They also have an order for Fried rice or Fried noodles. The pan fried noodles are so good. So crispy . Now the new style Baked Pork Bum is so delicious.
author: Jo Z.

description: First time at dim sum? You'll feel welcome here. They will patiently explain each dumpling. Staff is friendly, restaurant is spacious and airy. Everything is tasty as can be!
author: Junie C.

description: I had a very bad experience at this restaurant! One dim sum cart worker stopped for only a second asking if I wanted anything then left when I just started asking what she got in her cart. She began telling the next table what were inside the baskets of dim sum. When I indicated I want some, she stared at me and blamed me for not saying anything when she first asked. After serving the table next to me, she went away refusing to serve me! The whole thing was just unbelievable! I'm definitely not going there again and I will tell people how they refuse to serve customers for no good reasons!
author: Shelley H.

description: Very tasty ,price reasonable! Better make reservation if you do not want to wait! All dim sum dishes!
author: Michael K.

description:
Our first time at Dimsum! This was delicious. The food was great. Went with my teenage daughter and we both loved everything we ate and wished we had a few more people with us so we could try more food! Had 2 different dumplings, pork buns, shrimp rolls, sesame chicken and Chinese donuts and spent only $40! 
Took off a star only because it was a little confusing and there was not much explanation for newcomers especially when it came time to pay and we had to wait over 20 minutes for anyone to total up our bill.
author: Nathalie H.

description:
Pros: super fast to get your food because they bring dishes around on carts and you can just pick what looks good. the food is good. This place is not too expensive especially if you're with a big group. Though I did come with only one other person for lunch another day and it ended up being $30 total and we were stuffed --and I know this place is cheaper than similar other restaurants in SF 

I recommend: Shanghai (soup) dumplings, peaking duck with buns, bbq pork buns (steamed and baked are good), the potstickers were ok but nothing too special, the egg custard in puff pastries (not sure what they're called)

Cons: we went with a big party one day for lunch and there was another big table next to us that the carts always went past first, so they always took all the good stuff -- but you can order specific dim sum from the cart people if you have something in mind and they'll bring it to you. I don't really like how you don't know how much any of the items cost, you just point to what you want and they stamp your card, and it's a surprise at the end how much it costs.
author: Elena K.

description:
Dining on: 5/15/16
Sunday brunch

3.5*
I brought my friends from out of town to City View for dim sum on Bay to Breakers Sunday. It's clean and well-lit, close to their hotel, and the dim sum is it too Americanized. The quiet Commercial Street is also plus as I'm skeptical of the loudness and poor hygiene of most dim sum places in Chinatown. 

As my friends are from Dallas, where they normally don't eat dim sum, we ordered a variety of dim sums to taste. This place still retains the tradition of dim sum carts. Carts full of bamboo crates with steam billowing through the lids will parade down the dining room. Customers (mostly non-Chinese) could see what might be of their interests. 

Each order (ranging from $3-$9) usually has three to four pieces. The har gau (steamed shrimp dumplings) is good, but the siu mai (steamed pork dumpling) is a bit dry and the wrapper gooey--sticking to the top of the mouth. They have a good variety of dumplings with a mix and match of ingredients like leeks, spinach, watercress and meat. 

They have good selection of steamed, grilled, and deep fried plates. My health-conscious friends only shared a small order of deep fried egg rolls and they were crispy. But there are no shortage of calamari, fried dumplings, fried taro puffs and the like. The food we had were tasty and authentic. They also serve lunch portion of dinner entrees like the honey glazed walnut and shrimps, Peking duck (two pieces of duck with steamed buns), and spareribs. 

Service is adequate enough. Empty plates and crates quickly bused.  Water glasses always topped. My only gripe is that they are pushy--ready to run us out to turn the table. As soon as we put our chopsticks down and the food running thin on the table, the cashier clerk would come and ask if we need anything else with a check ready. She did it three times. But we only wanted to take a break and chatted so my friends kindly told her we are still looking forward to tasting more food. Isn't dim sum meant to be taken at a leisure pace?

So my feelings are mixed. I like the tasty food but I don't appreciate how they try to rush the check.
author: Matt Y.

description:
Got here on a Sunday at 12:30 and the wait time for four people was only 25 minutes. It was pretty packed so I was impressed that we got seated so quickly! The service was okay, they didn't come by with the dim sum cart until we were done with our first round of food. We waited about 15 minutes until another dim sum cart came to our table/our side in general. 

Chili oil was not very good or spicy. Very disappointed in that. 

Overall the food was good and not that expensive considering it was in Chinatown in SF.
author: Melody P.

description: This place is amazing! We can not get Dim Sum on the Big Island of Hawaii and if you want good Chinese food, you'd have to fly to Oahu and go to China Town. My first time to San Francisco and China Town was on top of my priority list. My party and I asked our Lyft driver to take us to the most recommended Dim Sum spot. He drove us to this little restaurant, but they didn't offer Dim Sum. So.... We went to Yelp. Luckily, City View was right across the street and up a block. We walked in and this place was PACKED! The entire place was well lit and extremely effervescent! So many people, so many carts! The noise level is a little higher than average, which is fine with me.  We were able to get a seat immediately. We were all given water and was offered hot tea. Then, the carts came by, one after another!!! Unlike the Dim Sum places in Oahu, you have a WIDE variety of different foods, not just Dim Sum (Chicken Feet for example). We were fortunate in our timing because shortly after we arrived, a plethora of guest showed up, lining all the way out the door!!! With the fast pace service, I didn't realize how fast we ate. With a party of four, we were in and out in less than an hour and we ate to our hearts content! The quality of food was spectacular and personally, so was the customer service!!! This is definitely the place to go on lunch break just because of the quick and quality of service. They have different sizes tables, ranging from big to small (two person). Everything was nice and clean, including the bathrooms (located down stairs). This place is definitely a place to remember and I will definitely be back with more people!!!
author: Maile H.

description: Delicious Chinese dim sum. Place was just buzzing with activity. Service was excellent and prices are reasonable
author: Yogi B.

description: Always good, always fast service, always a reasonable price. What more could you ask for? There is no view but the restaurant is spacious and bright and nicely decorated.
author: Ian C.

description: Great dim sum, convenient paid parking at Portsmouth square garage. Good selection, nice wait staff.
author: Elaine L.

description:
This place is too clean for a dim sum place in Chinatown. It's also pricier than your standard place but I always go with family so I usually don't have to pay. (Thanks awesome siblings!)

Dishes are standard and everything we order typically at other places are good here too.
author: Mimi T.

description:
TLDR - Decent dim sum that's more Americanized and lacks the normal variety of traditional dim sum, but takes reservations!

Not really your standard dim sum place. Their selection is more limited and seems a little more catered to Americans, based on both the food and the clientele. There were some very nontraditional dim sum items on the menu/carts, like calamari, chicken skewers, egg rolls, sesame chicken and lettuce wraps. We mostly avoided those and stuck with normal dim stuff items, which were generally not bad, but the limited selection left my dim sum craving somewhat unsatisfied.

Prices weren't too high: $3.85 for small dishes, $4.40 for medium, $5 for large and $6 for special. Tea was $3/person. Service is what you'd expect from any Chinese place. They don't have very many carts going around but they're surprisingly good about making their way around all the tables, even the ones in the corner.
