On the plus side, they take reservations even for dim sum (though it doesn't seem to get as packed as a lot of other places). And they validate 2 hrs parking at the Chinatown Portsmouth Square parking lot nearby.

GET:
* Shrimp Siu Mai ($6, special) - Amazing texture! Super tender and soft. Comes with 3 siu mai.
* Mushroom Fun Gao ($4.40, medium) - Comes with 3 dumplings filled with wood ear mushroom and veggies. Delicious!

STANDARD:
* Shrimp Dumpling ($5, large) - Comes with 4 pretty large dumplings.
* Turnip Cake ($3.85, small) - A little greasy had a good texture
* Chicken Feet ($3.85, small) - Tender and flavorful

SKIP:
* Chinese Broccoli ($6, special) - SUPER greasy
* Beef Rice Noodle Roll ($5, large) - The rice noodle had a weird mushy texture and the beef tasted odd
* Stuffed Bell Pepper ($5, large) - Comes with 3 green bell peppers topped with shrimp. Not really a traditional dim sum dish. Shrimp was the same as the shrimp dumpling or shrimp siu mai, but each bell pepper was sitting in a pool of oil. Kind of gross.
author: Jessie L.

description: Clean, lots of light, good authentic dim sum. Fast service and vibrant atmosphere. Is it the best dim sum ever? Maybe not but it's still a great meal, great price, great location and you can even book a table. The line didn't look at long either. Definitely better overall than HK Lounge where you have to wait an hour and eat mediocre dim sum...
author: Wendy C.

description: Solid dim sum place. This is the nicest looking place in Chinatown so good for friends-family who might be leery of a more authentic place ... also good for clients who want Dim sum but are not too adventurous. There's also parking in portsmith.
author: Joe B.

description: Excellent dim sum, highly recommended, great variety and no wait!!!! The Peking chicken was the best!!
author: Paco P.

description: Excellent food, excellent service. We came right at 11am when they opened and the restaurant filled up fast. The food was ready and we did not have to wait too long for a special dim sum dish. We had the soup dumplings, steamed pork buns, baked pork buns, Peking duck, shrimp dumplings, and more. Only downside is the lack of parking. Parking at the nearby lot is $4 for about an hours.
author: Laq Y.

description:
City View has decent dim-sum fare. 

Our party got a variety of dishes, but some of the highlights from that day were the shrimp siu mai, turnip cake, CHICKEN FEET (okay, maybe it was good to me because I have been craving these for the LONGEST time), shrimp har gao, and stuffed three treasures (tofu and eggplant). 

I was quite surprised they had calamari as an option, as I didn't think that was standard dim-sum food, but it was okay also. 

The space we were seated in (the corner) was very cramped, and felt lacking in air flow half of the time. Other than that, I had a satisfactory experience here, though I may not come back for a while since it's a bit out of the way. 

Always come with a group to eat dim-sum, for it's just too expensive to eat by yourself!
author: Viet N.

description: This was recommended to us walking around China town. We didn't even make it for the cart gals with the dim sum and it still was awesome!!!!! This will be a stop for every trip!
author: Tiffany G.

description:
Clean, bright, modern dim sum restaurant bordering Chinatown and the Financial District (FIDI).  Not overly pricey like Yang Sing but not cheap as it caters to the FIDI business crowd on weekdays.  Great option to bring out of town visitors staying at the Portsmouth Square Hilton.  I give it a four for being a place that you would take people to impress without overly spending.

Customers get treated to the push cart experience instead of the mark your dish on the paper experience - where you are at the whim of receiving a dessert before your first savory dish.  I know, I could order dessert at the end of the meal in those paper establishments and not mark it at all.  But for some reason, Baked Custard Buns are always the first to run out on weekends in most dim sum restaurants!  Ha, Ha.  Oops, I digress.  Oh, by the way, since it is a FIDI restaurant, Management will try to turn your table over quickly on weekdays.  "Do you want anyhting else?" was heard more than a few times.

The food is of decent quality although the wraps on the Mushroom Dumpling were too sticky and broke apart as you tried to pry it from the bamboo steamer.  The Walnut Shrimp were a bit to gritty as you could feel the sugar granules on your tongue.   Better to feel the granules on someone else's tongue right?  (Snuck in to see if anyone reads my write-ups).  The Peking Duck could be crispier but I understand that when you're serving fast food (FIDI fast) Peking Duck you settle for a less perfect version.  Who doesn't want Peking Duck for two?  Now if they could serve a Pork Belly Bau - that would rival their individual Peking Duck Bun as a seller.  Hear me traditional dim sum sit-down restaurants!?  Back to critiquing... the main stays like Xiao Loong Bao, Har Guow, Siu Mai, Fried Taro Cake, were passable.

All in all, a presentable dim sum restaurant for out-of-towers and business acquaintances.
author: Scott L.

description: Don't let the misleading name get you down. Their food is absolutely phenomenal. We got there an hour before they closed and didn't feel rushed. The chicken on a stick and pork rolls are a MUST HAVE. Oh! And the sesame chicken. Ughhhh so good!
author: Robby M.

description:
Always busy here and we came on 12/30.  Come before 1130am and you should be able to get a seat.  You get validated parking up until 1/1/17 from Portsmouth garage for 2 hours.  

I forgot to ask how much the S, M, L dimsum plates are but it's a bit pricey. 

The food was mediocre. Har Gow was good. The steamed sticky rice were small.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Nice dim sum place, very clean and bright. Food is very fresh and tasty. This came highly recommended by a Chinese friend and didn't disappoint. I took one star off for them running out of one of the popular dishes before we could even order.
author: Katherine G.

description: Clean, everyone is super friendly. The wait wasn't terrible. Service is super quick and the food was great. Can't complain!
author: Andrea L.

description: Best Dim Sum in the city. The wait is worth it and if you can't wait, come early and you'll never wait.
author: Donna F.

description: Decent quality and prices for dim sum. Clean. Allows for reservations.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I'm writing this review from the perspective of a tourist in the city. I grew up eating dim sum pretty often, but my wife didn't. Because of that, I spent a lot of time online before our trip to San Francisco trying to find a good dim sum place - somewhere with good food, but that wasn't a hole in the wall. (I'd be down for trying the dirtiest, non-English speaking place if they had the best dumplings in town, but I didn't think that would go over too well with the wife.)

The website for City View made it look like it would probably be good, so that's where we headed. As we walked there I began to get nervous. The street it was on was more like an alley and there weren't any signs that a nice restaurant would be anywhere near there. We got close to where it should be and, sure enough, there was a little wooden sign on the sidewalk with the name of the restaurant and an arrow pointing to it. The windows were heavily tinted and I figured this place must be a dump... but then we opened the doors and were greeted by a lovely, clean interior with plenty of linen-topped tables and carts running up and down the aisles. There were also Asians and white people eating here - a good sign that we would get good food, but also be able to order (plus I saw one of the white guys with one chopstick in each hand... clearly we wouldn't be the whitest people here today).

We ordered a ton of dumplings, sticky rice, honey walnut shrimp, and other goodies. Everything was delicious and exactly what I'd been looking forward to. I don't want to say the food was perfect, but it was pretty great and we enjoyed everything. The waiters were all very nice and, while some spoke English better than others, none of them had any trouble understanding our orders. They did a good job coming by with the carts and seemed to always be there just as we were thinking about getting another plate of whatever dumplings we just finished. The prices were also pretty reasonable, especially when it's possible to rack up a pretty hefty bill eating dim sum.

City View ended up being perfect for our needs. It has the delicious food and good variety that I was looking for, but was also clean and accessible for someone less adventurous (like my wife). I would definitely return here myself and wouldn't hesitate to recommend it for anyone else looking for a good balance of authenticity and accessibility.
author: Jeremy M.

description:
Review is for lunch, on a Tuesday with the hubs! Hooray for time that we have together during a work day!

Must haves:
- shrimp and chives dumpling (comes in 3 pieces)
- shrimp noodle (the one that comes in an oval dish with soy sauce)
- barbecue pork puff pastry 

Comparisons:
- seat-ability: easier to get a seat here than Yang Sing (Stevenson location)
- budget: less expensive than Yang Sing
- Shanghai dumpling comparison: Yang Sing's Shanghai dumplings are better, and it costs more at YS
author: Mary H.

description: Over the years this has become my favorite Dim Sum near the office. There are others that I eat at frequently, but none come close to the quality vs price that I can consistently rely on from City View. Save room for desert: their beignets are to die for.
author: Daniel S.

description:
Toddler scratch shit dimsum for the FiDi price.

Food:
We ordered about 15 different things. Everything was either a salt bomb or bland as faak. The XO rice roll was pretty good at first 2/3 of a bite and I was like "ooh it's crunchy on the outside, so interesting" until I bit into the last 1/3 of under-cooked rice fucking paste.

Only pity stars for the barely more existent service compared to most restaurants around Chinatown and the generally clean space.
author: Tian Q.

description:
I don't typically enjoy dim-sum that much...maybe because I grew up eating a lot so I don't care too much about it. 

I must say this place is very decent for the quality of the food to how much it cost. This place also seems very clean. 

We came here for a work lunch with about 8-9 people and the bill came out to be ~$170 which I thinks is pretty good for the amount of food we got. This is just as much for a party of 4 at yangsing. 

You should always go with 3- 4 people to dim-sum. Each dish comes with about 3-4 so if you want to try everything come with more people.
author: Sherry Y.

description: Been here a few times over the years and they have consistently stayed the same with great food and fast service. I usually get the lunch cart service which provides a great variety. The key is to not fill up too soon and to eat slowly while other options circulate around.
author: Laura H.

description:
It's been a while since I've been here. My co-worker asked me for a dim sum recommendation and I suggested this restaurant. A group of 7 arrived at noon (with reservations). It's relatively on the pricey side in Chinatown (near Financial District). There's a wide assortment of dim sum, all of which I must say are fresh (hot), beautifully plated and of course, delicious. Most of the dim sum are delivered by moving carts which come pretty frequently. However, if you want something you don't see, flag someone down, he/she will bring it to you. The service is prompt and attentive without the usual attitude you'll find in most dim sum places.

Clean and spacious dining area, a good selection of dim sum, all of which made the whole dim sum experience a pleasant one. Glad I made a good recommendation for my co-worker who ended up flipping the bill!
author: Em T.

description:
Not bad. The SO and I came in for dim sum on a Saturday without reservations. Mistake. City View is actually one of the few, if not only places, in SF that actually takes dim sum reservations, which is pretty nice when you don't have all day or want to take guests to dim sum but want to eat at a notable hour. They definitely deserve a fourth star for that alone.

We however, didn't have reservations and went into the wait queue with everyone else. The place was definitely the epitome of chaos because we were seated within a few minutes on a lucky whim that a waiter saw us standing and pointed at a random table and seated us.. while neglecting everyone else. oops.

Anyways, the food here is decent! We got the typical dim sum classics -- siu mai, shrimp dumplings, rice rolls with shrimp, pai gu, and some other things. The menu here is fairly limited relative to other dim sum places (no porridge, no basic fried noodles), and it's pretty clear that the places caters to the nontraditional crowd based on a) how great everyone's English is b) how Americanized some of their newer creations were c) the fact that they have a set menu that's basically just various forms of chow mein lol. 

That being said though, the dim sum dishes themselves were decent. The pai gu was not very good though, but everything else was quite comparable in quality. Price is decent and fair, and the place is quite clean.

tldr; most unique thing about this dim sum place is that they take reservations! and the food is decent
author: Jasmine X.

description:
I was very pleased both with the food and with the value. The staff were accommodating to our big group and were sure to bring us custard tarts as soon as they arrived, hot from the oven!
Lots of good options, so you'll need to pace yourself.
Our group paid about $25 per person.
author: B C.

description:
Decent but pricey dim sum in Chinatown. There is a nice cleanliness that is a stark contrast to most of the alleyways in SF, but a lack of the authentic Cantonese soul that goes into these steamed and fried brunch bites. The menu even has only English and Japanese.

I tried the standard shu Mai, har how, xiao long bao, Chinese broccoli, and shrimp noodles. The waiters took a while to bring out some of the dishes and I think at the end of brunch they ran out of things I wanted like egg tarts. While they do the cart experience, the food was pretty average and not anything special.

It's ok for a first timer doing Dim sum but as a veteran there's much better around the bay.
author: Steven V.

description: Exactly what you would expect in an excellent dim sum cart restaurant. All your favorites, super fast service and execution was good. The only thing keeping this from a 5 is that the wrappers on everything were a little thick. But other than "heavy handed" no complaints. We ate our faces off in 20 min and only $40.
author: Tate C.

description: There's a reason this is so highly rated for dim sum! On a nondescript side street, the exterior doesn't show the beautifully designed interior. The original art is stunning. Good thing we got there as it opened as there was a wait in a half hour. Everything we tried was excellent. Standouts were the lightly grilled pork dumplings, Peking duck and unusual soup dumpling which releases broth when popped in your mouth. Other favorites were the shrimp with walnuts, pot stickers and chicken dumplings. Can't go wrong though we did pass on the chicken feet. Excellent service and a total go-back.
author: Tess L.

description:
Well~ it is considered "high-end" dim sum place in Chinatown. It is recommended by our hotel. Let's give it a try.... 

The Service: SUPER EFFICIENT! Many staffs are on the floor. They constantly walk around and take away dirty/empty dishes right away. Very friendly service. 

The Food: The quality is so-so and it is a little too pricey for the quality. Portion is definitely smaller than what we have in Los Angeles.
author: Cassandra Y.

description: Visited this place for dim sum back in the summer for vacation to San Francisco/Bay Area and this place blew my mind!!! Dim sum will never taste the same in my hometown! The price did kind of shock us because it was pricier than we expected. But the food makes up for that because it was heaven!
author: Thao H.

description:
Ok we fell in love with this place immediately. Came here on Christmas Day at 2pm after having arrived earlier in San Francisco. It was my first true Dim Sum restaurant. I have always heard about the concept and was intrigued but there isn't good Dim Sum in GA. 

They started coming around with the carts and we were all overcome with delight at the feasts before us. Shumai, sesame chicken, buns, dumplings, potstickers, Chinese broccoli, crispy egg rolls. Absolutely wonderful. This place will always leave me wanting more. The sheer variety was astounding. 

The best part is it is off the beaten path. It is an intentional restaurant. You make the effort to come here. It is worth it.
author: Nellie F.

description: Food was good. Only thing I didn't appreciate was how the waiter snuck in a charge for tea!   We asked for water. Waiter said water and tea. We didn't think anything of it as he said it like it was complementary. We realized when we got the bill that $4.50 was added. I mentioned every Chinese restaurant I've been to gives tea for free and his response was "not in Chinatown" Wow. Not cool.
author: Candice V.

description:
Some complain that this place is too clean and too Americanized to be authentic. Since I am clean and I am American, I do not share their concern. 

I agree with some of the concerns from people who give this place a so-so review. This is not the dim sum experience that many people seek. But I'm OK with that. Would I call this the McDonald's of dim sum? Absolutely not. 

City View is one of my favorite dim sum places for exactly those reasons, but also because it's truly good. I took my family there on a weekend (the place was surprisingly busy), and my two sons (one picky, one not) really enjoyed it. About a year ago we took them to a place in the Inner Richmond which has more street cred, but none of us liked it. Does that make us bland and unadventurous? If so, I'd much rather have this whitey version of dim sum, thank you very much. 

The reason I like City View is that the ingredients seem fresh. I've been to dim sum places where everything tastes suspiciously similar; not the case at City View. I've also been to other places where an hour after eating I developed a tingly upper lip and a headache (I assume from too much MSG). Not the case here. In short, I've been to a lot of the other places that may be perceived as more authentic, but I still assert that City View's food is fresher and of better quality. 

And as another reviewer noted (very funny); service is surprisingly warm for this kind of establishment.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Dim sum is good here. They have a definite route while serving food so you have to keep an eye out. They are good about filling the carts and going to every table, and the servers are nice. 
It opens at 11 and I would recommend going close to that time as it does get really busy. There is a line out the door the whole time but it doesn't take TOO long to get seated. 

A little more pricey than some other places, but in the FiDi it's expected. Just being able to walk from work is pretty cool.
author: Lindsey P.

description: Really like this place in SF Chinatown.  First, it has good quality dim sum.  Har gow, shu mai, steamed baos and rice noodle rolls are all yummy!  Other things that make this a great place to come to:  dim sum carts rotate systematically and regularly throughout the restaurant so you continuously get a view of what is being offered without being missed.  Next, this place is modern, nice and clean.  Lastly, it's busy but organized.  Not a madhouse of crazy customer overload and chaos where you get so stressed out before even getting seated.  With their high quality food, excellent service and clean surroundings, City View Restaurant delivers more of an upscale dim sum experience that is so pleasurable and most importantly, enjoyable.
author: Kelly P.

description: This place has the Best Dim Sum. I can taste the freshness. My favorite is the shrimp dumplings.
author: Julie H.

description: Good food but they're always trying to rush you out. Also all of the entrees are quite heavy.
author: John G.

description:
XLB - 3/5 - Average. 
Fried crab claws - 4/5 - Really good. Huge and juicy. Would come back for this. 
Everything else - 2/5

Overall, "I'm a fan" of the crab claws.
author: Mark O.

description:
Great spot for dim sum tucked away in a small alley-like street between chinatown and fi-di, just below North Beach.  Look for the green awning.

Clean.
Prompt service.
Lots of food.
Not as expensive as Yank Sing.

So it's not the cheapest place but you can get out of there for less than $20 a head all-in with good food and good service.  Nothing too fancy.

Some of my favorites:

Shanghai (soup) dumpling (xiao long bao)
Char siu (pork) look fun (the beef is good too)
Pork buns (steamed and baked)
Peking duck (ok yeah it's a very standard American dim sum fare, but it's good)
Chicken siu mai (I don't love the shrimp so this is a good replacement for me)
Steamed custard buns - sometimes only the baked ones come out but ask for the steamed ones.  SOOOOOO GOOD.  But beware it comes out super hot and the custard is so full it will squirt out and make a mess if you're not careful.  My favorite thing.

They also have other plates like choi sum, eggplant, lettuce wraps etc.  Those get more expensive and I'm not sure if it's totally worth it.

Takes reservations but call early so you can get someone who speaks English and is patient enough to take your reservations.  If you call in the middle of dim sum rush, good luck getting someone to answer the phone and then expect to wait.

They charge for tea, so if you don't really want it, you should refuse it, otherwise you'll get charged even if you don't drink tea.

Bathrooms downstairs.

Takes cash and credit; 2 cards max per bill.

Parking is awful on Commercial St so good luck finding something nearby or just give up and uber there.
author: Traci H.

description:
I thought this place was okay. I went here two years ago on a family trip. We yelped for a dim sum place and the rating here was 4 stars at the time. Shoulldn't haven't gone here on the weekend. We waited for a little over 50 minutes. The service was fast and efficent once we got to a table. The decor was nice and clean. The restroom was located in the lower level. Was like a maze going there.

We got here not know the price and just began picking the typical dim sum dishes like the turnip cake, the chicken feet, shui mai, haw gow and the white rice noodle with meat and one with shrimp. The food was okay. Didn't jump out at me like the dim sum places in the 626 SGV area that I was accustomed to.

When we got our check, our hearts just sanked.... hahaha 4 people = 150+. Yep, GG SF. Many in the sgv area it would barely cost less than 30 dollars for 4. Eh, that's the premium you pay when you travel I guess.

Don't think I would come back, but who knows... might change my mind the next time I visit!
author: John T.

description: Crowds should be expected here, but even then I really enjoyed the atmosphere. Despite how busy it was we were seated within five minutes, which was an unexpected surprise. The food was mostly alright; I'll probably skip the Honey Walnut Prawns next time. I absolutely loved the Chinese doughnuts - would definitely recommend. Overall, would definitely go back. Parking's an issue but when is it not in the city? We parked in a garage about a two-minute walk away.
author: Audrey H.

description:
Lacks quality and substance. Noodle dishes (dumplings, pot stickers, etc) were all heavy and soggy, sparse filling with average to below average quality. I question whether they made them from scratch.
Chicken lettuce wrap was also sparse. In fact all portions were skimpy. Considering this place is more expensive than most Dim Sum restaurants in SF, it is a complete rip-off.
author: Michael S.

description: Never knew this place existed until I keep hearing my colleagues talk about it. I guess this is the closest and inexpensive dim sum place near the financial district. The dim sum is fresh! I like the shrimp and chives, eggplant,shrimp, and tofu, shrimp churn fun. Hoping to try different items next time. The wait could be long. Just don't try to come on a Friday. Or during 12pm. Best to arrive 11:30am or after 12:30pm (the lunch rush seemed to clear up a bit) but kinda hard to get dim sum , the carts did not come around frequent enough.
author: Ann L.

description: The best dim sum I've had. Never disappoints always consistently delicious. Expensive. But its fantastic.
author: Shane B.

description: Best dim sum in the Bay Area. Super crowded so people paired.   If you got a large party at least order one fookn rice.
author: Sunil S.

description:
This is a wonderful dim sum option. How do you choose a dim sum house when there are so many options in Chinatown? In past visits I would have just picked one off of Grant that looked appealing, but truth is, they all really look the same. This trip I was fortunate to have City View recommended by friends who live in the Bay area, and I was not disappointed.

First, I loved the layout of the restaurant, the tables are strategically placed to allow carts to move freely and efficiently through the aisles. Little things like the clean white tables cloths, ceramic tea pots, and quality chop sticks were nice. The professional service, attention, and attitude of the wait staff is a welcome change from the typical dim sum place.

I thought the food was outstanding. I liked the smaller portion sizes of the dishes. For example, the baked char siu bao were about half the size that you normally see. I thought the quality of all the dishes was outstanding, but my favorite dish was easily the Peking duck. The duck was cooked just right; tender, moist, and flavorful. It is served with steamed baos that are a perfect compliment to the natural saltiness and oil of the duck.

My other favorites included the Shanghai Dumplings, Pan Fried Chive Dumplings, Stuffed Crab Claw and the Pork Sui Mai. The Shanghai dumpling are smallish and served in individual alumunum pie shells to contain the wonderful juices. The Chive Dumplings were not greasy, and maybe the best I've ever had. The Crab Claws were king crab claws with a tasty shrimp stuffing. The Sui Mai dumplings were tasty and my daughter's favorite.

City View was a great experience for us. It is a bit more expensive than other places, and the dishes are generally smaller, but I thought it was worth it. It's a clean restaurant with good service, and great attention to detail. The quality and variety of dishes rival other Dim Sum places that I've had. I strongly recommend and would definitely come back.
author: Paul C.

description:
Expensive?  Yes.  But then it is SF. And it's still cheaper than Yank Sing.
Delicious?  Yes.  But not as delicate as Yank Sing.

We go here whenever the work collegues are craving dim sum.  The items come fast and furious, and we almost always over eat and have to deal with food coma.  But the 10 minute walk to and from the office does help with getting the stomach ready for the feast and also with digestion after. 

Tasty and always my go-to when I'm at work, but I wouldn't ever trek out specificaly for this place.
author: Cindy C.

description:
Dimsum prices:
Small - $3.85
Medium - $4.50
Large - $5
Special - $6
Tea - I THINK $4.50 a pot or $1.50 a person.

Walking in here, I noticed that it was very clean for a Chinese restaurant. Since it's clean, it has to be expensive and "good". Looking at the bill, my eyes popped. Above are your prices so no surprises.

I suggest getting here at 12pm and no later. At around 12:15pm, the place is packed and estimated wait time is about 20 minutes. This is the type of place where there are ladies pushing dim sum carts around and some of them speak English. They were also polite to customers which is a plus.

Tried a lot of dim sum and I have to say, it's pretty good. I tried about 10 different dim sum plates and all of them did not let me down. They were all delicious. Presentation of the food was lovely. Everything looked fresh and nicely cooked. My taste buds were satisfied.

Although the food and service were good, it was a little expensive for my taste. The portions were small for the price paid. They should probably put the prices somewhere... Anyways. If you have the money to pay, then this is definitely a dim sum place you should try.
author: Benita M.

description:
My best friend took me here earlier this year, and I had to come back! Great food the first time, and my expectations were met the second time.

The wait time was much shorter than we anticipated (and there were a lot of people in line). It went pretty fast. The service was very quick and efficient, and our server was very attentive and pleasant. I highly recommend to get:

- Shrimp shumai
- Pork shumai
- White noodle wrapped char siu pork
- Deep fried crab claw ball

Keep in mind this is a dim sum place, so you don't order. Rather, they come around with food and you just pick what you want. So you'll just have to keep an eye out for what looks good. And you can always ask the server what's inside. Everything is made fresh, so be careful! Everything might be hot when it lands on your table, just a word of caution.

Another word of advice for if you come with a larger party. They only allow two cards per table for payment. So be prepared with cash or your accountabilibuddy.

Overall, I recommend this place and I can't wait to come back again.
author: Jay C.

description: Excellent dim sum in a pleasant atmosphere. Not unreasonable given the high quality.
author: Alex K.

description: I was just recently in San Francisco and decided to try dim sum in NorCal! The line was so so long and when we wrote down our names to get a table the lady said it would be a 30 minute wait. However, it was much longer than 30 minutes. When we got seated, around lunch time, it was super tight and pack. The waitress and waiters hardly had any room and I felt squished. The service was not too bad but not so great either. Now the food. The servings were very small compared to SoCal dim sum. And when they were stamping our orders, it did not list any price it just says small, medium, large, special 3, etc. So my party was confused with the price and not sure how much we ate. I really enjoyed the spinach dumpling, this crab meat plate, and sesame chicken. Not sure if their dumplings are meant to be sticky but after a while it got sticky that I couldn't get it off from the plate. They don't offer chili oil so I was disappointed because I love chili oil and soy sauce together. Our total bill came out to $187 for 5 people which is pretty pricy to me. But it was overall good. I wouldn't come back but it was an experience to try and see the difference between NorCal dimsum and SoCal dimsum! Located in Chinatown!
author: Michelle V.

description: This is our to-go place in San Francisco whenever my friends want to get together to celebrate their birthdays.  Everything is tasty and food is hot and the service was attentive when we needed a refill of tea, asked for water, asked about certain dishes.  The shrimp dumplings, shrimp rice rolls, steamed black bean sauce spareribs are good as well as the onion pancake, yummy custard egg tarts, and sesame balls.  We always leave this place satisfied.  One con is that the restrooms are showing their age and if you have trouble walking downstairs, that is where the restrooms are.
author: Karen W.

description:
City View is a stand out for dim sum in San Francisco. Right when you are seated you are tempted by delicious items one cart after another. From expertly wrapped dumplings to delicious sesame balls, you can't go wrong with anything that you order.

Be sure to get there when they open to guarantee you won't have a wait as this place fills up quickly and there is always a line on Saturday/Sunday to get in.

I'd also recommend going with a group so you can try more items. If you don't see something you are looking for, just ask and if they have it they'll bring it over.

Definitely a great place for locals and tourists that I recommend to all my friends/family.
author: Peter D.

description: This is an excellent place for Dim-Sum. The usual items were as expected; pork buns, pot stickers, fish cakes and dumplings. My favorite was the duck which was served with a soft bun to make a miniature sandwich with. My second favorite was the sweet pork buns, which were packed with pork and featured a tasty, soft bun. For dessert, I had a green tea custard, which was superb. Rich, deep green tea flavor. Four stars for service, water was not received promptly, which is a must for sit-down restaurants.
author: Gordan J.

description:
We tried to find a dimsum place in china town. I found this restaurant from internet. 
We were there for 6 people and we have to wait about half an hour. It was okay. There was packed. 
The food was delivery cart style which i like because you can see all the food what it looks like before you order. 
There is no specific server. In general, they were nice. The food was decent. (Judge by asian lol)
Overall, i like it. I would go back there.
author: Mark T.

description:
For me, the har gaw and siu mai of a dim sum restaurant can easily tell how authentic a dim sum restaurant is and they also give a good idea of the general quality of the restaurant.  This test is almost always accurate.  This time it's no exception.

The har gaw and siu mai are excellent, and so are most of the items we ordered.  The Shanghai siu long bau is particularly good.  The skin is thin and the filling is moist with the juice wrapped inside the skin.  The sticky rice is yummy, and better still, the leaf peels off easily without the rice sticking to it -- which highlights the skill of the chef. 

Service is above average among Chinese dim sum restaurants.  The cart ladies have radios and they can be paged if you need to find a particular item.  Prices are expensive, especially compared to those in nearby Chinatown.  We ordered 6 regular items (ie, no special dishes) and the bill was $32 before tips.

It was an enjoyable dim sum experience, and we will certainly return if we visit SFO again in the future.
author: Rob L.

description: Xcellent dim sum restaurant on the edge of Chinatown. We tried the full range of choices and all were warm and tasty. Trolleys were never far away and service was exemplary. Had the coconut custard rolls for dessert. Mmmmm. Highly recommended.
author: Patricia E.

description: The food was pretty good here but it was so expensive! We ordered like 6 things and paid 70 dollars. I know that some things are more than others but it's insane that a plate so small could cost 10 dollars! I would come back again because the food was good but I would just be more cautious of what I ordered.
author: Lauren W.

description: This place is amazing, I will say every time I'm downtown this is where I go. and I tell people about it all the time..
author: Michael M.

description:
Hmm. I'd heard from a few people that this was their go-to for dim sum in the city. I realized when I arrived that I'd been there three or four years ago, and vaguely remember it being "just okay"... but I went in with an open mind... and...

It was just okay. And expensive. And nothing particularly special about it. Also, "City View" has a view of an alley with homeless people and garbage on the sidewalks.

So... um... yeah... this is NOT the place. I'll drive a little and stick to Koi Palace, methinks...
author: Sean B.

description: Awesome dim sum in the heart of San Francisco! Super fresh, wide selection and fast service.
author: Liz B.

description:
Richard Pro here with another review.

Used to really like this place but this is the first time I've been here since five years ago. It was a pretty disappointing lunch. The restaurant was packed, and it's nice and bright inside, quite different from your usual hole in the wall dim sum places. However, the variety of food was rather lacking for a Sunday lunch. Saw a very standard ordinary selection of 15 items or so. The cheung fun was excellent, the lotus rice with chicken was alright, and the pork spareribs were subpar. The fried calamari was horrible--thick breading and no seasoning. The fried green onion pancake was plain and bland. We ordered a few other things too but nothing really stood out.
author: Richard P.

description:
Pros:
1) Delicious 
2) Beautiful room- great lighting (great for birthdays)
3) In the heart of Chinatown (the only place that feels the same to me even after the tech boom changed the city)
4) The carts 
5) Not a bad wait
6) Those sesame balls ohhhhh man

Cons:
Heard people being screamed at in the kitchen- no idea what that was about but giving them the benefit of the doubt:/
author: Lu B.

description:
Best dim sum in S.F. !!!

I've been coming to this great dim sum place for years and have continued to be impressed by the food. Everything is fresh and tastes great! Perhaps due to the high-volume, there's always new batch coming out.

Seating is quick, very little waiting even at peak lunch hours. Service is exceptional. If I ask for something not on the cart, they relay the info to someone who does have what I want and it arrives promptly.
author: Dan N.

description: Best Dim Sum in China town. We remembered it from a few years ago but couldn't find it and had disappointing dim sum at other establishments. Finally a local new RGS place and lead us there. Very clean. Efficient. Great dim sum especially the scallops shrimp dumpling!
author: Mona M.

description:
This place has decent food but bad service (as most dim sum places are)
and pricey. Dim sum used to be really cheap. Why are all the chinese places turning into $$$ place?? 
I went here with 3 other people and we spent $150...
Good luck dim sum on Clement St would feed 4 people for $30. I am not going back to this place to get decent dim sum when I have to tip for bad service.
author: C M.

description: Mediocre dim sum. Even your basic shrimp dumpling and shu Mai  wasn't done right and had so much msg that I got sick from it.  I wouldn't go here unless you're super desperate and had nothing else to eat and everywhere was closed.
author: Thanh N.

description: I don't think I would have found this dim sum spot on my own. It's somewhat tucked away. But I'd recommend it to anyone because it's got pretty much all the right elements for a traditional dim sum experience (especially one where the dim sum ladies come out with dim sum carts) without having to venture too far from the heart of SF.
author: Yad L.

description:
City View is located downtown on Merchant between Kearney and Montgomery Streets, good luck finding parking.
.
Located in an Alley, City View has no view but it is a large high-energy dining room with a wonderful landscape painting on one wall that I just love to look at.
.
I like the energy of the lunch rush here. I can order off a menu and or choose items of interest right of the carts that circulate the dining room. 
.
My recent chicken in a lettuce cup I couldnt even pick up as they served it on a split lettuce leaf. Often the calamari is either far too salty or cold/old and chewy.
.
Although the filling of the Lo Mai Gai is a little sparse, I do love the flavor of this sticky rice in a Lotus Leaf. I am also a fan of their Shanghai Soup Dumpling. They always include something like a wine vinegar and shredded ginger. And, you can actually pick up their dumpling with out breaking it and loosing all the soup.
.
So much of this style of food is subjective; you will just have to come try them out for your self.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Tried out City View Restaurant for dim sum on 1/20/14 MLK Jr Day.  We got there on the late side around 1pm.  Still there was a long wait, a few people had made reservations & got a table Quick!  So if you ever want to eat there Make Reservations!

Dim sum they have carts & carry on trays.  Stuff we tried:

Jasmine Tea - that's what I picked.  There's a fee for tea per person.  I think even if you don't drink tea you'll have to pay.  I never not paid at dim sum places.

Turnip cakes - 3 to a plate.  Tasted fine.

Chive & shrimp dumplings - 3 on a plate, we got 2 orders.  tasted fine.

rolled up rice noodles - tasted ok, a bit undercooked some pieces.

shrimp dumplings - 3 to an order. fine

Shrimp rice noodles w/ sweet soy sauce - I liked it fine, nothing special.

chicken feet - tasted ok.

There's a dining room on the bottom level but they didn't open it up for dim sum.  Bathrooms are downstairs too.

Food was ok, I don't need to go back.
author: Ann L.

description:
Like:
- Clean
- Relatively quiet environment for dim sum
- Lotus leaf wrapped sticky rice
- Scallop dumplings

Ok:
- Not a lot of variety
- BBQ pork rice roll
- Custard buns
author: Michelle W.

description:
Update! I meant to do this some time ago. They now deserve 5 stars! Especially the lady hostess w/ glasses. She is as polite as they come and remembers our specialty order, from prior visits, makes accommodations and is just a great hostess. Service is no longer rushed again A+ service and food.  

Came At lunch with a coworker we felt very rushed. The waiter asked us four times if we were done and actually gave us our check prior to us finishing. We were only there for 45 minutes! Their goal is to turn over tables quickly because of the huge crowds. However, it greatly diminishes the service and ruins the experience. I literally wanted to scream go the hell away! I will let you know when we want our check. When he wasn't asking he was walking by nervously and anxiously pausing -it just made us very uncomfortable. We also had to wait 20 minutes before our ordered dumplings were bought out, by this time everything else was cold and pretty much done, so we didn't get to enjoy it with our crunchy items and vegetables. We wanted to enjoy our tea and relax for 10 minuets after our meal, but just didn't feel comfortable after being so rushed! PLEASE educate your staff. I give it 2 stars because I've been to a lot of dim sum places and the food is very good actually -except The greens were sitting in a huge puddle of oil. Also a man who appeared to be in charge did come out And asked if we had been helped yet prior to us being seated which was very nice. 

Ensure the dishes come out closer so they can be enjoyed "Hot" All together and train the staff not to rush customers. I will try it again and edit this review if the service has been corrected.
author: J S.

description: This was and still my favorite place to eat. My parents introduced this place to me and I have nothing but great memories and great dim sum. The last time I came was a year ago. Yet quality exceeded my expectations. I'll come here again.
author: Ethan C.

description:
While perusing Yelp reviews for a place for dim sum in San Francisco, City View had pretty good pictures and reviews.  Asked the bellhop at Hilton in Chinatown where he recommended dim sum and gave the same answer, City View restaurant, so off my brother and I went.

The restaurant is tucked away in an alley with pretty plain frontage.  Upon walking in, the restaurant appeared clean and inviting and smaller than I imagined.  The diners appeared to be heavy on the touristy side.

Push carts were prevalent with all the standards.  We choose chive pan-fried dumplings, deep-fried taro, chive and shrimp noodles, pork water dumplings, and a puff pastry with bbq pork inside.  Everything we sampled was excellent.  The deep-fried taro was really fresh and some of the tastiest I have ever had.  The puff pastry with bbq pork was ridiculously awesome!  Never had such a fresh pastry for dim sum, a must have!

So many choices in Chinatown, but City View is worth a re-visit.  Good service, fresh product, awesome selection.  "Tourister" friendly. Yum!
author: Tim Y.

description: Amazing food! Dim Sum was new to me but I'm a huge fan now. Everything we had was so good. Highly recommend this place!
author: Joe C.

description:
Tourist trap. But it is very clean and the bathrooms aren't disgusting. The place is very small for a dim sum restaurant and definitely caters to Americans. The food is luke-warm and most of the skins on the dim sums are tough. I have definitely had better. The place is so small that they were definitely urging us to leave because of the wait. This is place is also expensive. Expect to pay 20+/person. I won't be coming back. 

Bathrooms are downstairs. Three really small stalls in the women's restroom. No parking out front. Park in the nearby parking lots.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I've been to City View a couple of times and always left satisfied with my experience. I'd give them a higher rating but their service seems a bit worse than the normal "efficient" service you'd expect in these types of restaurants. That said, they have the standard dim sum fare, and it's done pretty well based on American standards.

Their prices are about right and the ambiance is also A-OK. If we're doing dim sum in the city, this place is a good option.
author: Art C.

description:
Honestly, I'm not from China, and my Dim Sum exposure has been limited to L.A., D.C. suburbs, and Columbus, but this restaurant was exemplary. The fresh and well-maintained interior and no-nonsense approach to pleasantly presented and served (as well as extremely tasty) food would make this place shine even if the cuisine wasn't something as extraordinarily fun as Dim Sum should always be.  My wife and I had a very pleasing array of shumai and other dumplings, and we ordered too much, as we always do, but I felt compelled to eat almost everything we had left on the table after my wife was done--which is not generally the case. 

The only sour note was that the calamari was quite cold under the batter, but the server could not have been more pleasant about offering either to remove it from the tab, or replacing the dish. I opted for replacement, and the replacement was quite clearly made from scratch, and was perfect on the second round.

Anybody staying in the financial district for any reason should immediately make this place a top choice for brunch.
author: Mister C.

description:
Solid dim sum spot right on the cusp of Chinatown and FiDi. Unlike many other Chinatown dim sum spots, City View has a nice ambiance and functions as a great option for a quick business lunch. I've been here numerous times with coworkers and the opinion is always a resounding A-ok. 

You get to select which items you want based on the different moving carts. Some of the highlights are the turnip cakes, sticky rice and shrimp rice rolls. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
Clean, simple and quiet are the first three words I think of City View. I wanted the cart experience so, after a little searching, this place stood out. 

Other than higher prices - which is definitely something to consider - the food and dining experience was pleasant, which kind of left me disappointed.

Dim Sum was an integral part of my childhood in Detroit. After church, we would drive 30 minutes to Windsor, Canada to indulge in small plates of amazingness. Yes, we would drive to another country! 

That being said, with almost every dim sum outing thereafter, was a loud and rambunctious event. With carts flying by, delicious and peculiar smells in the air, it was buzz of activity. Along with large rooms filled loud conversations and big families, these are elements I expect and associate with dim sum. Quite the opposite of clean, quiet and simple.

Overall, City View is a pleasant place with good food, but not an experience.
author: John N.

description:
I checked this place out with my wife and son on a Sunday afternoon, and the place was busy. We waited about 15 minutes, which wasn't all too bad for grabbing dim sum at this time of day.

I caveat my review as the dim sum places in the DC area may be a level below those you find in CA, specifically San Fran. or LA. But in my humble opinion, this place is good but not great.

The taro puffs were great, as well as the duck baos. However, the dumpling wrappers were a little rough/hard for my liking, despite the generous amount of filling.

Like other reviews noted, the place is cleaner than the other establishments in Chinatown.

I'd come here again if I didn't want to wait at the other well-known establishments, or if I wanted the typical dim sum cart service. Otherwise, check this as a default if you need an audible for dim sum.
author: Justin B.

description:
Considering this is in Chinatown, I expected City View to have higher standards of dim sum, but I was somewhat disappointed. Their siu mai were pretty small, and the dumpling skin was inconsistent between dishes. The shrimp dumplings' was thick and not soft, while the chive dumplings' was oily and slippery. Overall the popular dim sum dishes were not terrible, but left something to be desired. There was an eggplant and fried tofu dish that I liked, though, because the fried tofu had a shrimp embedded in it!

The main redeeming factor for this restaurant was their Peking duck and fried shrimp and crab balls. Peking duck is usually ordered during big family dinners and banquets, so I was surprised to see it here. It comes with two buns per serving for the diners' convenience. The duck isn't excessively fatty, and the bun was still warm, despite it being the last one on the cart. My only complaint was that the green onion should have been sliced more neatly, but that's a minor detail. The fried shrimp and crab balls are one of my favorite dishes, and it was perfect here. The shrimp outside was lightly fried, so there wasn't more breading than shrimp, and there was a nice big chunk of crab waiting inside. The dipping sauce was light and sweet, complementing the shrimp nicely. 

This is definitely not my first choice for dim sum, but I would be okay with coming back just for those two dishes.
author: KC W.

description: Love this place! This is one of the more reasonably-priced dim sum places I've been to near downtown. As much as I love the places out in Sunset, it's kinda a pain to go all the way out there every time I'm craving dim sum. It gets busy here on both weekdays and weekends, but I *think* they take reservations if you let them know in advance. That being said, when I've come here in groups of 4 or less, the wait isn't usually that long. I went here this past weekend and they had the dim sum on carts, something I don't always see in city centre dim sum restaurants due to the tables taking up so much space. That's one of the reasons I keep coming back - the cart way is particularly more engaging when coming here with out of town visitors. I don't get anything fancy here food-wise - just the usual things you'd find at most dim sum places. But that's good enough for me and keeps me coming back for more :)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Recommend by Yelp and a bunch of guidebooks, I wanted to get some baller dim sum while in Chinatown on my visit to SF. When I walked in on a Tuesday morning at 11:30, it was empty. My first instinct was to walk out-- empty place, not a good sign-- but thankfully, I have low self-esteem and love to second-guess myself.

I was ready to be a pretentious, pig-headed New Yorker and say that the dim sum here in Chinatown is better. But, after my meal I think things are pretty head-to-head.

Pros:
-Sesame chicken that was perfectly cooked and crisp.
-Egg custard mini-pies that are clearly made with lard and are just orgasmically perfect, not too sweet with a light filling and a flaky crust.
-Soup dumplings that were nice and chewy on the outside with a tasty filling.
-Classic steamed pork buns with a fluffy exterior and sweet meaty goodness inside.
-Helpful and efficient service, especially when the place is slow.

Cons:
-Shrimp shumai was mega-bland.
-Peking duck with soggy, chewy skin and really woody scallions that were essentially inedible.
-Shit ain't cheap.

When I was stuffed and ready to leave around 12:45, the place was jam packed with tourists and locals, and for good reason. I'd take that miserable 6 hour flight again just for those damn near perfect egg custard pies.
author: Sarah R.

description: Despite some really racist reviews on this place (caters to white people like Ton Kiang), this is my favorite dim sum place in the city. Definitely not as pricey as Yank Sing, but the same quality food. Dim Sum is my favorite Sunday morning activity. Anyone who knocks this place has an attitude problem; the number of white people in a restaurant does not downgrade its caliber. There, I said it!!
author: James R.

description: Hostess was very nice. The restaurant opens at 10 am and she let us come in 10 minutes early  Food is very delicious. Everything was made fresh and for a Chinese restaurant it was very clean I would recommend the Kung Pao Shrimp dumplings it was AMAZING!!!!
author: Maria C.

description:
When in San Francisco, you gotta hit Chinatown. When in Chinatown, you gotta eat dim sum. Seems like a no brainer! 

Sadly, we were told by our friends that most San Fran natives don't eat dim sum in Chinatown because it's too touristy. But they said this one was the best of the bunch. Now that I've dined there, I get why they eat elsewhere. 

I found the selection to be small. I'm Chinese, I eat dim sum at home a lot and o just found the selection to be lacking. They tried to pass off small portions of Americanized Chinese food as dim sum and I wasn't buying it. Everything I had there (sui mai, ha gow, woo gock, etc) I've had better at home in Chinatown. 

Not bad but not outstanding.
author: Natalie S.

description: My go-to dim sum place to take out-of-town guests. It's the usual Cantonese cart fare, but taken up a notch in terms of healthiness, ingredient quality, and ambiance. I stick to seafood except for the pork and crab xiao long bao (petite but juicy and intensely flavorful). As always, if you see something unusual, grab it before it goes (at my last visit, there was a vegetable dumpling that was deeply shiitake flavored, with a great kick to it). You can order special items, but it's not worth the extra expense (tried the Peking duck and found it disappointing, flaccid and greasy).
author: Lisa O.

description:
I don't think I can be convincing enough in words to express the fact that this is the best dim sum experience out there that I've found so far. The food is delicious, the staff is friendly, and the ambiance is clean and inviting. 

I typically feel like an outsider in places like this as a non-Chinese person, but I've dined here alone and with friends multiple times and never felt that way. The servers answered questions about what was in each dish, and the manager has even suggested ones for me (including the sesame ball dessert, which is absolutely amazing). 

The pork buns are my go-to, but I have enjoyed everything I've gotten here (except for a seafood dumpling that was too fishy for my taste), and always try to sample something new each time. On my past visit, I tried the fried noodle for the first time (amazing) and got the sesame chicken again (way better than any Panda Express). We also had a few dumplings (pork, shrimp and chive) and the Peking duck - which was incredible. 

Make it a point to go here - it's worth the wait if there is one!
author: Bradley T.

description: Food was really good and the price was reasonable.    Seating was a little challenging during weekend lunch.  Not easy to meet up with friends as they won t seat you until everybody gets there.
author: Oranee D.

description:
As far as dim sum goes, SF doesn't have much to offer. And that's not to say there's a lack of dim sum, because there certainly isn't: it's to say that, in spite of ALL the dim sum the city has to offer, they're all a bit lacking. Given that, to date, the best I've found in the area is Hong Kong Lounge, so compared to that, City View is even more... just okay.

Going with a few coworkers, the four of us ordered a slough of things, from dumplings, to buns, to rolls, and etc - admittedly, some more Americanized dishes than I'm used to. But, of all these things, not a single one stood out as being particularly good (or bad) - just all very consistently okay.

That said, the prices aren't too bad for this part of town, and coming in around noon without a reservation, the wait wasn't really more than about ten minutes. So, if I'm in dire need of some dim sum, I could see myself coming here again - though, there are a number of other places to try in the immediate area as well!

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - A fairly large restaurant, possibly with multiple floors (I wasn't paying particular attention to this part). Tables are spaced out pretty well enough that there's space to navigate through the halls, but not so far apart that all the seats between tables are suitable for wheelchairs.

Bathroom - Didn't check them out.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I feel like City View caters more towards the tourists/Americans that don't want to venture too deep into Chinatown. There's usually a wait, but no more than 45 min. 

As the carts come around, you're able to pick and choose. While the dim sum staples are available, there's also special items that come around such as peking duck, stir fried dishes, etc. There's a good variety and I can see how it appeals to the masses that may not be familiar with all the dim sum items.

Service is quick and friendly. 

Prices are a bit higher than typical dim sum restaurants, but I feel like you're paying the tourist fee. The quality is good as well.
author: Noelle H.

description: Decent but def. not special lunchtime dim sum. Cart service which is nice. Shrimp har gow and baked pork buns were the faves. Nice little portion of peking duck with a couple bao buns and scallions. Potstickers, chive dumplings, pork and peanut just fair. Salt and pepper calamari was good but not great - it's my go to dish to make my palate happy, and this one just crossed the threshold. $20 a piece for a filling lunch for four.
author: Seth N.

description:
Dim sum here is delicious! Prices are decent as well, our meal was $45 for two people but we had a good amount of leftovers. The service is great but be sure to go early as there will be a wait on the weekends.

Here's the breakdown of our order:

Shrimp har gow (4/5)
Peking duck (5/5)
Shrimp in rice noodle roll (2/5) - sauce was too sweet, adding in some soy sauce helped
Steamed BBQ pork bun (5/5)
Stuffed bell peppers (5/5)
Kung pow shrimp dumpling (2/5)
Sticky rice (3/5)
Custard pie (4/5)
Chicken feet (4/5)

Can't wait to go back!
author: Shali N.

description: Loved the Dim Sum and thought it was reasonably priced. Soup dumpling, pork pot stickers were my favorites, spinach dumpling pretty good too. Wish I was in town longer to try some of their menu items, a noodle dish went by and looked delicious! Will be back!
author: Chris E.

description:
Went here with boyfriend's family since they knew the owners there. The food was pretty solid. We did sit there for about 10 minutes before we got served with food in carts. We ordered off the menu as well. Two different noodle dishes. I ate way more than I should have but it was definitely worth a try here. 

For the 5 of us it was about $100 but they it was actually a good amount of food. I will admit I was the first to quit eating and just couldn't keep up with them. Couldn't keep up with the parents either.
author: Corie L.

description:
Good dim sum. The shrimp dumplings and shrimp noodles were tasty!  The other dumplings we had were easy to eat. The duck could have been a little more tender. The turnip cake was ok, not amazing, but ok.

Service was on point. The carts came around more than once, so there wasn't anything I left feeling "...if only..." about. 

Others said that this wasn't fancy inside, but I think it was a little fancy. :-)
author: Kathy M.

description: Decent dim sum when you're in the area but can't beat elite restaurant in la.  Sesame buns are pretty ok. Line is super long. Rude rude rude services. They charge you per head for tea even for little kids who can't have tea.  Then they come and demand more tip.  Ridiculous.
author: Susannah K.

description: Upgrading to a solid 4 stars now that we've eaten here several times and compared to other options in Chinatown. For the price, it's my favorite sit-down dim sum spot where I'd feel comfortable bringing the uninitiated, but plenty of Asians dining here so you know it's authentic. Service is good for this kind of place--efficient, no frills, but nice enough. Eat here! Your tastebuds will thank you.
author: Areena M.

description:
The shrimp dumpling (shrimp and chive dumpling to be exact) is a must. I go out of my way to eat here because of them! 
So are the donuts! The crispy onion pancake and pork buns are great too. This is our go-to for dim sum after trying  a lot of places in China Town.
author: Kat S.

description:
One of my coworkers and I have been wanting dim sum for so long for lunch.  We didn't want to pay a lot, so Yank Sing was out of the question.  We knew the trek to Chinatown was inevitable and decided on lunch at City View.  On the edge of FiDi & Chinatown in the Commercial Street alleyway is City View.  Unassuming from the outside, it's actually quite nice (in Chinese restaurant terms) and a decent, but not huge in size.  We got there after 11:30 and there were only a few tables filled; this changed within the next 15 minutes.

Top picks: Ha gaw (shrimp dumpling), steamed cha siu bao (bbq pork bun), scallop dumpling, ha cheung (shrimp rice noodle roll).  Good amount of shrimp in the shrimp dishes and the rice noodle wrappers were the right consistency.  I usually don't go for scallop dumplings, but enjoyed theirs.

The OK: Dan tat (egg custard) & potstickers.  These were all fine and standard, but nothing to write home about.  The egg custards are not served with the little wrappers and are on the smaller side, but still moist and buttery enough.  

Skip: The siu mai was weird, as the roe just didn't taste right and there was too much of it.  I usually love pan fried shrimp and chive dumpling everywhere I go, but their's was super greasy, mushy, and not browned enough.  

Service was fine and the restaurant was clean.  I'll admit, part of me still likes Yank Sing more, as in taste wise and  quality wise it's a little higher up there, but I can't justifying their high prices, unless it's a treat.  My lunch here was only $37 pre-tip (no tea), this at Yank Sing would be definitely over $50 for sure.  3.5 stars for City View.  If only I was closer to Chinatown so I can just get dim sum to go.  But when I have time and the dim sum craving hits, I'll be back with a coworker or friend to get my fix at City View.
author: Cat C.

description: The nicest and cleanest dim sum joint I have ever been too. Definitely not a hole in the wall place. The staff are all very nice and spoke great English (which is sometimes hard to find at a dim sum restaurant). As for the food, we got the typical spread of har gow, manapuas, cilantro shrimp dumplings, shu mai, and cheong fan. The skins on the har gow and cilantro dumplings were quite thick and not as translucent and delicate as other places I have been too. The cheong fan (rolled rice noodles with shrimp) was my favorite dish. The noodles had a nice bite to them. The bill was reasonable for dim sum, about $20 each. I probably won't go back because I know there are better dim sum places in SF that I want to try the next time I am there but if I lived in the city I would eat there again.
author: Kelsey O.

description:
On a first time visit to San Francisco for my pre-teen daughters we were looking for a place to introduce them to dim sum. City View turned out to be a great choice. 

We got there just after opening on Sunday and were seated immediately. The service was good and the servers we all willing to stop and explain the dishes to the whole family. 

The typical dishes were all nicely prepared. Our favorite of the day was the crab claw and the one disappointment was the overly crispy Szechuan chicken. The pork buns were very good, slightly sweet, sticky bread surrounding a good dollop of pork filling. 

Overall the girls really enjoyed their first dim sum and, like many, ate too much as the good dishes just kept coming.
author: Todd V.

description:
I've been coming here for as long as I can remember for dim sum!  Personally I think it's the best in the city.  Most of the dishes are steamed or baked as opposed to all that fried dim sum stuff. All the servers are super nice, which is kinda rare for a Chinese restaurant haha. 

If they don't have a dish you're looking for on the carts, they'll bring it out for you fresh from the kitchen. All the dishes are fresh and hot!  No gummy tastes or room temperatures from sitting on the carts for too long.  Although there's some negative reviews for this place, you can't be too picky.  This place is a go to for good solid dim sum. Honestly, there's no such thing as a top rated Chinese place. C'mon.
author: Alli W.

description: Consider this place a bit pricey for dim sum.  However, good was decent and service was great.  Got seated fairly quickly, only 10 min wait at 1pm.  Dishes you might want not be rotated into the cart.  If they cart does not have what you want, order it instead.
author: Henry T.

description: I glad we made a trip here. The building is beautiful the food was great. Amazing service. I totally will recommend.
author: Jenny R.

description: I like this place. it's small, but they still offer cart service. My (half Chinese) girlfriend likes it because they keep it clean and she loves the quality of the dim sum. I like it  for the same reasons, and because it's a nice respite down a quiet side street. Plus, I don't have to fight the crowds in Chinatown or drive out to Clement St. to get great food!
author: Tom M.

description:
I suppose it's a good dim sum spot for lunch if you're somewhere working in the FiDi.  Pretty busy place, and surprised that it was so big and clean considering it's more or less in Chinatown where commercial space is at a premium and cleanliness is...um, not at a premium.

So the party ordered shu mai, har gow, peking duck, turnip cake, chicken feet, xiao long bao, and BBQ pork buns.  I mean, it was good and I wasn't mad about any of it.  Hell, I was pretty satisfied.  Just that it wasn't particularly special to me, since L.A. dim sum is generally better overall.  Out of all that, I think only the turnip cake stood out to me because it was fried pretty well.  Everything else was standard fare to me.  Also doesn't help that this was a nearly $70 meal despite not really ordering all that much.

I still would've given it a four, but -0.5 stars for being more expensive than it should be considering the standard fare.  The other -0.5 stars is for making us wait 10 minutes to sit down even though there were clearly empty tables.
author: Alexander Y.

description: This was my first visit to City View which is just outside Chinatown proper.  We arrived about 45 minutes prior to them closing.  I was concerned the dimsum selection might be slim.  I was very wrong!  We had everything we wanted - well, really more than we wanted/needed.  The selections were great; the dimsum themselves were great too.  I'd definitely go back.
author: Tim L.

description: I have been consistently let down by dim sum restaurants in town. I came here with my family and we all really enjoyed the food. The staff is attentive and busses the entire table. All in all this place was the haven I needed from so much mediocrity to comparable restaurants.
author: Brian C.

description:
Only dim sum place I have ever seen that takes reservations. been there 2 times and each time if you arrive after 11:30am, you will be waiting about 20min for a table.

Solid dim sum, a bit pricey, but all the dishes are dericious and well made. Went there solo and spent $40, went with a group of 5 and spent $140. It is also a bit more upscale than most dim sum places.
author: Phillip T.

description:
Fantastic dim sum! A little pricier, but the quality and presentation makes it worth it. The place itself is not as noisy, and much more orderly than your typical dim sum resto, and much cleaner as well. All of the staff are very welcoming, polite, and even smile. 

The variety was good, with all of the usual suspects, and I even got my nephew from Michigan to munch on chicken feet. His wife? Not even close. We had no trouble getting seated in the middle of the work day lunch rush, but per some other reviews you might have a bit of a wait during those times.

It is tucked away on one of those alley looking streets on the border of China Town and The Financial District. I had to guide our cab driver via the Yelp app, so it may be difficult to find.

BTW, there is not a view of the city.
author: Dan H.

description:
I came here a few minutes after it opened for dim sum. Luckily I did because it got pretty busy. 

After you sit down, the servers come around with carts of dim sum. A lot of the foods I picked were delicious! However, a lot of the food had some sweetness to it. But for the most part, the flavors went well together. My favorites were the Shanghai dumplings, chicken skewers, and the Peking duck. 

The servers are all friendly and say what everything is in English.
author: Rachel H.

description:
When I think of China Town I think of a loud, smelly, and dirty place with really bomb food. This place not only has good food, but it's clean and peaceful. 

A plus side to this place is that they speak pretty good English, so it's easier to communicate what we want to order. 

The food is also not too greasy, I don't know if they have MSG in their food, but it's been about 30mins and I still don't have a headache, so that's a good sign!
author: Patricia V.

description: Decent if you need a quick fix or have a medium-big group! It's also nice that they take reservations. The buns and dumplings are decent (just get the usual pork bun, shumai, etc.) but skip the egg tarts! The service is not bad and the waiters are pretty quick when you ask them to get something. Overall, I'd go back again if I wanted dimsum and was in the area, but there are better places in the city if you're looking for quality over quantity!
author: Grace C.

description:
Love their Dim Sum. They are secretly hidden from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown. Prices are a bit heftier, but for their variety, freshness, and seclusion, it's worth the price. Their food is comparable to that of Asian Pearl's. 

MMM.
author: Alex C.

description: The Dim Sum is very good, excellent service, clean restaurant and a pleasant atmosphere to enjoy your stay at City View.  It is great to have nice clean, white table cloths and napkins.  Better than being in Hong Kong.
author: Edward P.

description:
What a great restaurant. We ate more than we should and the bill (for 2 people) was only $28. When we left, though, we smelled something amazing and it was chicken chow mein. Not sure why it wasn't on the menu we were given but it looked amazing. My favorites were the chive and shrimp dim sum and there was a folded shrimp one that was yummy.
Only recommendation is to serve the vinegar sauce on the table, I can eat that stuff with anything!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
City View is our go to spot for amazing SF dim sum. The kitchen nails every classic and everything comes out hot and fresh. 

Food:
We tried over 10 things and almost all were a success. Here our some of our favorites:
- pork and ginger potsticker
-steamed pork bun
-shrimp balls
-scallion pancake
-pork and peanut shumai
- our top favorite was the Shanghai dumpling, aka the soup dumpling. 
-Peking duck

The big no-nos:
-Walnut shrimp
-Anything else that seems Americanized


Service:
Service was not exactly warm and friendly, but we have grown to accept that in the world of dim sum. 
-If you are drinking tea or water, make sure to ask them for a pitcher on your table, otherwise you will be thirsty the entire time. 
-If you are requesting an item that you do not see on the carts, make sure to ask several times to ensure it comes to you

All in all, City View is an authentic experience not to be missed. The food is tasty, service is good enough, and it is definitely worth the wait.
author: Natalie K.

description:
City View is my go-to place for dim sum in the FiDi.  It isn't as precious--or as expensive, or as crowded--as Yank Sing, and I've never had a bad experience.  It gets crowded, but it's very roomy.  The service is just fine, and the food is great.  

I'm not a connoisseur of dim sum, but I know what I like, and I like City View.
author: Earline A.

description:
There are so many Dim Sum options in the city, most of the good ones being further away from Chinatown.  However, this is one of my preferred dim sum places and its pretty much right outside of Chinatown.  Shocking!  

The food is good and not overpriced.   You get your usual variety of Dim Sum being pushed out in carts. The items from Shiu Mai to Ha Gow are pretty tast, and I always get the chicken feet.  They also do special order items, such as the XO noodles, which are amazing rolled riced noodled that are soft and chewy inside but tasty and crunchy outside! 

The staff here  is pretty friendly for a Chinese dim sum spot.  I guess you should be if you are in the financial district competing against the likes of Yank Sing and Hakassan.
author: Veasna H.

description:
Came here for lunch with a pretty large group that needed to eat and get out as fast as possible, and this restaurant was basically perfect for that. I wasn't expecting too much in terms of the taste, but I was definitely proven wrong! 

Biggest surprise of the meal had to have been the chive and shrimp dumplings - didn't expect them to be so flavorful! Turnip cake was good as always, pork and shrimp shu mai were both on point. There's spicy chicken and skewers for those who don't like seafood as well. 

Fast and yummy - perfect for the busy people of FiDi in need of their dim sum fix.
author: Sophie H.

description:
Our group of four (two of whom had never had dim sum) came here for lunch on the recommendation of our hotel's front desk staff, and were all very happy with our meal.  We ordered a wide variety so that our dim sum newbies could try as much as possible, and everything was good; some things were great.  

Particular favorites were: "spicy" shrimp dumplings (just a hint of spice, which we enjoyed); veggie dumplings; chicken lettuce wraps; scallion pancakes; and crab balls.  The only thing we didn't really care for was the sticky rice, which may be personal preference; it had too many brine shrimp and sightly too much grease for us.  

This would have been 5 stars if the prices had been just a little more reasonable. We ordered a respectable amount of items, plus three sodas and one hot tea; the total was over $100.00 pre-tip.  We would return if we were in the area and looking for dim sum.
author: Violet G.

description:
"Dad, what's the best Dim Sum place?"
"That'll be City View" he chimed. "We went there when you were a child, but I don't know if you remember" 
I don't. 

But rare family dim summing in years with the family. And if my dad says the food is good, it's good. You can't argue with a chef. 

For the lower reviews here on yelp, I believe it's really the choice in Dim Sum you pick, because everything we got was exceptional. And the Wu family rule is never pick anything fried or very plain that you can make yourself.

Chives Dumpling - It's pan fried and it's definitely the best I've ever had. Fried parts are crispy to perfection and overall very flavorful.

XLB - Have had better at places that specialize in XLB, but it's pretty good here.

Shrimp Dumpling & Shiu Mai - These two always come in a pair for me and a usual must get at any dim sum for the Wu family. Above average compared to other places, but not the best thing here. Still good though.

Beef rice noodle (I don't know if the English translation is correct) - average. 

Vegetarian Tofu wrap - Ugh. I was looking forward to this the whole time but it was such a disappointment here.  It's usually my favorite dish at other places, but there was one ingredient that I HATED. I don't know what it's called in English, but it's the one that tastes like an old alley way filled with urine. AVOID. 

Steamed Rice wrap - There's only 2 and it's quite small. It's my brother's must have so we got it. It's flavorful and maybe above average, but it's not my personal favorite. 

Egg Tart - They were so mini and cute that I had to get it. LOL. I snap chatted this to my friends and they're like "Dude, you need to eat 50 of those to get full"  Definitely delicious, and above average. 

There was an eggplant clay pot dish that was really good as well. I'd get that again. 

Seafood fried noodle (Hoi seen jeen mein) - Kind of small here. The noodle was one round solid noodle cake all around that I had a hard time trying to even serve the soft inside portion. And there wasn't enough noodle to go around for 6 people. 

Overall, still the best Dim sum in Chinatown.
author: Harriet W.

description: Wow! This place has superb dim sun!!!! Best in taste and quality. Price is high or Id give a 5. Saw an alert on it after eating there and wouldnt have gone if i had seen it...... Glad i didnt see it! DELICIOUS
author: Martin H.

description: This is the second time I've been to this place (once for each time I have traveled to SF. For the quality of the Dim Sum (fresh and not greasy), it is worth checking this spot out for brunch. By far the must order dish is the BBQ pork buns (I even ordered an extra one to take home).
author: Anthony J.

description: Their dim sum are so delicious and mouth watering especially the chai dumplings. It is yummy.. and the place looks so grand and feels so comfortable.
author: Amber W.

description: love going to city view for dim sum. They take reservations for large groups which is a plus and their dim sum in my opinion is some of the best in the city.  very clean atmosphere and the waiters and hostesses are pretty nice.
author: Yasi N.

description:
Had a private party event to celebrate new grandbaby "Red Egg and Ginger Party".  Vincent, the restaurant manager did an excellent job in taking care of ordering the roast pig, making the red eggs and the ginger for this special event.  

Vincent and his staff were attentive and professional.  Vincent came by several times to check to see if we needed anything.  I appreciated this.

They even cut and served the sheet cake we brought for the party.  Vincent was very accommodating and we were happy customers.

The food was delicious and served hot at the tables.  All the guests raved about the dim sum and other entrees (i.e. dumplings, pork buns, chow mein; fried rice, etc.) and there were many dishes served.  The roast pig they ordered and served was fresh, moist and was from good quality vendor. 

I would recommend City View for a private party and definitely if you are looking for a place to hold a Red Egg and Ginger party, they will do a great job.  A++
