It would have been nice if they had an elevator for our elderly family members.  The bathroom can use a remodel and updating the area nearby to make it modern and appealing.

We will definitely have another private party event here.
author: Nanana A.

description:
I was really disappointed considering this was in SF's Chinatown and recommended in my friend's guidebook.  The servings seemed kind of small here, the food looked kind of sad, and the taste was very underwhelming.  I also went at 2:00, so they were out of a lot of the stuff I wanted.

What was ordered:

Turnip Cake - this was ok, but hard to mess up
Siu Mai - I've definitely had better
Har Gau - not very much flavor, shrimp was fresh at least
Shrimp Cheung Fun - even this dish was kind of off... not even sure what it was...
Mushroom dumplings- just wasn't a fan, the mushrooms weren't very good
Honey Walnut Shrimp - biggest disappointment for me since I love honey walnut shrimp.  this was just shrimp with a little bit of the honey mayo sauce on it (and I mean barely any sauce...).  It was fried, but there was barely any batter.  It also had a little bit of lemon on it, i like lemon, but it made it taste more like shrimp scampi and not honey walnut shrimp. 

This came out to $40, it was $44 before we reminded them that we did not drink tea.  I thought that was really high considering the portions and quality.  I've had much better dim sum for less.
author: Nina H.

description:
This place is my new go-to for dimsum in chinatown.  It's a bit on the outskirts of Chinatown, which is perfect so you don't have to skirt through old men carrying bok choy and celery or asian drivers trying to parallel park on the streets. nightmare.

This place takes reservations, and while full, didn't have a line out of the door. They have the carts and all the usual dimsum choices. PLUS their XLBs are so much better than the ones at delicious dimsum.  They were actually soup dumplings. Skin not as thin as the din tai fung ones but pretty darn close!!
author: Alice Z.

description: This is my go to SF spot for dim sum.  It's fresh and delicious.  The restaurant can get crowded, so go early for seats and no wait.  The carts are always loaded with fresh eats - and you really can't go wrong with any dumpling here.  Good parking and an east 10 min walk from Bart.
author: Kamael S.

description:
Went here for lunch after a walking tour of Chinatown. I have never been to a dim sun concept restaurant before, so it was very interesting to me.

The service was great, however, some were hard to understand what they were explaining they had to serve. 

The carts come around in almost a sequential order, apps, main courses, and dessert. 

Wait around, you'll get more and more options. 

The dumplings were amazing. Highly recommend them. Not expensive either.

A decent first experience at dim sun dining!
author: Kathryn P.

description: Good tasting dim sum. Fast service with lots of food displayed for u to choose from. But a bit pricey.
author: Bob M.

description:
My friends and I were desperately searching for a dim sum restaurant in SF that had the pushy carts. IT WAS SOOO DIFFICULT to find one which really surprises me. We finally stumbled upon this place and we got excited. However, it was a little too clean for my liking....Usually the good dim sum places are not pretty or clean inside so I thought this must be super Americanized or expensive. It was both.

We were so hungry so first thing we saw we just got. It was three pieces of siu mai for like $5. We were laughing our asses off because it was soo damn expensive for dim sum. If we were gonna feed ourselves at this rate, our bill would be easily over $100. We looked at the menu and the prices are RIDICULOUS. The food is average too so its not like we were paying for quality. My crazy friend yolod and got one of the cabbage leafs with the meat and it was about $6. I thought that was the price for four pieces, but nope it was just for one. We literally took a bite and passed it on and laughed our heads off over this whole experience. Our desperate search for dim sum culminated to eating three siu mai and one lettuce wrap for $16 somehow. We immediately left the place and found cheap, to go dim sum.

The only thing I liked about this place was that it was such a fun/funny experience with my friends. haha that lettuce wrap moment was total bonding time.

**TIPS**
1) Too expensive for dim sum.
2) Get dim sum to go for cheaper, more delicious dim sum.
author: Amy H.

description: Visiting from Seattle. It was between City View Restaurant and Champagne Seafood Dim Sum. We opted with City View since it was rated higher.  I'm very picky so City View did not disappoint. The service was EXEMPLARY by the entire staff. The food - OMG!!! Every dish we had was scrumptious/perfection. It was crowded, but we were lucky we waited 10 minutes since it was 2 of us. There were many more waiting to be seated and many more after we left.  People just kept coming. The reviews are true.  Thank you to all the reviews which helped us choose City View Restaurant.
author: S T.

description:
BEST DIM SUM IN CHINATOWN

If this isn't the best Dim Sum restaurant in San Francisco, then it's a close second to Yank Sing. We arrived early, shortly after they opened at 11 am, yet they soon emerged from the kitchen rolling carts of exquisite dishes.

This is always a dining experience to treasure.
author: John D.

description:
Very pricy dim sum, but it satisfied my craving so it's okay.  

The place looks clean enough, unlike the smaller places in Chinatown.  And the food was pretty yummy.  

Between two girls, we ate $40+...and didn't leave feeling full.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Although Yank Sing is by far the better known and oft-recommended dim sum stop in SF, I've honestly found it solid but overpriced.  I've
been hampering to return due to rave reviews of their xiao long bao,
but I've been on the search for a better SF place to recommend for
some time.

Enter City View.  Located in the heart of Chinatown on a side street
close to R&G Lounge, City View is a place you wouldn't find easily
unless you knew where to look.   But it seems the crowds do know this place and on an early weekend lunch, we were told that every one of the large banquet tables had been pre-booked. Luckily, my friend was one of the pre-bookers.

It was actually my second visit and while I enjoyed my first, I came
away more impressed this second time.  Not only did we order a greater array of dishes, but we actually arrived at a prime time just before they really got going.  A sample of our fare:

Pan fried chive and shrimp dumpling - nicely fried and with a warm and tender filling.  They do this well and the dumpling sizes are large
and generous

Peking Duck - I've seen this at a handful of dim sum places, yet
again, here it was better executed.  The duck skin was very recently
skinned (vs. sitting on a table/cart for hours) and the buns were warm
and soft.

Egg rolls - while the traditional Chinese egg rolls contain lots of
vegetable and a thick fried skin, the version here is more modern.
Long and thin, it's mainly shrimp and was hot and
crispy as if just fried.

Xiao Long Bao - those these were a hit with our table, I found them to
be average.  The skin was thin but each dumpling had no soup.  They do serve them in tin individual containers, but that's also useful if you
are worried about breaking the skin.  If there's no soup, why worry?

Shrimp Rice Noodle Rolls - our first entree. Standard. Nice amount of
shrimp but could have been hotter.

Calamari - hot, crispy, and freshly fried

Overall, we had a good dim sum meal and especially enjoyed the selection.  It's hard to gauge the price of a place when dining with a large group, but I'd guess that City View is moderate.  Not as cheap as the bargain places in SF, but a more solid value than Yank Sing.

It's definitely made my recommended list.  Way better than the tourist
Ton Kiang, more value than Yank Sing, and a quality replacement for
Harbor Village that I used to recommend until it closed.

City View accepts credit cards, including American Express.
author: Randy F.

description: Enjoyable experience, would classify this as a table buffet where we're served on our table and dishes can be repeated. If you want you can also select from a set menu. Great variety offered for meat lovers (pork, chicken and shrimp). Pricing is average, only gripe I have is that they charged us for tea, in a Chinese/Japanese restaurant I have usually got it for free so far. The sesame balls were nice and so we're most of the shrimp dishes. Veggie lovers have relatively lesser items to choose from.
author: Shobhan D.

description: Obsessed with the custard filled sweet pastry bread at this restaurant. Soooo good! Other traditional dim sum items were good but not spectacular. In particular, surprised to see fried calamari (overtired and oily) instead of the more common curry steamed squid. Not a bad choice in an area surprisingly low on sit down dim sum options.
author: Katherine C.

description:
solid dimsum but nothing that wowed me
sesame chicken was my favorite
author: David H.

description:
Because City View does well at being an authentically Chinese dim sum experience that is also pleasant enough to bring non-Asian friends, it gets an upgrade to 5 stars in my book. 

First off, Yang Sink is totally over-rated. When friends ask if they should bring out-of-towners there because it's "clean", I always resoundingly disagree. It's way over-priced and too sanitized an experience. City View is way better value for the same quality of food but you still get the hustle and bustle of an early afternoon dim sum weekend brunch in a comfortable setting. 

I like the har gow and siu mais here. They are generous with the filling and the skin is never too thick. Overall pretty well executed dumplings. The peking duck is succulent here with the steamed bun, scallion, and hoisin sauce. Yummy. Pan fried turnip cake is another go-to order item and it's well-excuted here. Other deep-fried seafood treats are worth ordering here. I mean, it's freshly deep fried. C'mon...what's there to think about?

Weekday lunchtime crowds come in waves right around noon so my advice is to get here a little before that to grab a table. On weekends, it's a total crap shoot but worth the wait in my opinion for a dim sum experience close to Chinatown that is satisfying and pleasing dining experience for just about anyone.
author: Jon L.

description:
Back in San Fran & since our flight was 3 hours late out of DFW due to inclement weather, we opted to take a taxi directly directly here, luggage in tow. 

IMHO this is the place for dim sum even tho it's technically a couple blocks outside Chinatown. Today the BBQ pork buns really shined & the steamed pork w peanuts was a bit of a letdown but overall a solid dim sum fix. 

Now for the tricky part, talking my 3 daughters into rolling their luggage uphill to the Westin St Francis ;)
author: Craig C.

description:
A local referred me to City View and it was a solid, hearty dumpling feast. We were starving and almost before we sat down the server presented us with roast pork buns. 

Overall the fare here is pretty much like I have had at any other dim sum restaurant. The standouts were the soup dumpling serving in a little foil pain with red vinegar and the shrimp and onion dumpling--super good.

Service was fast and friendly but we didn't feel rushed at all .
author: Billy T B.

description: Great food and service. Loved the restaurant.  Reasonable prices.  The carts kept coming with a wonderful selection of dishes.  The staff was very knowledgeable of all dishes.  Peking duck was fabulous!!
author: Kathy M.

description:
I came here to eat dim sum and what my taste experienced was mediocre. I asked my hotel person for good dim sum spots and she stated this place was the best in the area and so I yelped it and had mixed reviews, so figured I'd see for myself. 

I got typical dim sum dishes like the shrimps, buns, pork/shrimp, rice noodle sheet, etc. I was not impressed with any of the dishes, but they didn't taste bad. 

This place is pricier than the dim sum I'm used to paying. I ordered how much I would've at any other dim sum place, and almost paid 30% more. 

On the plus side, this interior is not dirty.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I don't know how we dropped $52 for 2 people. I've always wanted to see how much my tummy could hold. And where's there's a will, there's a way. Thanks to Yelp, I was able to track down this restaurant after an impromptu coffee with my male bff. The crowds here come and go in waves so get here early!

Don't be afraid to push your way up to the manager/hostess on the weekends to get your name on the list. Most of the people standing in the doorway have already put their name on the list so get on up there to the desk and find the lady with the clipboard. 

The great thing about this place is the amount of interesting dishes they've got on carts. I've yet to see normal shui mai or haw gow which in my humble opinion, is AWESOME! There were crab claws, lobster rolls, scallop dumplings, peking duck, and yummy deep fried shrimps in shells. I loved the selection here and feel it was totally worth the price. We'll definitely be back.
author: Jessica K.

description: Bit of a wait at 11:45 AM, but busy is a good sign.  Staff busy bringing lots of delicious looking selections. Ours were very good.  Slightly noisy for across-table talk.   Friendly folks.
author: Gary W.

description:
I'm impressed with the dim sum here. I was skeptical because it wasn't very busy and my experience with San Francisco Chinatown dim sum hasn't been that great. I've been here twice, both with large groups and both times, everyone was pleased.

City View is pretty spacious and very clean. The carts are available all week which is nice, compared to usual places that only have them on the weekends.

The service is good. Friendly and pleasant. 

All the dumplings we had were delicious. The turnip cake here is on point. Perfectly pan-fried and crispy on the outside, not too mushy inside. Great eggplant and tofu items. And the sesame balls are on point.

The only thing that didn't really win me over was the chicken feet and tripe with scallion. The chicken feet was in a very thick sauce that was very sweet. It took away from the chicken feet flavor. And the tripe was super bland. Not enough ginger and scallion. 

Prices are on the higher end.
author: Natasha S.

description:
I don't have a lot of experience with dim sum, but I enjoyed my meal here. We ate a lot of the dumpling-type items, and they were familiar to me as an American for sure, but everything was delicious. Many have commented on its tidiness and lack of chaos, and I'll chime in and agree there. Many people complained about it being tourist-y, and I can only say that my definition of "tourist-y" is anything near Pier 39. This wasn't anywhere near that. We went early and while there were lots of tables reserved, we didn't have a problem being seated (three of us) without a reservation (but again, we got there at 10:30 or so). 

Some people are saying it was pricey, and I didn't feel that way at all. The three of us ate for $60. Considering there are other popular spots (I will not name) which are reportedly $50/person or more now, I'm not seeing it. 

Service was very friendly, which was refreshing. Everyone was smiling! 

Parking in nearby garages was not terrible at the early hour we were there.
author: Eileen G.

description: Eaten here several times. This is one of the better tasting dim sum restaurants. Little crowded during lunch time. Food is consistent each time we eat here. No free parking. Table cloths and cloth napkins which make for a cleaner feeling eatery. Close to Chinatown, but their price a little higher and fair.
author: Clifford W.

description:
This place is located in a pretty alley and the place is pretty clean too. Service is okay too. But this is not really the place for an authentic dim sum experience. One might notice a low percentage of Chinese amongst the clientele here. Well, this is located just at the border of Chinatown and the Financial District... ChiFi? Also expect to pay more than your average dim sum place.

Food is sub par. Individual pieces of dishes are on the small side. The mini egg tarts were smaller than usual and not flaky. The fried taro dumplings were a spherical shape and not flaky. Inside was cha siu, not minced pork. The shrimp chang fun was good. The shrimp dumpling was good too, with large pieces of shrimp inside. The tofu skin rolls had an odd filling. The carrots very long and slender and not cooked enough. The chives dumpling was tiny, but tasty. Same goes for the fried salt water dumplings. The chicken feet were my favorite and were of the norm. There were probably only 2-3 carts roaming around total. One of which was always service lettuce cups or peking duck a la carte. What?
author: Jennifer W.

description: This is my favorite Dim Sum in San Francisco. A few of the other reviewers said that City View Restaurant is pricey, but I disagree. Especially when compared to a more famous one in the city. The service is excellent, it's a clean, nice spot and the food is well made.
author: Alexander M.

description:
The dumplings at this place are spectacular.

We had ordered a bunch of dumplings and my favorite were the scallop, chive and shrimp ones. The shrimp noodle roll was also pretty good.

Def. worth a visit. The servers were courteous and the ambiance was quite decent.
author: Anant A.

description:
Out of all the restaurants to eat in the city, my friends wanted to eat Chinese.  (I was out numbered 3 to 1).  They decided to eat dim sum at City View Restaurant.  We went at a good time as the place was not crowded.  The servers were bustling around with their tray carts and everything smelled so good.  I do not speak Chinese (bad Asian), fortunately, my friends do and did all the ordering.

The dim sum here was good.  They served the standard dim sum like shrimp dumpling, pork dumpling, custard roll, deep fried taro, etc.  

For a Chinese restaurant, the tableware was clean which surprised me.  There were a lot of non-Asians there so this place is obviously doing something right.

My friends and I left full and happy with our Buddha bellies.
author: Dean N.

description: I like the food. It is amazing the owner is really nice but it be cool if they can put how much each item on the menu so I would know how much I will be paying
author: Winston L.

description:
We stopped in here for lunch during our visit to SF last month.
We came in here a little after 11am and the place was crowded. We were greeted, seated, and served very fast, by friendly staff. The carts rolled by very frequently with a nice variety of dim sum. The dining area is open, clean and well lighted. We had several things including shrimp shumai, soup dumplings, crispy duck, hom bao, and shrimp and pork spring rolls, all of which where very tasty. And there is a nice little park area next door to sit and relax afterwards.
The food was very good, the service was friendly, and reasonably priced for the area.
author: Michael H.

description: It was the first time I ever had dim sum and this restaurant made my experience a blast. It was really good, plenty of choice and fast. The only fact that you never really know what is what price makes it four star, no big deal. But for a great experience, you can go there without hesitation! I will go back and bring friends.
author: Morea P.

description: Went here for lunch with a party of 10. It's everything I can ask for in a dim sum place. The place itself is clean and huge. There was only a 5 minute when we came at noon. We were seated, and immediately started receiving food on the carts. They came by very quickly and we were having trouble eating fast enough to keep room on the table. Everything was hot and delicious. The fare was the usual dim sum foods, shu mai, pork buns, potstickers, broccoli, etc. and was not too much nor too little greasy. The food came quick enough that we were all full in half an hour. Only allowed two cards for the bill though so we had to do some Venmo work to get everyone paying their fair share. Definitely an excellent choice for large groups aside from that however.
author: Nick H.

description: Love this place and try to hit up San Francisco as much as possible just to go here. Always fresh and if you don't see what you want just ask and they will get it for you. Been coming here for 10 years and always look forward to the next visit. It is a little unconventional in the fact that they come around with carts and you pick the foods you want but its great being able to eat with your eyes. Parking is a little hard and is almost always packed but the sesame rolls are super flavorful and always hot. For me the prices haven't changed and usually spend about $25-40 per person.
author: Nicole K.

description: Location: on the rim of China town; Setting: grand space but with high noise level. Food: authentic Cantonese dim sum; parking: nearby parking, 2 hours free with the restaurant validation. Free wifi: no.
author: Rose Z.

description:
City view is a decent place for dim sum,  but there are definitely wayyy better ones in SF. 

Pluses
+ Affordable, nice location in fidi
+ Clean and wide restaurant space

Minuses 
- The food was COLD. Dim sum doesn't do very well when it's not warm and fresh out of the kitchen. 
- The food was just not that tasty. 

I don't know if I would come back considering there are better choices in the area.
author: Vivian W.

description:
A lot has changed since our last visit. Unfortunately, the change has not been for the better. The dining room is still clean, light and airy and you can still make reservations. However, the quality and value of the food has deteriorated.

The BBQ baked pork buns and the sesame seed balls are still delicious but the size has diminished to half the original size. Funny how the price didn't also shrink in proportion to the size. The crab claws are OK but would have been better if they were hotter. The Chinese doughnuts were unpleasantly cold.

CV makes yummy dinosaur eggs. I don't know what they're really called but that's what my friends and I call them. Glutinous rice balls are stuffed with ground pork and deep fried. Too bad they were barely warm and smaller than I'm used to.

Those were the 2 recurring themes of the meal. 
1) It didn't matter whether we picked our dishes off a wandering cart or ordered directly from the kitchen, everything was at room temperature or lukewarm at best. The only exception was the tea which was piping hot. 
2) Portion sizes were much smaller than in previous visits.

Since GGB was closed for vacation, we tried to get our egg tart fix here at the restaurant. We tried to order egg tarts at around 11:00am. The server said they weren't available until 12:00 noon. However, not 15 minutes later, an order of egg tarts was delivered to a neighboring table. Major foul. 

The number of people in our party was bigger on this visit than on previous occasions but we ate less and the bill was more expensive. Hmmmm. Something doesn't compute. I don't think we'll be back.
author: Cece E.

description:
I was looking for a non-sketchy dim sum place to take my in-laws (who are not asian btw...) and we needed a "safe" place to go since we had a ton of stuff to do and no time to be sidelined by questionable food (ain't nobody got time for that).

Like any good Yelper would do, I scoured the reviews and settled on City View.  I was looking for authentic (for the most part), not too expensive, and easy to find as we were walking.  

Dudes and dudettes, get here before 12pm or you will get hangry waiting.  The food comes around quickly and they're good at telling you what they have.  Food was pretty good and from what I could tell it wasn't too expensive (though a bit more than the real hole in the wall establishments).

Restrooms were clean and the signage is visible from the street.  I'd hit this place up again for sure.

I appreciated the cherry flavored mini candy canes out for the season.
author: Lauren R.

description:
Decent dim sum for Chinatown. Isn't it funny how Chinatown isn't the gold standard for Asian or Chinese food in San Francisco? The good stuff is all in the Sunset or Richmond. If there are tourists reading this, keep that in mind!

Prices are not bad and the quality is ok. There isn't too much of a wait on the weekends if you come before 11. You can order off the menu but they do have the carts where you can check out the food and order. I think my favorite thing on the menu is the egg custard buns (not tarts!) and the stuff shrimp crab legs. They still have all the traditional fare like siu mai, xiao long bao, etc.
author: Kate M.

description:
Came here with a couple of friends on the weekend after craving some dim sum. Having moved to SF recently I wanted to find my go-to dim sum place. City view seemed to have pretty good ratings.

At 11am on a Sunday the wait was around 10 minutes~ for a group of three. It definitely feels like this place caters more towards tourists, non-asians but that does not mean the quality of the food was bad. It's pretty standard dim sum fare, with some special menu items as well. Service would be as you expect. Surprisingly no pushy servers giving you food which I've come to see as normal for most dim sum places. My experience was pretty great. Food was great and was a comfortable atmosphere. I'm definitely coming back here again, but will make sure I try out some other dim sum places as well.
author: Tahsin I.

description: This place is decent not great, one complaint of chinese restaurants is overuse of salt and MSG. This place however is the opposite the dim sum is not fragrant in smell and taste that real Hong Kong dim sum places have. The beef noodle roll is a test of good dim sum and here the meat was chopped into bits and the soy sauce oil used for seasoning is not fragrant and had no taste!
author: N A.

description:
Yes, the location (edge of Fin. Dist.) and the layout (wider aisles) plus the big windows on the street make City View just a bit different.
We loved the Dim Sum. Yes, a bit pricy, but we enjoyed the meal.
author: Peter C.

description: Came here with a group of friends on a weekend around noon. They stop serving dim sum at 2. This restaurant is located on a side street in Chinatown and I would never have known to walk down this street if it hadn't been for a friend that knew about this place. This is a large space, waited less than 10 mins to seat us 5. The place is also very clean and they bring the dim sum in carts or carry the special items in a round tray. We ordered 17 items and it came out to $25 per person including tip. It's pretty pricey but 6 of the items were special items and about 7 of those were large items. Everything tasted really fresh. They XLB is yummy. Would come back again. By the way, you don't get an actual city view when you dine in, maybe a view of the street.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
I went on Sunday around 1pm, it was perfect! Not too many people as I was expecting. 
The service is great, all the waiters are very attentions to you. They will bring everything you need really quick since they have a lot of employee. 
It's worth to try this place the price is great as the service!
author: Kim K.

description: Worst dim sum experience I've ever had In US. They only have very limited options and the service was extremely poor. We waited for about 20mins and no one had ever came to give us the menu and water. We had to keep reminding them we were ready to order. If you wanna try decent dim sum in SF or Chinatown, I highly suggest you to avoid this place.
author: Zyz M.

description: Gimmy sum dim sum.  No visit to SF culinary scene would be complete without some steamed Dim Sum. You'll find best quality and no mystery meat at this higher end, Cantonese establishment on the lower east side of China Town.
author: Kirk W.

description:
This place is located between the financial district and Chinatown, and while some may say that if you're going to get dimsum in SF, you better get it in Chinatown, I still say that this place is worth going to.
This place is incredibly small for a dimsum place so popular but they oriented the whole restaurant so that each table has plenty of leg space, unlike some other dimsum places I've had in my life. You won't feel cramped eating here, despite how small the restaurant as a whole may be.
I think the dimsum here is alright, everything was pretty good, but yes, I agree, the best dimsum is to be found in Chinatown. However, I'd rather come here for the good service and clean environment and to be around a smaller crowd.  This place definitely caters to the tourists, but I don't really mind. 
3/5 stars for cleanliness, service, and pretty decent dimsum.
author: Zoe H.

description: Went here for the first time off a recommendation from a friend with my girlfriend,who has never eaten dim sum and is from the South...we barely made it on time because we got there at 2pm, but Bonnie graciously greeted us and seated us promptly with a smile. The food was AMAZING!! Do yourself a favor and go here when your in San Fran! This place is legit.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Wow this place gets PACKED during FiDi lunch hours.  Luckily, our party of 12 had reservations and we were seated immediately.  

Before I start, let me explain what dim sum is.  I usually like to call it Chinese tapas.  It's a bunch of small "snack-like" dishes that make up a meal.  It ranges from pastries and tarts to meat-filled dumplings and buns.  It's not really for vegetarians because Chinese cuisine usually has lots of meat - primarily pork and shrimp (shumai, ha gao, etc).  

There are two types of dim sum places.  
(1) People walk around with carts with the dim sum and ask what you'd like.
(2) You get a menu with all the dim sum varieties and you "check" what you'd like to order.

This place falls under the first category.  The ladies walking around with the dim sum can get kind of impatient.  I usually prefer the latter option because I just feel very rushed when people are constantly walking by me and asking if I'd like x, y, or z.

The dim sum is decent, but a little bit on the oilier side.  Prices were kind of high too.. We ended up paying around $22 a person...With 12 people.... hmm... I have a family of 16.. and I don't ever recall it being that expensive.   

Ehh.. Chinatown dim sum... so overrated.  It's totally a tourist trap or a FiDi professionals trap.
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Delicious dim sum.  A little on the pricey side,  but not a rip off.  Between two of us, we had 7 dishes.

Steam dim sum only has 3 pieces.  Many other dim sum places serve four.   

Did not care for the steamed stuffed bean curd rolls. They are stuffed with vermicelli bean thread noodles with a hint of mushrooms. We thought it was the typical roll which is stuffed with pork and seafood.

Good service, nice clean dining room.   even the bathroom was clean, no not as  pristine as years ago.

It is my go-to dim sum restaurant in Chinatown/Financial/North Beach/Embarcadero/Union Square districts.
author: Debbie T.

description: First time at City View.  Got there early enough that we didn't have to wait in line for a Sunday dim sum.  I wouldn't say this place is the bomb, but if you're craving dim sum and there is no where else go to around, this place will do the job.  One thing I didn't like was that the shrimp dumpling wrap are much thicker than what I'm use to, I noticed that with many of their other dumplings as well.  Personally I don't like dumpling wraps that looks and taste doughy; the thickness of it covers up the meat and veggie flavor of the dumpling.  Price is fair and service was good.
author: Kat L.

description: We make a point to come here for dim sum whenever we visit San Francisco. I can't compare their dim sum to other places around town as this is the only one I've tried, and will probably remain the only one I'll continue to go back to. We went at 10am on a Saturday morning and had no problem being seated. We were immediately greeted with a pot of hot tea and the dim sum carts kept stopping at our table, we had barely been there 10 minutes and probably already had 8 different plates on our table! The dim sum is AMAZING. It's hot, fresh, and there are so many options. You must try the Peking duck! The bbq pork buns and the potstickers were two others that really stood out, but everything we chose we loved.  I always return back to nashville craving dim sum and sad that we will never have a city view at home. Also, the people who work here are very friendly!
author: Lauren A.

description:
BEST DIM SUM IN SAN FRANCISCO!!!!! :)

I've been here for lunch a number of times and am continually blown away by how  sophisticated the atmosphere is and how the good the food is despite having a low price tag (for 12 people it was $200 and we were stuffed). Each time I've gone without a reservation. Although it looks crazy crowded, I've never waited longer than 15 minutes, even with parties of 10+. For dinner they open up their downstairs because it's just that popular and delicious!

The soup dumplings, crab claws, and shrimp with walnuts are amongst my favorite dishes (if you can't tell I have no idea what their real names are haha). To be honest though, all the dishes they bring around are incredibly varied and delectable. Plus, you're never left with an empty plate for too long. The carts seem to come around pretty often, and the food is always steamy hot and fresh. The portions are small enough that you can share with friends to get a taste of everything and leave feeling very satisfied. Dishes usually come with four pieces each. 

The waiters and waitresses are not entirely friendly but they also have to deal with pushing around a cart full of food in a cramped space so it's understandable. 

Overall, I would highly recommend trying this place out!
author: Nicole G.

description:
There's a dim sum restaurant in the FiDi? In a little alley at that. Who knew?

Happy that I don't have to trek out further to Chinatown for dim sum with City View just a few blocks away from my workplace. I come here with coworkers when we want to satisfy our dim sum cravings. 

This place caters to the FiDi professional crowd and it's evident by the medium to large groups that I often see here right around noon. For this reason, it packs here so I don't advise coming at 12-12:30pm. Either come earlier around 11:45am, or take a late lunch and come after 1pm (which I do). I usually come around 1:30pm and crowding is never an issue.

As for the food, City View serves most dishes by pushing cart that dim sum ladies push throughout the restaurant. Their dim sum is good. Not superior to the likings of Hong Kong Lounge, Yank Sing, or even Ton Kiang (which IMO isn't all that). But, for the FiDi, it's good, dependable, reasonably priced and fills an empty tummy. 

I usually come here once a month and get the beef or shrimp noodle roll, spare ribs, stuffed eggplant, deep fried taro dumplings, har gow here. All are pretty good and service is not horrible.
author: Jing D.

description:
Pretty good, very busy dim sum restaurant.  Turnover is important, as it contributes to variety and freshness.  I'd ideally rate this 3.5 stars.

Good shu mai, har gow, char siu pork buns, etc.  There is only one cart making the rounds at any time, so don't expect to quickly load up on everything.  The deserts (egg custard, sesame balls, mango pudding) were probably the best items.

A few of the dishes were sub-par; the xiao long bao was actually the worst I've ever had, although that's not really fair since I only get soup dumplings at Din Tai Fung or Yank Sing otherwise.  (I wish DTF would open up in the Bay Area!)

There isn't a huge selection, but all the standard dim sum items were present.  We didn't check out the menu.

The restaurant itself is clean, and the staff are friendly.  It is "spacious for Chinatown", or crowded for a SoMA restaurant.

I'd probably still go to Yank Sing if I wanted the best dim sum in SF, but if I were in Chinatown, or wanted something different, or a bit less expensive, I'd definitely consider City View.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Great option for dim sum in SF.

Very clean and less chaotic that most dim sum places. Make a reservation if possible...although it's a bit lower key than Koi.

Street parking can be tough, but there are a couple garages nearby.
author: Kenny J.

description:
City View is one of my favorite dimsum places. Here's why:

AMBIANCE:
This is one of the most relaxing settings to have dim sum in San Francisco. Tall ceilings, well lit, non-garish decor and plenty of chair room; it has a modern, upscale feel to it.

FOOD:
Order the XO sauce pan fried noodles, Shanghai soup dumplings, sesame chicken, or any of the steamed dishes. If you're looking for fried dishes like the shrimp crab claws, Great Eastern does a slightly better job.

It's true, it's a bit pricey for dim sum. I've come here for lunch meetings so I haven't had to foot the bill...yet.
author: Mimi X.

description:
We had...
Stuffed crab claw
Peking duck
Chicken feet
Many kinds of dumplings
Calamari with salt and pepper
Sautéed greens
Shrimp stuffed peppers with eggplant and tofu
Bbq buns
Sticky rice
Shrimp with Walnut.
Would recommend all of it!!
author: Kerrie S.

description:
Came here for their dim sum because they have dim sum carts!
I usually like taking my family to have dim sum on a Saturday or Sunday morning. This place is a great place to go to. I love their fried chive dumplings. Very tasty. We also got a lot of other dim sum. All of them are pretty good. Our bill came out to be around $44 for 9 different dim sum that we had. They were a combination of medium, large, and special.
The staff is nice as well. We will definitely go back again.
author: Ervi L.

description:
I don't know how anyone could be giving this place a bad review. When it comes to dim-sum I have been around the block and I must say, this is the best sit down dim sum in SF. I am sure you have read the reviews for Yank Sing, it is good but $85 for two--outrageous. This place is very authentic, service on point, dumplings hot and delicious and best of all, no line! 

Honestly, if you are looking for a true dim sum experience look no further!
author: Ben K.

description:
I gotta say: I like this place. It's consistent, dependable, and sometimes lovable. Like a Golden Retriever.

Except it doesn't shed everywhere. Or need constant love and attention, walks, to be cleaned-up after, a vet...

Actually, it's nothing like a Golden Retriever.

So, you've got all your basics: har gow (shrimp dumplings), shu mai (pork dumplings), scallop shu mai, baos (pork buns), in addition to their honeyed shrimp (holy sweet shrimp!), roasted duck, fried spring rolls, chicken lettuce wraps, sesame balls, custard egg tarts, and more.

It's nothing amazing, but it certainly hits the spot when I'm craving dim sum. Fair prices, no ridiculous wait, decent service, and good food; can't complain.
author: Adena B.

description:
This place is very popular and pretty decent as well. I've had dim sum all my life and have found my favorite places in the bay area. This isn't a place I've been clamouring to run back to. It was good, but not the best. For me, dim sum is the only thing I'm snobby about. So when I go out to have some, I want to get the best I can. 

Don't get me wrong, this place is great if you're new to dim sum or want good quality and it's close or easier to get to. It's just not the mouth watering dim sum I seek. It's also a little pricey. You expect dim sum to be pricey but if it's not that great then it doesn't make the trip worth it.

Im still giving City View a 4 star review. I'm holding it up to very high standards and it meets some of them. The atmosphere and attitude are great! The food just barely misses the mark for me.
author: Andrew W.

description:
There are about a thousand dim sum places in and around Chinatown, and some of them look like tiny little hole-in-the-wall places where you're not sure, as a white person, of your ability to communicate well enough to get the point across that you intend to eat your food and pay for it, and some are a little more inviting to the tourist-trying-to-get-a-faux-sense-of-culture types.  City View, with its tableclothes and location between Chinatown and the financial district, seems to straddle that line.  There are Chinese people in there, and it is certainly difficult for a gringo like me to communicate with the staff, but there are also other cultural (and probably geographical) tourists frequenting the establishment.  The non-Chinese can certainly feel comfortable here.

That being the case, the actual dim sum seems to straddle that line as well.  Most of what they brought by our table was fairly tame... Didn't see any weird stuff like chicken feet, durien gelatin, tripe, etc.  It was, when you really evaluate it, typical dim sum.  It was good, but I don't feel like I had to go all the way over to Chinatown in San Francisco in order to get dim sum this good.

If you haven't had dim sum, this would probably be an excellent place to try it out.  It's not intimidating, it's clean, and it has a nice ambiance.  I have no doubt, however, that there are much better dim sum places to be found if you know Chinese and you know whom to ask.  And at $45 for a light lunch for three people, I'm sure there are much cheaper places, too.

If you go, however, get the calamari.  It might be the best calamari I've had.
author: Jeremy P.

description: I mean, it's definitely not terrible, but does it blow me away? No, not really.  Then again, my impression with dim sum with certain things is that it takes a lot for it to really suck, and what makes a dim sum restaurant really outstanding is usually based on the individual.  So, was it good? Yes. Was it offensive to me in any way? Absolutely not.  Am I going to make a strong recommendation to make sure someone visits City View while they're in SF? Eh, maybe?  I enjoyed all of their attention to making sure their environment was clean, so I guess bonus points for that.
author: Lisa I.

description: Super yummy & easy enough to figure out even if you've never done dim sum before. Also, they had a few vegetarian dishes which made eating there easier for some in our group. Highly recommend the Peking duck & eggplant with tofu.
author: Amanda I.

description: It's a good thing I was treating myself to a new dim sum adventure but in all honesty my tab alone could have fed a family of four at my usual go to dim summit in China Town. The space is nicer than any other spot but I typically eat dim sum for the various options, flavors, and price point.  The quality and flavors were great, I just can't' get passed the sticker shock.
author: Robert M.

description: Satisfactory dim sum, but nicer/cleaner than your average Chinese restaurant and not quite in  Chinatown (border between Financial District and Chinatown/Kearny). It's definitely NOT comparable to Yank Sing or Koi Palace, but there were a lot of non-Asian people here, and it's probably a good place to take people who want to eat something quasi-exotic but aren't ready for the noise and grit of a typical dim sum place.
author: Cailin H.

description: Excellent dim sum place. Very diverse selection compared to other places in SF. Noisy and crowded after 11:30 for lunch. Try things you don't normally eat.
author: Nowell W.

description:
The dim sum here is fantastic. I am a Flexitarian so I do not eat pork or beef. They ha dim sum choices with chicken and veggies! YAY! It's nice here with white linens. Great for business meetings, dates, special lunches with friends etc. 
They do have a large dining area for large events down stairs.
Street parking. This place is located off the beaten path of China town on the outskirts of the financial district.
author: Christine D.

description:
The first time I had dim sum was pretty unmemorable. Everything tasted bland and I thought it just wasn't for me. However, dim sum at City View changed all of that for me. 

I've had dim sum a few times at City View and each time the experience is great. All of the small plates are brought around to each table in small carts and you pick out what you like. You also get huge pots of tea and carafes of water. I like to try a little bit of everything and my favorites are the potstickers, BBQ pork buns, pork dumplings, shrimp dumplings, and chicken siu mai. Each special plate has tons of flavor and are all perfect for sharing. There is something for everyone! I never leave City View without having their desserts. We always share the custard buns! It's a small little puff filled with tons of sweet custard.

City View is located in the ever bustling and busy FiDi and is always filled with huge groups during peak lunch hours. I definitely recommend making a reservation because the wait time can be long. City View is probably the best dim sum I've ever had and you should definitely try it if you love dim sum or want to try a unique experience.
author: Stephanie C.

description: This place was a great find! The Dim Sum was very good and the dessert items were amazing!
author: Nathan C.

description: Amazing!! Best Chinese food I ever had. We tried some of everything and it was all wonderful. We took my family of 6 and left stuffed! HIGHLY recommend stooping here in China Town. We will definitely be back!
author: Sara D.

description:
FOOD:
1.) xiao long Bao = cute! In its own lil tin tray for the soup explosion .. Kinda sticks to the tray but still I haven't seen xlb offered at dimsum before and it was pretty yummy regardless hehee
2.) duck in Bao - usually for banquet but it's cool how they have a small version for dim sum :)
3.) Lo Mai gai - interesting had a part of it already flavored w its sauce 
4.) ha gow- good but not what I normally like kinda chunky n stuck to the bamboo steamers 
5.) shu Mai - same as ha gow
6.) Dan tat-mini size good 


SERVICE 
Roll around on dimsum trays they are a tad more Americanized to cater to the tourists so they don't mean mug as much haha

ATMOSPHERE 
a lil nicer more modern looking than typical red carpeted dim sum places. 

9.22.13
author: Angela L.

description: This is my new favorite dim sum place in the city.  My favorites were definitely the har gow (shrimp dumpling) and the shu mai (pork and shrimp dumpling).  The shanghai dumpling was also pretty good, I've just never been a fan of soup dumplings.
author: Cici A.

description:
We went early, about 10:30 am on Saturday.  Not many patrons yet.  Seated us right away.  The dim sums were very good to excellent as others commented.  I'll only add two points to show that these owners operate outside the box.

First they open only between 10 am and 2:30 pm, unbelievable in a high rent city even if they are on a side street just off Grant.  Additionally the immaculate white covered tables are all given plenty of space, not at all crowded.  Definitely pleasing visually as well as being comfortable.  

Second, the service method is improved.  The server pushing the cart or showing the food without the cart can talk with the kitchen on her microphone to relay what a customer wants.  If they can do it, someone comes shortly to show the dish.  For example we always ask for a green veggie which is never on a dim sum cart.  It is always a special order which comes much later.  Here she asked the kitchen what they had,  gai lan (Chinese broccoli).  I was happy with that and someone brought two small plates later.  We took one and the next table took the other as soon as they saw it.  This turned the special order into a ready order sale.  They don't do that for everything.  But beautifully cooked green veggies are sure winners.

City View may set a new trend in that little area between Chinatown and the financial area.  This is only maybe 4-5 blocks to the Bank of America building.  What could be nicer than a light and fast dim sum lunch if they can manage the traffic!
author: Ed M.

description:
I've taken 2 different groups of friends to this place, and everyone has been pleasantly surprised and had the same reaction - why didn't I know about this place earlier? Its on a side street on the edge of FidI and Chinatown, so it really literally is a hidden gem. Not only is the dim sum higher quality than any other Chinatown dim sum restaurant I've had, but it's also clean and service was pleasant. No stinky faces here! It's not quite as delicate as Yank Sing, but you're also not paying an arm and a leg for your food. We paid about ~$20/pp but we ordered a lot and left stuffed. They have all the standard dim sum here: XLB's, daikon cakes, fried taro cakes, shrimp dumplings, pea shoot dumplings, rice rolls, char siu bao's, etc. etc. Everything was good, I can't recall any misses. City view has quickly become my default group Sunday brunch choice.

They're open for lunch only and only serve dim sum!
author: Jennifer W.

description: sweet dim sum, probably the best in the city.
author: Aaron M.

description:
We walked into a very clean, welcoming, staff had all smiles. Every dim sum restaurant we have been to has grumpy service. Not this one. So kind and happy here!
My family of five ate so much, everyone had favorites. I loved the chicken feet and steamed pork buns best. Oh friend noodles were amazing. My kids devoured BBQ pastry, not sure what they were called. We had so many things. Dim sum is incredible!!! 
The only reason I gave one less star is because when we got our $113 bill, we were all surprised how expensive it was. The servers come around and stamp your bill if you take a dish from them. Our bill definitely had stamps, but there was no way for us to check bill. We just paid it. I can only assume we ate a lot...I mean a ton.  
The food was exceptional and worth every penny. Especially the servers. Way to go!
author: Heidi A.

description: Came here on the recommendation of our hotel concierge. Dining room is modern, tastefully decorated; not overly Asian. Dim sum is above average, standard fare with a few twists. Service is above average for Chinese restaurants. Clientele a mix of locals both Asian and non.  Overall I must give it a thumbs up for cleanliness, service, and good food.
author: J. K.

description:
This review is based entirely on the fact that I did a fair amount of research to try to find a restaurant in San Francisco that offers vegetarian Dim Sum options (not authentic, I know).
Well, I sat there for an hour and the only vegetarian things I saw were Chinese broccoli, tea, and water.  I kept asking for vegetarian items and was told "later", but I couldn't wait for more than an hour.  I don't know if they offer more vegetarian dishes when it's busier (place was maybe 40% full when I was there), but, needless to say, I left feeling very hungry!!!
author: Liz H.

description: Had dinner with friends not familiar with dim Sum. The restaurant was full at 1130am and when we left there was a line out the door. Well worth the wait. the service was excellent: Peking Duck, Honey walnut shrimp, BBQ pork buns were my favorite. Call and make reservations if you can. When I am SFO again I will be back
author: Debra H.

description:
MAKE A RESERVATION FOR 10:30 AM

10:30 AM may sound early, but this place gets packed and they tend to run out of the good dishes fast.

My friends and I ordered a TON of dishes, all of which were delicious, but what really stood out was the service. Everyone was friendly and explained the dishes in detail.
author: Alfonzo J.

description:
Okay so i came here with a friend who was in from out of town. He has never had dim sum and made it a point to go have some before heading home. My wife had been here before and told me it was good. So my buddy and I went and actually enjoyed our lunch. We got there at around 11:15 just after they opened and it was full. That was an indicator to me that it was good. Notice I'm not saying great. The food was tasty and wasn't bad at all. The selection of food was good. We ended up getting the steam pork buns twice. They were delicious. The shrimp dim sum was also good. 

Make sure you ask for the price list before you order. Or else you'll be grabbing everything and anything off of the cart. You don't want to do that unless you don't care about the tab at the end. 

The most important thing is this, I shall return to city view. Yes it lacks a view of the city but don't hate on it, it's just a name. Kinda like when people say their kid is cute. When we all know it's not true. But we still like the kid cause it's just the way it is.
author: Marvin G.

description:
Mmm. So good. The dim sum here is amazing. I'd especially recommend the scallop siu mai and the lotus leaf sticky rice, but we didn't have a plate that we didn't enjoy.

A few things:
-The wait is long for a bigger party, but we (2 people) were seated right away since they have a quite a few tables just for two.
-It is a bit pricey. The two dollar signs is an adequate portrayal of the cost. We had 8 plates of dim sum that totaled ~$50 after tax and tip. I'm sure there are cheaper alternatives in the area.
-The decor is nice. If you have family or friends in town and want to take them to a nicer Chinese restaurant, this will definitely do.
author: Takeo T.

description:
Crowded at work lunch time to my surprise.  The food was good, but I felt the menu was limited.   They didn't have baked char siu bao and other dishes, I usually prefer.  Otherwise, the food is okay.   Limited servers and carts walking around the restaurant, though it was busy. We had to call the cart over several times, as they just took too long to get to our table.   

Otherwise, the plates and glassware were clean...odd for a Chinese restaurant.  The staff was pleasant and responded when asked for something.   I will probably come back for a second take to see if the service and food is the same.
author: Marck N.

description:
Came up for a boys trip up to SF and met up with fellow Yelper David K. and I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised. I'm more of a fan of those Dim Sum restaurants that have a C rating/ Mom and Pop feel to it. I don't like the ones that are super catered to White people. I feel like a lot of Dim Sum restaurants in West LA are just that. Dim Sum has been the new, cool, hip place to go eat for Brunch on the weekends. This place was more of the former than the latter. If you want an authentic Dim Sum restaurant experience in SF. Then look no further. 

*Your usual selection of Dim Sum Items & Decent prices. I'd come back again. Cheers!
author: Justin Y.

description: I've been here many times and always work lunch, so I can't really complain (since I've never paid for the food). Good dim sum, much nicer than most Chinese restaurants in Chinatown, SF.
author: Yoko S.

description: Yummy food, quick service, friendly people, and lovely staff. Perfect way to become introduced to China Town in San Fran! The name of the restaurant however, does not have a city view.... But the food is so yummy it makes up for it!
author: Maddie G.

description:
The food is passable. It's not horrible. The prices are higher than usual. It's definitely cleaner than most Chinese dimsum places.

All the dimsum is quite small. For example, their Steamed Egg Yolk Bun is small than the palm of my hands! Especially their egg tarts too! It's like the size of a regular small roll of tape.

Their Seafood Fried Noodle can be good if they had more sauce to it. Also, their noodles could be a little more...together...it's very crushed into pieces.

I really liked their Shanghai dumplings. Most recommend!

My dad and I ordered about 4 dimsum plates and the Seafood Fried Noodles...the bill came out to be $40. Usually, I can get half of that price for that amount of food. So, yup, pretty damn expensive. It's good only if you go once in a while.
author: Annie H.

description: One of the few good dim sum places left that you can still order the food off carts which makes the experience so much more fun! The food is good, the service was excellent and the turnover time for a table is relatively quick!
author: Wilson T.

description:
Came here early on a Sunday to avoid the lines. An 11am arrival accomplished that as we were seated immediately. This place is one with the carts so you can be eating within seconds. The carts come by fairly often but I didn't see as much variety as I would have expected.

The servers are friendly and speak enough English. There are plenty of Non-Chinese here as this place is well-known. At times, it did not have that authentic feel. The food is average and I truly was just expected more. for the two of us, the bill came to $46, also not as cheap as I would have thought. The interior is nice though and perhaps that is what you are paying for.

PARKING TIP: They do validate for the Portsmouth Garage around the corner.
author: Steve V.

description:
In a nutshell: Decent food; good if you're craving dim sum and work in the FiDi. Prices are high

Food: solid, not great. It's passable and good if you have a craving and need something to hit the spot. Good variety, nothing spectacular. What surprised me was the price. Even the basic stuff is around $3.50-$4 a plate. Much too high for dim sum! Walk up the hill and go into one of the bakeries instead. 

Service: Chinese restaurants aren't known for their service - not bad here; above average for chinese places.
author: Andrew J.

description: Our group of four had to wait awhile to get seated at noon on a Friday, but I guess that's to be expected. I try everything, even if it isn't vegetarian (sometimes you gotta live a little) - and I liked everything at City View. Especially love the shrimp har gow, broccoli, scallion pancakes, bbq bun, and sesame balls. We didn't like the way the shiu mai was served, in little disposable aluminum cups - they stuck to the sides and broke, making a soupy mess. I know Yank Sing is kind of the gold standard in FiDi dim sum, and it's delicious, but we get better service at City View. It's easier to snag a server and they take care of you much faster.
author: Rachel M.

description:
Here's my summary: Good and clean, but not stellar dim sum.  Perfect for business occasions as it is nice and quiet here, while being very professional at all times.  Bring your white friends or business contacts from out of town, looking to find "authentic Chinese" flavors.  

But here is my thought - you would do better at Yangtze.  It is just as "real Chinese."  Take it from a real Chinese.
author: Mark M.

description:
3.5 stars 

This place is certainly cleaner and less crowded than most dim sum places in Chinatown (**"less crowded" still means crowded.... so call ahead if you have a large party). Prices are reasonable for being in the financial district and the food is alright. The shrimp dumplings weren't bad.
author: Erica H.

description:
This Place SUCKS! They need to give back a star for wasting my time. I left this joint paid my bill cuz the experience was so TERRIBLE! 

$24 bones for 2 sodas and 4 dim sum dishes that tasted funcky! What a rip off! They bring out carts with minimal servings, for a pretty full house, so if you're sitting at the end (toward the entrance) they run out of food. The shumai comes in an order of 3 versus the traditional 4 pieces for $4+ bones per order. Everything is miniaturized (smaller portions) from the Chinese broccoli to the dumplings. They only have 4 carts serving food versus others at 12. They don't really have variety, if they do, you have to wait a very long time for it to come out! Don't waste your time! I left, walked down the street and grabbed 8 pieces of shumai + 3 steamed pork buns, + 3 baked pork buns, + 5 sesame balls for $17 bones...which were far tastier then City View Restaurant!!
author: L G.

description:
4.5 Stars!

This place is awesome.  Dim sum was varied and delicious.  I make sure to visit each city's Chinatown to find dim sum.  After doing my research on Yelp, found this place in the Financial District.

Made it there around 11:45 and avoided the rush of the lunch crowd.  They have carts and the staff use headsets to let them know you are looking for a certain plate.

Smaller plates of walnut shrimp came out - Yums!  They had the standards, fresh and hot, siu mai hargow, chicken pan fried dumplings, shrimp and vegetable rolls.  All were great and we started the day of sightseeing through town very happy.  One of our best meals during our trip to the West Coast.

It gets crowded for lunch, but would be worth the wait!

Took out 1/2 a star because my waiter was not all too attentive.  Had to wait for water and ask a couple of people before receiving it.  Food is 5*.
author: Maria S.

description: One of my most frequented dim sum places in SF. The wait isn't too long usually, even for big parties (but makes sure you call ahead just to be sure). The carts come frequently enough and they generally have a good variety of options. I love their almond bun and pineapple buns, and their steamed pork is also very delicious. Would recommend coming here if you have nowhere else to brunch on the weekends as this place is fun and not that expensive.
author: Jessica X.

description:
We tried a little of everything for lunch, easy to do since the wait staff passes by with cart after cart of options.
Good place to go if you're super hungry, since as soon as you sit down you can start eating!

Highlights: 
Lettuce wraps with chicken, shrimp dumplings and the pork dumplings were great.  Also, the egg-y and incredibly light sugared donuts made a perfect dessert.

The green tea was also really good- not bitter and not watered down.

Not as good:
The fried rice was super greasy.  I don't think I've ever *not* liked fried rice, but this was bad.   

Sesame chicken (at least, I think that's what it was) was also super greasy, and tasted like it had come from a Chinese restaurant in the food court.  Disappointing.
author: Karyn L.

description:
2.5

Overpriced dim sum.  Food was bleh.  Dirty table clothes.  Service was lousy.

The skin on the har gow and fun guo were not very good.  It was a bit thick and lacked that chewy goodness.  Definitely had better tasting dim sum at the pastry shops in Chinatown.  However, I have to admit, the quality of food was better here than those 3 for $1.60 places.  They don't add pieces of fat as fillers in their har gow.  On a positive note, I did like the shrimp rice rolls.  

Service was non-existent.  We had piles of steamers stacked 4 high before someone came by to pick them up.  Also, they don't change the table clothes so  be careful of leaning against the table.

I spent $80+ for not so good dim sum and I wasn't even full.  Ended up going to Hon's Wun Tun house to fill the void.
author: Lorraine G.

description:
Dim sum with a pretty good atmosphere.

FOOD: sesame balls were super delicious, ha gow, turnip cake and the likes were all pretty good and standard. Egg tarts are tiny though!

ATMOSPHERE: Clean and not too chaotic. Lots of asians as well as tourists. 2 floors with the bathroom on the bottom floor. 

PARKING: Several garages. If you park on the street be aware of the restrictions and signs around there!
author: Emily C.

description:
I visited SF from LA. First time visiting this place. Food quality was good, especially the soup dumpling. It was above average, however the price was on expensive side. The service was slow. The number of food cart circulators was not adequate. There were times when you had to wait a while for new items. The variety was limited. However there was almost no wait. We got our table immediately, but with appointment. It will be good for a quick gathering with friends but if you are looking for excellent dim sum then this is not the place. The parking is bad as for downtown
Overall it is 3 star
author: Mt N.

description:
Dimsum when you want it without that ridiclous 1 or 2 hour wait from  hong Kong Lounge..

The servers here go around every table holding different kinds of delicous dimsum and you just tell them if you want it or not. You can also request something if you dont see it being served.

will definitely come back here again next time.
author: Steve S.

description:
4.5 stars if I may!  

My friends told me about this place for years, but for some reason, I kept going to the same dim sum place in Chinatown because it was comfortable and I knew it was pretty decent.  Well, color me converted to being a City View Restaurant dim sum fan!  

On the weekends when it's quiet in the Financial District, this place seems tucked away, but inside, it is bustling with people!  Luckily, we got a table pretty quickly right next to the kitchen, which was cool so I could get a quick first look at what was coming next on those carts!  :)  

It all looked so good, but for our first visit at this restaurant, we tried: flat noodles with beef (yum, great taste!), fried calamari (tasty, salty, loved the spicy vegetables mixed in underneath), Chinese greens with oyster sauce (always need some vegetables, it hit the spot), scallop and shrimp dumplings (loved how these were twisted and contorted with tiny peas and carrots to decorate), shrimp dumplings (loooooved it with water chestnuts, what a great combo!!), kung pao style chicken (ooo, this was a *hit* with us, definitely something to re-order again and again), all with some light, lovely jasmine tea.  

Oooo, yes, we are definitely fans of this place - can't wait to come back!  My belly was full, but I saw other dim sum that I would like to try next time: chive and shrimp dumplings, egg rolls, diced chicken and lettuce cups.  So much good stuff and not enough room in my tummy!!  

Their prices are a little higher than my normal go-to dim sum place, but I think the dim sum quality and taste plus friendly, nice service is worth the slightly higher price *any* day!!
author: Maile N.

description:
This place has amazing dim sum. I am no expert, but I work with several people who grew up eating dim sum, and they sware by this place. 
What I know is that we ate amazing food, and the prices were not exorbitant.
This place is a total gem, and can handle large groups.
author: Dana O.

description: This place was absolutely amazing. Food with culture but nothing too crazy. I'm so glad our tour guide told us about this place. There was a wait because this restaurant is popular, but you start getting food immediately after sitting down, so don't let a crowd at the door stop you.
author: Robin D.

description: My first experience with dim sum and I was not disappointed. Loved trying all of theses dishes I had never tried yet. It backed up in a small street and kind of hidden but if you can find it, it's worth going to as opposed to some other Chinatown restaurant failures
author: Jeffrey H.

description:
The pros:  the wait is never that long, so if you are in the mood for dim sum, it's a lot easier to get in here than at Yank Sing, Koi Palace, or R&G.  There is okay variety in general.  It's definitely not as expensive as Yank Sing.  There's convenient parking at the Golden Gateway garage.  

The cons:  The food is not as good as at the other restaurants, and not as refined.  On my last trip here, there was no one Chinese there besides me...whereas 85% of the people at Koi are Asian - this is always a bad sign.  Also, the variety and frequency definitely drops quickly after 1:30 pm.  Overall, decent but not the place you bring visitors to impress.
author: Vivian W.

description:
In San Francisco, there aren't a lot of clean looking dim sum places, except City View and maybe a few others.

The portions are not huge, which I like.  The service is good, the line is never very long.  I am happy when I walk out the door.  For this 42 year old Chinese dude, I like coming here at least once a month
author: Tony T.

description:
We were directed to either go here or Nanaking. Both looked pretty good. We were able to get a table for eight on a very busy Sunday at noon.  The food was served both on steam carts and on plain push carts. I appreciated being able to see the plates of food on the push carts, but there was no way of knowing how long they were being pushed around the facility.  Most of the dishes were quite good. We were dining with vegetarians and there were many different choices for them. 

We all left stuffed and the prices were very reasonable.
author: Mike M.

description: This is our favorite Dim Sum in SF!  We make sure we eat here every time we are in town.
author: Jennifer D.

description: SOLD. Went at 11:08am and was out by 11:45am. It was so fast we didn't even need to pay for parking (post 12pm). We originally went to great eastern but there was a 45 min wait. This place was really nice, clean, the carts came out right away and there was no wait. The food for the 2 of us including tax and tip was $30 and probably on the higher side for chinatown dimsum but due to the lack of wait or parking...it made our lives so much easier. They also do RSVP! They had a lot of options to choose from with the carts and the food was not very greasy. I would like to go back again to see if they had congee and some of their other dishes too.
author: Lily P.

description: This review is on dim sum.  Greasy and so much MSG. Who puts duck meat with skin in their chicken sticky rice? It's obviously leftover meat.  You know it's bad when you get a heartburn afterwards.  I don't understand why Chinese food is so bad in this city with such a huge Chinese population.
author: Apple M.

description: This dim sum restaurant seemed more Americanized than the other ones I had. We got here at around 12 and there were no line at all. In LA, most good dim sum restaurants are jam packed by 11:30.  Not to be racist or anything... But the plentiful of white people and the lack of older asian people made me a bit wary... Over all the food was decent... But not as good as LA dim sum... And twice the price :( portions were smaller too! I ordered an order of chicken feet... And they cut them in half to make it looks as if they are giving you more feet than you expected :/
author: Jamie L.

description: 3+.  Recommended by an oriental tourist info person as a decent dim sum place, we decided to give it a try. We are regulars at Vancouver, Canada dim sum places so we have seen a range. This one has excellent service with plenty of staff. It also has the traditional push cart service, supplemented by hand carried offerings.  This is something that is pretty well lost in Vancouver as most places have gone to the order sheets. We had some basics.  The Sui Mai were a bit smaller then what I am use to, but they have a flavour that is similar to some of the meat fillings my mother makes which makes them different than the majority of Vancouver places - they also had only 3 in a dish. The chicken feet had good flavour.  The spareribs were ok. We also got hum seui gok (deep fried meat filled balls), potstickers, bbq pork rice rolls ... All were ok. The deep fried squid, was really good.  Also had the sticky rice and char Sui rice rolls.  8 dishes in total which were a few more than we might normally have. Overall this is a good place to go to and they validated our parking for the Portsmouth lot.
author: Warren Q.

description:
Clean delicious dimsum
The Peking duck , taro puff and BBQ pork bun are faves , attentive service , quick wait what else is there not to like in this place.

Every visit is an experience.
author: Nelce S.

description: The food wasn't bad but for a place that serves Dim Sum, I would expect more selection/variety. I did enjoy the mango pudding...
author: Cindy C.

description: Good dim sum place. Ha kao with real shrimps and overall great variety of dim sum. Good service and clean.
author: Julien N.

description: Very clean for a dim sum restaurant. Food is decent. Love the fried crab claws which you can't find everywhere.
author: Judy L.

description:
Simply put, the best thing I tried were the shrimp egg rolls. The shrimp dumplings aren't very good and I suggest getting dumplings that have chives or scallions in addition to whatever else is inside the dumpling. I did try the shrimp rice noodle, chicken skewer, and the veggie egg rolls, all which were good items. 

Hostesses at the front are not friendly and those pushing the carts sometimes do not stop to tell you what they have, or they will turn their carts around right before they get to your table and end up skipping you. However, they are pretty good about re-filling your water. 

City View is clean, has plenty of tables but definitely gets packed during the lunch hour.
author: Maya S.

description: Good dim sum place.  But you got to come here super early.  Even at 1.30pm, they were sold out of XLB and egg tarts :(  plus you hopefully know what to order, as other places, staff is not very helpful and barely speaks English.
author: Bay L.

description: Wow! The best dumplings ever and my fave is the Look Fun, they call it rice noodle roll. I got it with shrimp. I'm from Hawaii and wanted dim sum. This spot was recommended by our concierge at the Hyatt. We came once, but it was closed so we decided to try again today and NO COMPLAINTS! clean, nice service, but super busy. They are only opened till 2 pm so come early and be prepared to wait at least 20 min. Chee hoo! Aurai!
author: Mary-jane G.

description: View fresh and very tasty. Arrive at 1000 am if you want a table. Don't pick the first things u see, they will come back around. There is no menu but don't worry it's quite diversified and everyone will find things they will love!
author: Stoik F.

description: Absolutely delicious, prices are very fair.  Very crowded, so if you're coming during peak hours, definitely make a reservation.
author: Marina M.

description: My favorite white-people dim sum place. No really, its good, it just has the staples done well. But you will Not find the chicken feet, pork blood stew, or thousand egg porridge here. Because if you did, the white people may not come, at least not in these numbers...
author: Phantom Of Yel P.

description:
Pretty good service for a sit-down dim sum joint! It took a while to get seated, but I came with a group of 4 around noon, so the wait wasn't totally unexpected. We put our name on the list and were told it was a 20 minute wait, so we stepped out and explored a tiny section of Chinatown before heading back... only to wait some more. Our total wait time was closer to 45 minutes, but once we were seated, the food carts came rolling by and it was time to eat!

Overall the experience was a pleasant one. All the typical dim sum fare was present, including tasty egg tarts (yay egg tarts!), and everything tasted great :)
author: Wendy T.

description: Great Dim Sum! Very good quality and very tasty. Was also very impressed with the service and cleanliness. I can't wait to come back! It was very busy, so I would recommend a reservation. The experience is lovely, with the carts coming by every 5-10 minutes with random items. Try the prawns, very good!
author: AJ N.

description:
I was really excited to eat dim sum in SF because I heard it's that much better. Sadly, this place didn't impress me much. Everything was just okay. Portions are a little smaller than dim sum in LA, by portion I mean the dim sum's actual size, which I liked because most dim sum places in LA just stuff shrimp in everything. 

Service here is not bad considering this is a Chinese restaurant. Parking is available but there are meters so bring change.
author: Karen N.

description: I like it here. I prefer carts to ordering off the menu, I just don't know enough to use the menu. The environment is a little sterile. Good stuff
author: Dave Y.

description: Pretty interior, looks clean. Very fast getting our food.
author: James S.

description:
Why are you called City View when you are on the first floor of a building facing an alley?

But actually the only thing I'm interested in seeing here is the vast array of fresh, artistically folded, perfectly cooked, delectable veggie and seafood stuffed dumplings sitting on my plate. 

Nice view.
author: Amy C.

description: Great place in Chinatown. Friendly staff. Portions were perfect, a little pricey as you add it all up but that's a consumer decision. The food is excellent. This is my first Dim Sum experience in the US. I will be back.
author: Jeremiah D.

description:
I've now been here twice for a hung over lunch and continue to walk away impressed. No frills, no unnecessary waiting - just bangin' in your face Dim Sum. Pretty sure we tried everything in the joint and it was just what the doctor ordered.

Highlights - definitely the pork bun followed by the "soupy" dumblings. No clue what they're actually called but they're awesome.

Great ambiance throughout as well. Oh, and it's cheap. Like I ate everything in sight, had a beer and my portion was $23. nbd.

You'll be glad you went. But it doesn't have a view so don't let the name throw you off.
author: Andrew S.

description: Honestly when I was in SF I couldn't decide on which restaurant to eat Dim Sum 'yum cha' so I searched on yelp for the popular dim sum restaurants and I came upon this restaurant. I wished they informed you about the pricing of each item before you order it and my bill was very high for the amount of food I ordered but I guess it was somewhat worth it because of the quality. Although I'd probably might not come here again - one time thing for me.
author: Jenny T.

description:
This is not your grandpa or grandma's dim sum place. No, I mean that literally, and not in a good way, because old Chinese people are the bellwether for whether dim sum falls within the correct region of price, service, and quality. Any good dim sum place has a following of grandmas, grandpas, aunties, and uncles, who have all told each other about the place for years through word of mouth only. And this place, from the outset, seemed sketchy because there was not a grandpa or grandma to be found, inside our outside the place.

Every month I organize a dim sum outing and it has usually been at Hong Kong Lounge in the Richmond. Owing to the fact that many people have to trek out there from the East Bay, we decided to mix it up and see if there was anything better than Gold Mountain in Chinatown. So we ended up at City View.

As mentioned above, the first warning was that at 10:30, the place was fairly empty. Most Chinese families arrive at around 10 or so (the Christian ones, who bring the largest parties, go to church early and then cruise in for dim sum immediately after.)

The second warning is that of those people who had arrived early, not a single one was Chinese (or even non-white.) Well, anyway, we were firm on trying a new place, so we went in anyway. Our party of 9 had half of the restaurant to itself when we seated ourselves at around 10:40.

The third warning was that we got forks and water by default, but this could have been a function of the whiteness of our party (quite high.)

Despite this, we were actually pleasantly surprised with the food. As others have said, they have all the staples. An interesting thing compared to other places is that the food here is not as overtly greasy as other dim sum places (usually, the cheaper, the greasier, but even the tasty places do have a significant grease factor.)
