Standouts are the 'fancy' siu mai with shrimp that only come 3 to a steamer instead of the all-pork ones that come with 4, and the 'char siew soh' (sweet baked pork pastry with sesame seeds.) They also have a large variety of steamed dumplings (some of which appear to be very expensive, but you won't really know until they stamp your card. Good luck asking the lady how much it is beforehand.)

Odd ones out include the xiao long bao (warning: expensive) which inexplicably come in foil cups. Our suspicion is that the goal is to assist people who puncture the soupy dumplings on the way to their plate, losing all the soup on the way. However, this backfires, because the dumpling sticks to the foil cup too! What's more they are nothing to write home about anyway. The skin is thin and not very stretchy, a far cry from the springy elasticity you can get at Kingdom of Dumpling.

But generally, we were satisfied. The only wildcard when we finished was the price. We expected it to be more expensive than most places because of the attentive service but by how much, we did not know. Additionally, you usually have a hint: dim sum bill cards usually have sections for "Small", "Medium", or "Large" dishes, and the price for these common sizes is printed next to the grid. Here, it was not, and menacingly enough, we had ordered many 'Special' dishes, which are more expensive than 'Large'.

The bill came out to slightly more than $180 after tax and tip for our party of 9. That is a bit expensive and as such this restaurant has not made it into our final restaurant rotation - it's still Gold Mountain and Hong Kong Lounge.

It's too bad, though, because it wins on many fronts, including proximity, cleanliness, and the fact that they actually use carts instead of taking your order. But that comes at a price, one that many in our dim sum group are not willing to pay. However, if you are accustomed to the opulence of Yank Sing, you will find City View to be a bargain with a similar level of service and presentation.
author: Josh K.

description:
When The Mother was still an active barrister and The Brother was an aspiring barrister, this is where they would convene for lunch to talk shop without going into too much detail.  Once in a great while, I would be invited when they were not up to talking shop.  Well, The Mother is happily retired, The Brother is very much an active barrister, and I am back at college pursuing higher education.  

Someday, I hope the three of us come back here for dim sum.  I would sometimes place a takeout order for myself.  I miss the place and I miss one of the managers, who seemed to live at City View 24/7/365.  I would take the mick out of him for not taking a day off.  The only time he would take off was with his wife on holiday..

I was going through some of the reviews, to me it is either you like or you do not like this dim sum establishment.   I quite like City View.  The dim sum is very fresh and tasty.  My past gripe was that there was never enough of the stuffed mushrooms with shrimp.  Once in a great while, they would make some more just for me.  Other basic favourites were pork siu mai, green peppers stuffed with shrimp, rice rolls with shrimp, shrimp har gow, bbq pork buns, among others.  

The bathrooms are located downstairs, that is my only gripe.  Far away from the huge kitchen where all the magic/dim sum making takes place.  

Someday, I must come back.  Miss those shrimp stuffed mushrooms.
author: Chiara A.

description:
We came here for dim sum after taking the SF Architecture walking tour (highly recommended) -- it's walking distance from where the tour lets out.  We got in around 1:30-2pm on a Sunday so there wasn't a line.  

I wouldn't say there was a huge variety of dim sum on hand, maybe because it was a bit late in the lunch hour, but what we had was very good.  The cha siu baos were better than our go-to place in Milpitas, their potstickers were really good, and I always appreciate a dim sum place that has little plates of honey walnut prawns and sesame chicken in circulation along with the typical dim sum stuff.   Unfortunately they had run out of baked pork buns by the time we were there.  Bummer.

Anyway, we were starving so dim sum "sit down and instantly get food" worked great for us, and the quality made us want to come up to the city more often...
author: Michaela L.

description:
Love this spot. Dim Sum Carts make this place fun and official. Call this place a cleaner & more upscale dim sum joint. None-the-less, there are locals AND tourists. Price is reasonable, and selection is pretty wide. I vote this place 2nd on my top 5 list.

- Soup dumplings / Pork dumplings / Shrimp dumplings / Fried dumplings
- Shu mai
- Spare Ribs
- Candied Walnut Prawns #YUMM
- Egg Tarts
- Sesame balls

..........the usual.
author: Monalisa M.

description: I read on Yelp that this place was quite good for Dim Sum.   Since they're very close to my work, I figured I'd give it a shot.    Yeah, it ain't bad but it certainly ain't Yank Sing.   The Dim Sum selection is actually quite limited, and some of my favorite Yank Sing dishes are nowhere to be found here.    In their defense though, I will say that City View Restaurant isn't nearly as painful on the checkbook as Yank Sing is.
author: David O.

description:
The Best decently priced Dim Sum I've found in the SF Downtown area so far.

Some dumplings skins were over cooked, but that happens at all dim sum spots.

The Chicken Feet weren't soggy.
author: Steven F.

description:
On Sunday, City View plummeted from 4 stars to 1 and I'm considering never again returning.

I give service people HUGE leeway and a lot of respect because I don't envy them their jobs. I could never do what they do. I don't have the patience, memory, concentration level or multi-tasking skills to juggle customers. Consequently, things have to be pretty bad for me to ding a place for service reasons.

Well, City View, consider yourself dinged.

I can't understand why our table seemed to have been singled out to be ignored. As I looked around, we were the only ones continuously craning our necks looking for someone to come help us. Everyone else around us seemed happy, with water glasses kept full and tables well-maintained.

The ultimate insult, though, was the $7.50 on our bill for two pots of tea. Not knowing better, we paid it. Later, I mentioned it to a Chinese friend of mine who goes to City View frequently and she was aghast. The regular tea should have been free, and special tea a dollar or two AT MOST. That's what SHE and HER FAMILY are charged.

Really, City View? Really? Nice racket you've got going there.
author: Valeria R.

description:
At first glance, this place screams, "We make good food, make good money, and our scenery and decor shows it!" I was sadly disappointed. Houston has a lot of decent dim sum places, and I know the reputation of San Francisco's Chinatown, so I expected the dim sum to blow my socks off, especially a place that appears swanky like City View. However, the food is bland, the service is mediocre, the portions are small, and the dishes are overpriced. Lunch for four people (about fourteen dishes) was $85 and only my mother left feeling full.

Now, don't get me wrong. The food isn't BAD. But it isn't really worth going out of your way for. Yeah, its indoors and there's waiter service, but there are other places that would both satisfy you, impress you, and you would leave with your pockets a lot heavier than eating here at this below average place.
author: Deedee D.

description:
Best actual dim sum (food) restaurant in the city. 

What I liked: 
-Within walking distance from the heart of the Financial District and Chinatown (AKA bubble tea afterwards!). 
-Clean interiors and exteriors (by Chinese restaurant standards).
-Shrimp shao mai - not the usual serving choice of meat for shao mai, but it was a tidbit sweet and surprisingly delicious.
-Other items that were unique included their xiaolongbao (shrimp dumplings), which came in individual metal serving scoops. No spoon needed, I guess...don't know how I feel about that. Not optimal eating practice, in my opinion. 
-Also, their shrimp changfen (rice noodle roll) included minced green onions, which I've never seen with the dish before. 
-Ask for mustard on the side to accompany the soy sauce on your dim sum orders. 
-Water pitcher at each table ensures less water refilling by the waiter and more constant source of water. 
-They accept credit cards - even AMEX. Small but such a pivotal detail to me. 

What I didn't like: 
-Ordered the dan tat (egg custards) which came out to be mini dan tats. The dan tats were not the flaky kind that I prefer. Put simply, there was not enough dan to the tat (egg to the custard). Hah - I think I'm so clever. 
-I wasn't digging the pork changfen (rice noodle roll) because it was the dry BBQ flavored pork and I felt like it didn't go well with the rice noodle.
-They don't serve one of my dim sum favorites - dou hua (soft tofu dessert with sugar syrup).
-They charge for hot tea!
author: Phoebe C.

description:
We were staying at the Hilton over the weekend so we did the three minute walk to City View for dim sum. Yes, there are definitely a lot of cheaper dim sum places nearby but, we wanted to a nicer and more importantly, cleaner place to go to. 

Yes, you do pay more but, we didn't mind this one time. Couldn't do it all the time because it was more expensive than what we pay for dim sum back in the San Gabriel valley were we live. However, we were on vacation so we wanted to go to a nicer place and we weren't disappointed. 

The service was very good and attentive and we found the dim sum to be quite good. It got pretty busy by noon and there was a good mixture of asians and non-asians. 

So, if you are looking for a bargain, this is definitely not the place but, if you are looking for a more pleasant and cleaner place to go to, this is it.
author: Peter C.

description: If you are a tourist, this would be a 5-star dim sum experience. The ambiance is modern, staff is efficient, and food is tasty at a fair price. This is a great place to bring a group of friends for a casual yum cha experience. Be prepared for a wait on the weekends, but you'll usually get seated within 15 mins. Compared to other dim sum restaurants, the portions here are smaller and there is less variety. The buns are pretty small, and a lot of the dishes weren't seasoned enough. I also tasted some sand in the vegetables :( Nevertheless, my friends really like it so I'll probably still end up coming here now and then.
author: Leslie C.

description:
Christmas shopping in the city worked up an appetite, figured we'd walk over to City View for some Dim Sum.  Not too far from Union Square and hidden on kind of an alley street Commercial is just past Sacramento off of Kearney.

For those of you who know the scoop, they wheel by carts with different kind of dim sum of shrimp, pork or chicken on small plates. They come by your table with a few different items (ask if your not sure what they are) and if nothing sounds interesting, just wait they'll be more coming out of the kitchen soon. I only eat the shrimp and chicken ones but can usually find plenty to keep me happy. And they have veggie plates too. 

Everything was quick and delicious today (especially since we were on a time crunch to get back to BART before 3). Had a nice pot of tea and about 6 different plates for $27 for two. The Sesame chicken was spicy and sticky sweet and my fav today. Only bummer was no Mango pudding...Boooooo! Really like that after my lunch...whats up with that you've had it in the past? Maybe I was too late at 2pm...oh well. Always a good lunch and delicious Dim Sum treat!
author: Susan D.

description: Very nice atmosphere for a Chinese Chinatown restaurant.  They fit as many tables as possible in there in true Asian style and every table was taken with a line out the door.  As busy as they were they served us quickly.  The food was very good had even a few options I've never seen served before, and other dishes I've never seen brought out "dim sum style" like the walnut shrimp.  There are no prices but the bill ended up a bit higher than most places, however I'm assuming with the nicer atmosphere... that's what it was paying for.  Nonetheless I would return here again.
author: Kimberly W.

description:
There isn't a view of the city but the food is delish! Okay...they gave me a parental scowl of disapproval when I said 'No...I didn't make a reservation' but they sat us anyway! 

6 people for Dim Sum on a Sunday. Go early folks...we got in under the rush at 10:30ish.
author: Jay H.

description: Dim sum on a Saturday morning. The place is off the beaten path on commercial in China town. Based on the size of the restaurant, they must get busy. We eat dim sum about once a month and thought it was great. We never really know what we are ordering. We just pick what looks good. Most of what we saw looked good. We liked everything that we picked. We were bummed that we didn't hold out for some of our favorites.
author: Aaron J.

description:
It's a spot I'd take someone who was new to dim sum (ie not a Chinese person) 

Overall pretty standard fare that didn't venture far off the beaten path.  Flavors were therefore fairly bland but approachable.

Had the usual...siu mai, har gow, lo bak go, char sui bao.  

Wasn't too busy, but things took a long time to come around.

Overall have had much better for cheaper.

I don't think I'd go back.

Oh and if you don't believe me, I see that Susy C. also didn't like it and she's the queen of Yelp.
author: Jay L.

description:
Overpriced dim sum. The meatballs were awful,  not just because of the hair I found in the dish, but in its mystery-meat like consistency and taste. 

The potstickers were good, but no better than the ones that you can get in the takeaway shops. They're just smaller, and cost more.

If you're in Chinatown, I recommend going to a more authentic joint.
author: Carolina C.

description:
My favorite place for dim sum.  

Everything is always fresh.  Top quality ingredients.  

(Relatively) quiet, nicely spaced tables.  

You can select your favorites from the carts that visit each table, or order from a little menu.  Or both.  

Tip:  If you, like me, love the little custard tarts, and see them rolling around, grab a plate when you first see them... don't wait until the end of your meal, because by that time they may be all gone! 

Prices are reasonable.  Service is friendly.  Interior is bright and clean.  

My favorite is a dish that is rolled up rice noodles that have been sauteed and are slightly spicy.  So yummy... And I always grab a plate of the spicy lightly breaded spicy chicken in a hot sweet sauce  -- can't remember what it's called, but it is worth trying!  

Be sure to specify that you'd like jasmine (or whatever your favorite is) tea, otherwise they just bring a pot of generic oolong.
author: Bevy M.

description:
This was our first visit to City View and based on the recommendation of a close friend. 
This store is not exactly in China Town but rather in the Financial District and although
they have short hours (they close at 2:30) it was worth doing lunch instead of a later meal. 
The property is extraordinarily clean and the service was tremendous. 
Unlike a lot of restaurants in China Town where  communication issues mare the meal, we understood everything we were ordering and ate like little piggies enjoying everything we ordered. 
I'd put this place on our Keepers List. 
Thanks Harold.
author: Ed M.

description:
Don't come here if you want authentic Chinese food. I bet you this place is for tourists. Their dim sum is not the typical dim sum food. They serve American Chinese food and try to count that dim sum. It wasn't authentic at all. For me, a Chinese, I would prefer Hong Kong lounge, or koi palace. These places are authentic. I would know because the majority of the people there are Cantonese. 
    The parking for city view is hard to find on the streets unless your lucky. So your better off in the parking lot under the playground.
author: Lauren N.

description:
I give City View Restaurant a 3.5 star rating.  

Service: I really do enjoy the dim sum cart places.  Sure it's really corny, but I guess I'm a pretty corny guy.  Service here was pretty good.  I mean sure the waiters/waitresses hardly speak any english, but they were very helpful in describing the various dishes. 4 stars

Quality: About average.  Definitely not the best dim sum I've had, but not the worst either.  I tend to like my dim sum piping hot, and it was warm.  And the dim sum was fairly decent size.  3 stars

Price: This definitely is a killer.  I get it's supposed to be a "fancy" restaurant and all but man....$20 per person?  And I probably would've eaten way more food after.  You're obviously paying for the atmosphere and experience here.  Not for the quality of food. 2.5 stars

So if you like dim sum cart places and are in the downtown area I would suggest you go here.  If you can venture out of SF to other places in the bay you're probably better off going there.  Overall if one of my friends wanted to go here I wouldn't hesitate, but you won't see me begging to come back.
author: Anthony I.

description: Food was quite good. Not many variety but it's ok. Service was ok apart from the lady greeting at the door. Horrible. Like I owed her money. :) no parking nearby
author: Martin N.

description: This place is clean but seems to draw more non traditional dim sum eaters. I was excited to try it because the hotel (Hilton) referred us when  I asked for a good, authentic Chinese dim sum restaurant. Although the shu mai and hargow were good, this restaurant did NOT offer traditional dishes such as beef tripe or braised tendon. Chicken feet was the only 'traditional' item I saw being served. Also, when I saw the cart with chicken lettuce wraps, I knew this was not exactly the place for me. This was more like a dumpling house than dim sum. My Caucasian boyfriend, however, loved the place, so there you have it.
author: Eureka P.

description:
Food = good.  Fresh flavors. Nice seafood. However...I'm a bit disappointed with their vegetables.  Overcooked (when steamed) or undercooked (with their chow mein).  Some of the food was lukewarm too.  

Dim sum is served on the carts.  So you better keep your eyes open for stuff.  (If you want to know the pricing of items, better ask for their menu...if they even know what you're asking for!)

They serve dim sum from 11 to 2:30 Mon-Fri and 10:00-2:30 on Sat & Sun...and they have a very small menu of rice plates and noodles (chow mein, ji mein, and chow fun), so plan on having dim sum if you come here.  

Prices = moderate. 

Service = tolerable.  They're not exactly attentative, unless you're in a large group.  As is typical of Chinese restaurants, they ignore your table of 2-3 persons.  Oddly, some of their staff is very ESL (I only say odd, because it's in FiDi, not the heart of Chinatown!)

Decor = simple, beautiful.  We simply loved the huge panoramic painting on the wall.  

Overall, we'll be back, but only as a backup.
author: Fannie S.

description:
Beautiful restaurant. Interior decoration is above par.

Feels like this place have gone downhill since the first time I was here. Not sure if it was due to the weekday.  The food was hot, but something feels missing. It just feels okay now and not great like how it used to be.  Food cart seems to come back frequently enough. However, desert cart ironically comes by when we don't need it and can't be found when we're ready for it.

Check out can be very difficult when they're very busy.  Would recommend sitting as close to the cashier as possible hand her the check and have a breezy check out.

$60+ for two people seems a little overpriced considering the quality of the food.

Would definitely recommend management review quality of food and restroom.
author: Vu N.

description: This is my favorite place for dim sum.  Everything here is delicious.  The restaurant is very clean and well lit.  The staff is very nice and accommodating.  I've tried many other dim sum restaurants but keep coming back to this one. We go every Sunday!
author: Jane L.

description:
City View executes classic dim sum quite well.  After returning from three weeks in Europe, I was jonesin' for some Chinese food.  

I indulged in fresh pan-fried dumplings that were only seconds separated from the skillet - the flavors were amazing.  Fresh leeks, prawns combined with the crisp exterior made me realize that it was good to be home.  Of course, I ordered my BBQ pork pastry and fought for the last one.  

I feel the need to comment on the service.  The girls who work there couldn't be nicer.  If I saw something I wanted across the room, they would walk over themselves to grab me a dish.  There weren't serving my favorite dumpling so they asked the kitchen to make me some.  I must admit that I love the opportunity to bust out in Cantonese with everyone.  I feel like I need to practice as much as I can now that my grandparents aren't around.
author: Monica L.

description:
I'm no expert in Dim Sum in SF, but I am an Dim Sum expert, period.

The food was pretty good, it wasn't mind blowing but it didn't leave me blowing chunks either.  The place was packed, so the carts were kind of slow getting around.  I'd suggest adding a cart or two, but I don't know if that would help.

I think the one thing I would take away as a plus from my dining experience with this place, has nothing to do with the food.  It was the adventure of finding it and trying it out.  The place is down an alley of sorts, not a dirty "Batman is going to swoop in and save your ass" type of alley, but a nice one.  If a nice alley were to exist.

Again, the food wasn't bad, it was pretty good.  Its a safe bet.
author: Anthoni L.

description: A very disappointed experience. We managed to get a table after 20 minutes wait while there seemed to be plenty of open tables throughout the restaurant.  The food was no more than mediore and the variety of food was non-existent.  Worst of all, the wait for each cart to pass our table was extremely long and dreadful.  Overall, the first and last experience at this place.
author: Bao N.

description: Great place! Bit pricey for dimsum, but great atmosphere and food so werf.
author: Peter C.

description: Walked in around 11:45 the service was great! We had someone with a gluten allergy and they were really helpful trying to figure out what had gluten or not (and a lot had gluten). The dim sum was fantastic! A little on the medium to expensive side (hence 4 stars) but definitely good for what you pay for.
author: Sylvia B.

description:
Without Yelping, I've tried Great Oriental and Four Seas in the past in Chinatown and so far this one's the better of the 3.

Their location is a lot better being away from Grant's hectic street.  It was Sunday morning and pretty busy, but we were immediately seated for our party of two.  It did take a while for the carts to come around to us, but I think our table location was to blame.

The food was good and all tasted fresh, but I didn't like how they they rip you off with only 3 pieces of dim sum for some of the plates.  I felt they were a little stingy with their portions; you can even verify this by taking a look at the hot chili sauce's smallest spoon in the world.

A bit on the pricey side for dim sum, but a lot better than waiting an hour and a half for Great Eastern down the street.

And yes, they charge for tea.
author: Philip I.

description:
3.5 stars.

The dim sum quality is good. They push round carts and walk around with trays with more specialty items. That's always good as you can see before you pick.

It's on the pricey side which is slightly to be expected I guess for dim sum in the city.
It loses star for lack of value to me.
author: Nick L.

description:
Good dim sum with authentic Chinese approach.

The green tea was lovely - the mensroom horrendous.
author: Simen R.

description:
Saturday morning Dim Sum in the City.  It was a bit hard to find down the alley but once we got there it was worth the hunt.  Soup dumplings, and Peking Duck had my name written all over them.  The only down side was that some dishes were severed not in the steam cart so they were not as hot.  Other than that, there was plenty of food moving around the dining area, even when it was very busy.
Dim Sum on Saturday morning...sure I will be back.

That's my story
author: Steve S.

description: Love this place!  If you arrive shortly before the noontime madness, it is easy to get a table and servers bring the carts around immediately. They have a number of servers who also clean up empty dishes to keep your table uncluttered. Price is decent too
author: Amelia C.

description:
This is a great place to grab dimsum with friends/family if you're in the downtown SF area and don't want to wait in line forever. 

My friends and I showed up at 11:30 on a Sunday and got a table within 15 minutes. For a dimsum restaurant, the restaurant was pretty nice in terms of decor/atmosphere.

The dimsum itself was very good - not the BEST dimsum I've ever had, but it definitely will do the trick if you're craving dimsum. Their duck, shrimp dumplings, shumai, baked pork buns, choy sum, cake things with chives/shrimp and walnut shrimp were all very good. Their spareribs had a bit of a strange taste to it and the egg tarts were just okay, which were my only complaints.

You'll end up spending around $20/person if you get a decent amount of plates on the table - sort of pricey - but you'll be a happy camper afterwards.
author: Jasmine A.

description:
Dear City View,

Ummm...

Your food's decent, I guess...but....

On a busy Saturday, with all your tables filled with hungry folks, why do you have just ONE dim sum cart circulating the place?   Is two too many to ask for?  5 carts seem appropriate actually, for a restaurant your size.

But...ONE cart for like...100+ people?  

Please re-evaluate your business strategy.

Sincerely,
Annoyed and Hungry
author: Kathy C.

description:
It was nice to connect with friends I had not seen in a while and celebrate a friend's birthday.

Otherwise, it was entirely disappointing.  The service was absolutely awful.  The food was just mediocre.  

A friend brought a cake and asked them to bring it out with the candles she brought.   They brought the box out with the cake, closed, with the candles in the box.  We had to ask the waiter to first clear the table and the dirty dishes.  They brought a pitcher of steaming hot water with a knife and plates with plastic forks.   We would have gladly paid for them to do it right.  The surprise ended up being on us.

If you want great dim sum, go to Yang Sing.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
$48 for lunch for two people?

Because of the language barrier, you can't ask how much the dishes are and there is no menu for reference (at least that's what they told me at lunch time). So you have no choice but to order blindly.

The dim sum was just okay but not worth the price. Aside from the fact that you get to experience the whole order-from-a-cart thing but ironically, some of my favorite Chinatown hole-in-the-walls actually have better quality.

Would I go back? Nah, I'm good.
author: Mariela D.

description:
Came here on a Sunday morning around 11. I know, I know, rookie mistake... but sometimes your new-to-dim-sum friends are hungover.

We waited about two hours for a table for 6. By the time we sat down, I was starving and tired of eating lucky candy, so we needed food fast. Luckily the resident Chinese kids of the table flagged down the carts faster than you can say "siu mai." A short time and many plates later, we were all stuffed... my friend handed off the check and we started making bets on how much the bill would be. "$95," I declared confidently. "No way," my friend scoffed. "I'm gonna say $78." A short time later, the bill arrived and it was... $120. Before tip.

I think I'll stick to my usual dim sum haunts outside the city, thanks.
author: Jackie L.

description:
The place is good, the location is super good if u work in financial district. The food is better than eating at some Togo dim sum places. Service is ok, although some people just don't speak proper English which makes it hard to understand what type of food they brought to u.
I am giving this place 3 stars for the way they trick people. They never disclose prices when they pass by your table with amazingly looking food. You get one here, two there and before you know you are full, your bill comes up to something that you would never expect from a Chinese place. I went there with my coworker and we didn't order any alcoholic drinks, and I would say we ate a good portion of food for lunch. But we didn't go crazy and ordered everything and anything. So the bill came over $80 for 2... I'm not sure how other people feel about spending around $50 ( incl tips) for just a lunch, but I felt terrible. If I knew that 3 little pieces of dumplings cost over $7, I would probably think twice before going to that place. Common, other places have the same dumplings for 5 times cheaper...especially being close to Chinatown I would totally be sensitive to prices. It's not cool to hide prices is all I can say.
author: Aya J.

description: We went for dim sum around 10 am on a Saturday and it was pretty empty. They had a good selection of dishes and we left very stuffed. Mostly Asians with some whiteys but surprisingly very bright and clean.
author: Tara W.

description:
American dimsum.. usually i really like these types of dimsum places but this place was just mediocre in my book.. Food was pretty pricey, servings were small, you will easily spend $20+ on an unsatisfying meal. Personally there was no dish here that really stood out to me. Everything was just OKAY. However! I really like the fact that its pretty spacious and servers were attentive and most of all its... clean! 

That being said.. if you have pretty picky guests in town that don't like to venture beyond panda express... this place is perfect!
author: James H.

description:
Wow this place got nasty since the last time I tried it. They totally cater to non-Asian customers like Ton Kiang on Geary. Not only was the food not good but it was also came out to $40 for two people for dim sum (overpriced!).

I knew I should have ran away when I walked in and saw that out of 20+ tables, there were ZERO tables of Asian customers. If you are non-Asian, don't like being surrounded by Asian people and don't know your dim sum, you will find this place just fine and dandy.
author: Alex P.

description: I enjoyed my time there.  Food was great. It was a busy Sunday brunch, but wait wasn't too long. I will go there again.
author: Jer M.

description:
As someone who is from Hong Kong and having had my fair share of dim sum in my lifetime, I feel obligated to give this place one star.  But to be fair, the food wasn't totally inedible to warrant this place that.  So two stars.  

Located on the total outskirts of Chinatown, it feels like City View is banking on the fact that it is located close enough to Chinatown and still serves food cart-style to lure people into thinking their food is legit.  Well, it's not.  They only serve the stereotypical dim sum that everyone and their mothers are familiar with.  Portions are small.  The dim sum are poorly made.  And they don't list the prices or indicate which items are small, medium, or large-sized.

I just so happened to come here because of a work luncheon.  And once we were ready to order food, the ladies pushing the carts assumed that we wanted most of the things they had and started piling food on our table.  Oh hell no.  Do not try to pull that one on me.  And so we forced her to take back the unwanted items.  

If you notice, there are no Chinese grandma and grandpas reading their newspapers here while sipping their cup of tea.  It is predominantly Fidi, non-Asian people dining here.  Being Chinese, I felt totally out of place.  But if you're new at this and not Chinese, you'd probably feel right at home.
author: Vanessa C.

description:
Pretty good dim sum, and recommended for taking out-of-towners since it's right by the FiDi/Chinatown/North Beach areas. Everything was good and hot, and the ladies go around with trays/carts rather quickly. Ten adults and five toddlers = $200+ so it's not cheap ITTET, but it's not Yank Sing prices either. This place only serves dim sum style menu items, and closes at 2:30pm (no dinner hours or anything after that). On par with Koi Palace? I'd say so, but without the same long wait time. The only issues were the lazy-Susan would barely rotate when trying to spin it, and there's no "view" to speak of.

Located on Commercial St (a one-way street btw), coming from Kearny St - not a block away from that Holiday Inn and the Portsmouth Square garage. The restroom is downstairs, and way in the back corner.
author: Peter L.

description:
Did you all know that City View caters Dim Sum to most of the top hotels in the city?  Did you know they also do many private events as well???  YES, they do and they do an amazing job!  

Thank you Vincent and team for making our cocktail hour a HIT!  We had dim sum for appetizers (I'm Chinese) and Persian food for the reception (hubby's Iranian), but we wanted very specific items as our guests had specific dietary needs.  I met with Vincent ONCE and everything was taken care of, he made everything to my specifications.  Every single savory bite was delicious and fresh.  Our guests raved about the food and my coordinator raved about how professional and efficient the staff were.  They came and set up, laid out all of the dim sum beautifully in steamer baskets along with providing all of the condiments, after wards they came and picked it up and that was it!  So great when you don't have to worry about a vendor.  
 
My ONLY complaint was that I did not get to eat all of the dim sum we selected because our guests gobbled them up!  :( Not to worry I guess because I can always go to City View for Dim Sum!  Yay!


Thank you again, Vincent.  You made our day very special!
author: Caryn W.

description: Good food, good service. The waiter was really nice and helpful. The pan fried pork dumplings were really good, as well as the turnip cakes. All the food was fresh, and what we ordered came out pretty quickly. It ended up being a little pricy however, but the amount of food was satisfying and delicious.
author: Courtney K.

description: We came here after doing the CNY YMCA 5k. Decent dim sum, but expensive. Service was pretty bad (maybe because it was more crowded than usual?), it took forever for the carts to show up at our table, and then it took at least another 20 minutes or more for the next round to show up. They were missing egg tarts for some reason, so we ended up going to Golden Gate bakery to pick some up instead (excellent choice by us!). We still ended up paying $18 a person. Pretty pricey for dim sum in my opinion.
author: Veronica C.

description: Now this is more like it! I really really need good dim sum and had bad experience at Great Eastern. That memory has been erased by my visit to City View. Yay! Really really good! Quality ingredients. Taste was excellent. Everything I ordered from the cart was just simply delicious. Oh yeah it was Saturday so they had the carts going. I'll be back many many times! And price was moderate. About $51 for 10 items. The eggplant with tofu was excellent. The shrimp and scallop shumais also were good. Oh heck just order anything.. I bet they will be good.
author: Vol T.

description: Love coming here for dim sum! Fast seating if just for 2 when I came here around 12:30 on a Sunday. Love the Peking duck with the bao and hoisin sauce.
author: Paulina L.

description:
Definitely one of the cleaner Chinese restaurants around the area.  City View is tucked away in the center between two streets and you can hit it only on one side of the main street on Kearny.  Although it is a bit hidden, still quite a few people go to this restaurant.  The dim sum is cart style with the waiters/waitresses carrying out some of the hot off the pan items as well.  You can order as well, but this is more of the quick pop and go type dim sum.

Variety is definitely the case here as there are plenty of options.  The barbeque pork bun is steamed just right, the shrimp dumplings are tasty, the glazed pork bun is not that great, the chicken feet is what you would expect, skinny shrimp egg rolls are quite tasty, turnip cake was the best I had that I could remember, and the steam pork dumplings are solid but nothing extraordinary.  Food is definitely solid on the whole, and the whole atmosphere is professional and clean.  The setting is restaurant style more than hole in the wall status.  You cannot go wrong here after a long night out at end up.
author: Tiger C.

description:
I wanted dim sum that was good, but not as expensive/overpriced as Yank Sing. I read reviews, and decided that I would try City View since it was in the general vicinity of where I was heading. Maybe the reviews were off.

The place is clean - hidden on a side street that has little to no traffic - and was filled with a mix of Asian and non-Asian clientele. We were seated quickly, and it was that awkward moment where I don't know if the waiters speak English or Chinese.

Eventually when the food came, I realized their selection was limited - they had some good items (like their shrimp cheung fun) and some run of the mill items.

I guess the bad review really stems from lack of variety and being overpriced for the quality. Sometimes (just sometimes), I can justify spending $$ on Yank Sing because I think it's good, but most of the time, i want to pay for what I get. And I don't think you get what you pay for here.

Next time, I'll just stop by and grab some dim sum to-go at another spot in Chinatown instead of coming to City View.
author: Alison C.

description:
Yummy yummy mothers day dim sum!!!
Quick service, hot food and lots of flavor!!
Lots of shrimp items and lots of veggie items.
Park in the lot across from the hilton/hyatt and they validate.
author: Roxanna A.

description: The food was great and so was the staff. They were welcoming and attentive, all the staff were able to speak english which make it easier for us and the tourist to understand what was being ordered. The restaurant alone was big it had 2 floors, top floor was mainly used for customers who's dining and I'm guessing bottom floor is used when it get's real busy the only down fall is the restroom which was located on the bottom floor. It's a little bit of a walk til you get to the restroom. I think as for dim sum goes, it was overly priced! We had only 4 people and the bill came out more than 90 bucks, but over all it was a good experience.
author: Nana S.

description:
Good dim sum place. I've been here a few times for lunch. It gets pretty crowded at noon so get there early or you'll have to wait a few minutes. The service is pretty standoffish which is why I gave this place 3 stars. As for the food, the dim sum is pretty good. 

One of my favorite dishes is the fried crab balls. Probably because its crab and its fried, but either way its pretty good stuff. The sui mai is also nice and juicy. I've eaten a lot of dry ones at dim sum places because they are kept warm in the cart for a long time. But the ones here were very fresh. The shrimp dumplings I have had here are not that good. There isn't any flavor in them. 

All in all, the food is generally fresh and pretty tasty. But there can be long lines during lunch and the service could be better. I think its comparable to the great eastern restaurant nearby.
author: Arthur C.

description:
3.5

Nice to see Asian servers who can speak English as well...

Clean, spacious restaurant. Dim sum is pretty standard. Nothing WOWed me. Prices could have been cheaper - I thought Chinatown is supposed to be cheaper everywhere!! but guess not? and that's why they couldn't get the fourth star. Spent $50 +tip, which was more than what we spent on French food... go figure?
author: Tania L.

description: My wife and I just flew in from South Carolina and  I purposely booked a hotel in Chinatown for this kind of restaurant. Best Dim Sum I've ever had outside of NYC. Will go there again before I leave!
author: Terrell B.

description: A favorite spot for Dim Sum, off the beaten path from Chinatown...gets busy on the weekends quickly so try to get there early.  A good size restaurant, so even if you arrive at a busy time, the wait is manageable.
author: Marc L.

description:
Very good dim sum.  We arrived on Sunday at about 2 PM the place was emptying so there was no wait.  The only sad thing is that the kitchens were closing in so most of the good dim sum were already gone. For instance there were no little Dragon balls which are probably the best there.
I have returned several times since and the place is still great. The only problem is that you end up ordering too much :-)
author: JJ B.

description:
It's a Sunnyvale-style Dim Sum place, at twice the price.

Clean, comfortable, very friendly staff, grumpy hostess, pedestrian food, very high prices. Nothing that was not in previous reviews. I read them and went anyway, so My Bad. 

After being moved by the grumpy hostess, the attentive and friendly staff made sure I had tea and wanted to pick from the carts. The carts and trays came around frequently; the dim sum was just fine: nothing exciting; nothing disappointing. When I asked about shrimp in green pepper, they had the kitchen make one up for me and let me know it would be a few minutes -- very good service, especially for a cart-based Dim Sum house.

The bill was, frankly, shocking. It was twice what I expected to pay. Maybe I'm a hick from the sticks ... no, no I'm not. The location is geographically the closest to Embarcadero, but it has no nice view or anything. Perhaps it is focused on the expense-account set.
author: Richard H.

description: Their dim sum is good but far from the best. Located near Chinatown, it got pretty crowded when we went there for lunch. The carts barely came around, which is a big no-no. When we finally got food, the first thing I noticed was how pretty it was. Unfortunately, the taste didn't match the presentation. I do like that they had lots of veggie options since one of the people with me was a vegetarian. The biggest issue I had with all their food was the lack of flavor. Again the food was ok, but I'd probably skip this place...there are better places in Chinatown.
author: Melisa C.

description:
This is my favorite Dim Sum place in SF.

The food is fresh and delicious, especially the steamed pork buns.

The prices are quite reasonable, and everything tastes awesome.

Make sure you get there before 1:30 (I think) for the full Dim Sum experience, after that they don't have the carts out anymore.
author: Kevin M.

description: Came here hoping to get some yummy dim sum in San Fran, but was dissapointed.  The rice rolls are good, but other than that everything else was just not up to par. Service was slow and the carts did not come around often enough.
author: Tina W.

description:
I am definitely NOT a dim sum conoisseur, but thought this place was great!  The name is deceptive, because it's basically a view of the building across the street, but you can't complain too much because the space itself is nice and clean.  We liked almost everything we ordered.  The spring rolls were great and most of the dumplings were delicious, especially some of the shrimp ones.  The spinach ones weren't very good, but I heard the crab roll was excellent.  Everyone's favorite was the spicy chicken dish-- I think we had at least four orders of it between the six of us!

I would recommend going early.  We didnt' get there until after 1 pm on a Sunday (the 4th of July), and after we were there a while we realized we were missing out on some of the options that had been available earlier.  Definitely a good China Town place to try out!
author: Samantha E.

description:
-1 star: a place called City View w/o anything close to a city view.
-1 star: any dim sum place that is not Great Eastern.

Now, with that out of the way, this is certainly a solid choice for dim sum, especially for lunch.  Service is quick. The place is clean.  The choices are ho-hum...but standard. The food is decent. And you're in and out in 40 minutes.

Best part about City View is that the line is significantly shorter than at Great Eastern and the bill is significantly less than at Yank Sing.
author: Susan L.

description: Great dimsum in fidi that does not cost an arm and a leg (aka Yank Sing). The food quality is quite good and the service is solid. We got here early so we didn't have to wait. I would return and recommend though I wish I would keep it a secret to myself.
author: Tracy L.

description: Very good dim sum, lots of selections. Very clean, fast and good service. They take reservation,  better to get one because they do get busy.  Will definitely go back.
author: Candy W.

description:
Often very crowded at lunch on the weekdays, expect to wait for food that you would expect to be much better than it is. Cost effective for a group but otherwise can be pricey if you want to try multiple things for just 2-3 people. I usually have to ask for water and it often arrives half way through my meal but tea is always there. The food comes around quickly in the carts but if you want something that you haven't seen it takes a while to get someone to order it for you and then eventually make its way to the table. Getting someone's attention is very hard, paying the bill is an elongated process because of it. Thankfully i now only go here when i'm with people that speak chinese and somehow my entire dining experience is more efficient. 

Service aside, food is pretty good for lunch and they can seat a pretty big group which is a plus since we often come with 10-15 people. What we like:  turnip cakes (so yummy), pork buns, sesame chicken, eggplant tofu, chicken feet,  all the siu mai are so-so, glazed walnut prawns (sweet but good), seafood dumpling, sticky rice, shrimp dumpling
author: sasha h.

description:
Looks like a fancy restaurant but definitely subpar dimsum. Won't be coming back again. The dimsum also comes around in the cart so its hard to order what you would like. The place seems to cater to travel groups and parties as opposed to smaller groups. 

I would recommend passing on this place and head over to Richmond for some better dimsum.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Should I start with the unfriendly door host or the dirty table or the slow service?

Luckily, that didn't affect the food too much, but definitely takes a couple stars off.  As for the food, we went for dim sum.  It was sllooowwwwww and everything was pretty typical, nothing stood out.  There are way too many dim sum places that are much quicker, better and with nicer staff then for me to ever go to this place again.
author: Josh D.

description:
Giving this place 4 stars as in comparison to other Chinese food places this one is clean, doesn't stink, but the servers still barely speak English, which preserves "authenticity".

Food is decent but variety could be better for dim sum
author: Sergey K.

description:
We tried all the usual dim sum fare: many kinds of dumplings, sesame balls, custard buns, duck, eggplant and tofu, greens, etc etc. All the food was good. The service was fine, and the dim sum started to roll by the instant we were seated. 

However, it was on the pricey side for dim sum. Came out to about $20 per person for a moderate amount of food. Lots of noms, but no feasting.
author: Rob R.

description: This rating is based upon San Francisco restaurants. In the San Gabriel Valley the rating would be 2.75 stars.  The egg buns are very good. The Peking Duck was good with the proper type of buns. One would think that the Dim Sim would be better in San Francisco. But while good in San Francisco it is just average when looking at San Gabriel Valley.
author: John B.

description:
I got taken away from my go-to dim sum spot in SF (see Great Eastern Restaurant) and came to City View with a bunch of guys. The wait was long, but not unexpected for getting dim sum on a Sunday morning.

Our biggest gripe with this place was just how horrible their service was. The dim sum carts rarely came by us and when they did, they were the ones that no one else wanted or they were the dessert carts. Almost literally, a cart would pass by us every other 5-10 minutes. We had to resort to flagging down a waiter and ordering some of the plates through him. After a good hour of just not getting any food, we called it a day and left highly unsatisfied. 

I understand this is sometimes the disadvantage of dim sum, where you're not always going to get the carts you want to come to you and at a frequent rate. But I've been to many dim sum restaurants before and I've never had as bad as dim sum service as City View. Not coming back.
author: Tom P.

description:
First time for me at a true dim sum restaurant. I was visiting my cousin before starting a business trip and he swore up and down about how we needed to go here Sunday morning before his boyfriend went to work. 

The variety of dishes you got to choose from was excellent. Some classic dishes as well as a large variety if things o had not had before. 

The custard in a small dish with a cherry on it was fabulous. I can't quite explain the flavor as I couldn't quite nail it but it was a tart berry like maybe a strawberry or along that line. Absolutely great. They also had a pinaple custard dumplings that was amazing. 

Very happy with the food and was pretty busy/full on a Sundayorning but we were seated quickly and they were around very fast while we stuffed ourselves
author: Tom B.

description:
Dim sum carts! Yesss! It's long been a dream of mine to enjoy some hot, steaming dim sum delivered in fresh batches right to my table for the pickin'. But sadly, that dream cannot be realized in the Triangle. And whenever I'm in SF for work, I can't seem to convince anyone to join me in this indulgence.

So on recent visit, I tricked an unsuspecting colleague into joining me on our free lunch. Turns out, she's vegetarian! Luckily the servers were really good about pointing out and bringing around some dishes she could try. I ordered a shrimp/chive dumpling, fried pork, sesame ball, tofu & eggplant, veggie dumpling, and egg-y tart thing. What a difference from the dim sum in the Triangle. Everything was better and way fresher, with the exception of maybe the fried pork, which is tastier and stuffed fatter back home.

Our bill ran us $35, which is pretty high for lunch. But I can say we left feeling pleasantly plump! And for now, my cart food cravings have been quelled.
author: Christina G.

description:
Every time I'm in San Francisco this has been my go to dim sum place.  The dim sum are good; we had peking duck, pork shu mai, crab claws, and others that was good (I just don't know what they are called).  For dessert we got some mango pudding which was also good.

The only draw back to this place is you have to arrive early otherwise there could be a long wait especially if your party is bigger than 2.  After all this place is in China town.  Also, since there are so many customers the service is miss or hit.  Today the service was good.  The dim sum carts kept coming around and when what we wanted wasn't on the dim sum cart we were able to order and what we ordered came quickly.
author: Dante D.

description:
I have taken large groups here multiple times. I recommend it for that purpose.

Here's my take on dim sum in San Francisco. Yank Sing is the fanciest and the best; it will impress people. But it costs literally twice as much as any other place, and it isn't twice as good. So, for your tourists, family member, VIPs, people who don't know dim sum (it's not as threatening; feels like an upscale place), it's the right place. Then there are a bunch of good places such as Hong Kong Flower Lounge (by SFO); Koi Palace (Daly City); Hong Kong Lounge (which used to to be the HK Flower Lounge two decades ago); and Ton Kiang. Those all are slightly better than City View.

So you might wonder: why City View? Well, they take reservations, which is not a small thing; they don't have a long wait; they are conveniently located for people coming from various places. And they are perfectly fine. Not great. But acceptable.

There is something to be said for reliability.
author: Frank W.

description:
It's a travesty that this restaurant has the same Yelp ranking as Great Eastern.  I am the Duke of Great Eastern and there's a reason for that.  It's perfect.  It's delicious and it's cheap.  No, they don't come around with the carts that people seem to love you so much but they do at City View.  So if that's your thing, great.  Aside from the carts, I can't really say much more positive about City View.  I guess I can comment on its cleanliness.  It seems clean and nice looking.  

But for dim sum?  Just not good.  

The reason I tried City View is, despite my addictive love affair with Great Eastern, I am always on the look out for another Dim Sum place.  I'm always willing to expand my dim sum selection.  A friend actually suggested this place to me and had the nerve to say it was on par if not better than Great Eastern. 

He is no longer my friend.  

At least he's not a friend I can trust when it comes to asian cuisine. Every dish that came out was consistently disappointing.  I had convinced two other friends to come with me (two other dim sum fanatics) and they consistently complained about the quality of the dumplings we were receiving.  

In the end, I only felt the pot stickers and the leek dumplings were any sort of decent.  Everything else we ordered was bland or worse.  

There's a bunch of dim sum places in the city.  You can skip this one.
author: Joe M.

description:
I'll take Dim Sum over turkey on Thanksgiving ANYDAY!  That was the feeling my fiance and I had on our trip to San Francisco last November.

After much deliberation (we originally had a reservation for brunch at the Garden Court in the Palace Hotel), we came to our senses and realized that a) we are not brunch people, b) we could never eat enough food to make up for the cost, and c) it's Thanksgiving and we can do whatever we want - let's eat our favorite food!

So began our walk to City View Restaurant.  We were staying at the Omni in the Financial District and our hotel was literally a two minute walk away.  It was wonderful.  San Francisco is JUST SO COOL.  I absolutely adore city life - and miss New York for that reason.  Being able to walk to dim sum was soo awesome, and the weather, although chilly, was comfortable.  City View is located along a side street - when you look ahead of you - you see a steep hill leading up to Chinatown.  Luckily - it's at the bottom of the hill so you don't have to do much climbing.

I had made a reservation for 12:30PM, but really didn't need it.  I assumed that it was because it was a holiday and the financial district pretty much shut down, so their usual business lunchers weren't there.  Just other Asian families, having a nice Thanksgiving brunch - Chinese style! :)

My fiance and I were seated promptly - the restaurant is rather big, bigger than I expected.  Everything was clean, which was a huge change for me since I'm used to Chinatown style dim sum.  The servers were friendlier than the norm (meaning they didn't yell at you in Chinese and throw your plates and silverware at you),  and the carts kept coming.  I will say I was a little concerned because at first the carts were slow.  But they picked up and before we knew it we had a full table of dishes!

The beef flat rice noodles are always my favorite.  We also had the steamed rice in lotus leaf and all the shumai you could imagine.  We ordered hot tea, and tried almost everything we could, including the xiao long bao.  Everything was fantastic and we were soo happy with our decision.  We spent soo much less than if we had gone to brunch (our entire bill with tip was about $60).  Maybe we were just scared into thinking San Francisco would be super expensive but we were quite content with that cost.  

All in all - a truly wonderful experience at City View, the restaurant made our Turkey Day extra special.  No matter what city we are in, Dim Sum on Thanksgiving may become an annual tradition!
author: Kristy K.

description:
2.5 Stars

My family came here this morning for a Mother's Day celebration: for mom, sister who just became a mom and my brother's wife who has three lovely kids.  

The weather was windy and cold -- is it summer in SF already?

My brother and his wife did most of the "ordering" since they were paying for the lunch.  

I was too busy with keeping my nieces and nephew preoccupied and encouraging them to eat.

I did manage to eat some of the dim sum, mostly shrimp and beef dumplings and some chow mein and vegetables.  

The place was crowded.  (This is my third trip to this place in the past six years and it fails to impress me each time.)    

The food was mediocre.  We came here because my sister loves this place.
author: Peace L.

description:
Stopped by City View on Saturday afternoon with a friend. We got there just before they stopped doing the Dim Sum carts. We were so glad we didn't leave the house any later, we would have been sad if we had missed the carts!

We ordered 7 dishes and it came out to be about $40
1. Steamed pork buns: these were great! the dough was super light and fluffy and the filling was flavorful!
2. Chicken on a stick: these were really good. The chicken was marinated and super tender.
3. Scallop dumplings: we were surprised that there was as much shrimp in them as there was,  since we were told they were scallop dumplings, but they were delicious. 
4. Pork Shumai: these were delicious little bites, the pork was really good and came with little bits of carrot on top.
5. Egg Rolls: I did not love these, I was expecting vegetable egg rolls, but there was shrimp in them. They didn't taste bad per say, but they were not what I was expecting so I was disappointed. 
6. Crab balls: I did not try one of these, I was too full by the time they came out, but my friend said they were good. 
7. Sesame Seed balls: amazing, I love the flavor of cooked sesame seeds.

Overall the food was great, it was a little pricy, but I will definitely be back.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Used to be amazing.  The dim sums are well made with high quality ingredients and attention to detail.

However, everything is too sweet.  The dim sum has a uniform taste - that is sweetness.  Please go back to old dim sum!
author: M K.

description: No wait, decent service, parking validated, dim sum not that greasy, just expect to pay about double the price. I'd say this one's for the white folks and not the true Chinese diners.
author: Ava C.

description:
Overall, City View is a solid place to go for dim sum in Chinatown. The restaurant decor and atmosphere is above average and the dim sum are good. Nothing we had  from the carts stood out as being amazing, but everything was tasty and good.

The sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves was very good. We had to special order it and it did take a while to come to the table, but it was very moist and had a little sauciness to it from the char siu pork.

On cold days, try to sit towards the back because it gets drafty even 1/2 way into the restaurant due to the front door opening.
author: Patrick H.

description:
Don't be fooled by the nice tablecloths, cotton napkins, and well dressed servers.  The food here is just mediocre.  

I believe the place was good years ago, but I went today, and it was pretty poor.  Everything was warm - not pipin' hot.  Duck was oily and sat in it's own juices.  Siu mai was ok, but how can one possibly do siu mai wrong.  

I suspect they buy it at the same cost and same VENDOR, but yet they charge probably twice or even more than the crappy dim sum place next door.

Fine - maybe for business partners or bosses you go here.  But if you want more bang for the buck (and quite honestly, probably the same quality), walk the 3 blocks and get real dim sum in Chinatown.  At least you can buy some Fun Snaps for your little nephews on the way home.
author: Isaac L.

description:
This place used to be very consistent but today's visit was not good.

Everything we ordered was a miss .

Chinese broccoli was tough not missing it's freshness
Hai gow looked and tasted old. The skin around it was hard and the shrimp inside tasted fishy :(
The pan fried Ho fun and globs of hoisin sauce in certain parts of the noodle it should be evenly spread and fried
The chicken feet looked like it was sitting under a headlamp 
The beef tripe also looked like it was sitting under a heat lamp.

I ordered two steamed beef noodles and waited ten min and had to cancel took too long...

Today they were not pushing "dim sum" it was more like "dim lap sap" :(

But the positives were the tea and ice  water and 7up  was good and they payed attention to refilling them :)

i will not be back
author: DOM d.

description:
Came in here for the Dim Sum lunch.  We just beat the lunch rush by just a couple of mins.  Arrived at 1140am.  I was suprised how many people suddenly came in after us.  Totally filled the place.  

We had a variety of things as one would imagine.  I appreciate that they give you the flat bun with the duck, not just the sauce.  The chicken feet were tasty and a bit spicy.  Spicier then most places.  Kinda wich they were bigger though.  They didn't have any sesame balls with the bean paste, I actually had to ask them for it.  Never saw them on a cart.  The rest of the dishes were good, just as good as any place in my home town, San Diego.

The service was good and quick.  They have pretty much any dish that every other DIm Sum place has.  I do like how clean the place is.  I'd go back for sure.
author: Scott D.

description: I love Dim Sum.  I love San Francisco.  The two go together like a horse and carriage.  Nice small portions, and decent prices, so you can try lots of really fun things.  My favorite was a king or snow crab claw stuffed and panko breaded with a sauce that was to live for.  It tops my all time favorite honey walnut prawns, which were some of the best I have ever had.  There were 7 in our party, so everyone got to try lots of different items from the strolling carts.  Most were excellent to outstanding.  A couple just were not to my personal tastes, but others in our party loved them.  Guess I am just not much into gooey, gelatinous things.....Excellent attentive service.  Thanks to my good friends, I got to experience some really good San Francisco dim sum.
author: David B.

description:
This is the best dim sum place in San Francisco. This is a really fun experience when dining with family, especially kids, or friends from out of town (ie, tourists), or just with local friends.

City View is a great value for the quality and portions of the food. Coming here in a group and ordering many different dishes, it still comes out to about $15 per person for lunch, which is only a dollar or two more than a lot of the sandwich places downtown.

My favorite dishes are the taro root, pot stickers, sesame chicken (a big hit with everyone who's tried it, spicy and sweet. A great dish if you're dining with picky children, or those new to dim sum), bbq pork buns, spring rolls, and the rolled noodle garlic thingies (that's the right name for them, right?). I love the egg custard, but the last two times I've visited they've been sold out. My family loves the shrimp hargow, it's their favorite dish here.

The carts seem to come around fairly often, and the food has always been fresh and hot. I like that if you don't see something you are looking for you can ask the waiter for it, or order from the menu.

The parking on the street can be tricky mid-day, and lots of the spots on Kearny are tow-away after 3 p.m.. Your best bet may be to park at the Hyatt down the street (Or, of course, take public transit). Portsmouth Square also has parking, but I'll never park there again after denting a fender on their impossibly tight turns down the ramps. Also, if you or your guests are disabled, the restaurant is located down a closed-off alley, so dropping off someone in front of the restaurant isn't an option, and the restrooms are located down a long staircase.
author: Umilia M.

description:
OMG! This place is TERRIBLE. The food is horrible and the service is WORSE. The spare ribs had a weird taste, food was warm not hot, not enough choices that a dim sum restaurant should have, waitresses were rude even though I was speaking in Cantonese to them, and sticky rice was WAY small (1/4 of what you would normally get). I was so dissatisfied that I was still hungry for more food.

What a major disappointment, how are they still in business?!?! I thought SF was all about the good food!?!?!
author: Stephanie Y.

description: This is a great place to go if you are craving dim sum at work! XO Noodles, shrimp and chive dumpling, hargow, Peking duck, chicken lettuce wraps, sesame chicken, scallop siu mai are all tasty! YUM!
author: Elaine D.

description:
Came here with work Friday... yum yum moo... I love drive by dim sum... a minor down side is that I don't like the fact that they charge for tea... really? tea? tea is crap... I avoid it like the plague, but they apparently charge it per head... but the plus is that there is A LOT of variety... the later u come for lunch the more they have... it's very gracious for big groups and the food is always hot! A minor tip... come after 12, even though it's packed there will be a lot of good stuff being cooked... too early or too late means there's not much out...

Oh! I know a lot of people say that the downside is that the waitresses don't speak any English... common folks... you're in Chinatown.. you're complaining that they don't speak a language that's not even the dominant one on the planet? get real... they speak money... point to the food u want and grab it... then you pay... they're waitresses in Chinatown... you're not going to have a meaningful conversation... point, grab, chew, and enjoy... quit your bitching...
author: Nathan D.

description: I agree with the reviewer who said City View Restaurant is "the nicest and cleanest dim sum joint I have ever been too."  Well, at least that I've been to in San Francisco.  We've tried many dim sum restaurants all over the city and so far it's our San Francisco favorite.  (Yes, we've had better dim sum in Hong Kong, Taiwan and Singapore but we like City View just as much as Yank Sing and it's cheaper.)  Everyone has their dim sum favorite and mine is char siu bao (barbecue pork-filled steam buns).  If a dim sum restaurant has good char siu bao I'm definitely a repeat customer.  And City View's are the BEST... extra delicious because they are small, have less dough, and are filled full of yummy barbecue pork.  In fact, I would give their char siu bao five stars and would come here just to eat a whole meal of them!  But lots of the other dim sum are quite delicious as well!  (Come early as City View Restaurant fills up quickly once the noon lunch hour strikes.)
author: Nancy C.

description: The dim sum here is solid, and they authentically pass by with carts.  They don't have all of the possible options for dim sum, but they do have all the basics (steamed pork buns, sui mai, long noodles, shrimp dumplings, sesame balls, etc.) as well as some special items that are quite good (Peking duck and chicken lettuce cups jump to mind).  I generally end up coming here for lunch from the Financial District since it's so close.  The service can be spotty, but it's definitely a good place to try.
author: Scott E.

description:
I really liked this place because most dim sum restaurants only serve dim sum in the morning, but here they do dim sum the whole time they are open.  

We were seated right away on a Saturday afternoon.  We were right by the kitchen, which was great for us because we got the first picks of whatever came out!  The portions were normal for a dim sum place.  Pricing was about par with other dim sum places I have been to.  I would definitely come back here again if we are near that area in the City.
author: Rose M.

description:
Picture #1: "I don't know what this is called but it was AWESOME." I CONCUR!

Everyone knows there's only two places in the U.S. to get bangin' Chinese food: New York & San Francisco! So I was jazzed to take a trip on the bus down to Chinatown on my recent Cali trip to have some San Fran dim sum, and it did not disappoint!

For some reason, despite all the time I've spent in New York and its REAL Chinatown, Flushing Queens, I have not been there for dim sum (I am usually there for dinner). But gosh is dim sum fun! No need to wait, everything's there fresh, you don't know what it's called and you end up eating like a champ.

I read some alarming reviews about how expensive this place is and I did not find it to be so. Apparently, some people have some trouble saying no! My dining partner and I chose about 2/5 of what was offered and 3/5 we refused, and our bill came to $35 for two people. Yeah, a little pricey for lunch, but for the quality of the food, it was great.

That noodly thing up at the top was great, as were the sesame balls, shrimp dumplings, and roasted pork buns. My only sad part (more my fault than anyone else's), we were there a little late so they ended cart service and our last two dim sum requests had to be made off the menu.

Overall, I am impressed with your Chinese food SF! Love your East-side/used to be Midwest-side Chinese food fanatique, Jon.
author: Jon R.

description:
I love City View! The food is very tasty and varied. If I'm with a big group I'll make a reservation but I've never had to wait long, even during the mid-week lunch rush. 

One of the things I love is that you sit down, order tea, and the food just starts coming. Shumai, soup dumplings, chicken and water chestnuts in a lettuce wrap, walnut shrimp, pan fried chive and shrimp dumplings...so many wonderful things!

There are occasional days where the carts just don't make it to my table, but I've always chalked that up to things being busy.

For the price? one of the better dim sum places in the city, in my opinion. Could the wrappers be thinner? Yes. But to come away stuffed for $20 apiece is a beautiful thing.
author: Emma L.

description: Came here on a Saturday morning and there was no line. We picked this place cause it was a sit down place with carts. I expected a lot more for dim sum in SF. Everything was just disappointing and not up to par. There wasn't much a variety either. The worse part, this place is super expensive. We paid too much for mediocre food. I've had way better dim sum in Orange County.
author: Jennifer W.

description: I wish I could give 3.5 stars instead of 3. I was pleasantly surprised about this tucked away spot. A friend recommended it for a place for those of us living in SOMA/closer to FiDi. Pretty good food overall and really great service (that's a big compliment for a Chinese restaurant)!
author: Nora Y.

description:
Between my bf n I, the bill was $45 includes tips. We ordered a lot of food. We wanted to try everything we possibly can. We ordered the typical (i.e shui mai and pot sticker). I love their chicken feet; probably the tastiest chicken feet I ever had. Their shui mai was good but it was a little dry. My bf tried Chinese broccoli for the first time; he didn't hate it. I love Chinese broccoli; but I had much better. My bf n I bought sesame balls for dessert; they're delish! I could eat 20 of these by myself lol. Bf also ordered sesame chicken; it was salty n sweet. It's ok, I didn't think it was excellent. I had their fried rice cake; it was very tasty... My bf didn't like it cuz it taste fishy to him. 


They bring out a pitcher of water; great addition since Chinese food are typically on the salty side.

Our server was friendly; wasn't bad service. They filled our pitcher as soon as it looks low. 

I came here on a Tuesday morning. Chinatown is busy!!! Parking; we couldn't find any street parking (you can't park on the meters with yellow lanes, unless you have a van or truck); we had to park in the garage valet. For about 1 hour and 15 mins; we paid $10.50. :(

Overall, I'm glad I was able to try great dim sum while I'm away from home.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Phenomenal choice for Dim Sum for the following reasons:

- Takes reservations and always makes them, which means the ultimate dream: Waitless brunch.
- Extremely clean and efficient; the opposite of your old hole-in-the-wall, rats-in-the-dumpling-wrappers place. White tablecloths, lazy susans for the big round tables, quiet chattable noise level, small enough to be sane but big enough for large table groups
- Service is extremely polite, effective, and helpful. Staff speaks English well enough to easily explain dishes, including what's inside each dumpling
- Not at all that expensive; surprisingly cheap based on ambiance and cleanliness (~17.00 including tax and tip to get completely stuffed and drink endless tea)

Get:

1. SOUP DUMPLINGS!!!!!*
2. Pea shoot dumplings - standout
3. Shrimp dumplings, very solid
4. Shrimp noodles
5. Sesame chicken
6. Pork buns! YUM, even though they're small and baked instead of steamed
7. Peking duck
8. Broccoli rabe

*  For the uninitiated, soup dumplings, aka Xiao Long Bao (XLB for Chowhounds), are something which may be new to you that you don't want to miss. They're Shanghaiese reverse wontons, so there's soup on the inside and they're served in tiny pie tins.  These aren't available many places so get them here, dream about them, go back soon.  I recommend ordering at least two sets, waiting a few minutes for them to cool, biting a hole in the top, sipping out the soup, then eating the dumpling. A-mazing.
author: Megan G.

description:
Quite possibly the best dim sum I've ever had. They have all of my dim sum favorites and then some. Not to mention everything is super fresh... no fishy tasting dumplings (sick). 

I went today with friends and we literally stayed an extra 15 minutes hounding the staff to please bring us pea shoot dumplings because they are THAT good. I also had my first soup dumpling here... to die for. I literally crave them every Sunday now and want to go back into the kitchen in hopes that someone's tiny Asian grandma will teach me how to make them. 

I digress... 

Anyway, I cant speak for any other Dim Sum places in SF, but City View is clean, takes reservations and they have a great selection of delicious treats going around on carts. Done and done.
author: Molly S.

description:
There's nothing more impressive than the view at City View. Oh wait this dim sum restaurant is located in an alleyway looking street in the Financial District.

Despite it's incognito location, I would say this is the best dim sum restaurant in the Financial District (I am not including Chinatown as part of FiDi in my statement despite its close proximity). Unfortunately, that's not saying much. Compared to the other dim sum offerings in FiDi, City View shines (think Yank Sing or Yack Sing as I call it). But relative to dim sum places in say the Richmond or Sunset district this place is just average and overpriced.

This definitely a more bougie dim sum place. It is clean and lacks the grime which is typical of most Chinese restaurants.  

This place serves all your favorite dim sum eats like: chicken feet, hai gow, siu mai, and various baos. They also have some "unique" dim sum offerings like fried taro root and fried crab balls. If you are with a group of picky eaters, you can also order plates of noodles and share that family style.

I feel like this place is price-y compared to other dim sum restaurants. But I still come to City View anytime I crave dim sum on a work day and don't want to enter into the heart of the jungle aka San Francisco's Chinatown (what other options do I honestly have?). I definitely would not come here if I have the time to eat at a more traditional style dim sum restaurant; the appearance of cleanliness is not worth the price at City View. I guess the grime is where all the taste comes from...
author: Allan Y.

description: I had a great lunch here. The place was busy, but the staff attentive. Great Dim Sum. Fresh and lots of variety. I cannot wait to come back.
author: Adrienne G.

description: Old school style dim sum.  Not fancy California stuff just the regulars perfectly prepared.  I'd still vote for Hong Kong Lounge as #1 but this is the best in the Downtown/Chinatown area.
author: Ric S.

description:
Oh the horror that is this restaurant.

Easily the most inefficient and aggravating serving staff I've ever had the displeasure of witnessing in action. We arrived starving and dismayed to see a gigantic crowd in the waiting area by the front doors. But why?

I scanned the restaurant and saw that there were at least 5 empty tables, but all of them either completely uncleaned, half-cleaned, or even worse, completely set and ready for the next customer. Frustratingly ready.

The maitre'd was flitting about doing one thing or another, sometimes washing things, sometimes passing by a table and grabbing a cup or teapot, but never doing her actual job: seating customers. 

The rest of the actual bussing/wait staff would collectively clean/setup a table all at the same time, neglecting the rest of the restaurant as they moved at snail's pace. Coming from certain cheaper and higher quality dim sum restaurants in Toronto, this service was just abysmal. 

Thankfully, after finally being seated, the service was much quicker and we were able to grab food off passing carts. Nothing stood out afterwards about their service, negative or positive.

The food itself was decent. The mini-peking duck rolls were fun but some of the classics like the hargow were less than fresh.

Definitely on the pricier side of dim sum, I guess due to its financial district location. I only gave it $$ but people who know real dim sum know that that's expensive. It's not a price I would willingly pay again for this experience.
author: Aloysius C.

description:
You can always count on a quick lunch for a large party when you head for dim sum with cart service. With food that's already making its way out of the kitchen, all you've got to do is point out the items that look good to you and you're on your way!

A table of 8 of us ploughed through I don't know how many dishes of veggies, dumplings, rice, turnips and other foods I don't know the name of. But we ate to our hearts content and I've gotta say, the dim sum was as good as any I've had back home (is that saying much for a white girl from Canada?).
author: Wendy P.

description: This was pretty good for a dim sum restaurant. Definitely the most efficient place I've been to, good service, but I have a feeling there are places with better dim sum overall. The quality of the food brings it to 3 stars.
author: Ani N.

description:
we arrived around 10:30am on a Sunday and already half the tables had "reserved" signs on them.  Clean and bright, good service by both the servers and the cart ladies.
