Flavour is good but wow is it ever expensive..I've never paid $8.20 for an order of crab claws (2).  Even the "small" dishes are $3.50 each...growing up in Toronto, Canada where most dim sum restaurant price their small dish @ about $2 each, we found it expensive!  We have to admit the trade off was that it was less than 3 blocks walk from our hotel @ Le Meridien, where we had left our car there, so we saved on the parking plus, it appears as though sit-down dim sum is not as accessible in California, so we were happy to have found one close by.  Our total bill was $80 for 4 adults, before tip...
The 3-star rating is totally based on the price.  Will admit, by the time we left @ about noon, the restaurant was packed with about 30 + ppl waiting in and outside the restaurant...everyone here must be rich as I won't be able to afford such dim sum prices on a regular basis...hope I'll find somewhere for reasonably priced for our next visit to SF.
author: Amy R.

description:
Disappointed: that's how I feel about City View. I should have figured with a name like that that the offerings weren't going to be as good in value in comparison to the other dim sum places nearby. 

Sure, the environment may be somewhat comforting to non-Chinese/ABCs since most of the customers are not Chinese here, but to me, that just means that the prices are going to be more expensive and that the food isn't going to be nearly as authentic. Yes, so their sign outside says "Dim Sum and Cantonese cuisine". And yes, some of the food was authentic. They seemed to serve too many dumplings though and not enough buns/chicken feet/et. al.

I was also disappointed with the size of the dishes: tiny tiny egg custards for how much?! I've seen larger custards for less money. When I think about dim sum, I think of it as being filling, not as something dainty. I also just didn't like the environment so much, nor did I like the price tag. 

The service was fine, I suppose...the carts came around often enough. Another plus is that they do accept credit cards, as opposed to most places in Chinatown. The place is also cleaner in terms of dining room/restrooms. 

However....next time I'm in the area, I'll be going elsewhere for better and cheaper dim sum.

P.S. For more on dim sum environments, check out my blog post http://cinnamonjuice.blogspot.com/2009/02/food-dim-sum-environment.html
author: Helene K.

description: Good dim sum near financial district at more reasonable prices than Yang Sing. Very clean chinese restaurant as well. Been coming here for years and the quality of food is still great after many years. I grew up in LA eating tons of amazing dim sum and this is my go to spot to satisfy my dim sum cravings on a workday in SF.
author: Debbie Y.

description: I found the quality of the dim sum here was good, and the restaurant feels clean.  Now I know some people feel that the dirtier hole in the wall places are the best, but I thought this place did both cleanliness and food decently well.  Carts kept coming around with a really nice variety.
author: Pam S.

description: The dim sum is superb and not expensive at all. 4 of us sat here on a Saturday morning, and ordered enough dim sum to choke a Budweiser Clydesdale, and out bill was $108 total. So basically $25-ish plus tax and tip for a hugely filling and satisfying meal. The staff were really good and the carts of deliciousness were aplenty.
author: Osito S.

description:
I'm not really into Dim Sum, but it wasn't so bad. There weren't that many options since there were barely any carts moving around. Also the place was absolutely packed, so that didn't make much sense.

It took forever to get the check and the service was just poor in general.
author: Tyler H.

description:
Why all the bad reviews?

Last week, I ate delicious dim sum at City View. I particularly enjoyed the small servings of Peking Duck.

On this particular visit, I was impressed by the variety. Usually, the husband and I stick to our favorites. But, this time I was accompanied by a friend who keeps Kosher. She had lots to choose from, including chicken shumai and spinach dumplings. 

The bill was around $80 for 4 people. We ate a lot of food. A bit pricey for lunch, I guess, but much better than some other dim sum places in SF.
author: Jessica N.

description: My 1st time going to this Commercial Street Alley and hidden in this alley is City View. I went for a party and we ordered a bunch of dim sum, all were good! There was also an order of beef fried rice, I HATE ginger and there were huge slivers of ginger all up in this dish, EWW for ME! but good for you if you like ginger. Also had pan fried noodle with chicken and that was good. They also gave us complimentary sesame balls, yum yum dim sum!
author: Karen T.

description:
We generally come here after our monthly meeting.  It's really busy during lunch (not sure about the weekend) and with a group of at least 8 people and no reservations, the hostess will disapprove you for trying to put some tables together even though we've calculated the geometry of the dim sum cart's ability to pass through.  The waiter gave us the okay and we sat as a group yet with an unpleasant stare from the hostess from afar.

The establishment is clean and their hot sauce is red and not an oxidized brownish color which I commonly see at Chinese restaurants.  Their noodle dishes are good, and their dim sum is simply OKAY - I'm always the default to finish what's left over but here I feel like I have to lie to my colleagues about being full.
author: Jona C.

description:
I love this dim sum restaurant.  I always took people here when they came to SF from out of town and wanted a dim sum experience that was not going to create a huge sad sum of a tab at the end of the meal.  City View fits the bill.

The location is a little weird, unless you work at 555 California or near there.  But I kind of liked that about it.  The service could be better sometimes.  But I still give it 5 stars for the affordable dim sum experience that is unique to San Francisco (or if not unique, then special).
author: Amber S.

description: Good experience at City View Restaurant for vegetarian dim sum. We got there shortly after they opened on a Sunday and were seated right away. It did fill up pretty quickly, so come early if you don't want to wait. When the first person came by with a tray with some offerings, we told her we were vegetarian. She came back shortly with several dumpling offerings (mushroom, spinach), veggie egg rolls, veggies and more. Having a nice dim sum experience while being a vegetarian was fine at this place. The restaurant was nice inside, white table cloth and all staffers were friendly too. For two people, our tab was $31. Would definitely come back next time we are in SF.
author: Sophia M.

description:
Ain't no Yank Sing!

My friend recommend this place and I was open to try a new spot. Uh huh honey. Mediocre at best.

The staff is not professional, helpful or friendly. The dim sum is just OK. 

We got there at 1:45 and they stop serving dim sum at 2. All we got was a few choices of old and hard hockey puck style dim sum. Hard to tell how many choices they have but I doubt it's not  as many as the real deal. 

Yes, Yank Sing is much more expensive but it's well worth it.
author: Chris S.

description:
This one's gonna be short. Went for a quick bite before heading out to the airport. Ordered various dim sum from this cute little restaurant located on the edge of Chinatown.

I love it when the little carts come around. Overall, cute place with friendly staff. Don't get me wrong, the dim sum was good, but I must admit that I have had better in Los Angeles. 

I would definitely go back when I have more time and can order more items off the menu.
author: Miko C.

description: I like this place one of the few places I go to eat dim sum. Arrive early otherwise you have to wait as it is full by noon. The servers return often with different selections to pick from overall a solid place to eat at.
author: Andres M.

description:
During lunch time during the week is really busy.  A lot of people in the financial district like to frequent this place because the food is good.  However, the service really sucks.  

I've been here many times with coworkers and the most we've had to wait is about twenty minutes which cuts into your lunch hours when you need to get back to work.  Once seats, all you have to do is point and choose.

I usually get the typical shu mai, hargow, pork buns and the noodle thing with the sauce.  You can even order plates of food like chow mein, fried rice, honey walnut shrimp, etc.  The prices at this place is average to pricey depending on what you order so beware of what you are ordering.

I'm never disappointed with the food but the service is the only thing I have to gripe about.

I remember one time when my coworker was unsatisfied with the service that she only gave $1 as a tip on her credit card.  Why is it she checks her balance and the restaurant charged her card for an extra $5.  My friend disputed that charge and luckily she had the receipt with the amount she left for the restaurant.  This is horrible and dishonest.

This place is good for the food but the service and people are horrible.  Be careful when you leave your credit card and check your balance as quick as you can the next day to ensure you weren't overcharged.
author: Mia D.

description: Quite possibly the best Dim Sum I have ever had.  Service was fast and friendly.  The carts come around very rapidly.  I made the mistake of picking off of the first two cars I saw and got full.  TIP: let all the carts go around and see what all they have; they have tons to choose from, then pig out!
author: Aman S.

description:
This used to be one of my old standbys in the City (I find Ton Kiang good but too crowded, and Yank Sing waaaay overpriced) but the last time I went during the week, we had the steamed pork spareribs with black beans and they were rancid. As in, probably cooked a few days ago and no one had ordered them so they just kept them and re-served them.

Pork spareribs with black bean sauce is one of my husband's favorite dimsum dishes and we tend to order it wherever we go to dimsum. It's a pretty good gauge of the quality of a place because not very many non-Chinese people order it.

You can get really, really sick from bad pork, so we told the waiter, who didn't seem to care, and even tried to charge us for the ribs. I think there's a 50% chance that the ribs went back into the rotation for the next unsuspecting customer. 

I've been eating dimsum since I could eat solid foods and that's never happened before.
author: Bianca L.

description:
As I've spent many a summer in Beijing where dim sum is cheap, well presented, and easy to come by, I've gotten pretty picky about my dim sum. City View definitely hit the spot though. Not only was everything delicious, it looked good too - no lumpy piles of rice noodle here, just pretty little plates of heaven. The place is spacious, clean, and while most of the servers were little Asian ladies that didn't give a fuck (but hey, that's part of the charm, right?), I still thought service was above-average. Some of the more memorable dishes were the taro cakes, the chive dumplings, and the xiao long bao.

Came for lunch on a weekday around 1 with a group of 6 and had to wait about 15 minutes.
author: Lisa W.

description:
We came across this place after searching on Yelp for a good Dim Sum place in downtown SF. City View is pretty big for a place in the city. The best part of City View is that it is clean. We have been a a few times usually on the weekends, it gets pretty packed. The longest I've waited was about 30minutes for a party of 2.  
Usually, when we come here or to any dim sum place we usually order the usual Siu Mai, Har-gow, steamed bbq pork buns, shrimp rice noodle, and the crab claws. Overall, this place is pretty good place for dim sum. I would have to say that they have the best crab claw, I've had the crab claw at other places and City Views is just the best, a bit pricey though 2 crab claws for 8 bucks, but it is worth the try. 

The service here is great, if you don't want to wait for the people to bring the tray or push the cart to you, you can ask for a menu and order and they will bring it to you.

I would totally recommend this place if you are in the area.
author: Christina T.

description: Reliable, decently priced dim sum. Not used to having the Shanghai dumplings in little pie tins (as opposed to soup spoons), but they're still tasty.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
This is the cleanest dim sum restaurant that I've ever been to. It was also pretty big and well-lit which you don't often seen for a Chinese place. It's unfortunate that they aren't open at night and are only open for dim sum because it's such nice ambiance.

The food carts came by often enough and the servers were attentive to our refills of water and tea which was good because my mom drinks tea like people breath air. This might be because we were pretty early before the place started to get really packed. There was a line when we were leaving which surprised me since this is more on the outskirts of Chinatown. The plates might be smaller for the price, but the food is good quality and presented nicely. It's delicious dim sum whether it's a weekday lunch or weekend brunch--at least that's been my few experiences so far!
author: Riannie W.

description:
I don't know why this place gets high reviews. Although the food comes out hot from the kitchen, the quality of the Dim Sum is just average at best.

The only reason I've eaten here is because it's one of the places my boss chooses, when he takes our department out to eat once a year as a thank you for our hard work. Otherwise I would not come here, because there are too many other better places, a few blocks further away in Chinatown.

The only positives I can find is that the place can accomodate large groups of people, location is closer to downtown, and it's cheaper than Yank Sing. So in my opinion, it's a popular convenient venue for a group lunch, but not because of the Dim Sum.
author: Luis C.

description:
Very good Dim Sum in a place that's not too noisy (in case you want to chat with the people you are eating with). You have to order the soup dim sum - it's a mouthful of brothy deliciousness. The pork buns are also really tasty.
Visit a little bit early or a little bit late - on week days there is a line out the door at regular lunch hours.
author: D Z.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE their bbq pork turnover & shrimp rice noodles. 

It's not like a normal dimsum place, it feels clean, roomy, and they're nice and helpful.
author: Hannah W.

description: Best dim sum in the city. So good. Get there early as it gets busy.
author: Sarah K.

description:
I found this place from Citysearch, before I heard of Yelp. It was "the spot" to go for dim sum if you're ever in the Bay.

I have to honestly say, it's quite a different location for a Chinese dim sum place to be in the middle of the financial district, but I digress.

Being from Los Angeles, I'm not used to seeing multi-level Chinese restaurants. The second floor is the main restaurant, they also have a lower floor for more patrons and the bathrooms are downstairs as well.

Overall, the dim sum here was fairly good and too pricey. For two (we're big eaters), it came to about ~$40 after tax and tip. We even had some left-overs to munch on as we strolled through the city. I wouldn't mind coming back, especially since it's been some time since I've been here last.
author: Wes S.

description:
Didn't really like this place very much.  It's only just outside of Chinatown into the financial district, and it kind of shows compared to the quality of dim sum restaurants in Chinatown.  Our first warning should've been that the ratio of asian to white patrons was a little low.

I don't know, I just thought it was expensive and not that good.  If you want dim sum in this area, go to New Asia or Great Eastern instead.
author: Chad H.

description: One working lunch, we stumbled into City View Restaurant, which is the abbreviated name.  It actually should be called "(you can see the) City (too bad you dont have a) View Restaurant".   Fortunately, once the little carts start rolling and you start asking questions like "does that have pork in it?" or "do you have those fried sesame balls?" all goes well.  I stuck with the seafood as my friends devoured random pig parts wrapped in steamed buns or stuffed into shumai.  The staff comes by a lot so you'll have to get used to saying "no thanks" - a good thing indeed when eating Dim Sum.
author: David S.

description:
Yum, I LOVE dim sum!

Right on the border of Chinatown & FiDi -- so it's Chinese enough to be real dim sum but classy & clean enough to meet FiDi standards. Now THAT's my kinda place.

On the pricey side for dim sum... we paid $22 a person, 7 people. I don't eat dim sum often but I know that's definitely the higher end for Chinese food. It was worth it though -- the food was absolutely deeeelish and when we didn't see an item we wanted, they were more than happy to order it from the kitchen for us (Tip: go with someone who knows their dim sum & speaks Chinese).
author: Miss H.

description:
The name is not indicative of anything to do with the food. The view is actually that of an alley way. This is a dim sum place? 

The first thing that surprised me is that through this shady alley is a pretty nice looking restaurant. The other surprise was that there was no line. Most popular dim sum places you gotta wade through people with a machete. You know what I'm talking about. Crowds fifteen people deep elbowing you to get to the front, not respecting any sort of line and thinking that staring at the podium will make things go faster. Not here. 

Went here to meet up with some of the fine LA Yelpers (hi guys!) who decided to make the trek up to SF. Good call on Jeff T's part since it was not hard to get tables for 30 and the food came out pretty fast. However don't expect any unusual stuff. This is pretty safe dim sum. No monkey sphincter, whale blow hole, or other likenesses to scare your friends fear factor style. I guess if you're in the mood, want straightforward and dont care to wait, this place is for you.
author: Kim N.

description: Very nice experience. Clean and tasty. We had duck and various dumpling. Duck was ver very good. Servers were nice and friendly.
author: Denis S.

description:
Solid Dim Sum for FiDi folks like myself. 
Came here with my boss and co-worker around 12:15 today -- expect a wait at this hour. The wait was definitely worth it. All of the dim sums we ate were fresh & flavorful for a reasonable price. Great selection, not greasy and well prepared. I'll be back with chopsticks in hand.
author: Sara P.

description: This is my favorite place for Dim Sum in the city. On the border of Chinatown and the Financial District, this restaurant mixes authenticity with elegance. It is clean and the service is quick and efficient. Best of all, the food is delicious! They roll around carts according to the old fashion and customers pick and choose whatever they would like from a variety of steamed, baked and fried dishes. There are so many items to choose from, it can be overwhelming! They have all the traditional items, as well as some newer innovations. It can get crowded, I recommend going when they first open - that way, you can pick and choose in peace.
author: CJ J.

description:
Ok. I think it's now safe to say that this place sucks. 
The main issue at hand here is that the food is over priced, especially for the quality of the dim sum. 
Dim sum comes in small portions - yes. But let's say that it wasn't tasty enough for me to even WANT to order anything and I'm a big eater!!! I tried about 2 items and stopped there. As already mentioned by numerous Yelpers, the skin used on the dumplings is extremely thick, so don't either bother to order Shanghai dumplings here. 
And yes, they really do charge you for tea even though it's an effing YUM CHA place.
Yum cha directly translates to "drink tea" in Cantonese.
You should also be wary that the majority of the customers here ARE NOT Chinese.
What's that tell you?

WALK YOUR ASS A BLOCK MORE OR TWO, GO TO CHINATOWN AND GET REAL DIM SUM. YOU KNOW, GOOD DIM SUM, GOOD ENOUGH THAT CHINESE PEOPLE ARE ACTUALLY EATING IT!!

+ an extra star for you because I met cool LA yelpers.
author: Susy C.

description:
With my limited dim sum experience, I'd say this place was more chill than the others I've been to. Perhaps it was because we were seated in a corner table, but there seemed to be less asian families with their kids running around than the dim sums down in socal. There's actually space to walk in the aisles when the servers are walking around with their carts full of deliciousness.

Although I did not get overwhelmed by the servers at this place, as always, remember to take a seasoned veteran of dim sum with you.
author: Seiji N.

description:
If you've been to restaurants in Taiwan and Hong Kong, you're bound to be disappointed by dim sum places in the United States- even in California, where there is a huge Chinese immigrant population.

While Cantonese dim sum is a little more authentic in NorCal than SoCal (which features more recent immigrant groups from Mainland China and Taiwan), I can't say I've been impressed all that much by most of the places I've seen in SF. However, if I had to pick a place to grab dim sum, City View would be it.

Not only is it clean and orderly (unusual for dim sum restaurants), but the food is REALLY good! Again, not the most elaborate or decadent dishes, but it hits the spot after a long, rainy weekend.

Be aware folks- "dirty" doesn't necessarily mean "authentic" for Chinese restaurants! Go to City View and leave with a full stomach... and your health.
author: Marc L.

description:
Best Dim Sum in the city other than Yank Sing. Between those two it's a toss up. In terms of price this place is b far the better value and it's where me and my friends go as a default. Koi Palace out in Daly City is good but too much of a drive and the line is long. City View is the go to spot for the city Dim Sum. 

Most dishes are as you would expect.
author: V L.

description: Been here twice, with about two years in between. Both times were disappointing. They didn't have all of the dim sum standards, either because they didn't serve them or were out (at 12pm?!). Second time I came here, my friend got really sick. I'm not sure if we just went on bad days, but every person you ask has a wildly different opinion on dim sum in SF. I would pass.
author: Neftalí J.

description: This is my absolute favorite place for dim sum in the entire Bay Area. The food is tasty, the service is good and the place is clean and has plenty of seating.
author: Justin Y.

description: A solid dim sum restaurant between the Financial District and Chinatown, with reasonable prices too! I really liked the Cheong Fan (rolled wide rice noodles) with shrimp.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
It's not bad!

Yea it's a little pricier than other dim sum places, but they have pretty good services and their foods aren't as greasy :)  It seems like they actually put some time into making their dim sums.  I usually don't feel good after greasy dim sum, but I feel fine every time I had lunch at City View.

Lunch time is usually filled with fiDi folks, so reservation is a good idea.
author: Gigi T.

description:
Loved this place! I just wished I could have eaten even more!  Location is in a little alley, definitely without a city view.  As usual with dim sum, if you don't see something they have, just ask, and they'll bring it out to you!

Tasty, tasty, tasty!
author: Kacey A.

description:
I feel for Ed M. I know how he felt growing up as the only Asian kid in elementary school. It's always the stupid questions about on what is the difference between our cultures.... as in like what do I eat when I get home. Like as in "food"?

Kids and their questions.

Coming into an alley where this restaurant resides, it reminds me walking into some of the alleyways of the famous TV show like "Friends" or from the movie "Bruce Almighty". Very serene to find this place being loomed over by very tall towering buildings in the financial district in San Francisco.

Several months back when a group of LA Yelpers decided to make a field trip to meet our esteemed colleagues from the north for a get together lunch, our gracious organizer Jeff T. decided to set it up at City View where the dim sums are the safe bet.

The place is a lot more "cleaner" and a bit more "classier" than your average dim sum joints. It's almost too elegant to believe that a dim sum place like this would exist. They also have a very nice window view to that movie set scene of Commercial Street outside.

The items are pretty standard in what you are going to get at most dim sum places http://www.flickr.com/photos/46869143@N00/497423560/in/set-72157600212700976/ . You still get the favorites of shu mai, hai gaw, or beef chops. Nothing really out of ordinary. Probably safe bets with them for serving out recognizable dishes for all the patrons. Heck, the only daring thing was chicken feet and I missed that soiree.

I had a very good meal and enjoyed the wonderful company with our good friends from all over the Bay area from Sacramento, Oakland, San Mateo, San Bruno, Fremont to San Francisco as they traveled far to join in on a very cool collective gatherings to welcome us.

Of course the inevitable question of what's the difference between SF Yelp and LA Yelp. Bring back memories of childhood in 5th grade as the one of the only non-Caucasian in the classroom. The only answer I can give them is.... "not much".

Hey good times!
------------------------

Unofficial Yelp notes:

Event took place on May 12, 2007

Pictures can be found here: http://www.flickr.com/photos/46869143@N00/sets/72157600212700976/
author: Mike L.

description:
I'm not a dim sum connoisseur by any stretch but we enjoyed our meal here!

My family and I were visiting SF and we found this place through Yelp.  We hadn't had asian in a few days and we were craving anything from the region! Heh.  Perhaps this influenced what we thought of the meal but what attracted us to this place was that it was "clean" and the food "good."  It pretty much lived up to those reviews, and after about 8 dishes, we payed about $40 for 2.  The most expensive was the walnut shrimp, which was $8 --pretty pricey considering it's a dim sum portion.  It's all good though, we're on vacation!!  I should also mention the service was decent too.

Thanks to our little one for being zonked out and letting us have a quiet lunch to ourselves, and to Yelpers for pointing us to a delicious meal that hit the spot!!
author: Leni A.

description:
I have always been looking for a solid dim sum spot in the city.  I have been to Yang Sink, which I like, but this is much closer to where I live.  
Out of the times I have been here, more often than not I have been happy with the food and service.  The few times I have been disappointed was when I came right after they opened to beat the rush.  Most of the food was not yet ready and the servers were definitely trying to push some broccoli and high tickets items like Duck down our throat.  
There is normally a wait on the weekends, 15-20 minutes, and this place really needs to get a better system to take names.  "The lady in the pink shirt" is not my ideal way to sign in.  
Overall the food is good, not as good as Yang Sink, but you are definitely going to pay less.
author: Devin C.

description:
OOOH I likey this place!!! Christine T took my dbf and I here for lunch yesterday and I was very impressed.  The restaurant is so clean and looked pretty classy. I was afraid it would be expensive, but Christine T assured me "this is the cheaper place" around here.  I was in disbelief.

But Oh my goodness gracious!!! Did my dbf and I love this place or what?!!?  It was sooooooooo good that we can't wait to eat there again. Now I think whenever I'm in the city, I'll ask Christine T to take me to City View!!

Very good service, high quality dim sum. I highly recommend. 

As for pricing, I'm not so sure....Christine T treated me and my dbf.  I'll make sure to grab the bill next time I'm there.

I'm a fan!
author: Dawn D.

description:
When I read reviews of restaurants here, I often see some that say "I don't understand all the raves" and I often wondered about those people.  Maybe they don't really appreciate good food?  Do they know what they are talking about?  Well, today I'm joining the club and it's all clear.

So yes, I came here today for lunch on a recommendation of a coworker (but of course I checked it out on Yelp as well).  And I truly do not understand the reviews of this place.  I've been to my fair share of dim sum places all over the world and although I wouldn't say this place was the worst I've ever had (that goes to the premade boxed dimsum from Trader Joe's), it certainly ranks close to the bottom of the list.  It's not even so ordinary and bland as to be forgettable.  It's just distinctly bad.

All the food came out lukewarm.  All the steamed dumpling wrappers were thick and chewy instead of being thin and almost transparent.  You could barely pull them off the paper at the bottom of the steamer.  Everything looked old (not made recently) and sloppily made at that.  

It was $14 for lunch and I felt like it was a complete waste of money.

If you don't want to go to a hole in the wall restaurant, then go to Yank Sing instead.  You may notice that Yank Sing is actually frequented by entire Chinese families. And please don't spread the rumor that this is the best dim sum in the city to others, you will give SF a bad name.
author: Jean K.

description:
I am looking at the bad reviews and I don't understand how my experience was so different than the previous posters. I went with 5 people and our total was $84. I feel like that is fair for what dim sum should cost. I usually expect to pay between $10-20/person whenever I go, so City View was average pricing. 

I felt like the food variety was fabulous! There were new things coming out all the time and the only problem I had with it was that it was still coming out as I was full and waiting for my check. Before we all left the restaurant we were already conspiring what to get next time! 

The chicken lettuce wraps were to die for!!

Overall, this was a deliciously wonderful experience and I can't wait to go again. I think it is valid to mention that because this is in the Financial District the location was very clean, the restaurant and bathrooms were tidy and well maintained and added to the pleasing ambiance of the place overall.

I don't know what people expect from dim sum but I thought that City View was a refreshing option within our area. I know that all five of us were full and satisfied when we left and it wasn't a big blow to our pocket books. The restaurant was clean and the service was friendly.
author: Mandy L.

description: I love this dim sum place!!! The food is excellent and affordable. The only downside is that there is always a waiting line for table, but it is definitely worth it. No reservations accepted but the line goes fast. My favorite dim sum place in the city!
author: Monika P.

description:
Dim sum virgin here.  I've never been to dim dum before.  I"m glad this was the first place.  

I was very hungry by the time we arrived.  First thing that came around was the duck with buns.  Very good.  Tried the turnip thing, think this was was just okay because I'm not used to the texture.  Chinese broccoli, pork buns,  shrimp rolls (fried and wrapped in white thing), pork in pastry, and a few other's I can't remember.  

Yummy, yummy, yummy.
author: Carolyn W.

description: Fabulous. Came for dim sum on a Sunday. Wonderful selection and nearly everything was exquisite. Super friendly service. We've found our dim sum spot in San Francisco.
author: David H.

description:
FOOD
Steamed pork buns - good+, hot, perfect amount of piggy inside
Shrimp & chive dumpling - excellent!  large yummy shrimp inside
Stick rice - good, but small portion
Shrimp rice noodle roll - good, nice size shrimps
pork dumpling (siu mai) - good+
shrimp dumping (har gow) - good+
char siu sou (bbq in pastry) - excellent!
Duck with steamed bun - good

PRICE - average+.  $40 including tip.

SERVICE - good and prompt

WAIT TIME - 10 min for party of 2 on Sunday early afternoon

Notes:  Nice place to bring someone who has never tried dim sum.  It's clean, nice decor, good for visiting out of town guests.  I like my dim sum in more grimey places like King of Kings in Oakland, but the SO likes carts.  I can see the appeal.  Clientele includes lotsa non-asians which is cool.  Down a side street, won't see it driving.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Very disappointing.  I was super excited to come to San Francisco to eat dim sum, as was my son.  We were very disappointed by City View.  In the place where we were seated, it seemed like we were the last place that the dim sum carts reached, so by the time they got to us, there was very little left on the cart.  The choices were quite limited, and they didn't have many of the regular stand-bys.  No har gow?!?!  The char siu bao were very small, no gin dui, no rice cakes, no noodles of any sort.  It also took asking three people to get a fork for my son.  The bill was $65 for three of us (no drinks) and we walked away still hungry.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I still consider myself a dim sum novice, but I've been to a few dim sum places now, and I think City View is probably the best I've tried so far.  I've come here a couple times with colleagues during lunch and we've never had trouble getting what we needed as far as decent service and a variety of dishes.  

I stay mostly veg, but I do eat seafood, and I've always eaten well here.  Their spinach dumplings were excellent, as were their seafood offerings.  I have to give a nod to their delicious sesame balls and their egg custard tarts that were right out of the oven.  The down side is that it caters to the FiDi crowd and it does get pricey.  If you come with a hungry group, expect to pay $25-30 each, boo.
author: Laura C.

description: My Dim Sum craving was cured! Has a good selection of dim sum as well. There's the fun of watching the cart come out and peering over to check out what cool stuff's in the cart. I think the dumplings here are pretty good. I like the Shrimp spring roll and Char Siew pastry. There's so many more that we didn't try cos we inhaled our food in 30 mins. Alls good here. Service is pretty thorough as well. I'll come back again!
author: Meredith C.

description:
nom nom nom.....

If you enjoy dim sum then you will like this place.  I on the other hand... adore dim sum and this spot is legit.

Let me preface this review with the fact that I grew up in the bay and thought that nothing could compare to Yank Sing. Then I lived in So Cal for 8 years and realized that I was very sheltered in terms of my dim sum exposure.  

Don't get me wrong I don't hate Yank Sing, but there are many other places with great dim sum that aren't atrociously overpriced, case in point City View Restaurant.

City View has all of the classics and some of the dishes that you can't always find at your traditional dim sum place.  The buns are awesome, the noodles are nothing short of perfection, the Peking duck by the slices are making me hungry just thinking about them... the chicken feet are second to none and last but definitely not least the shu mai, damn good!

I have to give 4.5 stars to this place because I wasn't in love with the dessert situation, but I will be back this weekend for sure.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
This is another favorite of mine. It's the best dim sum in the City. If you go for lunch, make sure to go early to beat the rush and having to wait for a table. The ambience is typical--noisy but that's OK. It's dim sum and I'd rather the waiter announce what the dish was before-hand than just point. The workers are very efficient. If you order something not on the cart, it's not long before they bring it out for you. 

All the dishes I've tried are great. I have never been brave enough to try to chicken feet...no thanks! Even the custard buns are yummy. You can tell that they take a lot of pride in making their dishes and people like me enjoy eating them!
author: Opinionated X.

description:
Busy place at lunchtime. No where to wait comfortably.

Dim sum was yummy but the servers really can't communicate much when you ask them about the various offerings on the cart, English being the challenge. 

Had a terrible time trying to get a glass of water. One busboy passed my request off to another and another. All nodded and appeared to accept my request but water never came. 

I'd say the answer to combatting the rushed feeling and the poor service would be to come at an off hour but then the dim sum wouldn't be at its freshest, would it?.
author: Paula H.

description:
WHEN: Lunch

WHY: Wanted tasty Dim Sum.

OVERALL: Yummy & Recommended 

PROS:
- Delicious Dim Sum
- Service was better than most Dim Sum establishments.
- Quick
- The dessert almond fruit parfait was great(and i dont even like fruit)
- The Dim Sum was the best I've had in SF( but I'm white & what the hell do i know about Dim Sum! My Chinese Boyfriend just orders for me)

CONS:
- Long Lines( but worth it)
- Noisy
author: Leigh P.

description:
Seated right away if you show up before 11:30AM on a Saturday. Friendly service since my friend kept asking multiple waiters for a specific dish. They push the carts around here, which I like. Better than getting a menu and having to order off that. 

The downside? The portions for everything were pretty small compared to most dimsum restaurants but the prices remained the same. Maybe it's just me but most things didn't taste as flavorful as other places too? It's not a bad restaurant, but meh, I've experienced better.
author: Diana Y.

description: I had Dim Sum here during lunch work hour. It does the job.
author: Jimmy T.

description:
This is also another of my favorite choice of a Dim Sum restaurant. City View Restaurant maybe a little pricey but the dims sums that they offer here is really good. 

Besides the dim sums the Fu Jian Fried Rice is one of the best fried rice ever! This is a good place for tourist to go and have a good time.
author: William B.

description:
Clean, comfortable, contemporary, good food, good service, reasonable pricing. I would return the next time I'm in SF and I would recommend to my friends.

Compared to other dim sum restaurants I've been to, this is a "five star" eatery in terms of cleanliness and decor. As for food, I give it four stars.
author: Ricardo H.

description:
Fresh & hot out the kitchen. Me likey! 

Get there before 11:18a on a Sunday if you don't want to be corralled at the hostess stand. The too-crowded-now-you-have-to-wait switch is flipped at this time. I timed it, having a seat with a clear view to the door. 

I don't really know the English for the dishes I like, so I'll just say everything is fresh, made w/ high-quality ingredients, plus... (1) I appreciate that they do not discriminate (blatantly, anyway lol) against me b/c I do not speak in Cantonese - I communicate & order in Mandarin; (2) it's a newer, bright dining room w/ clean, white tablecloths; (3) service is very fast & friendly; (4) prices are very reasonable (unlike Yank Sing, which is overly-touristy & so expensive!)

Oh, and one other convenient thing - if the push cart comes around and you don't see what you want, just tell the server what you're looking for and s/he will scream it over their walkie-talkie to who-knows-where, 5 mins later your requested dim sum shows up.  Sweet!  No need to play dim sum cart roulette!
author: Jen H.

description:
One of my friends from Cal was about to graduate and had never gone to much in San Francisco. I know, what a shocker! You can definitely join me in making fun of him and never letting him down; you know I already have. While I suggested that the best Chinese and dim sum that I've ever had, as a San Francisco native, was in the Richmond or the Sunset, he had always wanted to go to Chinatown. An adventure and some annoying walking around in circles later, we find City View!

Boy, did we get the real experience of a dim sum place here. A lot of the people working here didn't speak too much English and so I was able to get an ounce of customer service by using my scarcely used Mandarin. Score but goddammit, can someone here please speak anything but Cantonese?! When we were finally seated, I really liked the fact that it was like a traditional Hong Kong dim sum place where people that speak very little English walk around in carts hawking their food (+ points for keeping it tradish). However, it was a pain in the butt to decipher what they were charging for each "level" of plate and seeing that a lot of us were white, the more expensive carts came around over and over again. Hey, at least try to keep it a bit more classy (and less obvious), thank you very much!

The food was good, although I have to say, it was a bit on the skimpy side. I know, I know, it's the Chinese version of tapas but I am just a big hungry hungry hippo, especially when a lot of these things are my favorite!

Surprisingly, I thought this place was going to be a tourist trap being close to Chinatown and all. I know there are definitely places like this (usually figured out by the people hired to stand outside and get people to come in to their places) but this place was surprisingly good. While it was pricey, I thought this place was still a good place to go to overall. Better yet, my friends certainly thought so! (+ points to City View and obviously me)
author: Rick C.

description:
I think this is my favorite yum cha place. The place is clean and I love it when the carts come around, so you can actually see the quality of food. I love the pan fried shrimp and scallion dumpling. There are literally a ton of dishes I could name, but you should just go there and try it out. The chicken feet are "good". I do have to say I do not eat chicken feet, even though my bf tries to force me to eat one every time. I def would eat here 
again and I am actually craving it.

Ps. There is no view
author: Stephanie L.

description:
I visited San Francisco for a week and was impressed by pretty much all the dim sum restaurants that I visited at random in Chinatown. As a Bostonian who never left the east coast before, I had never experienced such tasty dim sum in my life. City View, however, is a major, major, MAJOR exception.

I had a copy of the Lonely Planet that I took with me on the trip and it mentioned the City View restaurant under Chinatown so I decided to check it out. I got there right when it opened at 11am and got seated immediately. When the food carts came out, I asked for all my usual and familiar dim sum dishes. I was pretty disappointed by most of them; I've had better dim sum in Boston.

By around 11:30, the restaurant almost immediately filled up and there were already a few people waiting for a seat at the door. Without even asking for the check, the waiter interrupted us and asked if we were finished and took our stamp card. When the check arrived, I was shocked to see that the total cost was $49 for two people. This was more than twice of what I was paying at other much better dim sum restaurants in the area.

The place does look and feel very clean compared to similar restaurants but don't be fooled: The food here sucks and is way overpriced.

This restaurant caters to unknowing tourists. I doubt that any local in their right mind would ever eat here. Stay away!
author: Andrew H.

description: It's packed for lunch. Long wait for mediocre dim sum? Shu Mai were too big and skin was too thick on most of the dumpling type. Disappointed with the flavor with the price tag that the food comes. Will not return again.
author: H H.

description: My boss took me here for a 'Welcome Lunch'. It's a big place. We had a table of 8 people so it was in the far corner. The first thing we got was the pot stickers. Super good. Wish they automatically cut them in half. Sucks trying to cut a pot sticker in half with chop sticks. I don't know the names of all the dishes but know them by what they look like. Had fried noodles, sesame chicken, shrimp rolls and etc. It was really good. Also got to try almond jello for the first time. Not sure if it was freshly made but it was good. I wish they were open longer so I can take my boyfriend there. I guess they must be pretty popular if they are only open for so long.
author: Jolene M.

description: I don't know. I'm definitely not a Dim Sum expert, but I have eaten my share in a variety of different cities and this was over the top yummers. The kids tried things I never would have expected because it all looked so delish. Part of the fun of DS is the carts and the cute lil gals lifting the lids, steam pouring out  the top of the bamboo containers and this did not disappoint. You had to flag down a server for drinks however they were prompt and courteous. We are not even curious about other places...we'll stick with City View.
author: Melina H.

description: One of the worst dim sum in the city--give me Koi Palace any day!!
author: C L.

description:
This place has great food and from what you can see it is clean.  I am not a person that has to eat at a clean Dim Sum place to enjoy it.  Most of the best Dim Sum places I have eaten have been less then clean.  What is great about this place other then the food is the service!  They are FAST and they have a good variety.

So many Dim Sum places have good food, but they will not bring that cart back in until some one eats that last questionable dish that has been circling for an hour!  I often wonder if the woman with the cart gets fired if she comes back with a dish still in the cart! FIRED... who am I kidding.. you have to be getting paid to get fired.

This is the kind of place you can even take your white friends from the Midwest!  

The only complaint is it is a bit pricey... so I will take one star off for that!
author: John F.

description: We wanted to try a new dim sum restaurant in SF, and came across this place since it was fairly close.  But boy, was I disappointed??? I would have taken the bus out to wait and eat at the Hong Kong lounge if I knew how the food would taste like at this place.  Especially for the price we paid, it was not any cheaper than the HKL!!!
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Went here this past labor day.  Had no idea where to get dim sum in the city.  Now I have a go too spot.  Commercial should be a alley more then a street though.

The first thing i noticed was the place appeared really nice and clean.  I've been to some dim sum spots where i was wondering how they past inspection.  Now i know this is just in the dining area and the kitchen could be a disaster but ignorance is bliss i guess.  having a nice clean looking restaurant works for me.  The service was fast with tea and waters and we had a table full of food within 5 min.  Another plus is the people serving the food were not mad when you didn't want something.

Can someone tell me if they work on commission at some dim sum places?  I swear i've been to some where i got the look of death when i turned them down.  Again,  pleasantly surprised that did not happen here.

After all of that, gotta say every item we got was very good.  If i'm in the city and want dim sum will be coming back here for sure!

On a quick side note, i guess SF doesn't recognize Labor Day as a holiday cuz we had a nice 75 dollar ticket waiting for us.  So make sure to feed your meter.
author: Hella B.

description:
After my unsatisfying dim sum excursion at a place in Chinatown the previous weekend, I am really happy that I chose to come here next... Much better experience. I'm being a bit generous, when I say 4 stars, but I'm just comparing it to places in the Bay Area, and not like, Vancouver.

good things:
-xiao long bao -- love it when places put them in individual foil containers; they served it to us steaming hot... the soup/(oil...) inside was really good!
-siu mai - really good. i think the filling had more than just the normal stuff - definitely try this
-turnip cake, potstickers, etc. - pretty standard quality
-we arrived close to their closing time, so after we ordered, all our food arrived pretty quickly... I like that

things I didn't like were:
-Chinese broccoli came drenched in sauce -- I like it when they put the sauce on the side, so you can control how much you want, because I usually like eating it plain. Also, the leaves were a bit soggy (I guess if you're the same way as I am, you can ask for the sauce on the side when you order?)
-they charge for tea .... $2.50 for 2 people
-on the pricier side, but not too bad considering that their quality is decent
author: Jessica W.

description:
The dim sum is pretty average but fresh and tasty.  A little bit on the pricey side.  They do tend to get busy after 12 so I'd suggest getting there a little earlier if you have a big party and they do take reservations. They do have a fairly friendly staff.

Be forewarned, their table cloths & napkins will leave white lint all over your dark clothes!!
author: May Y.

description: The dim sum was great! BUT the star of the entire restaurant was unexpectedly the Fried Rice! OMG! It's the best fried rice I have ever tasted in my entire life. I don't normally eat too much rice because of the carbs, but City View's fried rice is so worth it!  They hardly bring out the fried rice, but I ended up asking one of the waiters and they hooked me up! My wife and I couldn't believe how excellent the rice was. The employees are also so nice, I go in and they know what I want.
author: Harry C.

description: food was ok. service wasn't very good. our order never came after asking several different people....
author: Ru C.

description: Delish dim sum and the place is nice, clean and staff is friendly.
author: Vanessa M.

description: My mom and aunt were excited to come here for two things: the dim sum-sized portions of Peking duck (with steamed buns and hoisin sauce) and individual stir fry lettuce wraps (we only ordered one - we sacrificed our usual "cheapness" by coming here but we didn't lose our minds).  Since it is located in the Financial District and patronized primarily by professionals, City View Restaurant's cleanliness is another appeal, but this isn't going to become our new go-to spot or anything.
author: Jenn C.

description: good dim sum and great location!
author: Tasha D.

description:
Came here twice - first time when I first moved out here and second time when it was recommended to us from the concierge desk in the Hilton.  Didnt realize it was the same place until they sat us at the same table I sat the first time. 

On to the food.  The dim sum is a little more to the pricey side but pretty good. I'm not much of a dim sum person so I cant give the best review on the food but it was tasty and the only complaint would be that the dishes are small.  The service was great and quick.  I'd recommend checking it out.
author: Mookie L.

description:
Though yelp claims they have takeout, they really don't.  

It would have been faster to just sit at a table and eat than to wait for the food to go.  My friend and I were either ignored entirely or treated rudely, and our time was wasted waiting for mediocre, overpriced food.
author: Jason F.

description:
I think this place is a great place for first time dim sum eaters. You don't have to speak Chinese, the place is clean, and the food is good.

I've grown up eating at dirty dim sum restaurants, and some people are hardcore in that they believe their dim sum place has to be Chinese speaking only. I think City View, however, is better than most places. There are some that maybe better, but City View makes up for it for the most part with it's ease of dining experience in that it's clean and you don't have to learn Chinese.

I would definitely go back to eat dim sum here.
author: Lih-Wern W.

description:
Since we were staying within close proximity to Chinatown, I thought it was necessary to enjoy a dim sum lunch.  My brother had done some research and discovered the highly regarded City View Restaurant.  The destination was particularly convenient to our hotel, so we decided it was a perfect option.  Upon our arrival, I noticed that the restaurant was more upscale than the typical, impersonal dim sum palace I was used to in Manhattan's Chinatown.  The spot was also full of Asian clientele, which we took as a positive sign.  

Each cart that passed us displayed authentic dishes that were handsomely presented with bold colors and crisp freshness.  The BBQ Pork Bun possessed a sweet dough that was stuffed with tender pork in a savory marinade.  The Pan-Fired Potstickers were enjoyable, but nothing memorable.  Toasted Sesame Balls were filled with a sweet filling that packed the distinctive flavor of the seeds.
The shrimp dumplings were composed of large tender noodle balls encasing massive chunks of crisp shrimp.  Sticky rice noodles were also tastefully wrapped around tender shrimp and covered in a pool of soy sauce.  A delicious plate of egg-shaped fried taro domes were completed with a sweet custard filling of the same root vegetable.  Large prawns were served in a sweet mayonnaise and tossed with caramelized walnuts.  Lastly, we had fun composing crisp iceberg lettuce wraps stuffed with tender cubes of chicken, water chestnuts, and peanuts.

The City View Restaurant offered the most polished and flavorful dim sum experience of my foodie life.  I only wish it was located in New York!
author: Alison C.

description:
This is my favorite dim sum place in the city. I love that they actually have cart service, the restaurant has lots of nice natural light, the staff are friendly and speak a reasonable amount of English, and the price is right! Some tasty items include:

-Shrimp har gow (spelling? forgive me, I speak not Chinese)
-Fried shrimp and chive dumplings - OMG sooooooooo good
-Shrimp rice noodle
-Shrimp and cilantro dumplings
(I don't eat land animals so I cannot vouch for their pork dishes...)

I also really want to try the eggplant/tofu dish - it looks quite large but I think I am going to conquer it when I go there tomorrow for my dim sum fix. City View is the best! I don't know what all of you people are complaining about, but stay away! More dim sum for me!
author: Rachael S.

description: Nice dim sum place. Not a whole in the wall.  This is on a quiet and clean alley between financial district and Chinatown. Delicious and authentic dim sum. Nice white cloth dining in a bright and airy space. Prices are very reasonable. This is a place you would go for good food, decent prices, and not be embarrassed to be worth a date.
author: Lev E.

description:
My husband and I ate here, on a tip from a 3rd generation not-so-fluent-in-Cantonese Chinese American woman who runs a shop on Grant. She says she likes it because it's very clean, the dim sum is just bite size and they have great daan-taats (custard tarts) and "things that look like cupcakes filled with a really nice cream." She could not tell me what they are called in English or Cantonese...turns out she means laaih-wohng-baau (steam custard filled buns).

We passed on the daan-taats and went for the laaih-wohng-baau, which were definitely top notch.  The siu mai had a nice flavor, and were more of a bite size. The special dim sum we tried was one lovely, delicate chicken filled dumpling in a clear, light broth.  Their sticky rice chicken wrapped in banana leaves is yummy as well. And the wu-tau-so (ground taro fried in a whisker-like pastry) was wonderful - they were big, but the taro was mixed so that it was lighter than other wu-tau-so we've had.

I can see why this place appeals to a non-Chinese crowd. I joked with my husband that this is the most white people I'd ever seen in a dim sum restaurant! When we first sat down, the most noise we heard was chopsticks clanging on plates.  My Chinese friends would have found that environment to be lacking "yeet lau" - noise and excitement.

The staff seem accustomed to working with non-Chinese patrons. They explained items in English as they carried trays and pushed carts around the room. So this would be a great place for dim sum newbies to go to.

It is a little pricey, but worth it. Very good service and quality food.
author: Lisa R.

description:
We came for dim sum on a Monday at 11:15 am and there were only 3 other tables.  Upon being seated, our server told us that the dim sum carts would begin service in about 5 minutes.  We were somewhat worried, but fortunately, once the carts started coming around, we found the dim sum to be delicious!  The cart attendants were friendly and encouraged you to try all sorts of dishes.  The servers were also friendly and efficient.  Although the prices are a little higher than other dim sum restaurants, the quality is worth it.

By the time we left about an hour later, the restaurant was filled with happy diners...
author: Zoey W.

description: I think I've written about City View on every social networking site I can find. It's my favorite dim sum restaurant - and for the right price. My wife and I ate here two days in a row on our last trip to San Francisco - and we didn't repeat an order either time. We were having fun and just picking whatever we wanted until we were stuffed and I don't think the bill was over $30 - including beverages. If you get there during the middle of lunch hour, be prepared to wait - it's worth it.
author: Jonathan W.

description: Finally a good dimsum restaurant in Chinatown! My go to spot is usually HK Lounge in Richmond, but this is my new go to spot closer to my house for the dimsum cravings. Everything is super fresh, hot, crispy, delicious! Not too expensive either, still well under $20/pp.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Oh man. Overpriced and un-fresh, this is a crap place for dim sum. 

Check out Dol Ho up the hill. It might not look like much, but it'll taste a lot better than this turd of a restaurant.
author: Guillermo K.

description:
After my last experience at CityView, im pretty horrified with their customer service. 

While ordering on the phone at 11: 
Amy: Hi can I order one peking duck, a chow mein and a fried rice? Oh and I can pick up some dim sum too there right? Its pre-made? 
Hostess: Okay, what time are you picking up? 
Amy: 11:45, I will come there to pick that up and get some dim sum. 
Hostess: Okay you get dimsum when you come. 

Called them at 11:15:
Amy: Sorry I would like to cancel the fried rice and chow mein since my coworkers dont want it anymore. 
Hostess: You cant, already made. 
Amy: What do you mean I cant? Its only 11:15!
Hostess: Its already made.
Amy: You cant force me to purchase all that food, im giving plenty of notice...
Hostess: You still buying dim sum? 
Amy: Yes. 
Hostess: Fine. (HANGS UP PHONE) 

What the! then when I get there, the hostess tells me the dim sum will take 5 min. 15 min later waiting I push her to either cancel the order or give to me asap as I had a meeting. 

The peking duck itself was 43 dollars and the total bill came out to 127 for a meager amount of food. At that price, I think service should be a lot better than what their dishing out.
author: Amy S.

description:
I love City View.  They are better and cleaner than the dim sum places in Chinatown and much more inexpensive than Yank Sing.  Yank Sing is more geared towards the gringo crowd so you don't get a lot of traditional Chinese dim sum like the shrimp rice rolls (cheung fun).  I took some co-workers here for lunch and they raved that it was nicer than Yank Sing.

Decor is clean.  Service is what you'd expect at chinese restaurants - competent w/o being friendly.
author: Wendy H.

description: Good dim sum. Very clean restaurant. Most of the servers speak/understand English well, which made it easy for the non-Asian members of my party to order on their own. The prices are higher than average but it's probably worth it.
author: John C.

description: Biggest disappointment about this place is that the name was a misnomer. Ain't no view. Otherwise, really pretty restaurant; all the dim sum was solid. I liked how they had some different choices from the "uz" - peanut and pork dumpling, for example. Prices were a bit steep.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I think I'm in the middle between 2 stars and 3 stars.  I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt and will go with 3.  

Since this dim sum restaurant is in the "financial district", it's one of the few dim sum places.  When I say it's in the financial district, I think it's barely there since Chinatown is a block away.  

We were sat fairly quickly considering we were coming in for lunch right at 12.  The place was almost filled.  I was immediately impressed by the cleanliness of the restaurant.   Chinese restaurants aren't known for that so they scored a few extra points because of this.  

The food was ok at best. I like how they have the cart function while at the same time you have the ability to order from someone.  While the selection was decent, the tastiness of everything was as I said ok at best.  I have had a lot better.  There was no specific dish that stood out as a must eat.

There was nothing special about this place that would make me say you have to try it.  If you want dim sum and are in the financial district, this is probably your best chance.
author: Patrick L.

description:
Coworkers and I came here for dim sum to welcome our newest team member. Luckily we made reservations because this place gets pretty jam packed during lunch time. 

The dim sum is very average. The shrimp dumplings were small and the skin was a bit too thick. The shanghainese dumplings (xiao long baos) were also not that good -- there was hardly any soup in the dumping! But the service is pretty good and the location is really close to the office which makes it very convenient.
author: Helen Y.

description:
We had out of town guests and wanted to take them to a dim sum restaurant where they still have push carts.  That was hard to find as most of the dim sum places either bring out a menu that you check off or maybe bring food items out on trays.  I called a few friends and wanted someplace moderately priced with the push carts.  They recommended City View and emphasized the validated parking at Portsmouth Square.

It is off the beaten path on Commercial Street on the edge of Chinatown and the Financial District.  It opened at 11:00 AM and our party of six arrived just at opening.  There was one or two other parties there and we were able to get a nice table.  The place was clean and reminded me of some of the nicer restaurants in Hong Kong.  Even the restrooms were clean.  Of course I would expect that early in the AM.

True to form, the rolling carts came and we had our fill. Our table was somewhat in the middle and the push carts came by and turnaround there so we had plenty of gander time.   The service was friendly and excellent.  The servers constantly filled our tea and water.  We had a variety of dim sum and it is always nice to look at what you are ordering and ask the attendants about the items. I can't remember exactly what we ordered, but it was the standard pork buns, shrimp balls, pork siu mai, vegetables, etc.  For those unaccustomed to eating dim sum, it is nice to see what you are ordering.  When we ordered, they would check off a slip that was on our table.  Most of the items were excellent. We really did not know the price of each individual plate, but I had an inkling it was going to be expensive based on previous reviews.

The restaurant (even though it was comparatively large) quickly filled up and people were awaiting outside before noon.  Most of the diners appear to be business people and tourists and there weren't that many locals.  There is also dining in the lower level, but it wasn't open during our Thursday visit.  Maybe it is open during the weekends.

When we got our bill, it was $120 or an average of $20 per person.  Of course, we had big eaters at our table.  I wouldn't say this is a moderately priced restaurant.  I would classify it on the expensive side, particularly for lunch.

We had free parking due to the validation and I think they are only open for lunch.  My advise is to come early. This is a great place to take out-of-town guests, but I am still looking for where the locals eat.  When we go to Chinatown, we usually get to-go food at Yong Kee.  If anyone has recommendations, I'd sure like to hear from them.
author: Robert J.

description:
Definitely never going there again! I don't know if I just went there on an off day or something but the food was horrible. The food tasted really nasty. Like if the seafood wasn't fresh. Random dishes had nasty aftertastes.

The 4 of us ordered a few dishes and decided it was best to finish lunch elsewhere. Somehow, our total came out to around $60 which was totally ridiculous since we barely ordered anything. I'm not from the area so I don't know how the pricing is different but in LA, usually we go with a group of 6-8 people and to eat a complete dim sum meal is only around $80-100.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Slightly better than average dim sum.  It gets pretty busy on Sundays so if you're not into waiting for a table, try to go early.  

The waiter comes, gives you tea and/or water, and you wait for the carts to come by.  Depending on how good your Chinglish is, you can point to some stuff and either nod or shake your head.  Alternatively, you can do what we do and close your eyes and point to one thing in each cart to try.  If you're not allergic to anything, the worst thing that could happen is that you waste 4 or 5 bucks on something and then know not to order that ever again.  Or you could get lucky and find something delish!  The food quality is not as good as Yank Sing, but the prices are much more reasonable.  

Park in the Portsmouth Garage and they will validate for up to 2 hours of free parking.  =)
author: Maxine S.

description:
I don't know a whole lot about dim-sum. Period. But I do know everything I ate here was delicious. Pot stickers were amazing! The honey walnut shrimp was one of my favorite dishes. BF was very happy with the mini-peking duck plate we were offered as well. Tons and tons of options for you to choose from. I also enjoyed the little hot rolls full of bbq-ish pork (don't ask me what they were called, I'm a dim-sum cart virgin.)

There is certainly no worry that you will leave still hungry as the dim-sum carts are plentiful and come by very often, for your eating pleasure. I may have been with a friend that spoke Chinese, but I think we would have received great service anyway. Everyone was friendly and the water and hot tea was kept full the whole time!  Everyone that was eating there seemed to be enjoying themselves as well. Nice lil popular Sunday lunch spot!
author: Lauren D.

description:
I first ate at City View when it was recommended to me by my Cantonese girlfriend who had it recommended to her by her Cantonese boss. 

Today, I ate there again with my friend Zach and I enjoyed it immensely both times.

The place is clean, the staff is unusually nice, there was no wait at 1pm on a Saturday and all of our dishes were great. We liked it so much, in fact, that we're going back tomorrow morning for more.
author: Chrissy Q.

description:
Nice clean resturaunt, service was so so. Food was a bit over priced.

There was no views of any kind especially the city as the resturaunt in on the 1st floor.
author: Mike T.

description: The dim sum quality is very good here in this modern looking restaurant off Kearney in SF Chinatown.  I am only giving it three stars because of its lack of variety.  The Cha S Baos were very good.  Shui mai, and shrimp lo lo were outstanding.  I need to visit on the weekend to check out the variety.  This is a solid bet for dim sum in Chinatown.
author: Thomas W.

description:
I would recommend this place to anyone who loves dimsum! 

My first time was memorable. It's in a nice location on Commercial and Montgomery. It's clean inside and very well lighted. Prices are moderate and they do have dim sum carts here. 

My personal favorites are the har gow, shu mai, and the lotus sticky rice. Including the sesame balls! However, you can order chicken lettuce wraps per leaf and peking duck per bun! So genius instead of ordering a whole order. Definitely great for portion control! ;o)
author: Mika D.

description:
This is a pretty good dim sum place, probably the best sit down one I've been to. It is run by authentic Chinese people. They usher people in as fast as they can and they push you to order and pay as fast as you arrived. 

Cash is a preference (what's new). The food is great, hot and delicious. It could be the MSG, I dont know. The price point is cheap. 

The service is OK, but if you're stranger phobic, I don't recommend going here, they will seat you with strangers at the same table.
author: Nance H.

description:
Although not truly located in Chinatown as one may think, it is very closely located near Portsmouth Square Plaza underground parking.

We did not have a reservation for a Saturday noon arrival and only had to wait 5 minutes tops to get a table for 5.

Service was speedy and the various food trucks that rolled by looked fresh and appetizing and very tempting to reach for all that went by.

Will be back surely.
author: Peter B.

description: City View is by far my favorite dim sum restaurant in SF.  Very nice inside and half the price as Yank Sing. The quality is great and the staff are incredibly friendly.  My boyfriend and I go every week and the total bill with tip and tax is always about $40, including a little food to take home.
author: Teresa H.

description:
You can find me here at least once, sometime twice a month.. It's literally 1.5 blocks from work.. 

Dimsum used to be a Sunday family affair - a real treat. We'd do it a few times a year... NOW that's it's so easily accessible I'm ecstatic.. I love dimsum.. I love City View.. 

Love the orange flavored chicken, and the shrimp with walnuts, and all their dimsum.. except that shark fin stuff (yuck).. I like it all (Almost)
author: Monica S.

description: A fun dim sum experience and on a less crowded street than the hassle of most streets in Chinatown.
author: Vicki L.

description:
City View is a good place to bring freinds and families from out of town.  The dimsum is always consistent.  Food and service are good.  The seafood tastes fresh.   The restaurant is clean and has a nice ambience.

The sweet stuffs like egg custards  tend to be mediocre.   I would roam chinatown for these.
author: Kris H.

description:
I didn't plan to write a review of City View, but after reading what a few others wrote, I felt the need.  I met two girlfriends here for lunch.  Of note, based on several other reviews I read:

1.  The place was packed with Chinese folks.
2.  Lunch cost us $14 each including the tip.  

I'm not a regular dim sum eater, so I can't make any claims about the quality or authenticity of it, but everything we tried was fresh tasting, piping hot and tasty.  The servers were friendly and helpful in explaining their items.  The tea was a bit lackluster in my mind, but whatever.

We did decide however that dim sum places ought to take on the system of the Brazilian Churrascaria - with the slow down, bring more, stop cards...we could have used some alone time to catch up...maybe that's just us.

Anyhow - I thought it was a fun and filling lunch.
author: Mac M.

description:
good dim sum, also way cheaper than yank sing

If you go, try and get there at 12:30 or before, they stop making new food at like 1pm, so the selection dries up really fast

Also going with a big party (6-8) is better you can get a bigger selection and share :).
author: Michael E.

description:
Excellent service. Dumplings were tasty but nothing to write home about.

We had a hard time finding a sit-down dim sum place. Service was great, we were seated quickly and immediately had several carts show up with all of the delicious dumplings that I love. Everything was serviceable but nothing to write home about. I expected more out of Chinatown in San Francisco.
author: Jack B.

description:
Pretty clean place with decent food served in the carts. It caters mostly to the business clientele of the FiDi so it gets busy during weekday lunch time, but you can still finish dining within an hour. It is a little pricey than other dim sum places, but you're paying for the more "upscale" atmosphere. Overall, food is pretty good, but service was a little slow.

Notable Items To Get:
- Pork Dumplings (although they put carrots on top instead of fish eggs)
- Shrimp Dumplings
- Shrimp Crepes
- Pan-Fried Chives & Shrimp Dumplings = really good!
author: Linda C.

description:
If you are thinking of getting good Dim Sum at lunchtime from City View Restaurant...Just keep going.  Dinner may be a different story.

We got their and the place was packed.  The door greeter had the personality of a cardboard box.  She told us the wait would be 15 minutes, turned out more like 30.  So we were finally seated at a corner table for 2, it was better suited for 1.  Then the table behind us was seated, and that patron immediately proceeded to knock my chair repeatedly trying to make room for his ample stomach.  I actually physically picked up the table and moved it a foot away.  

It then took another 10 minutes for any of the food to come rolling by.  I had to flag it in like airplane or we may have gone hungry.  The first samplings included the BBQ Pork Pastry, Sesame Chicken and Shrimp Dumpling.  They weren't bad but not spectacular.  Then we had the Pork Shumai....I actually thought that item was a joke after I tasted it.  There is no way anyone could find that palatable.  It tasted like month old pork that had been dredged through an outdoor sewer.  I tried to get that taste out of my mouth with a deep fried monstrosity that only worsened the situation.  I finally just rinsed my mouth with water and got my bill and left.  

True I have only had Dim Sum once before, in HK.  But it was a far different experience and by far better.  Avoid this place unless you like to overpay for standard Chinese fair and like to be surprised by rancid food.
author: Steve J.

description: So good!!!! I am in love and want to go back tomorrow. I have only eaten dim sum a handful of times but this was the best by far! The staff was friendly, it was clean, but most importantly, delicious!!!
author: Lacey S.

description:
"City View"......ahahhahaha once you find out where it is located it's not much of a view for you....so if it's your first time coming and expecting to see a great view of San Francisco here....hahahah I guess that's how you got suckered into coming here! But honestly, the name of the place may be misleading but the food is pretty good. For dim sum I usually like going to Koi Palace but this place is just as good. 

If you're expecting to find street parking...keep dreaming, you practically in Chinatown, go park in the parking lot. There's one about 4 min walk away.

The day I came, the wait wasn't too bad, but it did get busy later on, I guess people were slowly coming in for lunch.

We ordered a lot of different dim sum, a lot of them were still warm, taste fresh and delish! On top of the food we picked out from the carts, we also ordered a gravey seafood pan fried noodles, it was very good. The seafood and veggies here alll taste very fresh. Things weren't too greasy and didn't taste like there's a lot of msg like you would normally taste at restaurants and it's not really greasy, so I guess that's a plus.

OH!! on top of everything, the place was big AND clean....you know not a lot of places in Chinatown is "clean" so this place took me by surprise...everyone was friendly, you can stop anyone and they're willing to help or find someone who can help you, unlike KOI....takes 15 min to get service....overall, I had a pretty good experience here...would definitely recommend this place for dim sum if you're around the area.
author: Helen T.

description:
The one thing this place can play up is their ambiance.  It's nice compared to other Chinatown dim sum places.  We were seated instantly @ 11am on a Sunday.  They had a decent selection but I did have to ask for the pan fried turnip cake three times - but it's my fave!  It finally arrived as one of our last dishes and it was uber pan fried - something I rarely see.  So I knew it was going to be instantly delish.  We ordered the table shrimp dumplings, shrimp & chive, stick rice wrapped in lotus leaves, tripe, minced beef wrapped in rice noodles w/ extra delicious sauce (2nd best dish), and the sugared fried donuts for dessert.  

Service is pretty good and mostly everyone was nice.  
The crowd was a hybrid of 1/2 caucasian and chinese.  Price was reasonable - $18 amongst 3 of us girls.    

The pros for going on Saturday is that people are constantly leaving as it's all metered parking around there.  Sunday you don't have to pay for a meter but that also means it's harder to find a space.  All in all this place is pretty solid.
author: Meredith K.

description:
I moved to Seattle a few years ago and quickly realized that good dim sum is a luxury to be cherished. And when I'm stomping about in the rain and the cold hungering for some dumplings, I often think of City View.

I have no clue why it's called City View, but this is a great restaurant to duck into when you're being touristy shopping around in Chinatown. Its main appeal to me is that it's clean (or appears to be), which is something I don't typically associate with Chinatown (there I said it). It's also English friendly in the sense that I can get by and I don't speak Chinese, but the waitresses are at least patient enough to open all the baskets for you to inspect while they persist in talking in Chinese. It's got your usual variety of shrimp dumplings and siu mai, as well as sweet sesame balls and XLB soup dumplings. Not the cheapest place, but still reasonable. 

This place isn't as fancy pants as Yank Sing or Koi Palace, but it's more affordable and I've never had to wait very long. And if you're in SF, count your lucky stars and enjoy your dim sum!
author: natalie n.

description:
This restaurant is THE reason I am addicted to sesame balls. 
I agree with a lot of the other reviews:
1) It slows down after the lunch rush, and the service gets a lot slower and less frequent so you have to start requesting things.
2) Not cheap, not expensive.
3) Shark fin dumplings were amazing; the pot stickers were greasy. Mmm, greasy. There is also an eggplant and tofu dish that is bigger than a lot of the other plates. It is possibly the greasiest thing they serve, and that is why I love it. I love it almost as much as the sesame balls.

It's fabulous for someone who needs instant gratification (moi), and I always leave feeling full and happy.
author: Merrilee T.

description:
When we got to San Francisco, we decided we wanted some dim sum. We went to Chinatown, yelped a couple of places we walked passed. Most of the places we yelped only had 2 stars.
