The ones with 3-4 stars had long lines. Finally, we found City View Restaurant on yelp! Walked a few blocks to get to it. 

When we walked in, we were seated right away. There was only a line for big parties. Despite getting seated so quickly, we were stuck in a corner where it wasn't very accessible to the carts. It took a while for us to come across our first cart. Sometimes it would take 10mins for the next cart to come. 

The food was good! The portions were somewhat small though. Selection seemed a bit limited too. Service was mediocre. We ordered some walnut prawns, and they didn't come by with it till we were about to leave. Didn't even get to try it since we were pretty much full by then.
author: Erica C.

description: One of our favorite places to go for brunch when in SF.  I love their sesame balls and my husband loves their BBQ chicken feet.
author: Fiona N.

description: $94 dollars for four people is a little much for dim sum. I can see paying $15 a person max, but this place too expensive.  The food was good and the service was fine, but on my next trip to SF I will be looking for a different dim sum restaurant.
author: Eric G.

description:
Dim Sum
Tasty shrimp bao
BBQ pork bao okay
Nice noodles
Efficient food service
Beautiful banquet room downstairs w/beautiful Chinese art
author: Rosquete B.

description:
I went to this place a few times with my coworkers for lunch. Most of the time we had to plan to get there very early to be ahead of the lunch crowd.

The restaurant looks clean compared to typical Chinese restaurants. Their food is very tasty. The best dim sum I ever experienced. Servers are attentive. My only complaint is the food portion which is slightly small compared to the price that I paid.
author: C I.

description: This is our go-to Dim Sum place in San Francisco.  Yes the prices are a little higher, not as high as  Yank Sing, but the food is consistenly good.  Good service.  It can get a little busy and have a bit of a wait but we always go early.
author: Raymond L.

description:
We came here for lunch and the restaurant was pretty full but luckily there was a table so there was no wait.
We had the following:
Har gow: so-so..have had better-please devein your shrimp before serving!!
Shrimp & chive dumpling: ok
Shrimp Chow fun-very good.

Service was ok.
author: Lizete S.

description:
yea, after 3 years, I came back and no changes to the place. It still sucks.  And I found some paper in my bbq pork bun. Gross!

Some of stuff was not hot enough.  Their shrimp crepe was again not very great. it's dry and chewy.  
Service was so slow.  
I think I'm extra picky b/c I'm chinese and we have dimsum on a regular basis?  
The only plus thing is that it's close to financial district.  Def. not coming back!
author: AhLin C.

description:
If you're looking for a relaxing Sunday meal with warm and friendly staff, City View isn't the place for you.  But if you're hoping to try some of the best dim sum in San Francisco, hustle on down.

City View is crowded almost any day (and any time of day), especially on Sundays, but tables open up quickly (mostly because you'll get chased out once you stop picking food from the carts) and it's a fun way to have lunch.  I love the variety of food that comes around: steamed, fried, boiled dumplings with pork, chicken, or shrimp.  The steamed pork buns are fluffy, moist, and particularly delicious - probably the best bao I've had.  I also can't get enough of the fried pork dumplings, with their crispy sweet shells.  I don't understand the names of everything I eat, but it's all wonderful.

However, they are running a money operating business.  While the dishes range from $3-$6, the little plates can add up fast if you're not paying attention.  Also, I've noticed the hostess and waiters hurry you along towards the end of the meal.  On one visit in particular, we asked for some Chinese doughnuts, only to be told that there weren't any.  As we were paying the bill, several trays of the doughnuts walked by.  It was obvious the hostess wanted us to scoot and didn't want us to wait for the next batch to come out.

I always chalk the lack of service up to a cultural experience - something to joke about as we enjoy the delicious food!
author: Kristin M.

description:
Dim Sum sounds pretty damn good on a Sunday morning after a rough night of partying! 
It think we stumbled in here around 12pm and got seated right away, which honestly surprised me. All my Dim Sum experiences in the South Bay have been tied to a huge line with a wait time (even with reservation) and a ridiculously packed place. Not here!
 The service was quick and they had pretty fresh items on every cart passing our table. Overall the flavor was good but a tiny tiny bit more on the oily side. The soup dumplings were delicious - definitely a must get. Other favorite items were the duck as well as the flat rice noodles with pork. 
Prices are fair, tad more on the expensive side compared to the South Bay Restaurants. In sum I enjoyed my food and the experience here, so this place is definitely a good choice for Dim Sum in San Francisco.
author: Sonja S.

description: Best dim sum in the City by far.  Nice people.  Good food.  Frequent selection.  Slightly upscale atmosphere.  Like it.
author: Greg W.

description:
Excellent food!  We went here for lunch on a Friday at 12:15pm and even though there were a lot of people before us, we still got a table in about 10 minutes.  I've never been to a place where they bring the food around and you pick off of the cart - so fun!

I was nervous the bill would be huge because we were picking out food like crazy but for 4 people it came to $60 - pretty nice!  I have no idea what we got but it was all delicious.  Not a place for vegetarians.

My only negative was that it's a bit of a cluster putting your name down for a table.  The hostess is really nice but doesn't communicate very well so people just keep squeezing in the area.

I will definitely go back!  Next time we'll go outside of the lunch rush!
author: Bonnie P.

description:
I was recommended to this restaurant by a chef at a Dim Sum cooking class at Ramekins in Sonoma.

Every chance I get I come here, and I bring everyone that I can. Excellent value, clean, and amazing fresh food.

Quick service. Avoid the calamari, its so so.
author: Kelly L.

description: Four of us decided to have Dim Sum before the Chinatown Community Fair but didn't want to try to ind a table in the middle of the madness, so we thought a place on the border of Chinatown would be a smarter option. Yes and no. Got seated immediately which was good, the place was very clean and cheery, but uh-oh! more Caucasian than Chinese people. A bad sign. The food came around with the cart ladies fairly frequently, but I have to say it was just alright. As a matter of fact I can think of no stand out plates. Very mediocre and on the expensive side. If you have Dim Sum novices and want a no pressure experience, then this will work. If you are more seasoned then try elsewhere.
author: Ron W.

description:
what a rip off!  

8 dishes equally scattered across the "small", "large" and "special" categories on the little stampy card set us back $40 and change!   really???  the har gow were pathetic...i mean if they were any drier they would give off static electricity.  as a matter of fact, there was another dumpling type thing that was dry too...

oh and they didn't come back with the change because they just assumed we wanted to leave that as a tip.  whack.

one saving grace is they are clean.

that is all.  

will not go back.

you should stay away too.
author: Sally T.

description:
I've walked by this restaurant multiple times since my boys and I love New Hong Kong across the street, but since we had a larger group today we decided to treat ourselves to a nicer meal and made reservations for 8 at City View.  It was a good thing we called in ahead of time because despite the rain, there was still a respectable line there.  

The food is about on par for an upper class dim sum restaurant.  Definitely better than your usual dim sum venues scattered around Chinatown, but nothing special.  The one thing that threw me off was the shrimp dumpling plate.  As a staple of the dim sum meal I definitely judge the restaurant by how good these dumplings (and the siu mai) taste.  The shrimp wasn't very fresh and left a funny aftertaste.  But other than that the food and decor was as acceptable.
author: Jason L.

description:
Fresh and clean tasting dim sum.  Some of the best shrimp balls I have had anywhere.  I have been coming here for 10 years and its my biggest regret that I cannot go more often since I don't work downtown anymore.

Staff is friendly and most of them have been there as long as I have been going.  If you go downtown on a weekend they validate your parking too.
author: Jennie M.

description:
City View has decent decor but that's unfortunately where the decency ends. I had Dim Sum here for lunch on a Sunday afternoon and find the quality mostly sub-par. 

None of the dishes had particularly appetizing presentation and did not taste any better. For example most of the dumpling wrapping were made too thick, shrimp dumpling did not taste fresh, xiao long bao were dry and didn't have the broth inside, and all the fried dishes were far too oily.

On top of that, we spent $57 for just 2 people. This is the first and probably last visit for me.
author: John P.

description: Very little variety at dim sum and no Chinese menu to order from. Would go someplace else for better dishes
author: Alan H.

description: Been here on several occasions and my experience has always been pleasant. Yes, more expensive than typical dim sum, but the decor is a lot fancier, and the staff are relatively nicer than the other places in Chinatown. Anything deep-fried is gonna be really good: mild taro puff piled high like a top hat, juicy crab/shrimp claw, the calamari that I had to beg four waiters to find was to die for, and the scallion pancake is crispy and salty and is complimented by the hot chili sauce perfectly. The shrimp in rice noodle roll is lacking, like some other users have said. The usual shrimp dumpling, mushroom dumpling, chives and shrimp dumpling, and soup dumpling were average. I don't care for soup dumplings at all. And basically my only criteria for dumplings at this point is that they don't fall apart when I peel it off the steamer, which has been a constant for me at New Asia. The fish cake in eggplant is interesting and tasty, but oily. The chicken kebab is good also but you can get those for a dollar a stick on Stockton Street. My only regret is not having ordered the crispy seafood noodle dish. Not sure if they charge for tea, but that seems to be the norm today and complaining won't change it. One complaint is that the egg tarts are super small and they are the price of a small dish when there are only 3? The middle jiggles pleasantly but there's no eggy flavor about it. But what my non-Asian MIL wants (and does not understand about Chinatown), my MIL gets. Overall, ten dishes added up to be about $65, and this fed 3 people to the brim.
author: Rachel H.

description: Great San Francisco dim sum. Fast, clean and friendly.
author: j c.

description:
Yumm, probably in my top 3 of best dim sum restaurants. My friends and I were staying at the Hilton down the street, and we were craving good but in expensive dim sum. We asked the concierge for a recommendation and he suggested City View. So we got there, and it was full so you know it's good, but we were seated within 5 minutes (and luckily we beat the crowd that came after us). It was a bit fancy looking so I was nervous it would be expensive. There was a variety that came out at first but my friends and I were mostly interested in the streamed food which kind of took a while. Eventually we started pigging out and it was so delicious, fresh, and flavorful.

The only downside is the dumplings were pretty small, and it was on the pricier side. About 14 including tax & tip split between 3 people. It's worth it though.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
Was introduced to City View by a good friend who likes Dim Sum as much as I do.  Prior to my visit here, I was loyal to Yank Sing for my Dim Sum cravings.  Although Yank Sing is delicious, its damn expensive.  I considered trying out some of the Dim Sum places in Chinatown, but after reading reviews on Yelp for some of the more well known places, I was scared off by stories about cockroach sightings and just unacceptable filth in these establishments.

The food at City View is great and the service is so so.  Expect long lunch lines at 12:00-12:30.  It dies down a little by 1:00, but it still busy.  My favorite is the fried chicken and the pot stickers.

On a scale of 1-10, I give Yank Sing a 9.5 and I give City View a 7.  The main reason to go to City View aside from good food and clean ambiance, it the price.  The bill will generally be half of what you would pay at Yank Sing
author: Ash S.

description:
Came to celebrate a girlfriend's birthday yesterday.  The food was decent and the restaurant was clean with a decent atmosphere for a Chinese restaurant.  This is funny, the restaurant is a street view... not sure why they call themselves "City View", but whatever!

Service was positively atrocious... although it's been a while since I've been out for Chinese food, and I think that may just be par for the course at dim sum.  

I had to flag down the waiters constantly for water refills and a couple of the ladies pushing carts tried to skip our table and we had to call them over.  

i wish they had more variety, especially vegetarian and vegetable dishes.  But I did enjoy our selection.

We had brought a cake, hoping they could bring it out after our meal.  You'd expect that they'd put the cake on a plate, light the candles and present the cake to us like any normal restaurant would.  Instead, they simply dropped off the cake still in the box (!?!?!), which obviously made the moment not very special.  We had to do the honors ourselves.  Luckily, they didn't charge us a cake - cutting fee, although we would have gladly paid.  Not a great celebratory experience.

We ate well and the total bill per person was $22, which is certainly a good deal.  I doubt I will ever be back here.
author: Sheila D.

description:
City View is technically in the middle of Chinatown and the Financial District because its so close to Chinatown as well.  Its only open till 2:30 PM so our party was really lucky when we walked in at 2:15 which is a great time to come because the lines are shorter.  However, the downside to that might be that the carts are going around anymore and you have to order a la carte off the menu.  Which I totally preferred because my husband is vegetarian and it was easier to order things off the menu for him.  

City View gets an A + for the vegetarian choices and our server who recommended all these awesome choices.  The veggie rice rolls and mushroom dumplings are off the hook and even better than some of the regular stuff. Scallop dumplings are a MUST.  The stuffed mushrooms in black pepper sauce are a great choice especially since you usually dont find it at every dim sum place.  

The price is on par with many dim sum places that I have been to and have heard it is a lot more reasonable than Yank Sing.
author: Tina A.

description:
Order of choy--no taste except oil. yuck.
Order of sew mai - they never brought.  
Told us they close the kitchen early and you can't order any more food half hour before closing on a Saturday afternoon.
Overpriced.
author: Foodsy C.

description: Yes, it is very spendy.  But in this case, I think you do get what you pay for.  We came here for yum cha (dim sum) one morning, and it was packed with people.  My wife remarked that she could tell by the way people were dressed, that it was a bit more upscale than the normal dim sum places we tend to frequent.  I really enjoyed their dumplings with chives and the shu mai.  And as Yosie G. mentioned in a review a few years ago, they really do use real crab claw in their crab claw dumplings--a real nice touch, I think.  My son declared that their char siu bau was the best he ever had anywhere (even better than Sportful Garden in Hong Kong).  And he ate THREE of them, so he must have really liked them.  I'm not a huge fan of char siu bau, but I did notice there were no hard bits of fat in these that I have encountered in other restaurants.  We had jasmine tea, and it was a pretty good quality brew.  All the tables were taken upstairs, and there was a downstairs too (where the restrooms are), but those tables were not being used.  Perhaps they are used when dinner is served.  I couldn't eat here often on my current salary, but once every few years when I visit San Francisco, this place will definitely be at the top of my list!
author: Norm G.

description:
This place has pretty good dim sum at a decent price given its location.  I've been here many times for lunch during the weekday and have always been satisfied. I also think it's a value compared to Yank Sing because quite a few of their dim sum are about as tasty, if not more tasty, than Yank Sing, but for cheaper.  When my friend and I come here our tab averages about $40, but we tend to order quite a bit.

My friend and I were there on Monday and our tab was $42.  We were a little surprised that it came out that high since we thought we ordered less than usual, but this is what it got us if I remember everything: Fung chau (chicken feet), shrimp har gow, 2 shrimp siu mai, pork siu mai, shanghai dumpling, turnip cake, crab claw, pan fried chive and shrimp dumpling.

We think the fung chau is pretty great here and usually order 3 or 4, but this time opted for just 1. The flavor is savory and texture just right. It's not mushy soft or really hard.

Shrimp har gow is usually done well provided that you let it cool a bit before eating it otherwise the skin will still be pretty soft and you run the risk of your dumpling just falling apart.

Siu mai is pretty standard; not really better than anywhere else, but definitely not bad.

I don't know why I continue to order Shanghai dumpling here. When I first came here I remember them being half way decent, but now they're pretty lame. You get 4 dumplings that come in little aluminum pans (picture mini pie pans). Almost every single time I try to get them out of those pans, no matter how careful I am, the damn dumpling rips open and the soup pours out. Lucky me the soup goes into the pan and I can just sip it from there, but there isn't even much soup in the dumpling since it's mostly filled with meat. On top of that, they give you red vinegar for dipping. For really good Shanghai dumplings I recommend Shanghai Dumpling Shop in Millbrae. (note to self: stop ordering those damn dumplings here).

Turnip cake I don't usually order since it's so filling for me, but this past visit I was craving it and I was happy with it. Can't say much else about that.

Fried crab claw is usually my friend's thing, but I've had it a few times and it's pretty good. Exterior has a nice liitle crisp and filling has good chunks of shrimp and crab.

The pan fried chive and shrimp dumpling has a nice crust on the pan fried sides and the inside usually has good sized chunks of shrimp.

We've had some other seafood dumplings in the past, but we felt that they just weren't worth it. Those items seemed overpriced for what we got. A lot of times it didn't seem like our dumplings had much seafood.
For example, in the past if we were to replace a few item from the above list with say some scallop dumplings or "seafood" dumplings our tab would be roughly $60! Boo!

Anyhow, they've got the best reasonably priced dim sum near my work (that I know of), otherwise I'd go to Inner Richmond for even cheaper, good dim sum.
author: Dennis Z.

description:
This place is clean and close to the Transamerica Building..  If you are not asian, don't worry; you'll feel right at home and they make it easy for you to order.  The food is good and comparable to Yang Sing, but for half the price.   I was perplexed as to the name since I didn't see any views of the city.

The XLB dumplings were one of the best I've tried at a dim sum place.  Also tried the rice noodle with shrimp.  The pork siu mai used ground carrots instead of fish eggs on top.  Also had a spinach and shrimp dumpling. I am not a chicken feet aficionado but from the foot I tried it tasted better than most other places I've had and was warm and well flavored.  They also had egg tarts and mango pudding.  The sticky rice looked good and so did the pork buns.  They also had egg rolls for the hard core dim summers.  

The service is pretty good and there are plenty of carts going around.   It wasn't too busy early in the week for lunch and would work well for groups.  Probably gets packed on the weekends.
author: Summit S.

description:
Very good dim sum in downtown SF. The food is always cooked right assembled well, and generally fresh. While it won't be the best dim sum you'll ever have, it's much better than most of the restaurants in chinatown.

The line moves quickly, and they will generally accommodate you if you call while you are on the way in. This restaurant is also very clean. I hate having to go to a dirty dim sum place, and clean my own plate off with a napkin.

This is right on the border of chinatown, but much better than most dim sum restaurants in chinatown. Unfortunately it is a bit more expensive, but that's understandable being closer to the financial district than in the middle of a crowded chinatown street.
author: Kevin G.

description:
Really liked this place. A lot less hectic than most other dim sum places (though that might be part of the fun for some) even though it's pretty crowded most of the time. Go before noon if you don't want to wait long.

Not as much variety as some places, but the dishes they do, they do extremely well. Prices are not cheap, but not particularly expensive either.
author: Alessandro P.

description:
It wasn't TERRIBLE, as in I wanted to throw up afterwards, but definitely wasn't the best dimsum I've ever had. The food was greasy and service was a bit slow, with the waitresses trying to shove food on your table even after you say no. This is all pretty typical at dimsum places, but overall the food did not live up to the hype. Pretty disappointing when I had been craving good dimsum for ages!

For better dimsum, try Joy Luck Place in San Mateo... it's a bit pricey but you definitely get what you pay for (and it keeps you full for the rest of the day!).
author: Natalie W.

description: I really do enjoy some dim sum and when my friend considered about eating some at san fran, I was extremely excited. Yes food gets me this way. The restaurant was clean and nicely decorated so I'll give them kudos. Anyways, after getting my favorite dishes, I thought the taste was pretty good but after getting the check. I thought WOW, $68 for three people. Seriously, my family would get more plates than what we got and the check would be half the price. I'm not sure if I'll be coming back here, but I have the right to change my mind. We'll see.
author: Phyu A.

description: Great place for lunch!  Excellent dim sum and fast service gets you back to work in no time!
author: Nors D.

description:
City View. Love the irony of the name, but besides that the food is solid, prices aren't bad. And it's Dim Sum.

I like this style of dim sum, where they bring around hot food ready to eat, instead of example plates that you still have to order and wait for. Provided there's no line, you can be in the door, seating, and stuffing your mouth full of hot and wonderfuls within 45 seconds.

That's my kind of Dim Sum.
author: Jarrod B.

description:
A new favorite!

Seafood, dumplings, etc., are all present in a tasty, non-greasy, slightly-expensive-but-not-as-expensive-as-Yank-Sing way. Dining room, china, and silverware are all clean. A reasonable non-gut-busting amount of food cost us $17/adult (there were 6 adults and a 1-yr-old; the 1-yr-old ate for free).

We showed up around 11am for Saturday dim sum brunch. It didn't look like it was getting crowded until around 12:30-1pm.

Tip: they validate parking at Portsmouth Square Garage.
author: Rob T.

description: Dimsum just doesn't exist in my hometown, with the lack of Chinese immigrants. I couldn't understand a word the waitresses said, but everything was delicious none-the-less. This is my kind of dining: grab whatever looks good at the time until you can't eat anymore. I will always crave these sweet and savory pockets of deliciousness.
author: Jessica S.

description:
Completely solid lunch dim sum: nothing felt too greasy and everything was really tasty.  We got there about 11:30, got seated immediately, and the food tasted fresh.

-1 star because it was pretty pricey for dim sum and they charged for the tea so the total after tax & tip was ~$20 a person for lunch.  (To be fair, we had some of the fancier things like fried crab claw and scallop mu shu.)

Personal favorites: sesame ball, pea pods (perfectly crispy, I was impressed), honey shrimp with walnuts, scallop mu shu, shrimp & veggie dumpling
author: Audrey C.

description:
I can see why the long is lunch for dim sum after 12:30pm.....this place is really good!

The service is great and food quality is excellent!  I love their food and i love how we pick our food from the menu and they bring the food to use- Versus picking it out from a cart.  That just tells you the difference from a dim sum joint with carts!  I know, cuz I'm Chinese!!

I really like their fried rices!!
author: Alvin M.

description:
I'm not an experienced dim sum-er, but came with two friends who are. I enjoyed it overall, but it seemed overpriced for what it was. Next time I might try one of these many take-out tiny dim sum places I keep reading about.

First of all, don't sit near the door. It's amazing that nearly every single moron that walks in the place doesn't close the door behind them, and is somehow totally oblivious to the giant gusts of cold air blowing past them as they stand and wait there. Needless to say, I was cold. And irritated. And am still bitter.

The food overall was solid, just expensive for what it was. Validated parking is always a nice draw, though this was my first experience with the Portsmouth Square garage--it is CROWDED. The line was wrapped around the block at points.
author: Derek S.

description:
Let me start with this:
Beats the Michigan dim-sum,
but no city view. (a haiku)

The fare wasn't remarkable. I'd say probably average. I'm not too familiar with the names of all the standard entrees, but the sticky rice and seafood dumpling were pretty tasty.  Other than that, most of the dumplings and other dishes were really quite greasy, and the 'tofu' dish I ordered to expand variety was not really just tofu but some kind of unidentified meat with a unexpectedly strange tasting sauce.

The servers and wait help seemed very busy, and no one stopped to offer us water or tea after we were seated until we asked.  

I think this place would be all right if you know what you want and are familiar with the dishes being served.  Overall, I wasn't very impressed with my experience, especially after seeing that it cost over $60 for two people when I've had better for less.
author: Anne I.

description:
Balancing between quality and price, my wife and I think it's the best value for dim sum in San Francisco.  Is there better tasting dim sum elsewhere?  Yes, but not at the reasonable prices City View offers.  Are there cheaper places elsewhere?  Yes, but not with food this good.

Thus, we are regulars there ... and, yes, they're pretty consistent.

By the way, the service is quite good although I have to admit that they're more attentive and accommodating when we speak Chinese with them.
author: Les G.

description: Terrific Dim Sum.  Our favorite in the city with Yang Sing
author: John R.

description:
This place is one of the best dim sum restaurants I've been to yet! 

Lots of dim sum to choose from, desserts, and an assortment of petite plates of dinner dishes were available as well (i.e. walnut shrimp, peking duck, etc.)

Shrimp noodle with the sweet soy sauce is usually my most favored.. but this place has Bbq pork noodle?! Same concoction, except in place of the shrimp they put Bbq pork; big YUM!

No hole in the wall joint here; tall glass windows, and white simplicity made the place look informal yet elegant.
author: Anne D.

description:
I've been eating dim sum all my life. I've been to all the top Dim Sum places in LA. Elite, Rooster, Happy Harbor etc. I know what good dim sum is. This place is bad! and to top it off it is extremely overpriced. 

Siu Mai- Their Siu Mai is probably the worst Siu Mai I have ever had. You can get better stuff from the takeout places in La. 

Steamed Beef Noodle- Soggy and overcooked. 

Peking Duck with steamed bread- Horrible.

We had some other dishes that were mediocre but the three above stand out as being poor.

Their service was also extremely bad. But that is expected at dim sum places. So I wont knock them for that. 2 stars based on food.

Oh and the white cloth napkins bleed. Put it on your lap and take it off and you will see what i mean.
author: Thanh S.

description:
City View has good dim sum. We enjoyed all the dishes we tried, even when we weren't sure exactly what they were (some mysterious deep fried vegetable was delicious). Between 2 of us, we tried around 10+ dishes and the total was $38. 

It's clean, people are friendly, service was okay. A lot of the servers had really thick accents but they all tried to tell us what the dishes were in English. Also, not all the carts came around to our area, which was a little annoying when we saw some good stuff bypassing us. 

Only con: there is no view of the city here!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
3 stars but 1 star extra for awesome crab claws and taro!

No complaints --
good variety of dimsum
not too expensive (aka, not "bend me over and f me" prices like Yank Sing)
pretty close
clean, open restaurant
friendly servers

They didn't bring any xiao long bao out, but according to Steve L., you have to ask for it :( Bummer.
author: T L.

description:
Instead of our usual gorging and the falling into several food comas for Easter brunch at some hotel, my wife's family opted to go out for dim sum instead.

For the past couple of years, we've reserved 2 tables at Cityview. What I like about this place is that it's between Chinatown and the Financial District, so if one is persistent, one can find street parking, or just park in Portsmouth Square garage for 2 hours of validated parking. This isn't a place one would happen to pass by on the street. It's located on Commercial Alley between Kearny St. and Montgomery. 

There's two levels to this restaurant: a street level and a sub-street level. On this Sunday, the street level of the restaurant was full, but the sub level was closed. Bathrooms and kitchen are on the sub level. 

It's a very clean restaurant. Waiters are frequently cleaning tables, and clearing off empty plates off of tables. Layout of the tables are efficient, yet not a tight, crammed feeling. Enough room for the dim sum carts to pass out through without banging on a customer's elbow. 

Dim sum carts frequently make their rounds around the restaurant, and the dim sum was still hot in their steamers. 

We ordered a lot from the carts, and I can't remember everything what we had. The ha gow (shrimp dumplings), were pretty good, thin skinned, nice whole pieces of shrimp. Both the chicken and pork siu mai were also good, but I found the pork version to be much juicier than the chicken. 

We were waiting the the xiao long bao to come out. But didn't see it. Spoke with the manager, and he said he'll bring some out for us when they're ready. Few minutes later, he came by with 2 steamers for each of our tables. They were OK. Skin was too thick, and slightly doughy. Soupy insides were already absorbed into the skin. 

My father-in-law also preordered Peking duck and dry-fried beef chow fun. The duck was really juicy, and the skin had the perfect combination of crispiness on the outside, juicy moistness on the inside. Went well with the freshly-steamed buns. Beef chow fun was OK, but by then I was too full. 

The owner gave us a complimentary plate of fried sesame balls and coconut buns, which were fresh made, and really good. 

Very good service, and a very accommodating manager/owner. This as well as the food has been pretty consistent over the years.
author: Steve L.

description:
I have been here many times.  It is one of the meeting places used by my wife's Hong Kong prep school alumni assoc.  These ladies know how to find good values!

They validate parking if you park in the Portsmouth Square underground garage.

Food is always good.  We usually have dim sum with some green veggies.  I especially like the woo-gok(stuffed taro).  It is light & not oily.    

Service is usually quick & friendly.  On weekends it can get very busy.  You may have to wait 10-20 minutes for a table.  My last visit was on a Thursday.  It was not too crowded so the atmosphere was very relaxed.  A couple of the servers laughed with me while trying to describe the dishes in their carts, in English.

The decor is simple downtown business.  Not surprising since it is only a block from the B of A building.
author: Saul M.

description:
I went to City View last weekend for a dim sum lunch around noon on Sunday. There were a ton of people milling about in the entrance area, and it wasn't clear whether they were waiting to be seated or just confused about how to put their name in for a table. Once we got there, we just went up to the host desk, which is a little ways into the restaurant, and upon asking to have our name down for a table for two, were seated immediately.

That was the good part. After we were seated, though, we were basically ignored by any servers offering tea or water and it took asking one of the bussers for some tea before we got anything to drink.

Carts come around frequently, but because the place was so busy, you're fairly rushed to decide whether or not you want to get a particular item. We ended up getting most of the standard dim sum fare, but nothing stood out. The dishes were a little greasier than I'd have liked.

Of course, Dim Sum is such a subjective experience and it changes drastically with what dishes you end up getting. With that caveat, I was disappointed with what we ended up with at City View. The har gau was good, but the rest of what we got (sticky rice, sesame balls, siu mai) was very ordinary at best. One tofu dish we tried was particularly disappointing.

In the end, we spent around 60 dollars for two people, which was more than the experience was worth. I'd prefer to go somewhere cheaper and less hectic.

Also, there is no city view at City View. Don't be deceived.
author: Dan L.

description:
This was our first time for Dim Sum so take that into consideration.  We had a total of 12 plates/orders and the total was $60.00 which others have told us is very pricey compared to other places.

Food was yummy and the place was very clean.  It was hard to understand the servers but to be expected in Chinatown.

We would go back.  We will also try other places.
author: Andrea L.

description: This is a good option for dim sum in Chinatown. Apparently, if you go to the burbs, the food is much cheaper, but there was a good variety cart options, efficient service at noon on a Sunday and a bustly but not chaotic environment. We ended up spending about $20 each, so not exactly cheap, but we were full and happy.
author: Rachel M.

description:
The day that I went to CIty VIew, it was hands down the best dim sum I had ever had in my life. the restaurant was very clean. 

In my experience, each dim sum restaurant usually has 2-3 items that the do very well. At City View, EVERYTHING I ordered was just perfect. The food was hot, the textures were perfect, and the service was great to. This restaurant is very clean, and located in between the financial district and Chinatown. The soup dumplings here are great, as well as all the standard dim sum dishes. 5 stars for great food, great service, a clean environment, and fair prices for GREAT Dim Sum!
author: Khoa L.

description:
My wife and I ate there based on referral from concierge at hotel.  The atmosphere was good for dim sum.  Service was fast and food was good.  It was medium to high priced for dim sum.  The two of us ate a fair amount and bill was $55.
The only reason we didn't give it 4 stars was the steamed pork buns were not great and that is my wife's favorite.
author: John M.

description:
i have eaten at City View about 8-10 times; only for lunch on work days. a review is overdue.

Negatives: this place is very expensive and to experience everything you would like to eat during a limited hour doesn't really work. also it takes forever to get your check to pay and leave.

Positive: fresh food, extremely clean environment, always busy so get there early.

you can ask for individual dishes - but that doesn't mean they will make it to your table. that also goes for refilled water glasses or more hot tea. if you feel more comfortable eating with a fork, good luck. at times i've been ignored.

having said that (and i see i have more negatives than positives) i really like this place and enjoy eating there at lunch - it's a nice break away from the office.
author: Deb B.

description: Sunday Dim Sum.  Always a good idea.  The food was OK, the selection seemed to be limited because many of the better choices showed up late as we were leaving.  Maybe going early to beat the crowd came at a price.  The price at about $35 per person was much more than what I call $$
author: Andy B.

description: We arrived about 1:30 and possibly that's why we had a better experience than some of the other reviewers.  We got a table right away and everyone we talked to was very nice and helpful.  The dim sum was pretty good, not the best I've ever had but absolutely worth it.  Our check was $56 without drinks and all 4 of us were stuffed.
author: Onj J.

description:
undisclosed prices for  dishes across the "small", "large" and "special" categories on the little stamps card set us back $98 for 4 adults and an 98 year old grandma with regular dishes without any alcohol (just tea)

A "Special" for $8 for a small rice roll with a few shrimp?

Really price?  the were pathetic.

Food is average

but great service, so we  gave 15% for tip
 

We will not go back.

You should check out the hidden price before seating down.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
I wasn't much of a dim sum person because I always thought the food was too greasy for me, but after coming here, I realized that it was all because I was going to the wrong restaurants.

This place is clean! Able to accomodate large groups. There's a lot of variety for dim sum and it tastes good, not so greasy like other places I've been to.  I've always gone around 11am and was able to get a table right away, but I did notice the afternoon rush of people that would come after me, so plan accordingly.

I don't know the names of the dishes but these are my staples:

Peking Duck - Love love love it!
Flat shrimp roll dumpling - god the sauce is sooo good.  they tried to take the sauce away from the table but you better believe my hand whipped out with lightening speed to stop them.
Fried shrimp &chive dmpling - drool worthy
Rolled flat noodle - was a little on the sweet side but good
Chinese spinach - a tad oily but still yummy
And basically they have a vast variety of diff dumplings we tried but the above is usually what i get.
As for prices, some people told me it's on the pricier side, but I thought it was reasonable.
author: C A.

description: Great CLEAN dim sum restaurant in Chinatown. Went here on a Sunday at 1:00pm and the place was practically empty. Not sure why. The decor was nice and elegant like. Nothing was dirty or came close to being a China Town stop and go restaurant. All of the dishes came out tasty and fast. Friendly services, moderately priced, wide variety of dishes you'd find at any dim sum restaurant.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Before I begin, let me ask you a few questions.

Do you like food? And I mean, REALLY like food?
Yes? Good - moving on.

 Are you willing to experience new things - things which you might not be sure what they are, but there is a guarantee that they will be good? 
If you answered no, stop reading now and head over to Mc. Donald's. 
If you answered yes....Congratulations! You made it.

The reason I ask this is because in order to entirely enjoy yourself and indulge fully into the culinary juggernaut that is Dim Sum, you have to keep an open mind. You may be able to stay safe with your Chicken Teriyaki dish at sushi places, but not here my friend. Carts will fly by; the cart lady will open the lids to reveal the unknown little treasures. You may ask what they are if you so please, but the response will most likely be unintelligible. It's just you and the food, and if you're like me, you couldn't ask for anything more.

Now that's out of the way, lets move on to the actual restaurant, which is the star of this show anyway. 
City View is concealed away beside the main Chinatown drag. The green banner and flimsy sign exterior do nothing to foretell the beautiful interior waiting for you. Inside, the restaurant is friendly, spacious, clean, and most importantly, busy. The food is nothing short of spectacular as well. The thing I love about Dim Sum is that it pleases my impatience and my stomach's eagerness; for once you are seated you are bombarded with the food carts. It's hard to summarize all of the food I've ordered in one review, because each dish could fill up a page of nonsensical bliss-filled insanity, so I'm just going to again tell you that yes - the food is indeed good.

The only reason why I have to give this place 4 star instead of 5 is the variety. The food here is pretty authentic, but they bring out the "safer" food (buns, shrimp and x) too much. While you can order whatever you want from the staff, it would be nice if you didn't have to. The other Dim Sum places tend to have a greater selection and more interesting things. But with that said, the items I've had here taste far better than elsewhere. 

You just can't do wrong at City View. Show up, point to everything that comes your way, and enjoy some of the best Dim Sum I've had in California.
author: Russell S.

description:
Nothing wrong with this place.  Nothing particularly spectacular either.  Had a "gays of the office" lunch here, since it's just around the corner from our office.  The food was ok - some of it was flavorless, to be honest.  (Please, please don't tame down Chinese food, just because a lot of white people eat here, seriously...).  It got to us quickly, though I was rammed in to by a number of carts.  The only kind of sad thing was how terribly long it took to get them to let us pay.

Oh, and two notes of warning.  1) Reservations are a good idea around lunch time.  2) An itemized receipt here is a no go.  Just a copy of a sheet with stamps on it.  Good luck explaining that to accounting...
author: Adam T.

description:
Wondering through the Financial District/Chinatown we were looking for seriously good dim-sum. We actually went to a restaurant that was on yelp but they didn't serve dim-sum but they did recommend this place which was right down the street. We had to wait a while since it was lunch time but once we got seated the food started coming and man was it good! I can see why the wait was so long. Unfortunately, since I was so hungry I just shoveled whatever was brought by into my mouth so I don't really remember what we had but it was good! 

I definitely recommend this place to anyone who wants good dim sum in the city.
author: Sara B.

description:
After reading 400+ reviews here I was excited to try this place.
On Sat around 11am, we walked in expecting at least 30 min wait.  However, the restaurant was literally empty with only three tables occupied.  hmmm... did I read the reviews right? Is this the right place? 
After double checking the address, we sat down and waited for the yummy dim sum carts to pass by.  They did pass by, but they barely had any dim sum.  In total, they had 5 different dim sum dishes circulating the restaurant over and over.  I asked them for the most simple shrimp, pork, etc. dim sums every single time they passed by, but they didn't make any new ones.  So, we ended up eating just those 5 dishes. 
Btw, why are they serving walnut shrimp, kung pao chicken, etc. in the dim sum cart?
author: jody k.

description:
It's hard to find a dim sum place that has good food but doesn't treat you like a third-class citizen if you don't speak Chinese.  City View, however, serves up great dim sum without the attitude (some of the servers are actually, dare I say it, pleasant).  There are also two added benefits -- the price is pretty reasonable, and the decor is clean and professional.

All of the dumplings are very tasty, as are the pork buns and the noodle dishes.  I have it on good authority that the chicken feet are also very good.  

Definitely well worth your consideration.  If you speak Chinese you have better options, I'm sure, but for the rest of us who also enjoy dim sum City View is a must-try.
author: Paul K.

description:
People are always asking me where to go for dim sum. Guess cuz I'm Chinese. I would have to say for the best, you need to go to China, but if you can't and want a pleasant place that's clean with okay service, City View is a good choice. Very busy on the weekends, so be prepared to wait a little. They have a good variety of dim sum and if you're hankering for something you don't see, just ask. 

This place has nice clean table clothes and nothing is sticky like some other dim sum places I've been. They've got the little ladies that push the carts around, with steamers and plates of yummy food. Definitely a good spot to stop for lunch while hanging out in Chinatown. We go after our kids have some play time at the Portsmouth Square playground, just a couple blocks away.
author: Cindy F.

description:
4.5 stars... when is Yelp going to allow us to do half stars?  Just a thought.

The word dim sum conjures up bizarre thoughts like loud carts, hole in the wall or large dining halls of huge family gatherings and a lot of little kids, loud noises, fried foods, egg custard tarts (not a fan), sesame covered fried mochi with adzuki inside (very good by the way), egg rolls galore...  Boy I really needed to get over this mindset and after this weekend I officially have.  I think I was traumatized when I was very young and that is why it created such negative thoughts in my head... my experience in LA was a bit overwhelming for me too.   

So I was kind of skeptical of dim sum... and no I'm not Chinese (Vinny) so I don't know everything about dim sum... in fact I've only been to dim sum 8 times in my life and 6 of those were at Yang Sink and that doesn't count in my book.  A good friend got a group of us to brunch over some dim sum and I kid you not my friends in the city have the most amazing palates (they are either chefs or cook better than most chefs naturally).  I trust what they select and I eat everything and anything but I was just not up for the Chicken Feet this particular morning.  I did sample the sauce that it was cooked in and it was spectacular and I could see how even chicken's feet would taste good in it.

My apologies I'm horrible with the Chinese names of dim sum, well Chinese food in general.  Ordering Chow Han all these years it was funny to see how many times Chow Fun would be in the take out box (flat thick rice noodles instead of friend rice).  Is that right?  A little help please.

Most Notable:
The pork buns (char sui?) not your typical ones in the fluffy chewy white dough (they had those too) but in a more tan pastry shell think Chinese Coconut Bread dough...?

Sesame Chicken ( of course with a dollop of the red chili paste on the table)

The usual Shrimp and Vegetables steamed and served in pot sticker form... can't go wrong.

And my Tsing Tao: just what I needed after 20 hours of straight drinking the day before.

Good:
Although the shrimp was smaller in size than most Walnut Shrimp that I've had in the past, it tasted great.

The steamed shrimp stuffed small shiitake mushrooms looked like something I would be addicted too... think shumai filling spooning a shiitake cap.  It was okay but served cold, it would have been nice heated.

Fried Tofu or Age-san served with stuffed Eggplant and Peppers (again this shrimp shumai like filling) looked delicious but was slightly deceiving.  I usually love the spicy and sweetness in dishes like sautéed Chinese Eggplant but I had a bite of one corner of the tofu.  It was good but not that sweet and spicy effect I was looking for.  And stuffing steamed shrimp fillers in too many dishes gets kind of old.

I didn't try the regular egg rolls but I did try their skinnier version their cousin.  Shrimp fried cigars... of course love all the dipping sauce, sweet & sour, hot sauce, a dash of soy and some vinegar (yes on the same plate).

The custard filled pastry-like thing was amazing.  Custard buns anyone?  Again reminded of Coconut Bread something we always picked up in Chinatown while I was growing up on our way home from Jr. Tennis Tournaments in Nor Cal. Which I competed in almost every weekend in the summer from age 10 to 16.

The Chicken Lettuce cups, had pine nuts, nice twist but even after I made 2 mini cups with my little filling it was still too salty for my liking.

Not So Much:
The sticky  rice in what looked to be a banana leaf but the chefs at the table said it wasn't.  I'm just not a fan of this rice that tends to take on the flavor of the leaf (which got our table in a heated brief discussion about grape leaves and Dolmas).  A bit too earthy and herbal for me... and awkward with the rice which tends to be sweet.  However, I did see a few sliced Chinese sausages hidden in there and I'm always game for a little sausage.  Heart Sausage!

The Chinese Broccoli  usually served parboiled and chilled with a sweet brown sauce.  I tend to love these more refreshing dishes but I was too stuffed and it came after our dessert (sweet dishes) and friends were telling me it was the greasiest plate that we had ordered all day.  Strange and not appetizing.

I hear their pan sautéed/fried noodle dish was good but we didn't see anyone carting that over to us during our visit, it's probably a special order item so next time I'll get that for sure.

My New Mindset - discovery, Chinese style tapas, sharing, Tsing Tao, clean atmosphere, friendly staff, cultural learning center, veggies (love the string beans at Yang Sink), 

So 25 plus plates and a dozen Tsing Taos later (there were 8 in our party) our bill was $210 with tip.   AMAZING and so RECESSION FRIENDLY! This bill would have easily been over $350 without tip at Yank Sing which is almost teetering on becoming my now 2nd favorite place to dimsum and yes that is a verb.
author: Shiho F.

description: What I value in a dimsum place isn't the decor or ambiance, but that the dimsum is good and cheap. The prices at City View make me feel like I'm paying for the nice decorations more than I am paying for the dimsum. Maybe it's just because I've been too used to grimey Oakland dimsum restaurants that charge you 7 bucks a head after eating a ton of xiu mai and shrimp dumplings but City View is definitely not at the top of my list.
author: Angelo T.

description:
I've been to this place probably 5 or more times and we have had a pretty decent meal but this time was different.

We were seated right away at about 11am but it took about 10 minutes before the first waiter came around to offer us some food. The shrimp tasted so bad my brother had to spit it out. To me it kind of tasted like beech. Everything we ate was cold as well. The quality of the food was very abysmal. Most of the food tasted pretty old. Everyone in our party had a major stomach ache later that afternoon. Need I say more...

I would have to say over the last two times I went to this place I could tell the quality was going down but I would have never expected it to be this bad. The total bill was over $115 for 4 people.

On another note we went to Ranch 99 just to pick up some groceries and I grabbed some Dim Sum to go. I could not believe how much better a grocery stores food was compared to a established restaurant.

What happened to this place :(
author: Ben B.

description:
Got there right before opening hours and the place filled up pretty quick. 

Everything was so delicious,  i love dim sum and it's not something i get in paris and wait to be states side to eat it. This place was much better than what im used to in Torrance, CA.

We ate at another chinese place the night before and here we ate way more for less.

Will go back soon hopefully!
author: Sylvie L.

description: Sis wanted some Dim Sum and wanted this place only. Drove around five times searching for a parking spot but didn't want to pay for a spot at the nearby garage (go figure but she can't walk that far). Finally got one a block away and walked to the restaurant and joined the line (when isn't there a line?) which didn't last 14mins. It was about 11-ish AM and though the place was packed, the tables were getting empty. I ordered mostly seafood (I see seafood and I eat it) while she kept to meats and others. Good was good and hot, served by the various women pushing their little carts. Parking is the worst problem for eating here and the little alley the restaurant is located at isn't the best, nor the cleanest, but still a good place to eat if you don't mind paying the price for the Dim Sum. (Wonders often about the name as there is NO view)
author: Tony L.

description:
The dim sum was OK and overpriced for what it was. None of the dim sum items stood out as being great. This was the closest sit down dim sum place I can find near Union Square. 

It is definitely not your typical dim sum place. It doesn't look like a Chinese restaurant inside and all the people serving dim sum were not pushing carts.
author: Linh R.

description:
For the third day of my husband's and my anniversary trip to San Francisco we wanted to sample dim sum.  Since we are dim sum newbies, we were looking for a place that was satisfying, cheap, and helpful to ignorant tourists such as ourselves.  This place was everything we were looking for!

Cute little carts chock full of tasty treats?  Check.
Endless amounts of food at less than $5 a dish?  Double check.
Clean, well kept dining room that sat us immediately on a Saturday afternoon? Check and mate.

We enjoyed every dish, although I was a little too eager with the sesame balls and coated my mouth with super hot sesame paste, which was quite painful, but my own fault.  If you are sitting near the kitchen, allow for cooling down time!

It was a great experience for we out-of-towners.  Check it out!
author: Brie K.

description:
Catered to tourists

My family was in SF for a day only and I wanted to try the dim sum here, we turned to yelp to help us find a place and came across city view. The food was mediocre at best, and I know dim sum. I grew up in Los Angeles near all the great Chinese restaurants. I really wanted to compare dim sum in SF to that back home. Unfortunately, this place was a complete let down. It was obvious the food was not freshly cooked and selection was rather small.  I should have known immediately as I stepped in and saw that everyone else was a tourist, like me. I don't think anyone there was a local. What really pissed me off was the price, nearly $40 for 7dishes. We had har gow, siu Mai, chicken feet, rice rolls with beef, two orders of steamed BBQ pork buns, and a deep fried taro dish. I liked the BBQ buns and taro dish the most, the rest was just okay.  
If you are in town and in for some okay tasting dim sum and want to pay twice the price, come here! Btw, there is no "city view" from this restaurant either.
author: A V.

description:
Just realized they charged for tea.

We always thought they just added gratuity.

Wrong.

Automatically lose one star from my last review.  I mean seriously, who the hell charges for tea!?!?
author: Vince S.

description:
When my sister said that So Cal had better Chinese food than SF, I sort of agreed but my opinion quickly changed after we ate here. I will give the place many stars based on their cleanliness but the flavor just wasn't hitting the spot for me. I thought it was some what over priced for dim sum and the portions are smaller than I what I'm used to. I will have to agree that SF Chinese is still better than Denver, but So Cal restaurants take the cake on this one!  

I do have one question though, what is with that lame baby spoon for the chili sauce????????????????????? Really? You give the table of 7 a little tiny jar of chili sauce that is 1/3 the size of a baby food jar and then give them a baby spoon to serve it with? I know Asians are obsessed with all things miniature, but this is ridiculous. It wasn't until our table polished off 3 jars of the stuff that they finally upgraded us to a bigger spoon. And when I say bigger spoon, I mean that we were upgraded to the ladle of miniature spoons which is about 1/8 tsp.
author: Yvonne C.

description:
This place has great, good quality food. It is my favorite dimsum in SF. 
Yeah there may be more "authentic" places or fancier places in SF, but none of them have the combination of price and quality this has. Yank Sing for example has a fancier ambiance but costs 3x as much and has worse service. This place doesn't have much street parking nearby but neither does yank sing. So I give this place 4 stars. It would be 5 if they had wifi.
author: Zachary H.

description: Not as good as Yank Sing, but also not as pricey.  Good variety of dim sum, and the carts come out pretty regularly.  The ambience is definitely nicer than your average Chinatown place.
author: B. Y.

description: This is a nice place but it is far too expensive for what it is. As a group of 12, we paid $20 each for a very simple lunch. I think there will be far better place with a lot cheaper prices especially for big groups.
author: Anonymous R.

description:
For freezy!  Yum!

Ok, so another free lunch yelp review. 

City View is cool as long as you have the most important thing: RESERVATIONS! Anyways went with some old friends to reconect and was not disappointed. They had lots of the main dim sum dishes that you expect to see and of course some favs of mine (peking duck and lettuce wraps). Service is good; the carts and waitress go around quite often and the remaining staff work hard to keep your tea filled on time. I've eaten here quite a few times and has always enjoyed my dining experience. Like i've said i've dined here before and would come back!
author: Julie F.

description:
Mmmmmmhhh.... Dim Sum....

Lucky for us, we had a table reserved for lunch as this place really gets busy. If you like dim sum, you will like this place. Everything tastes really good, especially the clam dumplings. 
Unfortunately we did not get any of the special dessert balls, even though we waited for 20 minutes. 
Nice place to bring out-of-towners.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
Fairly ordinary fare and a little pricey.
Ambience: Very busy but perhaps this was because it was Chinese NY. Mostly Chinese clientele which should be a good sign.
Service: Hit and miss. The hostess was rude and all but ignored everyone asking only to be put on her list. Meanwhile my actual waiters were very pleasant. The dim sum waiters could be lined up or non-existent for long periods at a time.
Food: Meh. Seeing all the Chinese here I was hopeful of something a little more out of the norm but it was your typical Americanized dim sum. Nothing more unusual than fried tofu. And mostly fairly bland in flavors too. The only memorable item was the Peking duck.
Price: Overpriced but probably due to being right in the financial district. Certainly way more than the prices for equally good fare in Chinatown (only a couple of blocks away). Of course, the place is also more spacious and cleaner than you'd find there.
Overall, it was not as good as I hoped upon seeing the long wait line.
author: Geoff A.

description: I have been here quite a few times now and all have been for work related functions.  I must say that I have not been disappointed in the quality of their food nor the amount of different choices they offer.  There are waiters and waitresses constantly walking past your table with many options to choose from.  If you work in the financial district or anywhere within walking distance, City View Restaurant is definitely a good choice for your dim sum craving.
author: Omar G.

description:
No trip into San Francisco is complete without a stop for some dim sum, in my humble opinion. I have eaten here several times with Stuart and the boys, and once, during the Moon Festival, we took Stuart's Godparents here. In other words, family is welcome here, and it's also fine for dining alone or with one other person, tho' really, the more the merrier when it comes to dim sum.

We strolled in and waddled out! It is so easy to go overboard here because everything is so fresh, looks small due to the steaming baskets...one thing leads to another, and before you know it, one more bite is not an option!

I am particularly fond of shu mai with shrimp, the pork buns, the pot stickers, the turnip cake, and several other dumplings. This time around I tasted pork & ginger dumplings that really set the bar up another notch! When in season, the soft-shelled crab is excellent here!

The room is big & cavernous and the name of the place was not meant to be ironic, but it is. There is no City 'view', unless you consider the HQ of the Method soap & cleaning products building truly view-worthy. No indeed, you will just have to look at your dim sum, your charming dining companions, or your own expanding waistline! 

Seriously, this is a great spot to enjoy some reasonably priced dim sum and try several new things. Very enjoyable!
author: Suzanne F.

description:
I can't guarantee they know what vegetarian means, but the vegetable dumplings (some filled with bamboo and mushroom, some filled with a green vegetable which I forget--maybe spinach?) tasted vegan, in addition to being incredibly fresh and cooked just right. (I asked the hostess if they had vegetarian dim sum, and she directed me to these). You can't go wrong with the bean paste filled sesame balls, either.

Though it was really crowded for lunch on a weekday, since there were only two of us we got seated pretty quick--no complaints about the service. 

Can't speak for all the veg / vegan options as the offerings always rotate, but as a vegan, I would come here again. If the idea of a little fish sauce in your food freaks you out, do your homework really thoroughly (or just avoid Chinese food in general).  We had some sauteed snow peas that tasted slightly fishy to me.  My favorite thing was actually some saucy eggplant and tofu--my friend ate the shrimp-stuffed bell pepper that came sitting on top. Again, if you are a squeamish veg, you might want to go elsewhere, but if you are like me, nostalgic for dim sum and not too worried about cross-contamination, this place might hit the spot.
author: Tamara F.

description:
Freshest, best quality, most variety dim sum in/near Chinatown I've found.

And they take reservations!

City View for FiDi/Chinatown.
Yank Sing for SOMA.
Ton Kiang for Richmond.
author: Melanie C.

description:
11/17/09
we got there around 1pm. we walked in and were seated right away. got water and a pot of tea. then came all the goodies!!! it was fun to wait for the cart to come by and ask what everything was and pick and choose what we wanted. the carts came by about every 5 - 8 minutes or so. everything was fresh and tasty. we had vegetable egg rolls, shanghai dumplings, pot stickers, spinach dumplings, mushroom dumplings, a big plate of shrimp, some kid of fried rice, and rice noodles wrapped around beef. I think that's all of it. we were stuffed. it was great that most of the girls let you know what was on the cart and explained it. if they didn't I asked and they were happy to explain. I thought it worked out well for us, as we were dim sum newbies! total was $41
author: Liza M.

description:
city view a misnomer...alleyway restaurant....surprisingly large scale..bi-level restaurant...interior clean....servers tidy....trek to the basement level restrooms.....

weekend dim sum brunch...large twenty-five party dining...tables reserved 'n' ready..no surprise for a slow starting day for city view....patrons arriving...sporadic...tricklin' in a few....tea drinkin' 'n' waitin'....servers showin' no sign of disappointment....

steam some dim sum!..hungry.....sparse carts...a pair?....mostly hand carried trays....servers slangin' small plate items.....found sticky rice good....yet..dumplin' items dry.....meat items cold....items seemingly off.....atleast beer to please.....
author: Hen A.

description: Food-wise, I think this is one of the better dim sum places around.  However, service is very slow, and the prices are a bit inflated compared to 'market' dim sum prices.  It gets a bit annoying but I was very hungry when I came, and left satisfied.
author: Josh Q.

description:
I don't get what it is about expensive dim sum. It's good. It's better then the run-of the mill hole in the wall place down Stockton, but is it $200 better? 

Uh - no. 

Granted - I have only come here with work so I can indulge without the guilt of paying $7 for 4 pork dumplings - but if you want cheap and good there are other places in the city that offer more buck for you dollar.
author: johanna a.

description:
I was in Hong Kong for thanksgiving this year and actually got a turkey.  (I'll get back to that.)  I also had some of the most amazing dim sum ever and came back with a craving.  Lucky for me, City View is literally half a block from my office. 

In Hong Kong, they call going to dim sum "yum cha" or literally "drink tea."  It is not just about the food but the entire experience and while City View is not quite as good as the places I tried in HK, I have to say it is doing its part to put the YUM in yum cha here in The City.

The tea is good and helps digestion.  The food that comes around (many in bamboo steamers) is pretty much all delicious and if you will excuse my butchering gwailo phonetic rendering, here are some of my favorites.  

Char siu bau - Steamed (or baked) sweet buns with roasted pork and onion filling.  Think I could live on these alone if I had to.  But I dont.  

Har gau - delicate steamed shrimp dumplings in a translucent skin.

Shao mai - small steamed pork dumplings in a thin wrapper and topped with crab roe.

Cheong fun - wide rice noodles that are steamed and rolled with a variety of fillings such as shrimp and then sometimes fried and sprinkled with sesame seeds or sweet sauce.  

There are many more that I love and many that I have no idea what they are or what they are called yet taste amazing.  But these all-stars should get you started.

As for getting the turkey in Hong Kong my only advice is this.  Start at 7-11, then head for the most famous alley there and continue drinking.  Then roll right up the middle of it - dont try anything too fancy or you may get the spins and end up in the gutter.  Stay focused and the pins basically fall by themselves.  Then repeat, and repeat and the turkey will present itself and you just have to feel thankful.  Chest beating and climbing tall buildings like you are King (of the) Kong is optional.

Happy Thanksgiving
author: Brad C.

description:
City View is my pick for best dim sum in the city. Tucked away on a little side street in the Financial district, City View seems to avoid the touristy crowds and lunchtime dim sum rush. The dishes are fresh with quite a variety of dishes. I particularly liked their scallop and shrimp dumplings, snap peas, and shrimp-stuffed mushrooms. Lots of choices for pork eaters and non-pork eaters like myself alike. 

Nothing's worse than being at a dim sum place where the "good" cart never seems to come around or runs out before it gets to you. Never a problem at City View. I've never had to wait long for that dish I was hankering for to come rolling out.

Bonus points: a most clean and delightful bathroom!
author: Megan K.

description: Went to City View restaurant last Saturday (9/6/14) which was when Chinatown was having their Autumn Moon festival. I don't know if it was because of the festival that they really had the dim sum pouring out. We were there for lunch and tons of options and were continuously being brought by. Had a few that I wasn't sure what they were - it was hard for us to understand some servers (all part of the fun). We never had dim sum before but it was all good to us. Don't know what a serving cost but the bill was a lot less than what we thought it might be. Atmosphere was good and would go again
author: Keith B.

description:
The food, while acceptable, is not spectacular.  Portions were much too small.  In fact, the shrimp dumpling size resembled the size of the ones you can buy frozen at the market.  

I'm a girl with a healthy appetite.  When I go out for dim sum, I expect to gorge in the greasy goodness, drink a whole lot of tea, and then carry my belly out.  

Instead, I left the table thinking about what a waste of $ the experience had been.  I was still hungry.  Service hadn't been all that great.  The wait had been long.  If I am going to have to wait in line to get a seat for dim sum, pay that much for that kind of service, and leave hungry, I might as well drag myself out to Daly City's Koi Palace.  Yes, I would rather drive all the way out there [It might actually be closer to where I live] and starve myself for the hour before seating than go to CV again.

The restaurant seemed to be geared towards the younger crowd.  It's not a difficult task, considering that the prices are quite high and this restaurant is also located where most would consider on the border of Chinatown.
author: Tinna H.

description:
I'm salivating...the dim sum here was SO GOOD!

I studied my Yelp very carefully. I was confused between Yank Sing and City view, which were the top two contenders of my SF dim sum experience. I know my dim sum in Seattle, so it was San Fran.'s turn.

City View won because it was cheap and walkable from Union Square. The restaurant itself was very spacious, despite it in an alley. Considering how many times we got lost during our stay in SF, we managed to find City View quite easily.

The food came out quickly and was great. Steamed bits, soup, egg rolls, peking duck, asparagus. All cooked perfectly and not soggy, or greasy. The bill was under 40 dollars and we walked out stuffed.

My only regret was we didn't get to try out our Mandarin.
author: A.J. S.

description:
I'm not a big fan of dim sum, being a vegetarian and all. BUT, this place had a surprisingly decent array of veggie options! 

Chinese broccoli, asparagus, mushroom pot stickers, rice noodles, veggie egg rolls are the dishes that I got. And then your usual dessert items: sesame balls, egg custard, etc. 

I thought I'd leave hungry, but to my surprise, I left stuffed! Everything veggie that I ate was very flavorful and fresh tasting. The service was attentive and fast. We were in and out of there in 1hour. 

Total bill $110 for a party of five.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Short review: 

For two of us, the bill was under $40, and we ate a boatload of food. Cost-effective, yes. And we could have taken some stuff home as well, if we weren't hopping on a plane shortly after. We had a lot of standard dim sum items like shumai and gyoza. They were good, sort of standard. The duck was tasty but, as duck usually is, a little greasy. I was thrilled for xiao long bao, and they did not disappoint. And what was even better was that you were able to eat them almost right away - the broth inside was hot but not molten lava hot like they usually seem to be. I wasn't a fan of the sesame balls, but I never am. The friend I was with thought they were fantastic though, so bonus points there. There were several other items she recognized from when she was younger and lived with her parents (she is Vietnamese), which was pretty cool. I'm extra white, so I just ate pretty much anything she put on the table. There were a few things we didn't get to, just out of sheer eating volume. Which... bummer... but hey, it'd make me want to come back.

We also arrived at 1030am so things were real fresh and hot. The carts also come around about every five to ten minutes, so there is minimal wait between choosing your next items.
author: Kate C.

description:
I don't get it, where's the view? Minus 1 star...Anyhoo, that is besides the point. 

We can here after a miserable, horrible, detestable, forgettable, regrettable, deplorable, lamentable, terrible, pitiable, abominable dinner at Straits (as recommended by someone who works in the hotel industry in the city) the night before - more on this restaurant later, if I deemed it even worthy of Yelp.

Had to call 411 for this place's address and phone number and when I got connected, was able to get a table reserved for 4 at 1130 on a Sunday morning. Hmmm...is a repeat of dinner waiting to happen? I mean, they take reservations, a dimsum place on a Sunday. 

Well, we got there and was seated promptly. Our table even had a "reserved" sign - plus 1 star. 

The place didn't look Chinese at all. I mean, it was bright, airy and clean. And no funky smell even. Really.  Did 411 give me the wrong restaurant?  No, I clearly remember the thick accent of the girl who answered the phone.  So, plus another star for that.

I'm glad that I had my Taiwanese friend with us and took charge of ordering.

Him:  "Do you eat chicken feet?"
Which I immediately retorted, "Do you eat balut?"

Case closed.

Anyways...he began motioning to those ladies with their carts and trays to come to our table.  And without warning,  he started speaking in tongues...Oh wait, it's only Chinese. Sorry, it's a Sunday, ya know?

As the food quickly started coming in no particular sequence, it was instantaneously devoured. Don't ask me what we got. To borrow some wise words from my fellow Caucasians, "they all look the same to me."

The thing is, I'm not particularly fond of Chinese food. Perhaps it's the oil, or maybe the spices, or perhaps the thought that it might be some random meat - don't take it against me, I also came from another Asian country. I actually enjoyed dimsum here. That's something. So, plus another star.

Before leaving, my Taiwanese friend seemed a bit flustered and giddy. He motioned with his lips for me to look behind...Lo and behold...there's the view.  Seated on the next table. 

And what a fucking view! Plus 1 more star.
author: Marco d.

description:
This was a suprisingly clean and delicious restaurant. We had the shrimp and chives dumplings, and bunch of other dumplings. Can't remember all the things we had, cause we ate soo much. 
Service was good. Really clean and a nice restaurant to take friends and family from out of town.
author: Shaheen L.

description: I don't know how this compares to dimsum in the city (I'm assuming Chinatown would have better options) but in comparison to dimsum places in Westminster/Irvine/Monterey Park, it definitely doesn't measure up. Our friend from SF took us here because it's in the Financial District and therefore, is a lot cleaner than other places, but usually when talking about dimsum, there's a negative correlation between taste and cleanliness...
author: Grace C.

description:
Hi, my name is Claire, I am a Dim Sum Aholic.  

Yes, it's true, I am addicted.  This place is freaking awesome, the women pushing around their huge vats of steaming pork buns, and shrimp rolls, and fried crab claws, and stuffed mushrooms.  It's like serious heaven for someone with the munchies.  This is the ultimate restaurant for out-of-towners that just can't believe their LUCK, at having such a wonderful, traditional meal, or your buddy who's sick of their work cubicle and need to inappropriately gorge themselves in an attempt to satisfy their dissatisfaction with life....uhmmmmmm, wait....
author: Claire C.

description: Closed at 2:30 Sunday, we arrived at 2:25, and they fed us plenty of delicious dim sum.  Commercial Avenue wasn't easy to spot, so keep your eyes peeled!  Clean, pleasant, large.  $53 + tip for 5 people to eat a light lunch.
author: Kim S.

description:
Here we are at no. 100... Oh the Yelp review memories... panties, prime rib, Wrigley Field (GO CUBS!!)... that fucking beeotch St. Valentines Day, sushi and all those other reviews in between... *grin* I've had a couple of other places that I could have reviewed this week, but I've been sandbagging for a bit so that I could have a five-starer in this spot.

Given my current level of hungover hell, one would think that having a positive experience in a loud-noisy dim sum restaurant with a group of Yelpers wouldn't be possiable.

They would be wrong.

So the occasion for this trip to City View was none other than our FABULOUS Ed M.'s b-day celebration.  It is the beginning of his birthday week and today's lunch was organized by the lovely d "half woman, half dim sum" d. for ELEVEN AM the morning after a DYL...  I was a little sketchy about being in good shape for this in the first place, but it was Ed and it was dim sum and I was like "yeah, what the fuck, I'll just be good and not get hammered at DYL..."

Ha-ha, right?
All y'all that saw me yesterday nite know what my level of drunk was.
H.A.M.M.E.R.E.D.
What does that spell?

That spells Kate K. waking up at 8:45 am and having the following running commentary (aloud) as she wanders clueless around her apartment trying to figure out what just happened:

"Oh shit, it's 8:45 am, I'm late to work!  Oh wait, it's a Saturday.  Oh, WTF?  Why am I still in my clothes and why is the heat turned all the way up to 90 degrees and the TV is still on?  Where is Matthew S.?  I'm going to kill him for leaving the front door open... oh wait, there's a text saying he's not coming home - I must have left the front door open... bad Kate.  WTF? Oh good god, my head hurts like bitch... SHIT today is the day I'm supposed to have dim sum for Ed's birthday!!!"

This is me about five minutes later:
Kate K. says:

Oh... man... I can barely life my head up.
What did you guys do to me last nite?

I don't think I"m going to make it... :(

This is Ed M. a few minutes after that:
Ed M. says:

Kate - no excuse.  Carla and Drue are coming, and if they can make it, so can you.

Sigh.
So I wander aimlessly around for about ten minutes trying to figure out what the hell I'm doing.

Then I call Drue C. to find out what time people are going.
Then I look on Yelp to see WHERE I have agreed to go... Oh, CITY VIEW - that's right by my apartment - sweet, I'm in good shape then.

So finally - after a brief freakout involving me not knowing where my keys were - I leave my Chinatown apartment to head to City View... I enter the restaurant to knowing looks from my Yelpie buddies...
