I actually have beaten Drue "I'm on the Wagon" C. and Carla "Hump Train" D. to the restaurant... swank, I'm so cool I'm not the last DYL drunk person there!

Ed and AJ give me a lovely tour of the dim sum set up and I dig in.
And, let me tell you LE YUM.
Seriously - I *always* go to the Richmond for my dim sum... I'm kind of picky that way... but, the Capital Restaurant?  Some seriously good dim sum - and, right by my apartment - how swank is that???

Despite having some issues with chopsticks due to "drunk shake" I was able to consume a wide variety of yummy-yummies... MMMM... !

Of course this whole experience was only made more awesome by the company... although laughing that hard made my head hurt worse than it did before...  It also cleared up some mysteries about what happened towards the end of the DYL... which is good... (Who made out with a bum?)  And, as always it was awesome to spend more time with my favorite group of Yelpers celebrating Ed "I'm more awesome than Arby's wrapped in bacon dipped in cheese sauce and deep fried" M.'s birthday...

Hope it made him feel loveED.
;)
author: Kate R.

description:
Really?  People think this is good dim sum?

Lack of variety...lack of flavor...and thus lack of stars in this review.

I can easily walk up a few more blocks into Chinatown to any hole-in-the-wall mom-and-pop dim sum cafe/bakery and get better dim sum than City View.
author: Liz C.

description:
This place wasn't bad. The food tasted pretty fresh, but it wasn't as expensive as everyone was making it out to be. 

My only complaint was the limited selection of food choices. They clearly withheld some of the more exotic things, like my precious chicken feet. Luckily I was able to request that.

Oh, and the carts hardly ever went by our table. I felt myself having to get someone's attention every time we wanted something.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Compared to the other $0.99 crap dimsum takeout in Chinatown these days, this place is the "better than nothing" choice for dimsum in the financial district and Chinatown area.

The place serves mediocre dimsum and yet is packed on most days during the lunch hours.

The staff speaks English to everyone all the time, which is very strange for a dimsum place. But other than that, they are very unattentive and rude. Some of them hardly bother to tell you what's in the cart when you wave them down.

So if you're stuck in the area and must have dimsum, than go to City View.
author: Tommy T.

description:
Came here for lunch today with my coworkers ...a total of 9 of us for dim sum today. It's a close walk from the financial district, and it was pretty packed when we got here. Luckily I called ahead and asked them if we came right now, if we could get a table..and they said yes! Of course this was at 11:20 am - otherwise we would have waited til 1pm for a reservation. It's kinda shabby looking on the outside, but when you walk inside its surprisingly pretty nice. Not bad for a chinese restaurant near chinatown! 

Quality of the food was pretty good..everything was fresh and hot. They had most of the staples you see in everyday dim sum places: shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, egg tarts, rice noodle roll, shanghai dumplings, etc. Although everything was good - its a little more Americanized for me. I like the dim sum places with more authentic dim sum: the chicken feet, the beef balls, the tripe, beef stew, etc. I guess they probably don't want to scare the non-chinese patrons off with that tho! Best thing about this is they have carts! I love ordering off carts!

The service here was pretty attentive..it probably helped that I was able to communicate with them in chinese. So we were able to get water, refill on tea, etc pretty quickly. Overall, not a bad place to come here to eat dim sum. A little pricier ($18 a head) than places I've been to - but its close to the fidi, so you pay for the ambiance and convenience.
author: Betty S.

description:
WTF?!  40 bucks for 7 dimsum dishes!  AND being Chinese- I am PISSED! 

i don't know why this place gets such good reviews cuz let me tell you, it ain't worth the hype.  first of all, the dimsum dishes were tiny.  second, there was not a lot of dimsum being circulated so my friend and i ended up getting whatever passed by and third....they were dry- YES folks DRY- it's sacrilege to bite into dry-ass siu mai.  

what kind of dimsum place doesn't have hot mustard on the table....a bad one.  seriously, if you're thinking of going to dimsum near Chinatown...make the extra effort, walk up the hill and go to any one of them IN Chinatown.  i am sure you can get a better and much tastier meal.
author: Thi T.

description:
As for dim sum downtown, I know of three choices: Canton House, Yank Sing, and City View.  Simply put, City View is the best of the three, and NOT the most expensive (that would be Yank Sing).

We went at 12:15, were seated in about 10 minutes, gorged ourselves on great dim sum, and left with pockets $23 lighter.   I couldn't ask for more from a dim sum restaurant.
author: joe b.

description:
Some of the best dim sum I have ever had. The selection is incredible in terms of what you can have, from the normal egg rolls to the extravagant walnut prawns; this i the only place that I know of that serves walnut prawns at dim sum. 

 I have been to this place three times, and every time I am amazed by the quality and the taste. So far this it the top dim sum for me. I have taken Asians as well as non Asians and they like it as well. 

It can be a tad bit of a wait though because they come highly recommended, though with a small group of 2 people, I got a table right away, versus a group of 6 who had a bit of a wait. 

This has become my special dim sum place. It is worth a trip to trek to and afterward, you can walk up to Chinatown and take a stroll. It is also a little bit on the pricey side, but well worth it.
author: Christopher C.

description:
The quality of the ingredients, the consistency and flavors made this the best dim sum I've ever eaten. 

Peking duck as a small plate? Delicious and unctuous with wonderful fresh buns. The best hargow ever with big pieces of fresh prawns. Crunchy gai lan. Tasty steamed pork buns with beautifully seasoned barbequed pork. Chicken in lettuce leaf stir-fried with pine nuts. Very good lo mai gai with a nice balance of sticky rice, chicken, lap cheong sausage. It all went well with good chrysanthemum tea.

Attractive, clean ambiance, helpful staff. $27 for a lot of food. Where has this place been all my life?
author: Pat L.

description:
City View Dim Sum, as everyone points out, has no view of anything whatsoever, which isn't much of an issue when you think about what's important for a dim sum restaurant.  As long as the food is good and the price is cheap and the service is fast, right?

Food was alright.  I can't name a single memorable thing I ate, but at the same time, I didn't taste anything gross either.  10 of us ordered a lot of food, which added up to about $20 a person before tips.  Not the cheapest lunch you can find around financial district/chinatown.  

The service is pretty fast and the bus boy filled our water very promptly.  But the seating is really awkward.  The tables are so close there are couple of seats that aren't "sittable" cuz there are people sitting directly behind them and there is simply no room.   Maybe that's part of the charm of dim sum, the crowd, the noise, the coziness, right?
author: Candice B.

description:
Wow, I am impressed! This place was nice, clean, good food, and decent service. I don't usually have dim sum in Chinatown, but my dining companions (who were out of town) wanted the "Chinatown" dim sum experience. I asked my friend to recommend a good, CLEAN place, and City View was suggested.

They serve their dim sum the traditional way with carts or hand held. So we were able to order whatever we wanted based on what was brought out. They had a really good selection of dumplings and other dishes. We were a party of 6, so we ordered a BUNCH of stuff. I really enjoyed all the steamed dumplings. They offered more than just the typical shrimp and dork dumplings, so that was a plus!

I highly recommend coming here if you're looking for good dim sum in Chinatown.
author: Denise L.

description:
I went there last weekend on Sunday, I have heard that this place would be really busy but we were luck enough got seat right away. 

For my experience, this place is just OK, the price wasn't remarkable and we were seated without asking if we wanted tea or water, but the server gave us a tea pot and Yes, it was on our bill. Kindda tricky, i don't mind to pay but this one we didn't order it. 

When we asked for fried rice , the server didn't bring it to our table and i thought she might not understand what we asked for anyway. For the taste is just ok, but i like some other place.

This place is big, it's good for a large party, but i suggest to make reservation before hit there.
author: Sasitorn O.

description:
Clean, fast, cart dim sum.
All the basics, but if you see it riding by, get it, because the selections kept changing.
Fancier than Great Eastern.  Maybe more accommodating to the FiDi suit wearing puppets that litter the place at lunch.
author: Kev M.

description:
I laugh at the name of this place for the sheer fact that it's on the ground floor of an alley way of a street.  Where the heck is the view?  The only windows in the place is the front from where you enter the restaurant.  I guess getting the view of the exterior wall of the building next door or the cars in the street is considered a good "city" view, but I envisioned something more.  Maybe I expect too much.

The restaurant itself is very nice inside, very clean and tidy.  However, for SF and the proximity this is to China Town, you could do a lot better when it comes to Dim Sum.  While run by Chinese, this is really catered to the American crowd and not your traditional Chinese experience.  Sure the food comes out in carts and all but the selection is thin, and the serving sizes are small.  I dunno, but unless you really know Dim Sum (and I'm amused at how many non-Chinese people classify themselves as 'experts') you're really getting ripped off here.

The egg tarts are the size of a quarter, the BBQ pork buns have a tablespoon of meat in them, the Har-Gow are no bigger than my thumb, and need I go on?  The taste was really light too, you needed a good amount of chili sauce and soy sauce to really get the flavors going.

Definitely more for the "Financial" sector.  not recommended for people that want REAL Dim Sum, especially within just walking distance away.  

(parking available in Portsmouth Square)
author: Yehoy L.

description:
great dimsum.  convenient location.  good diverse mix of diners.

get their early if you want the peking duck, baked pork buns and shanghai dumplings
author: nick g.

description:
I would like to start off by saying that I do not go to dim sum restaurants often, mainly because they are open only for lunch and on the weekends my husband and I love to eat at breakfast places.

But I will say that I can only compare city view to yang sing so I will use that as a starting point since yang sing is so well known.

What I like about city view is the fact that is was much cheaper than yang sing and not nearly as crowded. However, I found the choices to be less than yang sing and much oilier. I definitely yang sing is better but for the price it is reasonable. I am not sure if I would go again, for the reasons I mentioned above. Also, since I do not go very often, I think I may just stick with yang sing because if I am only going to eat dim sum occasionally, I might as well go to the best place in the city.
author: Kimberly H.

description: We picked this place after not being able to find parking in Chinatown this weekend (Chinese New Year).  Paid a bit more than we would have Chinatown, but we found the service and food to be very good.
author: Anne and Mike M.

description: My coworker introduced me to this secret hidden dim sum spot and we have since been there twice.  I really love this place!  It's clean, inviting, and the service is super quick.  The carts come out consistently even if the place is packed (which it usually is).  The location is kinda weird, in between the financial district and china town so you will see a lot of professionals dining here.  During the week the place gets extremely busy and youll have to wait 10-15 minutes.  Totally worth it though!  They offer everything in the dim sum family plus some random chinese dishes such as orange chicken.  This place is awesome if you're a first time dim sum goer as its not too dingy like some other Chinatown places.  Be prepared to pay about $15-20 per person which is a little steaper than some of the small shops in Chinatown.  But you won't be sorry!
author: Tiffany L.

description:
My white mom:  I'd like the Chicken Feet, please.

DimSumLady:  Uhhhhh Huh?

White Mom:  Chicken Feet. I'd like them.

DimSumLady: No no no - you like dis? You know what ?

White Mom: Yes I would like to try it please.

DimSumLady: No no no white wady.  No no tee hee teee hee hee

White Mom: GIVE ME THE GODDAMN CHICKEN FEET FOR FUCKS SAKE

DimSumLady: Ohhhhhhh .....  why you no say so first time?

And then my mom slurped and sucked on the chicken feet.

Meanwhile - the LL and I had all kinds of delicious other dim sums that did not include chicken feet.  City View is the best because it is so veddy crean and no sketchy.
author: Jerkey J.

description: We had some really good Dim Sum at City View.  I had wanted to go to Yank Sing, but my wife wanted to eat in the Chinatown area, so this is what we picked.  I think it was a really good choice, we had friends that ate at Yank Sing on the same trip and were really disappointed with the price.  They told us that after we recommended City View, then they went there later in the trip and the price was way less than 1/2 the price they paid at Yank Sing and the food was better, so we were glad they took our tip.  We had some regular items that you would have at a typical Chinese restaurant, as well as quite a few Dim Sum items.  The food was really good.  I would just recommend, getting smaller plates, so you can try more things.
author: Mauri F.

description: Decent Dim Sum place. Very busy, atmosphere is nice, mediocre tasting and way overpriced. I would not recommend this place unless you want to be fancy and eat bland food.
author: Kent N.

description: Went there for dim sum this afternoon...Fabulous!! Sorry they're not open at night!
author: Marina F.

description:
My friend took me here while I was in town so I don't have a comparison but it's one of her fav places to get dim sum.  The food was pretty good and pretty reasonable.

I love being able to eat small portions of many different foods  So this kind of place is perfect for me.  Wasn't sure what the majority of the stuff was, but it was all very tasty.
author: sara r.

description: Very clean restaurant with fast, efficient service. Carts came often with a huge selection of items. My favorite was eggplant and tofu dish and the pork steamed dumplings. Only issue was not being able to understand what the items were. We had one dish wrapped in grape leaves that was absolutely horrible, but no way to communicate that to the wait staff.
author: Henrietta L.

description:
Solid!

Last weekend was a treat.  Got to check some sweet bands at BFD, got to burn some of the fat that's been accumulating thanks to school, and got to confirm that City View is the best overall dim sum that I've been to in  SF.  That's a 3-for-3 weekend.

So why's City View my fave dim sum spot in the city?  Well the reasons are 3-fold.

1.  Tastiness.  I think this is the best tasting dim sum I would go to regularly living in / around SF.  Everything's fresh , the food's seasoned just enough (if it's too heavy, I start suspecting that they're trying to compensate for poor quality ingredients), and the dumpling skins are perfectly firm (sounds dirty, I know).  My friends rave over Koi Palace, but I don't recall being wowed by the food there, but maybe I need to give them another chance.  The other places I recall being really tasty are Ton Kiang and Mayflower, but it is a royal PAIN to park in the Richmond at prime dim sum hours; which brings me to point #2...

2.  FREE VALIDATED PARKING at Portsmouth Square garage.  It's essentially across the street from City View.  Compared with Koi Palace, with as packed as KP gets, at Portsmouth you can find find a spot there that's practically closer to CV than some of the spots in the lot at KP are.  The other benefit of the parking at CV is that you're not battling all the Po Po's for 40 parking spots in a restaurant that serves like 300 people.  I swear I almost ended up in the Circuit City lot once trying to park at KP.

3.  Space / reservations.  Yes, they take reservations at CV.  This allows you to find when there's an open spot for your party and text your buddies to arrive at 12:15 when your reservation time is actually at 12:30 because you know they'll be late anyways.  But at least they'll only be 15 minutes late b/c of the free validated parking instead of the usual 30 minute tardiness that they usually pull.  You know it's true.

So...we had all the standard dim sum fare.  Har gow, siu mai, pai gwat, etc.  All good.  CV is a little more pricey, but it's worth it.  Ordered a little more than we needed all for $17 pp.  So we probably could've gotten away with $15 pp.  Also, the place is clean and has a tasteful setting.

Magic ratings (out of 10):
Food: 8
Ambience: 7
Value: 10 (for the factors mentioned above)
author: J S.

description:
Ok, first of all, if you're going to name your restaurant "City View" I expect to see a city view.  Nope.  Should have guessed since Commercial is a freaking alley.

So this dim sum place is alright, but a lot of non Chinese people, which already means (to me) that it's more for tourists and Chinese people think it's a ripoff.  Part A is correct, obviously since it's like near Chinatown.  Part B is probably correct too, since you find the most Chinese people eating dim sum in Richmond where it's cheaper (except Ton Kiang). 

The food is alright though, I mean it's not horrible but their egg tarts were so tiny I put the whole thing in my mouth at once (not a good idea cuz the custard was hot).  Their chili sauce seemed spicier than other places though, which is good.  And they have real crab claw in the deep fried crab claw with the breaded shrimp (not just shrimp ball). 

The total cost for 7 people was 115$ before tip (and after calculating everything it ended up being like 20$/person).  Not that cheap for dim sum considering I love cheap dim sum places, you do the math.  For the people who don't think this place is expensive, you obviously haven't been to the cheap but still delicious dim sum places.
author: Yosie G.

description: City View has the best dim sum I have ever had.  Of course, I've only been to less than 10 dim sum places but CV is really good.  Their prices are a little higher than average but you can easily see that your extra bucks goes into quality.  The dining area was sorta upscale as well.  If you go, you should try to get there before noon.  I was there at 11:30 and the place was pretty dead except for 2 other customers.  Less than 30 minutes later, the place started jumpin and by the time we left, there were people waiting inside and out for a table.  It was packed!  They have a lot of choices and they were all good.  If you're in the neighborhood, give CV a try.  You won't be sorry.
author: Mike C.

description: Good dim sum, nothing special, located in the financial district.
author: J. G.

description: I will admit that theit dim sum is not as greasy as other places in the area, but nothing is really tasty enough for me to go back.  I'll admit that I'm not a dim sum expert, but I have had dim sum from terrible to superb in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Hong Kong.  I would rate this place as decent, but they seem a buck more expensive on each dish that similar places, so that knocks off a point.
author: Mike W.

description: Best dim sum ever! Service was a little lacking, we waited for a long time toward the end of our meal. There was a prawn with walnuts and some type of orange sauce. It was the best dim sum item I have ever eaten!
author: Donna H.

description:
I wouldn't dream of coming downtown on a weekend for dim sum.  I think most dim sum fans would agree that the best values for dim sum in the city are in the Inner Richmond.  However, when it is a Tuesday afternoon and you start craving dim sum - your options are somewhat limited.  In a nut shell, you can choose from: Yank Sing, Canton Dim Sum, or City View.

Accordingly, the only sensible way for me to review this place is by comparing it to Yank Sing and Canton Dim Sum.  In this regard, City View is "average" - which is actually a really good thing.

Of the three, Yank Sing is the most expensive (i.e. about $30+ for lunch) and Canton Dim Sum is the cheapest (i.e. about $12+ for lunch).  City View falls somewhere in the middle and will probably cost you a Hamilton.  

As for the quality, Yank Sing is probably the best (at least in my opinion).  Canton isn't bad - but is a little on the doughy side.  City View, on the other hand is a very close second to Yank Sing. 

As for the specifics: the shanghai dumplings (my favorite dim sum plate) are great here - and you should never visit either Yank Sing or City View without ordering them.  The pot stickers here may be my favorite pot stickers in the city (though I'm not really all that into pot stickers).  And, the lettuce wraps are really great.  On the bad side, their shrimp gau are not as good as the shrimp gau at Canton and Yank Sing.  All in all, everything is at least "pretty good" here though.

Oh, and as a side note - everything is pretty much served in threes here - which is great if you are in a group of three - but slightly annoying if you arrive in a group of four.  

Conclusion: City View is cheaper than Yank Sing and better than Canton Dim Sum.  Since I loathe spending a lot of money on lunch, Yank Sing is only for special occasions for me.  Canton Dim Sum is the cheapest, but for the occasional treat, I'm more than ok splurging the extra couple bucks to go to City View.  Sometimes being average can amount to being great.
author: Matthew H.

description:
The dim sum is generally good but overpriced. I would rather head to C-town for some dim sum that is just as good (if not better) and pay considerably less. The restaurant obviously caters to the people who work in the financial district. 

I suggest making reservations especially if you have a large party with you. The place gets pretty packed by 11:45am.
author: Joy A.

description: decent dim sum. a little "americanized" - I didn't see the chicken feet!! but the items we tried were solid.
author: Erica L.

description:
The food wasn't bad, but there wasn't much variety - it was the same things that kept getting circulated over and over again.  I was looking for BBQ pork buns, spareribs, and turnip cake - all things that are pretty typical for dim sum.  In two hours of eating there, these three items did not appear once.  When we asked for them and specifically requested the turnip cakes, we were told to wait 5 minutes - but they never appeared.

Some items came around every five minutes - the shu mai lady practically hovered around us.  And some other items came once and never came back - I should have grabbed them while I had the chance/1  I sent the dessert lady away and asked her to come back later when we actually wanted dessert, since she came by in the first fifteen minutes of our eating.  She never came back.

There were also servers carrying things that looked very interesting, but NEVER came by our table.

Pros - their egg custard tart is pretty good but pricey.  They also have this fried ball - with a savory filling in the middle.  It's similar in texture to the sesame balls popular at dim sum places, but not sweet. That was unique and tasty.  They also cleared empty plates from our table pretty fast.

Cons - poor variety in choices, cart rotation not consistent, EXPENSIVE (for dim sum, anyway - I'm used to paying $15 a person.  Our bill came out to about $25/person).

It was worth visiting to know that I will just go to my standby dim sum place, or in Chinatown, go to Great Eastern instead.
author: Mary M.

description:
I was surprised to find this brightly lit, clean and pretty good dim sum in borderline Financial District and Chinatown! 
I've heard many friends or Yelpers mentioned that this place is good and at a fraction of Yank Sing prices, this place is really not so bad. I called at 11:30am to secure a 12noon reservation and the owner was very nice and accomodating. It was busy but there was no huge lines compared to Koi Palace or Yank Sing.

Our out of towner guests liked the selection too and was also impressed that the place was clean and well lit and modern! We had a bunch of different dumplings, fun/rice rolls, spring rolls, dessert and all come up to $86 (not incl tips yet). 

Yes, we'll come back and also bring out of towners!

FYI: They validate 2 hour parking at the nearby Chinatown garage.
author: Yan M.

description:
I was not impressed by this place. The food was salty and greasy. Our server was never there and there was not a lot of selection to choose from. We only went to this place because I heard good reviews. Well, I ate here and probably will not be back. 

So, they will only get two stars. I don't know what for. I guess I'm being generous due to the Christmas season.
author: Kathy T.

description:
My go-to place in the city for authentic dimsum.  It's clean (almost elegant) and their dimsum is priced about 20-30% less than Yank Sing.  For standard dimsum (har gau, siu mai, chicken feet, cheong fun, etc.) City View is  actually better than Yank Sing.  I go to Yank Sing for the more unusual stuff and the shanghai dumplings, which are second to none.  

The dimsum at City View are fairly delicate - no fist size dumplings here.  The har gau and the beef cheong fun are especially good due to the well executed rice noodle "skin".  I also like the crispy sesame balls for dessert. 

The restaurant is fairly quiet for a dimsum place (could be because half of the clientele are non-Chinese) and the wait is not too long during the weekends.  Service seems to have gotten better.  I originally had issues with the hostess who was really good at ignoring diners but I haven't seen her around recently.  The owners are there fairly often which may be the reason for the improved service.
author: Anna S.

description: I have not had a bunch of great experiences with dim sum, but this one helped turn a corner on that for me. While there is virtually nothing healthy to choose from (save for an elusive plate of bok choi), when in "Rome" be prepared for a fried food feast!  The walnut prawns were a hands-down winner, as were all the steamed dumpling-type items.  Side note to all reviews here: You are never going to get nice/happy/pleasant service at a dim sum joint, especially by the cart pushers -- that's part of the deal so deal with it!
author: e w.

description: I will make some enemies writing a review about Cityview, because it is such a well kept secret. I love this place. It's got white table clothes, and specialty teas. The selection is varied. The seafood is fresh, as in, just-killed Asian fresh, not "defrosted from frozen" western fresh. The tables are big and round, and the prices are a compromise between Chinatown dim sum cafes and Yank Sing. The wait isn't bad, and they take reservations. Not like Koi Palace where there are 3 reservation lists and a lot of corruption, but a single list that they respect. Eat dim sum in style, and enjoy the food without having to chase it with a Pepsi afterwards.
author: Anna B.

description:
This was is a very strange Chinese restaurant. I came here my mom who really only spoke Chinese. The matre d' did not respond in Chinese when my Mom asked for a table. Some of the staff was uncaring and almost rude. I was almost tempted to suggest that we should try somewhere else.

Their lunch menu (for noodles, rice & stuff) was only in English and they didn't have any Chinese menu! I know, we asked. How does a Chinese restaurant not have Chinese on their menu?

The food was okay. Some good, some not so good. Dumpling wrappers were a little too thick on some of the dim sum we ordered. There was nothing spectacular to talk about regarding the flavor of all the dim sum and stir fry noodles we ordered. The dim sum selection was very limited to what I think of as safe for to the non-dim-sum going crowd of the financial district, and lacked some the tasty and common dim-sum items like chicken feet. Some of the meat used was not trimmed enough and had some tough sinue parts.

I wanted to give this a one star, but the average food quality saved it from that fate.
author: H L.

description: I used to work around the corner from here and came for lunch whenever I could sneak off for a good hour. It is usually crowded. It is not bad as it is pretty authentic, but the food is rather greasy. I am a huge fan of shanghai dumplings and the ones here are just ok ... they come in a little foil cup to catch the soup, which causes the skin to become sticky and the bottom of the dumpling to tear. Wah Wah.  I always feel rushed when I am here because of the crowds and the carts dont roll around to the tables when it gets busy. You have to be willing to do the leg work, as one would in Hong Kong, if you want to get all the dishes you want.
author: Candid K.

description:
Excellent dim sum in the FiDi/Chinatown area. The wait during peak times on weekdays can be long, so I recommend going when they open at 11am.  I've never been on a weekend, so I can't comment.

City View seems to have borrowed some of Yank Sing's sensibilities, and this is seen in how much of the clientele is not Chinese.  With that said, this restaurant has not made any concessions when it comes to traditional dim sum dishes.  Black bean sauce spareribs, phoenix talons, steamed BBQ pork buns...you name it....are available.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: I really like Chinese food and have been to China to eat their dim sum. So compared to this restaurant, it wasn't as good. Some of the dim sum with the shrimp in it was extremely over cooked and dry. Another thing was, this place was really expensive compared to other restaurants. If it is this expensive I would expect it to be SUPER GOOD, but it wasn't. :( (but I wish it was...)
author: Linda P.

description:
I may not be Chinese... But, I will tell you one thing, i know my asian cuisine. 

I have called myself a connoisseur of many different types of cuisine; Dim Sum, Pho, Burritos (wait). In any case, i know what I like out of a Dim Sum restaurant, and City View fulfills all requirements in my book. 

Lets talk quality of food. The food is always served hot, steaming, and fresh just how I like it. Flavors are top notch and the variety of different types of Dim Sum are amazing. My personal suggestion, Shanghai Dumpling. To die for, what you think i'm kidding? I'm serious!


Overall cleanliness and atmosphere, City View on the outside may not look like much since it is located in an Alley Way with homeless people sprinkled around the street. But let me tell you, once you get into City View it's clean, it's big, and it has bathrooms. 

Price and reliability, I have been to City View a countless number of times and every single time the food has been excellent and the price somehow never breaks $35 between two people. And the funny thing is, sometimes we go hungrier, so we eat more, and still $35 dollars. You've got to be kidding me! At Yank Sing, everything we ate at City View would have cost $80, no joke. 

I APPROVE CITY VIEW BIG TIME!
author: Eric T.

description: I really enjoyed my dim sum lunch here. There were none of those items that you lament ordering that you end up just picking at because they taste terrible. It's a white tablecloth place and the servers speak English, so the prices are higher and reflect this.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Pleasant, clean ambiance. Great service - carts were passing us all the time, we were never at a loss for food. Yummy chrysanthemum tea, that was always refilled whenever we needed. Delicious food - seafood shu-mei, pork buns, various dumplings and yummy sesame chicken - to name a few. It helped that one of our lunch companions spoke Mandarin, so we left a lot of the ordering to her. :) 

Yes, City View is "Americanized dim sum," but given my hesitation towards chicken feet, and my new fear of tripe, this was just fine with me. ;)
author: Sally M.

description:
Possibly the best dim sum I have had. Everything was quality, finely crafted and delicious. Even the chicken feet looked tasty...though I wouldn't touch those...it's goddamn feet. 

The place is clean, friendly and we were able to make reservations for New Years Day, the day before. This was great. Especially, if you have experienced the madness at places like Koi Palace on New Years Day.
author: Scott M.

description: This hit the spot.  My first dim sum experience in SF, it was exactly what I wanted. It tasted great and it was fresh.  We went fairly early in the morning, which I would suggest as it started to fill up when we were leaving.  When it was more empty, they walked around with treys, but the carts started rolling a little bit more often at the end of our meal.  Additionally, there was a guy who came around with a menu at the end. Because of these two factors, we missed the duck (we were WAY too full by the time it was coming around), which is something I really wanted. I don't dock the restaurant, however, since it was our timing and enormous appetite that filled us up with other delicious offerings.  A little bit on the expensive side, especially for dim sum, but overall it was a great sunday brunch.
author: Phil C.

description: Not bad ! Service was kinda shitty but what do u expect in chinatown. I went with my chinese friend and she ordered a bunch of stuff that I had no clue what they were, but they were all good. My fav were these stuffed crab leg things. Next dim sum joint I go to will be a hole in the wall just for kicks.
author: Mario W.

description: Friendly service if you compare with other places in Chinatown and the dim sum is excellent .
author: Tim B.

description: Great place, very affordable, plenty efficient on a Sunday at noon. Shanghai dumplings were not the best, but everything else was good.
author: Sam Z.

description:
Well, apparently this place is a great alternative to Yang Tze (?? - can't remember the name of the place downtown), and it was definitley packed when we arrived and seemed to have a nice mix of locals and tourists. Unfortunately, the food we tried was TERRIBLE. This could have been a combination of an untrained palate in the finer Cantonese cuisine, or perhaps just a general ignorance concerning dim sum as a whole, so I'm planning on coming here again with some of my Cantonese friends for another go.

Considered cheap for a dim sum place - depending on the type of dim sum the plates were $2 or $3, with more traditional plates going for $7 - $10.
author: Reman C.

description:
I'm relatively easy to please when it comes to dim sum.

Pork.  Buns.

Service was quick and getting in and out on a Saturday afternoon was relatively painless.
author: Jen I.

description:
On a recent trip to SF I took Yelpers' advice and came here for my Dim Sum fix.THANK YOU! 

Not only was this dim sum fantastic and cheap (at lunch anyway) the restaurant was FAR cleaner than any other dim sum restaurant I've ever seen. I could have gorged myself on BBQ pork buns but was tempted by a variety of unusual dumplings I haven't come across in my dim sum adventures. I was pleasantly surprised by almost everything I tasted (and you know how wrong you can go with dim sum).

Be sure to go early for lunch; I watched a huge crowd materialize to wait for seats. 

Myself and 2 grown men pigged out big time and still the bill only came to $40. Since hubby frowned on stealing the cooks, I'm making City View a regular stop when I'm in town.
author: Amanda W.

description:
By far the cleanest Dim Sum place I have been too in a long time!!!  Pristine white table cloths, clean push carts, clean dishes, and clean cups.

1 star - my friend speaks the language, it made everything easier

1 star - lots of variety of steamed dim sum choices, no fried stuffs please!!!  

1 star - I love shrimp, straight up har gow (shrimp dumpling), shrimp with greens, shrimp with cilantro, har chur fun (shrimp wrapped in those big chow fun type noodles), shrimp in eggplant.  Can you tell I love shrimp?

1 star - my friend told me she's having a baby!!! How cool is that?  Yeah, not food related but how cool is that?

Minus 1 star - By far one of the most expensive dim sum places at $20 a head.  

I mean I loved it when I used to go to dim sum places where it could be anywhere from 4 to 8 people and when you broke it down, it still came out to 11 bucks each!!!

Either way, it is a good clean yummy dim sum place to go to.  Bummer on the prices but you know, if you're in the FiDi and you got some $$$ then go for it!
author: Jenn A.

description: Well if my wife says its awesome.. it is.. for the price and the variety.. this place is awesome.. we have been to many dim sum places in the bay area... and this one ranks at the top.. plus it in the heart of San Francisco.. not many dim sum places are around there... if you are in town looking for dim sum.. this is definitely the place to go.. and the price is not outrageous like yank sing..
author: Kaio T.

description:
Overall, a good place. It's pricey, but it's good quality and it has a lot of variety. The decor is actually quite nice, and the place is spacious, clean, and has a lot of (real) plants. Service is quick and efficient. 
Probably going with a small group of people improves the price-quality ratio, especially if you like to try many things (for those who don't know, dim-sum features 3-4 units portions).
author: Sara P.

description: The pork siu mai was very good.  The soup dumplings were dry and disappointing.  The sticky rice was a little sweet for me, I like Yang Sing's much better.  They told me they did not have chile bean paste, which I missed.  The other dumplings I had were good.  But I will have to walk a little farther next time I crave dim sum, just to go to Yang Sing if for no other reason than their chile bean paste.  But, this place is cheaper than Yank Sing, which is a huge draw and reason enough for three stars.
author: Amber B.

description:
I can't complain about this place.  For Sunday brunch we wanted to eat dim sum and start the day.  We chose this place because it was a 10 minute walking distance from our hotel (Westin at the Market Place).  We arrive around 10:30 ish so I guess we got there before the rush because when it turned around 11 ish the room was pretty packed.  The place is overall clean and nicely decorated for the most part.

At first I thought they didn't have carts when I saw ladies walking around with dishes on trays, but I was wrong.  We just arrived early so the carts were just coming out.  We ordered a shu mai, shrimp dumpling, shrimp and chives, pork bun, stuffed mushrooms, fried crab claw, and a chicken dish.  All the dishes were good and didn't feel too greasy.  I loved the shrimp and chive dish and my husband thought the shu mai was presented nicely where it didn't seem like it was just stuffed together but they took the time to put the pork inside and place the shrimp on top for great presentation.  The pork buns were tasty with the dough part being very good and the flavor of the barbecue sauce being tasty.  I thought it could have had more pork in it.

Overall I had a good time here and I would come back if I'm in town.
author: Sharona R.

description: My favorite place to lunch in Financial District! Food is fresh and tasty. Love chicken feet and pekin duck and steamed dim sum!
author: Zarina M.

description:
Simply put - THE WORST dim sum I've ever had. Way overpriced, it was $70 for 3ppl. Their Sunday dim sum selection sucked - and I don't eat it, but what kind of place doesn't have chicken feet? Also the worst har gow and siu mai I've ever had. Siu mai were 4 ridiculously tiny pieces that also didn't taste good, I've had better frozen ones. Har gow was big but lousy and almost more garlic than shrimp inside. 
Service was also pretty slow and the timing of the carts and new dishes was really inconsistent. Wouldn't see the good carts for 20 minutes sometimes and the place isn't that big.
A friend brought us there because one in our party asked for a "clean place" without much of a wait - both bad things for dim sum. I didn't know about his stupid request until after the fact. Another indication of crappy Asian food - lots of white people (sorry haoles, but generally true!) Cityview was maybe 2/3 Asian? Unusual for dim sum joint on a Sunday in Vegas at least, maybe sf is different.
So this place was awful to me, but you may like it if you prefer more westernized asian food. I'm not saying the servers speak perfect English or anything, but they kept trying to push the sesame chicken and BBQ chicken skewers on us from their carts. Yup that's what they served at dim sum.... nuff said.
author: Nik O.

description:
yum yum dim SUM! I had never realized how Dim Sum is actually supposed to be served until I walked into City View. I'm embarrassed to admit it, but yeah, I asked for a menu :P

So don't do what I did, just sit down, relax and let the food come to you . . . cart, after cart, after cart. I can't give the best review since I don't know the many names of the delicate little dishes at City View, but I can say that the Siu Mai is great, the Taro specials are AMAZING and the regular standard Pork Buns arrive perfectly hot and steaming. 

I heard about this place from Co-workers and it really is the best dim sum place you can go to for the quality, price and atmosphere. Since then, anytime friends or family visit me at work, I take 'em to City View and they are impressed and full. But don't let the Dim Sum fool you, you might be hungry in a few hours. 

With great friends, it's a fun place but can add up. Make sure you know what you're ordering! The specials are more or less $6 a piece, so don't go crazy unless you want a fatty bill.

This is not one of your funk ass China Town places with 20% off coupons and "free" pot stickers. City View is an awesome place you will want to come back to.
author: katie k.

description:
We had a large group (15) here for lunch and found it to be a really nice restaurant but almost less authentic than the myriad dim sum places more in the heart of Chinatown. But that didn't keep the quality down, and unlike many of the other reviewers we had great service.

It almost feels like a hotel restaurant- a bit sterile (not that most large dim sum places don't have that feel) but tons of carts flying back and forth.

The food was quite good overall. Of particular note was the roast duck w/ plum sauce, the little pork buns wrapped in a triangle of flaky pastry and the har gow (shrimp in rice wrappers). I wasn't a huge fan of their siu mai (pork) but they were snatched up and chowed down pretty quickly, so maybe it was just me. 

Our group definitely seemed happier with City View (a misnomer, as they are on the first floor of a building in an alley?) than with New Asia, which is where we typically head for our dim sum fix. It was pretty expensive (@ $21 per person w/ tip) but overall definitely hit the dim sum spot. I'd give 'em 3.5 stars if it was possible. A solid, if not wildly inventive, choice.
author: Elizabeth E.

description:
I thought SF was known for their amazing dim sum? Well, clearly not City View. Props that it was pretty clean- however the service was ridiculously bad and the food? very very average- where some items were below average. Even the staples of dim sum were poor here.

Shao Mai- they tasted like they were previously frozen. Small in size and low in taste. yuck.

Shrimp Dumplings- the rice wrap outside of it was jelly-esque and the consistency was not good at all.

Sticky Chicken Rice Wrapped in Tea Leaves- small and lacked imagination.

Radish Cakes- cold and dry

Char Siu Bao- again, tasted like it was previously frozen.

In general, I had high expectations however I was only left was a high bill at the end. $20 per person for crappy food.

Not Recommended. LA has much better dim sum. Shocking.
author: Joel Y.

description:
I was craving dim sum and met my mom here for lunch.  The only good thing about the place was the location.  We waited over 20 minutes for a table for 2.  As I was waiting I saw at least 5 open tables that were never filled which pissed me off!

We sat down and started racking up the bill with small 2 bite plates.  The selection was so small we only picked about 5 different dishes.  I was disappointed with them all.  Half of them were cold and the other half were disgusting.  I wanted steamed pork buns (the reason for going to dim sum) and didn't even see a one.

The bill totaled to over 50 dollars and I wasn't even full or near satisfied.

DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY HERE, THIS PLACE IS AWFUL.
author: Kari R.

description:
The food is really good!
It is nice to see what you are going to order.
Since you pay by the number of plate you take, they always try to push you to take one more plate.
author: Jonas S.

description:
Wow, here's my first review. Hopefully the first of hundred's, or dozens...let's just hope I break double digits first..

Went down to City View yesterday morning with my friend Mike L/LA Yelper for dim sum with SF Yelpers. 

City View's has a fairly upscale ambiance. It's not as high-end as some of the other dim sum places in SF, but it's not nearly as loud and chaotic either. Good place for conversation and food.

When it comes to dim sum items, I'm a pretty straight-ahead guy, I like sao mai, har gow, and pai gou (yes, I probably misspelled, but I've always had trouble writing out Chinese or Cantonese in this case phonetically). City View does these basics very well. The other stuff was pretty good too.

This is definitely a good place to take people new to SF for dim sum. Although, City View's nestled on a little side street so it's a little hard to find the first time. Commercial Street's between Sacramento and Clay Just look for the big red banner of the Pacific Heritage Museum that's next door.
author: Mike L.

description: Very large open dim sum place with different pass arounds. Difficult to know what you're getting, but everything was pretty good.
author: Monika M.

description:
Are you serious? This place is catered to the white-collared crowd who pay $15 for a salad. They can charge $10 per dish and people would still go. The dim sum was average at best and the prices were outrageous.

There are many dim sum places here in the Bay Area that are more affordable. The taste is made for Americans. Most of the tables were filled with white people who came with their so-called Asian co-workers who think sweet and sour pork is tasty Chinese food.

This place is a rip off, go deeper into Chinatown and find yourself some real dim sum.
author: SF N.

description:
Bad food.
Bad service.
Dirty tablecloths.
Dirty silverware.
Loud.
Smelly.

Yeah, definitely give it a try.
author: Mekhala I.

description:
I recently realized I live in San Francisco and am Chinese (it was shocking), and unless I started trying out more dim sum places, I'd probably have to give up my Asian Card.  So I rounded up some friends, and decided to check this place on the recommendation of SFGate.com.

I really enjoyed it.  We were a party of 10, but they were able to seat us relatively quickly.  To be fair, I was late, so my friends did most of the waiting, but still it was no more than 20 minutes before our entire party was seated.  This being around noon on a Saturday, in Downtown Chinatown, for dim sum.  I was pretty impressed.

They actually put two groups of tables together to seat us, but the place itself had several large round tables (12-15 people) as well.  They were taken up by a birthday celebration (Note to self:  har gow and Tsingtao before noon, now that's a great birthday idea!), so this place is ideal for bringing a large group.

The food was really good.  We tried all the staples many times and some of the more adventurous items as well.  The only complaint I heard at the table was that the portions were small.  One friend kept calling them "dainty".  Certainly I've seen larger shui mai, but I didn't really mind.

Here's a tip for the more inexperienced dim sum-er.  If you are with a larger party that includes those who aren't as familiar with the concept, try to seat yourself close to the point of entry, so to speak.  This means if you're at a rectangular table, sit on the end towards the middle of the restaurant, or if at a round table, closest to where the carts come around.  This is key because usually you'll be tasked with the decision of yes/no each time the cart passes (a big responsibility, yes), but also you'll usually get first crack at whatever you order.  Also, when you pass something down the table, if it makes it back up to you, you can gun it guilt free.  (WIN!)  With great power, comes great responsibility.  But also great perks!

The service was really fast.  We were never at a shortage of food, and our tea was refilled as soon as we offset the lid.  Usually if a cart came by and ran out of what we wanted, we could make a special order that came within minutes, hot and fresh.

As for cost, it was a little pricey.  It came to be about $23/person including tip.  This is definitely going to be more than most dim sum places, but I also noted that we were ordering things left and right without regard, we had a bunch of soft drinks, and the place was clean, the service fast, the food delicious, so it was well worth it.

Would I go back?  Certainly, but I think I should try some other places first.  Definitely good to bring someone who hasn't had dim sum before and who probably won't go for metal pan, hole-in-the-wall joints.
author: Zhi Q.

description:
There are few things in life that are more enjoyable than sitting down to dim sum.  The carts come by, and the little steamer basket lids are removed, and you have the "voila!" moment of discovering what you're about to be served (or conversely, the moment of "ummm.... no thank you, I'm not entirely comfortable with the thousand-year-old egg concept, I am painfully white.")

While I was totally pleased with a handful of the dumplings and the peking duck/steamed bun combo, I really wasn't too stoked on the sui mai... which was, unfortunately, the bulk of what was being passed around.  They were pretty gluey, which is a trait they often have... it's just not for me.  I think I'm a sucker for wonton skins.

My other complaint was that I felt as though the distribution of carts circling the restaurant was pretty uneven, and I didn't see the variety of dishes that other parts of the dining room were seeing... which was something I learned as I was snaking through the tables on my way out... otherwise I probably would have simply asked the staff, all of whom were very nice.

Not the most economical or euphoric dim sum lunch expereince, but it will do in a pinch.
author: Laura F.

description: This is my go to dim-sum place in the city. Definitely a bit of a splurge, but it's worth it for the clean, friendly atmosphere. Typical dim-sum fare, but if you get a chance try the crab puffs...so good! Show up anytime on a sat/sun and will not have to wait more than 5 minutes. The staff is friendly and responsive...they also use walkie talkies to expedite specific requests. Check it out.
author: J S.

description: Excellent dim sum, delivered quickly!  Cheaper and, I think, better, than Yank Sing.
author: Mark H.

description: Tucked away in little Commercial street just off of Kearny is City View, a Chinatown restaurant which actually serves up great Chinese food. Dim sum is the thing at lunch time and you won't find sloppily made items passing off as true authentic Cantonese dim sum here. The lunch crowd between Mon and Fri flows steadily so don't be surprised if you have to wait for a table between noon and 1pm. Prices are slightly higher than your shoddy dim sum on Grant St, but definitely worth it. Still a great little secret for those not in the know.
author: Anita L.

description: Authentic dim sum with great quality ingredients. The restaurant is pretty clean too compared to other dim sum places. Would have been 5 stars but it is not that pricey!
author: Wayne T.

description:
Here is the deal.

It's a little bit of everything.  The wee bits of food is fresh and comes out fast.

Atmosphere:
It's clean and very white. The place is located down a little alley in the financial district which gives it a more authentic allure for it being pretty trendy.

Tips:
believe it or not, try to sit by the kitchen in the back. Normally I would never suggest this- but this is where the food comes out so you will be there first dibs on the best. 

Come in multiples of three. Each dish comes with an average of three pieces. If you are there with four, someone is going to be fighting for the last pork bun.

Pitfalls:
It's expensive. 

Yelpers!
author: Aaron A.

description:
This restaurant is tough to find since it's on a tiny side street but it's packed nonetheless which is a good sign.  I work around the corner but have only been here a couple of times - both times the food was tasty.

Came here yesterday with several co-workers and waited around 10-15 minutes for a table.  Special winner included the char shiu pastry and the always-popular steamed dumplings and the rolled up chow fun noodles - YUMMY.  The sesame balls were also very good.

Definitely would come here again.
author: Yuan W.

description:
This place is my go to place for dim sum on Sunday mornings. 

I usually go in a relatively large group, so sometimes we make a reservation and sometimes we just wing it. Usually we arrive a bit on the early side of the day so if there is a wait, it isn't too bad. 

For the price of the food, it is pretty tasty. They constantly have servers rolling through so you definitely will get food fast. They have so much variety as well that there is usually something for everybody. To be honest, I really have no complaints on this place and I will keep going back there for my dim sum cravings :)
author: Diana R.

description:
Pace yourself people! Pace yourself...

  I've eaten here a couple times and each time my friends and I eat too much too fast and then we see something yummy right as we sign our bill :(  I like the variety and the speed of service we receive here. Both times we have been seated quickly without waiting, our food is cooked well, and our water glasses are never empty. Compared to Gold Mountain, City View is less chaotic, has little to no wait, the food quality is a touch better, but may be a *bit* less authentic. Either way it's my preferred dim sum spot until some suggests otherwise ;)
author: chelsea b.

description:
We came here with some friends while they were in town for brunch. 

There were so many veggie choices, I was almost over-whelmed, and that never happens to me with Chinese! my all-time fav dish will always be sweet black bean steamed buns. mmm. We had both spinach and mushroom dumplings, plus the most tender asparagus stems in a sweet and savory sauce. 

The ambiance was minimalistic from what I can remember, and the energy was fast-paced. I will say it was clean. The waitstaff came to our table frequently to replenish our lazy susan with gooey dumplings and fresh veggies. 

the location is strange (downtownish) and there definitely isn't any city view, but the food sure was good.
author: Amber K.

description:
I'm quite ecstatic to have found a decent dim sum joint in SF Chinatown.. (I know, how ironic, but the fact of the matter is...Chinatown does NOT have great food...just lots of tourist traps and random knick knacks and souvenirs.)

And this spot is much cleaner than your average Chinatown place, too... I don't mind the hole-in-the-walls, but for those of you who do...then you'll feel fine going here.


City View has some good dim sum.... my favorite (actually at most dim sum restaurants) is BBQ Pork or Shrimp "Churng Fun". (Chow Fun Rolls.)

Not too expensive either... about $10-$12 per person, I'd say.

I'd definitely go here again!
author: Jennie L.

description:
Dim Sum? How about Dim YUM!

(it's probably been used before, but hahaha!!! anyway)

I am in full agreement with my fellow Yelpers: Great dim sum, not cheap ($30 for two people), and clean. I arrived around 12:30 and my friend and I were seated right away. The only "problem" was that he was hungry and in a hurry, so we ordered the first things we saw instead of waiting for the more interesting stuff, which means we absolutely have to go back.
author: J-Meoww W.

description: I think I may make this a monthly brunch for me and I will have to travel from the East Bay.  I've gone twice in the one last month and the food was consistent, hot, and fresh.  They have the Shanghai dumplings - broth inside the dumpling.  The mixture of cliental (non-Chinese) and Chinese locals means the food is good.  I haven't experience the wait lines as described.  The first time I went - we had a party of 9 and called ahead to reserve a table.  The second time I went - we had a party of three and got right in.  Oakland Chinatown does not have as good dim sum but may be slightly cheaper.
author: Gilbert D.

description: I am a bit disappointed at this place.  There is always a line during lunch hour and I thought it must be really good, which is not true... This is just too touristy, I've had much better dim sum in inner sunset area.
author: Karen Z.

description:
This is a decent dim sum place.  It's clean and in a convenient location if you live in SF.  Most of the dim sum items are pretty tasty and highly recommended --char sui baos, shu mais, luo bo gaos, xia jiaos (especially the cilantro-shrimp ones).  

The xiao long baos weren't very good at all though.  The dumpling wrappings were thick and chewy, and the filling didn't have much soup.  The usual burst of juice upon biting into one of these suckers was missing.   I love xiao long baos, so this was a big problem.  

The service on a Sunday is pretty slow and sparse too, at least when I went (around 10:30AM).  Only 1 cart was circling around the first 20 minutes we were there.
author: chewy c.

description: Another place that is just Yumm-O.....I love love love dim sum and this place is great....only open for the lunch hour and it gets packed quick. Don't get there when the doors open cuz the food isn't quite ready...I'd say wait an hour then RUN there! heehee...but it's really good, not greasy and decent prices.
author: Rita J.

description: Service is pretty good, we were seated pretty fast on a Saturday morning. The food is a little pricey and I've tested better dim sum elsewhere too. We ordered xiao lung bao, har gao, veggies, and other regular dim sum food, but I have to say the veggies tasted the best of everything.  Would come back again to try something else next time.
author: Ruo Yuan L.

description: Hands down the best dim sum I've had in SF, and really good value for the money.  Service is fast and friendly, and the place is large enough that you rarely have to wait very long for a table.  The pork buns and sesame balls are among the best I've ever had .
author: Shruti Y.

description:
Let me start out by saying I am not a huge Dim Sum fan. The biggest reason for that is everything is the same just wrapped up in a different package. How many times can I eat shrimp in one sitting but prepared a different way. 

Everyone at the table seemed to enjoy what they were eating. And from some of the big Dim Sum fans this was a great place. There were eleven of us ordering left and right and each person walked away with no more than $22 in damages to their wallet. Now that is recession proof! 

The place appeared clean, the food was fast, it was no frills. My only complaint was the chair I was sitting in kept getting bumped by the DIM SUM cart...watch where you are going...and  please stay out from behind the wheel of a car.

See their clean score: 
http://www.cleanscores.com/rest-168483-City-View-Restaurant-San-Francisco
author: Scott P.

description:
While the food is very good, if it is crowded, and you happen not to be Asian, good luck trying to even get the hostess to take your name down, much less give you a table.  We stood for almost 10 minutes with her never returning to the host stand, finally she walks past and I ask, "Can I put my name down on the list?"  She stares at me for a few seconds, doesn't answer, turns around and walks away.  When she comes back, another guys on the other side of the crowd away from the host stand asks to put his name down and she takes it before taking ours.  She seemed totally overwhelmed, and was not qualified to be a hostess.

SO RUDE!
author: Steve B.

description: Underwhelming.  Disappointing.  Not many options if you don't like pork.  Couldn't believe lunch here was $40 or $45 for two people and I still felt hungry because all I'd really had was tea, a few bites of chicken, and a sesame ball.  Will try other places rather than going back here.
author: Molly P.

description: DELICIOUS! They had all my favorites - steamed (& baked) BBQ pork buns, Chinese broccoli, shu mai, and other classics and they even give you Peking duck in pieces!  I even now have some new ones I love. Their dumplings are really delicious w/ a kick of ginger and I love how often the carts come by. The place is CLEAN and efficient - just wish they also sold boba or thai iced tea or something. Perfect for lunch since you don't have to wait for your food to be made. Go by Noon and you will be in and out of there - any later and the place fills up.
author: Barndi K.

description: Was not too greasy or salty.  I didn't feel BLEH after eating here which happen a lot of times after Dim Sum.  The Har Gow and Shu Mai were both excellent.  They didn't put on too hard a sell like some places do.  Price was reasonable at $15 a person for lunch.  Liked the fried rice noodles very much too.  Clean setting and lots of light in the upstairs; a nice plus over Pearl City.
author: Marc S.

description: Came here with 6 other colleagues for a late lunch on Friday.  The dim sum was average and full of MSG since I could feel my lips and tongue getting heavy/numb (my personal indicator that msg is in the food).  The waiter we had was pretty bad which no care for anything it seemed like.  He dropped a few things on my bag which was in the empty chair next to me and knocked my glasses off the table without saying sorry or picking them up.  My colleagues ordered the crispy noodles at the beginning when we got there and they never came. He wrote it down and put the order on our ticket but never turned it in.  $110 without tip for 7 of us.
author: Bling L.

description:
So many delicious items, so little time and not enough room in my stomach!  I was amazed about how clean this restaurant was and how attentive the service was.  We were served immediately and had dim sum carts coming by like whoa!  

Honestly, I don't even know the specifics of what I ate.  I just pointed and said okay and was pleasantly surprised every time.  I do remember that the duck rolls were so yummy and flavorful.  I went a second time and didn't get to experience those so it was sad.

However, for having been two times, I have been happy, full and content upon my exit.  I would defiantly come back again for some more flavorful items and another good time!
author: Cara D.

description: My boyfriend and I went to brunch with a friend today. It was my first time there, and I have only ever been to dim sum at Mayflower, so I wasn't sure what to expect. We got there at 11am on a Sunday. The place was pretty packed, but we were able to get a table without a wait, which was great. We had a choice of tea, and our friend picked one for us, which was great. Overall the service was excellent. The waitresses all spoke English and Mandarin, which was nice for those that don't speak Chinese. There was a very large selection of items to choose from. We had a lot of different types of dumplings, some meat choices and some vegetarian options. I thought the food was pretty good. Dim sum is never very cheap, but I can say that the prices are decent. I took one star off because the restaurant does not offer any validated option (that I know of) for parking.
author: Steph G.

description:
We had many out of town relatives to host after my brother's wedding reception on Saturday. Dim sum was the choice for Sunday Brunch. Weeks ahead, we called Ton Kiang who said, "yes we can accomodate a group of 35 but only at 2pm. Defeated, my sister-in-law was hoping for an early lunch so that her family, in town from Tokyo, could spend the rest of the day sightseeing. And so, thanks to you yelpers, I found City View. And thanks to Vincent and the City View staff, my hungry, loud and boisterous extended family  of 35 had a wonderful experience at 11:30am on Sunday. Vincent came around twice to ask if everything was going alright and if we needed anything. 

A little embarrassed that my Dim Sum vocabulary is limited to "Har Gow and Siu Mai" that I can't articulate my favorites beyond the snap peas, Peking Duck or the crisp Chinese Broccoli or the "fat noodle with shrimp in it" or "the one that is baked with a little bit of curry on the outside and char siu inside". This is where the bf comes in handy - he orders for us.

Additional bonus: parking is validated for the first two hours at the Portsmouth garage and it is right around the corner. Easy to drop off the older parents and kiddies before parking.

Highly recommended for large groups. Ask for Vincent, he was so helpful and friendly.
author: Theda E.

description:
I worked in the financial district area for 4 years before discovering City View and only when I was training a new employing and making my way out of working in SF!! Its tucked away in an alley on the border of the financial district and china town.

Its not cheap, not expensive but priced to match the quality and service you get. If you don't see what you want on the carts, just ask. They are usually accommodating.  

This is my go to place for dim sum. I bring everyone there.
author: Roseabelle M.

description: Good dim sum, good value, and good service. Food was ok, not the greatest but certainly solid. Can be slow sometimes in terms of variety of foods which is why it doesnt get  a higher rating.
author: Stephen R.

description: A great restaurant that has easily been overlooked. The special here is their dim sum. Great service and friendly staff. Parking is not a problem either because you get validated for 2 hrs. For 5 people the damage was minimal too so this place fits the QARP (Quality at reasonable price) bill.
author: Jafar Amir Hanovic Ismailov M.

description:
after getting food poisoning at an unnamed dim sum restaurant on 16th i had sworn off the little buns, but i was convinced of the quality and tastitude of City View by coworkers and we decided it would be our year of the rat lunch celebration.

City view which does not in face have a city view, lived up to their word, with cart after cart of steaming morsels 

the waitstaff can be a little awkward as they ply you with unidentifiable buns and wontons, i was happy to find a fine selection of veggie offerings, including a plate of various braised fake meats, veggie buns, and asian greens.

leaving an hour or so later with lighter wallets we were all quit happy.
author: Jared Z.

description:
City View's dim sum was good but not the best the city can offer. I'm on the hunt for the very best so sadly, City View doesn't make the cut. Being off the beaten path in the financial district, on the one hand, it's nice and quiet, but on the other hand, it feels a little too upscale for dim sum. I didn't get the sense that the hardcore local chinese go there. Also, the bill came out to be surprisingly on the high side. I think it came out to about $20-30 each. I just returned from having dim sum at Gold Mountain and we each paid $12. That review is coming up next! Based on the ambiance and price, City View is similar to Ton Kiang in the Richmond and I prefer Ton Kiang.

Highlights: bau, don tart, har gau
Lowlights: mango pudding
author: Susan L.

description: Great food. Very clean. Linen service. Fresh sesame balls.  A+  This is not on a major strip - you'll have to duck down a side street to find it, bring your map!
author: Tom K.

description: Pretty decent dim sum. Not the best I've had but it's probably the best sit down dim sum you'll be able to get in Chinatown/the city. The service sucked even for a Chinese place. Good pork buns, good taro cake, good sesame balls, good chicken feet. The only thing we didn't like was the pork ribs. Our large party didn't have to wait too terribly long which was a plus.
author: Heather U.

description:
3.5 stars.

I came back here today after craving dim sum for more than a year. Sunday at 12:30, super crowded, but our party of 2 got seated within 10 minutes. Sweet!

When I think of San Francisco Dim Sum, this is the place I go to. The food is really pretty good, but I have to mention that I don't know that many dim sum places and don't eat it often. But City View is still one of the best I've tried.

Anyhow, service was quick and most of the cart people were very friendly. The chive balls were really freaking good, except they were greasier than usual. Actually everything seemed a little greasier than usual. And the most disappointing thing (and the main reason why I've lowered my rating) was that most of our dishes came out cold!!!!!!!! Cold dim sum is a sin!!!!!!!!!!!!

I'll give them credit that the steamed stuff came out hot, which was very good. And all in all, flavor was as good as I remembered. I just can't get over eating a bowl of warm/almost cold sticky rice, fried crab balls, chive balls, etc. I absolutely hate cold food.

Oh yeah, I asked if they had congee...they don't!!!!!!!! SUPER SADFACE!!!

Our bill came out to $40 (plus tip), and we got about 7 plates. I don't mind the price because I don't know if dim sum can be cheaper and have great taste/quality. 

All in all, this will still be my dim sum place to got to in the city until someone directs me to another place. I like this place; it brings back really good childhood memories of when my mom used to take us on SF trips to eat dim sum in Chinatown. Maybe they were just off today.
author: Angela H.

description: I always look forward to a trip centered around going to City View.  The food is always good and the service is fast.  This time through we took it upon ourselves to order select dishes and found that one of the wait staff catered to our requests without issue.  This was a real improvement from having waited for various plates to emerge from the kitchen...  My only advice is to sit as close to the kitchen door as possible and don't blink because your favorite dish could pass you by!
author: Brian D.

description: whenever i'm homesick i come here and eat my little chinese heart out. with my parents of course so that they can pay the slightly pricey dim sum. love their "ha cherng fun, cha sew go, cha sew bow, baw law nai wong bow" yahhhhhh. always order their mango pudding right when you get there. haha. generally by the time my family and i are done eating they sell out ! their "dan taat" is good too! and crispy donut thing! and i love how clean the place is. i don't know about you but it makes me feel like i can just eat and not worry about dirt or what not! but i've officially decided every family has their "go to " place for dim sum. this place just happens to be mine!!
author: Kayla O.

description:
City VIew is a dim sum restaurant that is located in between the Financial District and Chinatown on Commercial Street. I was first introduced to City View by my aunt who works in the Embarcadero Center complex. Decided to head there for lunch today as it's been while since I've had dim sum. 

This place is only open for dim sum and I would say they cater to the business folks. Don't be fooled though while they do cater to business folks the prices aren't that ridiculous. The staff is friendly and they are quick when it comes to making sure your table is clear of empty plates. The assortment is good and the food is fresh. If you're afraid of any language barrier don't be worried as the staff seemed quite proficient in English. 

Overall a very yummy place to enjoy dim sum in the Financial District at a reasonable price.
author: Kevin L.

description:
First off, let me make something clear...I love dim sum...So I am kind of a snob when it comes to quality and variety. My friends took me here, as a cheaper MUCH BETTER alternative than Yank Sing. It was good, left me full and craving more for the rest of the day :)
Nothing special, just your average busy dim sum place...There was a line out the door of people waiting when we finished and the place was packed! Call and see if they take reservations first, or get there fairly early.
author: Jarrod R.

description:
City View was great, the second best dim sum I have had in SF proper and better than any other in Chinatown.  Superior to Yank Sing and half the price.

Run to Commercial street, take everything off of the carts you can fit on your table, devour it all and leave fat and happy.
author: Aaron T.

description:
City View doesn't actually have a city view. It has a view of a shitty alley.  If you came here for the view, you'll have to get past that if you want to enjoy your dim sum.

There's a lot of space in this place, but it's still usually jam packed on a weekend around noon. It's hidden enough that tourists don't seem to find it, but it seems to be pretty popular anyway. They keep it nice and clean too. I ease in here every Sunday to get my char siu bao on and whatever morsels happen to come by on the carts that week. 

The staff is pretty friendly and usually expedient. The prices are the best around for the quality you get. Yank Sing is the only place I've tried in the city that gives CV a run for their yuan, but it's prohibitively expensive and actually falls short of CV on a few dishes (except maybe chicken feet. I can't really say for sure cause I won't eat those shits. They look like mushy dragon talons. Why anyone would eat chicken feet when pork buns are an option is beyond me?! Some people act like you're a dim sum poseur unless you've had them. Like you aren't hardcore enough. These are stupid people that were tricked into eating them by someone else and can only regain their self esteem by eroding yours. Don't listen to them. If you ignore the chicken feet, the accusers will not let you hear the end of it, but rest assured...inside they are crying.) 

Pro tip: If you are lucky enough to get approached by a cart jockey with those little bamboo buckets of warm, layered Tofu and sugar water (tofu-fa i think it's called?), jump on it. It's nummy.
author: Gabe M.

description:
Fellow Yelper Dana B. & I got our dim sum on at City View one fine Friday lunch hour.  We were not disappointed at all.  The restaurant is super clean, the dim sum is delish (the honey walnut prawns are like crack), & the servers clear your dishes away quickly so your table can hold more yummy goodness.

This place definitely caters to the FiDi crowd, but it would also be an excellent place to take people who are dim sum virgins.  The quality of the food is excellent & the prices aren't completely outrageous.
author: Jenny M.

description:
This is a very good dim sum stop for people who want a clean place to dine, with friendly wait staff and reasonable prices.  Having grown up in the Bay Area and having dim sum at the various dim sum sum houses around Chinatown, I would have to say this one ranks as one of my favorites.  

I usually bring my friends here who are apprehensive about many of the traditional down and dirty dim sum houses.  In the years that I've been coming here, I've noticed that if my friends who like Yand Sing a lot, love this place because it's a little more authentic, but half the price of Yank Sing.  My Chinese friends who grew up with the weekly dim sum experience at the massive Chinatown dim sum restaurants are usually not impressed with this place because it is more expensive (but the quality of the ingredients is better) and it's too clean.  

I like this place a lot because:
  * It's reasonably priced for the quality of dim sum
  * Their sesame balls are delightful
  * Baked pork buns are fantastic
  * Rice noodle rolls are making my mouth water
  * Peking duck usually fills my craving
author: Rod C.

description:
The morning after our friends' wedding, we rolled over to City View to soak up the alcohol in our bellies. Never having been here, I was unpleasantly surprised. We ordered pretty standard dim sum fare-

- shrimp dumpling, spare rib, bbq pork buns, eggplant w/ fried stuffed tofu, long noodle with beef (tsang fen (sp??), siu-mai, etc etc.

I've had a lot better better dim sum in my life time, and honestly for the price these guys charge, it should have been a million times better. Flavors were okay..., but really nothing mind blowing, just so-so.

The one really sore spot was the push cart servers. It may have been a simple mistake, but it really ruined lunch for me as I had to double check the notation for what was being charged everytime. On the second pass of the cart, we ordered 2 dishes and the woman marked down two dishes, hesitated for a minute, looked around and then marked a third and walked off. I was a little shocked that she did that right in front of me and I asked someone to grab her back and explain why we got charged for an extra dish. The offender had an incredulous look for a few minutes and then switched to the "I got my hand caught in the cookie jar" look. The other server apologized about a million times and said she would only count 1 of the next two dishes we got just to even things out. She put down the next set of shrimp dumpling as a "large dish" and didn't stamp the siu mai, and now we were even. 

At this point I don't know if I can trust anybody, are siu mai and shrimp dumpling considered "large dishes?". Other comparable dumplings were subsequently counted as "medium dishes". Not feeling like arguing over $0.50 a dish, I let it go. But the whole ordeal f-ed up lunch as instead of enjoying it, we were all trying to determine if someone was trying to pull a fast one on us. Could have been an honest mistake, but.. if you saw the look on the woman's face...

3 for food. 1 for service. Annoyed. Going to steer elsewhere next time I'm in the financial district.
author: Stephen W.

description: Went here for lunch with a large group. I was eager to try it after eating at Yank Sing and overall, I enjoyed City View more.  Food wise, I thought it was comparable if not better and it was much cheaper. They also had the beef and shrimp flat rice noodle which I was not able to get at Yank Sing!
