It was crowded for lunch but with reservations we were able to get seated right away. Service was not consistent, otherwise nothing too terrible to complain about.
author: Amy N.

description:
Clean and convenient, City View was a great place for an impromptu dim sum lunch.  The food was average (hence the three-star rating), but when you're hankering for some dumplings, it does hit the spot.  

We arrived right at noon on a Wednesday, and the restaurant quickly filled up, so I would advise getting there early.  The prices were reasonable and we were in and out within 40 minutes.
author: Marcus C.

description:
Clean and bright, this is a great spot for dim sum.

We rolled in on a Sunday at about 10:30, thinking that we were going to be the only two people in the joint, but we were surprised at the crowd so early.

All of the dim sum is tasty and fresh, the servers are helpful and sweet.  

Park in the Chinatown garage and get validated for free parking.
author: Tony A.

description:
Whenever we're in SF, this is the place we go to for dim sum! Coming from L.A. where dim sum is plentiful in Chinatown or Alhambra, this place ranks as my favorite places to eat dim sum. 

There are new, modern food that I've eaten here and never eaten elsewhere. Everything is super good! The place is also very clean, spacious and inviting.

I'm also trying to find the best xiao long bao. The tastiest wonton-like-dumpling with soup inside! The best I've had is in New York  Chinatown - Joe's. The xiao long bao in City View is, so far, my second favorite!
author: Leah B.

description:
*Best Hangover Place*

Everyone thinks that City View is their little secret but when you go you relize the secret is out. It is great dim sum- clean, good service (Vera is the best) and you are in and out quick. 

Hard to park around there but worth the circles around the block.
author: Paige B.

description:
Very fancy dim sum! Everything I tried was fabulous and the place is quite elegant and spotless.

Great choice for a fast but most excellent lunch!
author: Ericka A.

description:
I love Dim Sum and I'm sure that some would disagree with me, but in my opinion City View has the best dim sum in the Bay Area.  This restaurant is a top SF request for our out-of-town relatives and the reason why two of our friends who are non-Asian and picky-PICKY eaters have become dim-sum enthusiasts.  Seriously, this place is that damn good!  

During our last visit, we brought our cousins from Canada here who always budget time during their SF trips to include lunch at City View.  There were 8 of us and although we caught the lunch rush, we were seated promptly.  We ordered the Calamari, multiple servings of Shumai, Pork buns, Shrimp Dumplings, Chinese Spare-ribs, Honey Walnut Prawns, Tofu and plates of Fried Rice and Hong Kong style Chow-Mein.  We got 3 plates of everything (minus the rice & chow-mein) and everything disappeared within a matter of seconds.  All of the dishes were delectable and the service was pretty decent.  

And last, but not least, they let us have the Sesame Balls that were fresh from the pan.  They were perfect, hot and crunchy on the outside with gooey, sweet bean paste on the inside. And I love that their Sesame Balls don't ooze out disgusting grease like some that are made at other Chinese restaurants or bakeries.  

By lunch's end, our bellies were full and our cravings were abundantly satiated.  We were in and out of the restaurant in less than an hour which is quite a task to be accomplished for a large party at noon on a Thursday.  Try to arrive at 11, you'll get the best dim sum picks and by the time you're done with your meal, you'll have dodged the mad lunch hour rush.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
San Francisco is well-known for the range of excellent restaurants, except for dim-sum.  I haven't really found any incredible dim-sum restaurant so far.  However, City View can almost remove that statement from me.  It's not the best dim-sum or the most authentic dim-sum I've ever had, but it far above average comparing to most the d.s. restaurants in the city.

Go there early, it tends to get crowded very quickly during lunch hour.

Happy Dim-Sum!
author: N. C.

description:
I was introduced to this place by my boss, who is also an SF local. She is Chinese so I took her recommendation seriously since she knows her Dim Sum and I wanted it to be authentic. I've been here a total of six times now, although I'd never gotten around to yelping about it. I've only been there for lunch and the wait is always out the door, which makes it a difficult place to be in and out of in an hour.

However, the selection is great and the food is awesome! I always let my boss do the ordering because I still can't get the names down exactly right. I know what I like, but can really only tell by looking.

So, here's a descriptor of the what I loved at City View:
1. The sticky rice is my fave.
2. White buns with pork in them (sho-pow).
3. Steamed dumplings with mushrooms or shrimp in them.
4. Green veggies in brown sauce.
5. For dessert, these little brown balls of something with something in them that tastes close to peanut butter and covered in sesame seeds.

I hate that I can't memorize the names but they are tough. Either way, give this place a try if you have a flexible lunch hour!
author: Becky O.

description:
I think this is the best dim-sum restaurant in the city given location, selection and price.  They have all of the standard dim sum items and come around relatively often.  Also, while it isn't bargain basement I come away thinking I get a good value.

I suggest coming before noon during the week to guarantee a good table.  Not sure about when to come on the weekend.  I've sat all over the restaurant- I think the best tables are closest to the kitchen.  You'll get what you want much quicker and won't have to chase after carts, which is sometimes necessary if you are banished to the corner.

Luckily, I've also found them good about refilling tea

Some of the items served here I've liked a lot
- Custard egg tarts
- Fried taro and pork pouch
- Shumai
- Shrimp rice noodle dumplings
- Round shrimp dumplings
- Chinese broccoli (usually my only source of greens)
- Red bean/sesame sweet dumplings
- Turnip cake

While I normally love BBQ pork buns and rice patty in lotus leaves, at City View I am sometimes a little bit disappointed.  They're still good, just not exceptional.
author: Jeff A.

description: Best SF Chinatown Dimsum at a sitdown i've found... very clean, polite staff... delicious food
author: Miss P.

description: Great Dim-Sum!!!  I haven't had a lot of dim-sum, but this place had great food.  We missed the cart service (it ends 30 min before they close) but they let us order off the menu and the dishes were still tasty.  Basic decorations and hard to find location, but the food was good and this place was recommended by locals at my hotel.  I would eat here again if i lived in SFO.
author: Sara K.

description: Very good place for dim sum, but it is preferable to come here on weekends.  The reason I say that is because of it's location at the edge of the Financial District, they tend to get a lot of the nearby office workers for lunch on weekdays.  Therefore, they serve more non-traditional dishes to cater to their taste during the week.  I once spoke to the manager and he even says that is the scheme.  The more traditional Chinese dim sum have a higher likelihood of being served during weekends.
author: H K.

description: city view made me sweat. good food.  Stick to the dim sum, leave the other stuff for another restaurant.
author: Cafe L.

description:
For $20-25 a person, this is the best dim sum I've found in SF. If you know of a better place in this range, please let me know. I generally go to dim sum 1-2x per month with some friends- and city view has been a staple for over a year.

Good quality- significantly better than many of the cheaper dim sum joints on Stockton.  Maybe not as high as Yank Sing, but you're also not paying $40+ a person. 

Great variety- I wish I knew the names of more of the dishes, but I only know them by what they look like. My favorites are the peking duck, pan friend shrimp + chives dumplings, shanghai dumplings, lettuce wraps, Chinese broccoli, pork shu mai, shrimp dumplings, pork fun (flat rice noodle stuffed with pork), walnut shrimp, BBQ pork bun.. the list goes on.

City View lost a star because they can be inconsistent with dish availability- if you come too late on a Sat/Sun, they may be sold out of the specific dumpling that you're craving.

Great place and value- I am a big fan
author: VL K.

description: A friend of mine told me about this place after harbour village closed down, i finally went about a year ago and my god!!!! the dim sum is greeeeeeat! the service is greeeeeeeat!!!! What more can i say, no matter what you gotta try this restaurant, once you go there you won't want to go anywhere else for dim sum
author: William C.

description:
Been here over 10 times.  Decent dim sum place.  The food is definitely good but the speed at which they bring you the food is painfully slow.  Our group would ask for Shanghai dumplings for around 15 minutes before the cart would come by.  Pricing is fair and the people are generally pretty nice but the speed at which the carts go around the restaurant is too slow.  They need to have a set route  for the carts so they make sure they don't miss the tables in the corner.  The selection of food is pretty good but a lot of the dishes are cold (sometimes the dumplings are warm). 

If you're in the financial district and you're craving dim sum, this is 1 of 2 decent places. Make sure you go slightly before noon if you want to be seated immediately.  Any later, and you will have to wait because the crowd  comes very soon after noon.
author: Paul C.

description: Great dim sum and the prices are reasonable, especially for SF standards. Highly recommended for great, cheap dim sum
author: Michelle D.

description:
Tasty spot for Dim Sum for lunch, if you work near the financial district.  Sure beats the robbers at Yank Sing...those guys are like 300% more expensive than dim sum should be.

Anyway, clean spot, great selection.  You could probably find something cheaper if you don't mind the staff not speaking english or eating off a clean plate.  Details.  Sometimes the best places are the dirtiest!  Anyway, tons of choices for DS in SF, but this is a good one.   Mmmmmm, sho mai.
author: Vince B.

description:
OK so it's 2009 and I decided one of my New Year's resolutions should be to write Yelp reviews.  We use Yelp for everything, and I guess I should start contributing to it!

Went to Dim Sum today after a drunken NYE.  My fiance found on Yelp with 4 stars, so we thought we'd try it.  It says Financial District, but it really is at the border of Chinatown.

The restaurant is fairly large so the 7 of us only waited 10 or 15 minutes for a table.

Everything was good.  Our Chinese friend was ordering for us, so I couldn't tell you what most of the stuff was called.  The asparagus was yummy.  The steamed dumplings were excellent - really soft and the BBQ pork had just the right amount of flavor.  They have Shanghai soup dumplings - not great (I like when all the soup pours out of the dumpling when you bite into it) but the flavor was good.

It was a great hangover meal.

This place is only open for dim sum (until 2:30 p.m.)
author: Christine O.

description:
Great place to bring outta towners who wanted to go to chinatown. They'd never had dim sum, I wanted to make sure they got the full cart experience.
Plenty of good food and IMO a bargain. At yank sing this would've been $80. Here, $40.
author: Margie L.

description:
This place was very good. i just got back from lunch with my girlfriend and thought everything was super tasty! 

We had..

Pork dumplings
shrimp dumpling
shrimp egg rolls
Shanghai soup dumplings
Fried pork buns
Pork and shrimp dumplings
Walnut Shrimps
And ended it with Custard Cakes

The bill ended up being $47 with a $8 tip... Not the cheapest place but still cheaper then the $106 bill i got surprised with at Yank Sing!
I recommend this place if you want good dim sum with cart service!!! Get there before 11am if you don't want to wait!
author: Chris B.

description: The best dim sum I've ever had.  They have a wide selection of items.  Get there early, there was a line out the door by noon.
author: Deet G.

description:
3.5 stars
Tucked away little gem of a dimsum place in the FiDi...  a little more expensive than your hole-in-the-wall dimsum place, but worth it...
author: Rose C R.

description:
I always go with coworkers and they know to let me sit on the outside of the table. I'm a cart nazi. I have to be the one to swipe those little delicious trays of dim sum goodness for us all. I also like to have a variety, bc dim sum usually consists of fried goodness, but I also like to have some green godliness to counteract any catalysts. 

It's pretty busy during lunch, so reservations are smart. They are a little pricier than other areas, but it's worth it. 

I think I want some sum today.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I love dim sum almost as much as I hate public bathrooms.


 I love dim sum because it's greasy, tasty, and whether you're getting dumplings, eggplant, mushrooms or whatever, it's going to be stuffed with this ground up, barely recognizable mixture of shrimp and pork that would make any gourmet cry.


 I love it because it's convenient and cures hangovers. You can find me at one of the dim sum joints in Chinatown or the Richmond almost every weekend around brunch time, working the lazy Susan like an oversized Technics DJ deck, chowing down on whatever the locals are eating. Ooh, that looks gross - let's try it!


 But most of all, I love dim sum because it's cheap. Cheap, cheap, cheap, cheap! I am a cheap bastard! I love the idea of paying $6-8 a head, including tax and tip, for a delicious brunch.


 Unfortunately, City View doesn't meet any of the aforementioned dim sum criteria. The ingredients are fresh and distinguishable from one another. You don't see too many locals tucking into chicken feet or beef tripe. And at $20+ a head, it ain't cheap.


 As good as it is, City View really doesn't fit into my personal dim sum paradigm.


 But to their credit, they're the first dim sum place that had a toilet I wasn't scared of. That's probably not the criteria by which most people would judge a restaurant, but anybody who knows me really well knows that a public toilet where I'd take a poo is really a groundbreaking, astonishing achievement.
author: Omid T.

description:
Came to City View today after church. I thought it would take us a really long time to get seated since we had a large party; but they were pretty nice about seating us at 2 large banquet tables next to each other so we could start eating quickly. : )

The food was solid & all the usual dim sum dishes were there (Har gow, siu mai, chicken feet, cherng fun, cha siu bao....). The dumplings I tried were made just right in that there was a good firmness when you bit into them! (I took the cue from my Taiwanese friend who pointed out Siu Loong Baos are not really Cantonese & probably wouldn't be very good. So I didn't taste those.) 

The one dish that surprised me most was the Egg Custard. The actual custard part was really well done (flavorful, smooth, & delicate) while the crust was decent (although rather crispy).
author: Sabrina L.

description:
I actually only want to give this place 3.5 stars...but I'll be nice. 

I've had better...in Chinatown L.A.~!! I thought a lot of the food here was bit on the dry side. The service was just decent but the place did look a lot cleaner than most dim sum places I've been to. Was brought here by one of the coolest SF yelpers, Jeff T. He set everything up and for the most part it all went smoothly...except...so many people showed up that some of us had to sit at the kiddie table...guess who?? Yup you got it...me. Always late...
author: Caroline Y.

description:
My favorite dim sum around here.  Park at the Portsmouth garage.  

These guys have a great selection of stuff that's non-seafood, since I don't eat seafood.  Can accommodate larger parties, and is great atmosphere inside.  There is this huge mural inside that is pretty cool.  Clean restrooms.
author: Dong T.

description: Good tasting food.  Somewhat pricey, but not as pricey as Yank Sing.  Go early during lunch to beat the rush.
author: Brett F.

description: We thought City View was a great find.  It was recommended by locals.  The dim sum was fresh, tender, attractive and delicious.  It was NOT greasy (as it can often be).  There was plenty of room (we arrived late), close to a huge parking garage, and conveniently located near China Town.  I definitely plan to return whenever I visit San Fran.
author: Fern B.

description: It's convenient, reliable, tasty, and quick.  The Shanghai soup dumplings are delicious!  It is a little pricey for Dim Sum but overall a great choice for a quick Financial District brunch/lunch!  I will certainly go again when  I get a lunch time dim sum craving =D
author: Jessica J.

description: On the edge of Chinatown. Pleasant surroundings, spacious. Good service, good dim sum. $20 per person. A winner.
author: Mary B.

description: Ok. this is not the best place for dim sum. However, if you happen to be in the downtown Chinatown area or you work in the neighborhood...and just happen to feel like dim sum for lunch...sure, stop by.  one thing for sure about this place is that its clean. you cannot find a lot of clean restaurants in this neighborhood. so, if that is your #1 criterion for choosing a place to dine then this is a good place.  Avoid sitting near the front door...its a high traffic area and door is always swung wide open.  you might need a sweater or jacket because it gets drafty...cold. the staff never seems to notice, and you really have to work had to get their attention. let's talk about the food.  the tea...there is a charge.  not sure when they start chaging tea, but for the money you pay for...the tea was not fragrant; somewhat light but bitter tasting.  the dim sum selection was average.  the shrimp dumpling was good, and the rest of the dumplings were fresh and ok.  skip the chicken kabob. its oily...perhaps it was fried first before it was put on a skwer. the lotus wrap rice was a bit soggy.  all in all, food was just ok. not sure why there is always a large crowd...
author: D C.

description:
3.5 more likely.
this place is always bumping and has all the classic faves.

shu mai, har gow, pork stuffed taro, peking duck & buns, fried crab claw balls, chinese brocolli, salt & pepper calamari, etc.

they are quick to seat you.

service is semi hot & cold attitude & rudeness...this is a classic staple with most dim sum places much like chili oil or soy sauce.  teehee

city view...it is okay though...we coo...
i will always come back to you like a battered girlfriend.
author: Tiger Lily ..

description:
I love to go to City View for lunch - and on Sundays it is even better because there is an abundance of parking so my friends with cars will go with me.

They're quick bringing out the dimsum and they always have a good variety - unlike the uber expensive Yank Sing.

If you decide you need fried rice or noodles, they aren't super greasy and the fried rice has chopped up gai lon.  

The sesame balls aren't too big which I like, but the mango pudding was not so good.
author: Robyn C.

description:
I think City View takes the (turnip) cake in the price-to-quality, bang-to-buck ratio.  I do like the other higher end dim sum places in SF, but City View is my go-to place for dim sum.  There is good variety and high turnover so you almost always get something hot and steamy, not tepid and gluey.  Sometimes, coveted but uncommon dishes get only one pass during service so be vigilant whilst enjoying your food.  I passed on the tofu dessert because I was still chowing down on the savories, and when I was ready for the sweets, it was sold out--and we arrived at before noon, too!!  If you reeeealllly want something, though, it's best just to ask for the item instead of waiting for it to come to you.  That is good generic life advice, but it rings extra true for dim sum.

And PLEASE, don't block the aisles with Hummer-sized baby strollers.  The dim sum carts must circulate, and the food is getting cold.
author: maiko h.

description:
Problem: Visitors from out of town who have never tried dim sum
Solution: City View, it's in Chinatown and is clean and nice in the inside AND they'll provide your guests with forks. A little pricey but a safe bet.

Taste-wise: it was only "okay" and have had much better.  Standard selection: har gau was a little dry, siu mai small, char siu baau decent and walnut shrimp semi-flavorful.  If it's too "chinese" for your guests, they can still order traditional stuff (beef/noodle/rice dishes) from the main menu.  

Spongebob Awesomeness: 3 krabby patties and a half-dozen egg tarts
author: Ronald M.

description: Came here for a business meeting and was excited to try it because I had heard good things about this place from another co-worker.  They definitely have a good variety of dim sum here which is a plus.  But as far as the taste, it was a-ok.  The food wasn't stellar but it wasn't bad either.  And the pricing was a little high in my opinion.  I would give it another shot before crossing it off my list.
author: Sunny H.

description: Had been looking for a dim sum that serves with carts for a first time experience for my friends and coworkers.  We narrowed it down to 3 places in SF near Chinatown and we chose city view since it was nearest to our destination.  Knowing it was the weekend of the Chinese parade we made reservations for 12.  As we got there we notice we could only fit 10 per table.  The lady who I guess was running the seating chart was hella rude and bitchy.  We couldn't fit everyone at a table cuz we ended up having an extra person but she didnt have to be rude about it.  She was yelling at us and the worker who gave us another small extra table to sit at.  I was like damn in front of hella customers.  Anyways food was ok I've had better.  Lots of the stuff was on the greasy side but the walnut shrimp and mango pudding was off the hook.  The egg tarts were too runny and the fried rice noodle things tasted like chemicals.  Also minus one star for getting charged for either the hot tea or glasses of water.
author: Thuyvi M.

description: If you are looking for a clean n tasty  place to eat dim sum in the inner belly of sf, cityview delivers. We enjoyed the traditional steamed pork and  shrimp,  dumplings, which were tasty morcels of goodness. The duck was amazing, full of meat and  freshly prepared.  Our only knock was that they did not have porridge, what's up with that? Overall a great dim sum experience. Ivan dim summed it up by saying "best dim sum I ever had."
author: The Captain S.

description: Consistently good traditional Cantonese style Dim sum. Service is quick and always friendly.
author: Isabella L.

description: One of the best.  I have had really not anything better. it is pricer and cleaner than most in china town but you pay for what you get and that is an amazing steam cart and nice duck.  Worth it!
author: matt l.

description: This may be my new favorite dim sum joint in the city. It has all the normal favorites and all are extremely well done. The dining room is clean and there are plenty of seats. What more could one ask for?
author: Brian B.

description: Simply fabulous Dim Sum!  We had lunch here today and the Dim Sum was so fresh and wonderful!  We have a few Dim Sum places back home in Dallas that are good, but they don't hold a candle to City View. The restaurant is clean, selection great and prices reasonable.  Being in Chinatown, I imagine the food is made from the freshest ingredients right from the local markets.  Definitely coming back here when I return to SF.
author: Jeaux B.

description: Do not eat here, the place is so over priced. Came here with three other people our bill was over 50 dollars and we left still hungry. We ordered a total of 8 or 9 items that weren't even that good. Do yourself a favor and walk across the street into the heart of china town and im sure you'll stumble across a better place
author: calvin a.

description:
I love this place!!  My favorite POSH dimsum house, esp for people that do not normally do Chinese food!  The place looks superbly clean and upscale!  The food is yummy!  I especially love their sticky fried rice, walnut prawns and gelatin coconut cakes!  You can't go wrong by taking your friends to this place!  Especially as it's in Ctown, and makes for an overall great experience!!  On the weekends, the place is less crowded, especially if you go when they open!

I must admit, my real preference is to go to a pink box, point and choose place, like You's Dimsum or Goodluck Dimsum, but this is a great place to take out of towners or for special occasions.  Their carts could be faster on the weekends... but all and all, this is a great posh place to take my mom's friends!
author: GingerSnap G.

description:
Nice and clean restaurant for dim sum.  Definitely less chaotic then most traditional dim-sum places.

But if you want that chaotic out of the world dim-sum experience, this is not the place to be.  It might be fair to say that this is "Chic dim-sum."
author: Alan T.

description:
The reason to come here is the ambiance and cleanliness - a slip below Yank Sing, but better than anything you'll find in Chinatown. A lot less grease than C'town joints.

On my budget, I have to stick with Gold Mountain or Lichee Garden.
author: Marisa L.

description:
good dim sum.  Decently priced.  Quality is definitely top notch.  Another place I like to drop by for lunch.

Solid 4 stars!
author: Tadd L.

description:
I went to dim sum with a few of my friends and had a decent meal here. We made reservations and got in with little wait (around 1 PM) but I expect it would be more difficult earlier in the day. Our tea came quickly as did all of the carts and trays of food. No lag, clean tables, and all the waitresses and waiters spoke English. 

As for the food, it was pretty good. Nothing to make me keel over in joy but overall solid dim sum food. The bill was pretty good too considering the amount of food we purchased - around $68 for six people.
author: Madeline N.

description:
I would give it 5 if it weren't for the service.  We asked a coupla times for some items such as pork potstickers, they nodded, said they would bring some out but they never did. Maybe it was a language thing but after that, the servers kept coming around only to ignore our table and show everyone else their offerings! 
It was strange...up until that point the four of us LOVED it! 
The food is really good.  You MUST MUST MUST try the triangle pork buns wrapped in the most delicate, flaky pastry EVER! Thats coming from a pastry chef (not to sound cocky!) but DAMN! Is it ever the Shiz!
My advice, go there, eat, don't ask for anything extra and you will do fine!
author: Suzanne L.

description:
I could have sworn I'd already written a review for City View. I must be losing my mind. 

Anyway, this is one of my (other) favorite dim sum places. I work in the area and if you ask me, it's one of the best in the FiDi/Chinatown. Very good and everything I've had here has been fresh. The prices, as others have mentioned are not the cheapest, especially compared to some of the other dim sum places in Chinatown but the quality is worth it. Definitely cheaper (and closer for me!) than Yank Sing. I think the peking duck and virtually anything with shirmp here is great. All in all, recommended.
author: Anita B.

description:
I keep confusing people by calling this place "City Lights" which is an old Chinese place in DC. Not the same. I'm also a fan of the places where I'm the only person who doesn't speak Chinese and I have to point.  Those spots are fine by me. I'd review them but I can't always read the signs so I have to call them "that place with the green awning" and Google can't map that. Yet. 

City View gets 4 stars from me because I think it's as good or better than Yank Sing sit down, but cheaper and you can order more things off menu (steamed custard buns, for example). I work with people who don't have padded expense accounts but like to go out in big groups for the dim summin'. City View is perfect for that.
author: mahi m.

description:
One of my favorite Dim Sum restaurants in the city! I've always dropped in at lunch on a weekday.

Kind of hard to find, it's in an alley.

Business crowd
Pricey
Service 7/10 - it can get packed, might be a wait.
Cleanliness 8/10
Ambience 8/10

I especially love going home with a box of the custard buns.
author: Rese D.

description: We actually drive across a bridge to eat at City View.  The food is always good and so is the service.  The kitchen menu has some great noodles you can order.  I for one crave a couple of dim sum items and order them when I walk in to ensure they arrive before I get too full on items on the cart.  Some reviews below say its expensive.  I guess for dim sum it is but a clean white table cloth and linen and good service...worth it to me. : ))
author: G V.

description: Good Dim Sum, it can be hard to get a table around lunch time but once you sit down the wait was worth it.  Pork Buns are a must
author: Prescott f.

description: I always make it a priority to visit this place for dim sum lunch.  Since you can pick and choose what you want, it's pretty much a hit every time.  The place is called "City View" and well, if you pronounce it with a really bad accent, it makes sense.  Let's just say, there is no "View" per say.
author: Chris N.

description:
so this past sunday i went to this place for some dim sum....opt out of the usual places i go by my place cause i figured hey its gonna be in china town probably better. 

well  as everyone knows parking is a pain but when we got in it wasnt that long of a wait, probably cause our party was only a party of 2, but the place was pretty bustling with business.

we sat down and was given tea...it took awhile for a cart to come our way but yeah we started to get the usual stuff such as the chinese broccoli, siu mai, shrimp dumplings, pork buns, etc. . .

well the overall experience was ok, i forget how it is to be in a place where the majority of workers can not speak english, at one point we had asked the waiter what was in it and she repeated the name. then we ask again and she looked at us as if we shouldve not even ask her the question.

the dim sum itself was ok, i think the portions were a little small and not to mention the selection wasnt as large as i thought it would be. im not going to knock this place though cause it was decent, but just didnt compared to all the other places ive been too.
author: Tofer M.

description: There is a really long wait for some pretty mediocre food (dim sum)
author: lily l.

description: Utterly disappointed by this place. Sorry, I wanted to go to this place for the longest time and finally got to do it with my mom. The place is clean and on the border of Chinatown, but that about it. The food was not that great for the price. I had better dim sum in Chinatown with better price. Also not much for variety here, I thought. I do not recommend this place. Go to Chinatown and try dim sum there.
author: Leon C.

description: I don't care what anyone says, City View is still my go to dim sum place in San Francisco.  It's in walking distance for me, fresh food, clean decor, good service, and fair prices.  Can't wait till my next visit!!!
author: HY L.

description:
Food is below average at best but what made me give them only 1 star is the attitude of the hostess.  We called ahead and asked if we can make a reservation for dim sum since I am taking my elderly grandparents and I didn't want them to have to wait long.  They told us that they don't take reservation and just come by, the line isn't long. 

Long story short, they let another similiar sized party that arrived after we did go first.  When we questioned them about it, they said, they had a reservation. I told the hostess that we tried to make a reservation and were told that they don't take them.  She didn't seem to like that but gave us the next table.  I won't come here again.
author: Stanley T.

description:
More of my FiDi longings...

OMG, Yank SIng has NOTHING on this place; it's SO MUCH LESS EXPENSIVE & TASTIER!!!  I'm surprised that there isn't more hype for them!  

It's large & REALLY clean.  Their selection can only be described as INTIMIDATING, but in a yummy, kid in candy store, I-wanna-try-everything kind of way!!!  The food is fresh, hot & just plain delish...the table service was on point (usually; other times I've had to wait forever & a day a for my expensive soda...thus the point reduction!), & carts circulated like no tomorrow.  Just make sure you have reservations, especially during lunch hour!!!
author: Amoura B.

description: A friend suggested City View to me as a perfect place to go for both quality dim sum, and as a place which would be suitable for people who have never had dim sum but are willing to try it. She pretty much nailed it - the quality of the dim sum was very high, and the restaurant was clean enough and nice enough that you could take your parents here without any hesitation. As an added bonus, it's a bit off the beaten path, so it didn't get too crowded even during peak dim sum hours. Next time I'm in San Francisco, I'm definitely stopping in again.
author: Dennis L.

description:
Me lovey me some dim sum

Ok really this place is great - clean, good prices, nice waitstaff, large windows let in great light on a sunday morning and me lovey me some dim sum! =)
author: Sienna G.

description:
good dim sum
Shiu mai a little rubbery
Shrimp with chive dumpling very good
Shrimp dumpling very good
Decent sticky rice
No mango pudding or custard tarts
Very sad would be 4 stars but no mango pudding or custard tarts.  Sold out.
author: Matt N.

description:
3.5 stars. Minus a few stars, for service. 

Can you even get a refill here? Try. It's almost like mission impossible. 

Other then that, the food here is actually quite decent. It's crowded during lunch, and understandably so.

The dim sum isn't that bad. It's not the best, so don't expect HK dim sum, in SF. If you want something decent, then you'll be happy. The chow fun, and ha gow, is really good though. The skin might be a little on the chewy side, but I kind of like it that way.

Once again, crappy service. Can't really except great service, in a Chinese place though.
author: Charles K.

description:
Use to come here at least once a week for lunch when I worked in SF everyday. This is definately one of our top 2 dim sum spots in the city. We still come here whenever we are in SF.

I havent had a bad experience yet. The pan fried shrimp and chive and the sesame balls are absolutely the best I have ever had.

Parking can be a pain but if your use to it and know where to park then your all good. The street is closed at Montgomery so what I do is back into it from Kearny for VIP metered parking smack dab in the front =)
author: Marlon O.

description:
My boss Harlene treated me to this Dimsum place on the Admininstrative Professional's Day or something like that. This is my first time at a Dimsum Restaurant but not new to eating dimsum...hmmm

I enjoyed it the first time and 6 visits after with Elaine, Harlene and Sheralyn not necessarily altogether I am still enjoying it. Just had lunch there today. Our tabs vary because it depends on whether we wanna try on some more new stuff, if we stick to the basics which is chicken feet for me and shrimp dumplings for elaine we average like $15 a-piece.

Since this is located in the heart of the financial district I have no way of inviting my non-bank-working friends, they are open on Saturday i guess but I dont wanna be on this side of town on weekends.

Service is not that great its alright though, I cant complain. When you get the chance check it out.
author: Malou C.

description:
This was actually a bit more expensive than I had expected. About $75 for 4 people. The food was good depending on what it was. The ha gaw was a little on the fishy side. The fried sesame balls were fresh and delish. The baked cha xiao bao was also good. 

I'd go back on a Friday, I hear the food selection is better.
author: Kitty N.

description:
Loveeeeeeeeee the Dimsum. I am not a meat person so this place with ample chicken and seafood suits me great. Carts roll out all the time unless you go at the end of the hour. Don't have a reservation...Don't be surprised with atleast 15-20mins of waiting time..specially on a Friday, of course you can't expect any better in the downtown on a Friday. 

Compared to Yank Sing the prices are a lottttttttt cheaper. 2 ppl can eat for the price of YS's 1. 

Crab legs, chicken feet , big rice noodles and specially the chili chicken is worth going for.
author: Mali S.

description: This place is great if you are looking for dim sum with the traditional cart service.  Service is extremely fast.  Within 30 seconds of sitting down, we had tea and our first dish.  The food was very good when we were there, but there weren't a wide variety of dishes on the day we were there.  It was primarily shrimp & vegetable focused.  We tried the shrimp dumplings, shrimp egg rolls, & some type of crab claw appetizer that was excellent.  We had 7 dishes plus tea between two people for a cost of around $45. The downside of the service was that the servers did not speak English well so it was hard to communicate what we were looking for and what they were serving.  Overall, the experience was good enough for a 2nd look so I'm sure we'll try it again.  An added plus is that they do validate parking.
author: Kim D.

description: This is an over priced ok Dim Sum place. When we arrived they've already stopped the carts so we had to order from the menu. It wasn't a big deal except for the menu wasn't very descriptive so we didn't really know what we were getting.
author: Patrick L.

description:
By far the best Dim Sum restaurant in the city... Clean enough and formal enough for the "round eye" and authentic enough for the authentic crowd. 

I have been frequenting this restaurant for over 15 years, and enjoy it every time... great place to bring friends, but get here early as its always packed out the door at noon. 

Best dishes are ha gao (steamed shrimp balls), xiao long bao (shanghai dumplings with soup broth inside) cha shiu bao (pork buns) and an array of different non cart items that you should figure out how to order... 

All in all, cleanliness, price, location, and a great place to hang out with a few friends, I can't think of any other dim sum place that compares.
author: Peter V.

description: City View is legit if you are looking for great Dim Sum. The dumplings are very tasty and steaming hot. There is a wide selection of fresh dumplings that will be offered to you as soon as you sit down. The services is good and the management is very polite. The value to taste ratio makes City View a 5 star location.
author: Garrett J.

description: Personally I love Yank sing, but this is a dim-sum place to go all the time, because it's more price friendly.  The food is decent!
author: Elena L.

description: I love this place for dim sum. If you arrive right at noon, there will be a flurry of carts serving up a large variety of dumplings. I think the dim sum here is some of the best I've had. It's a great place for lunch if you don't have much time since they serve up the food so quickly. I highly recommend City View if you are in the mood for some yummy dim sum.
author: Courtney T.

description:
So far this is my favourite dim sum place in SF - better than Ton Kiang.

What I really liked was the different choices, sure they had the standard selection of shumai, steamed buns and dumplings but they had a few experimental concoctions which I found really appetizing. Well, maybe not that original but for some reason I really get excited about any eggplant/meat combination... I'm just weird i guess. 

Seriously though, this place was good and everything was pretty fresh - which is usually why its good to get to dim sum places earlier rather than later
author: Krishnan S.

description:
city view. no actual view, but if a dim sum place can lure me twice in 48 hours, there must be something special about it.

well.. well.. dim sum is a snack, but since america has bastardized it, it becomes an outright buffet, and when you're four strong with different appetites, its prime time to order everything.

first things first. dim sum joints are always a bit funky and not so clean, which usually never phases me, but this places is surprisingly clean and super packed. service was decent, considering its a dim sum place. they need to pay a little more attention to the water levels. my water glass went low a couple times... all that salt, a girl gets a little thirsty here.

the shrimp fun rolls are good, and fresh, the shrimp was clean and fresh. the ha gao was above par. the sticky rice was super yummy. the scallop steamed dumplings with cilantro were light and well seasoned. the sesame balls were a bit oily, but what do you expect for a deep fried donut type thing. the shanghai style dumplings with the soup were delish, but came too late in our journey of foods to get the full attention it deserves. the fried tofu thing was yummy. BUT! the chow fun is a little lacking, oily, and a bit bland.  stick with the dim sum.

prices are a little more pricey in comparison to other random dim sum joints, but the quality is there, and the cleanliness of the place is promising.

city view. this hidden joint in some alley in the financial district is far from a view, but a great little sf treasure.
author: Natalie G.

description:
Ehhhh.

What's great about this place is that it is clean and it seats a lot of people. Food is mediocre compared to other dim sum places. You have a good mix of traditional dim sum plates and more Americanized Chinese dishes. The person who was my cashier rudely reminded me that tip was not included in the check, which made me not want to leave a tip.
author: K L.

description:
yum.  Got all my favorites, hai gow, sui mai, chinese broccoli, ribs in black bean sauce, seasame balls and more.  The peking duck was good and so were the other items we tried.  We went as a large group and they were pretty accomodating plus with more people we got to try lots of different things.  It was very clean and the service was good.  Even though the place was packed we didn't feel rushed (perhaps it's because we kept ordering so much)

They validate parking too if you are driving in.
author: Mabelle A.

description:
City View is good choice to take first-time dim sumers who might be freaked out by the dingy hole-in-the-wall type restaurants. It's clean, slightly upscale ambiance with decent service and reasonable prices. Once you break them in, then you take them to those mom and pop places, because those are the BEST.

Today's meal consisted of: shu mei, shrimp dumplings, stick rice wrapped in lotus leaves, turnip cake, pork ribs, salty fried pork balls, stuffed mushrooms, chicken feet, mushrooms & vermicelli crepe, Chinese broccoli, pineapple buns, and egg custards. All was yummy except the broccoli; it was very stale. The star of the table was, and rightfully so, the chicken feet. This happens to be my favorite dim sum dish. There's nothing like biting into the succulent skin and chewing on the cartilage. Thumbs up. Overall the flavor seemed a little less prominent than when I was here last time, but this place still beats the overrated and way overpriced Yank Sing.
author: Linda L.

description:
This was my first dim sum experience & possibly my last! For all of you who have never had dim sum before, you sit at your table and wait for servers to come around to you and offer you a variety of small dishes. The idea is kind of like the Chinese version of Tapas, but dim sum is much different. The servers are on commission, so therefore come to your table every two minutes offering you dishes that either look disgusting (have crab legs sticking out of them) or you just don't want at that time. They put a stamp on your bill each time you receive a plate in order to determine how much to charge you in the end.

Generally, when it comes to food I am not usually a big fan of greasy Chinese appetizers, but if I am in the mood for them, they can actually be quite tasty. We tried various plates including: pot stickers, egg rolls, pork buns, rice patties (which taste like potato pancakes) and a few others. The food was actually ok.

The service on the other hand was a different story. As my friend Yan G. stated, "Unlike their dim sum, service at City View is spotty, aggressive and abrupt.  Prepare to fight for the servers' attention, and do not be surprised when you're offered the same dish over and over again.  Oh, and get your credit card ready as soon as you get the check.  Otherwise, you'll be subjected to the dirty looks by the servers and impatient patrons alike."

I would probably go back and try City View again, but this time I would definitely prepare myself for the culture shock beforehand. It almost reminded me of dining in an outdoor caf in Europe and being harassed by beggars, but of course these beggars are bringing you food. I just think that if the servers were not on commission, they wouldn't be as annoying. For now I'll just look at the annoyance as a cultural difference and continue to eat my food!
author: Elaine S.

description:
This was my first dim sum experience. It was a packed house and we waited about five minutes...but as soon as we sat down the food started pouring onto the table. I went with about 12 coworkers and it was great. i loved the food and the speed. i dont think i would go with less then 8 or 10 people, so i can try everything the people bring to the table. 

I was with 3 or for people who do this regularly and they told me this is one of their favorite places in the area...
author: justin b.

description:
You know, I've never been cool. I was the only Chinese kid at my elementary school, junior high, high school, and hence, was ripe for the picking. I wore thick glasses, was good at math, and brought weird things in my lunchbox to school everyday.


 Ewwwww, is that dog?! 
No, it's deep fried dried shredded pork and soy sauce. 
Mrs. Johnson!!! Eddo's making us eat dooooggggg!!!


 Kids can be such wankers.


 I moved to San Francisco around five years ago, started meeting so many wonderful intelligent and sincere people, eaten at the best and worst places, experienced horrifying and superb service.


 And last Saturday, after a heavy night of drinking for most people, a group of friends joined me for some good dim sum in spacious and large City View restaurant, which is the least Chinese-y name for any dim sum place I've ever been to.


 But the dim sum came quickly, in carts, and I reveled in grunting want and no want in Chinglish to the mostly-Cantonese speaking staff. The siu mais were delicious, as was the beijing duck, and the xiao lung baos were above average. This was a decent standard dim sum place to bring any visitors to our fair City by the Bay to experience a typical Hong Kong style breakfast.


 And I sat there and observed the 20+ stalwart and mostly hungover friends who wandered down an alley bordering Chinatown and the FiDi on a beautiful Saturday morning and I thought - this is what it feels like to be cool.


 And that's what it is. Real friends won't make fun of you for eating weird food. Real friends won't look at you weird if you eat chicken feet. Real friends won't giggle at you for being fat, or wearing glasses, or for liking math.


 Friendship is collectively bigger than any group of people, but for one hour on Saturday, I felt like the cool kid. And well, sweaty fat Chinese kids with thick glasses who are good at math and bring fried egg, dried shredded pork, and soy sauce sandwiches to lunch, well, we just don't feel that way very often.
author: eddo

description:
Fresh and delicous food in a VERY VERY clean atmosphere with excellent service. I was impressed and will be recommeding this place to everyone!
I was almost going to give up on finding a good dim sum place since every place I've been to is one or all of the following: dirty, food that feels and tastes greasy , terrible customer service etc... City View is the rare exception and is a jewel in the Chinatown area.
It is pricey. My friend and I DEVOURED like 8 dishes worth of food and it was about 10.00 per person including tip. There is a mix or people in carts and people with tray offerings which I liked. I was surprised that we were charged for tea but I guess in this climate of being nickled and dimed...Clientle is mostly business professionals since its near the Financial District and some trendy locals.  Overall delicious food!
author: luvtotravel J.

description:
Great Dim Sum place at the edge of the Financial District.
 Restaurant is very clean and the service is efficient.
Nice windows that let a lot of light, very high ceilings that do not make you feel claustrophobic. Every time we go we do not need to wait too long to get a sit during weekdays. I do not know over the weekend.
author: Lydia H.

description:
Middle-of-the-road dim sum place that's not the best nor the cheapest. The best part about this place for me is that it's not too crowded and getting a table was not a problem either of the two times I have been there.

It is clean and comfortable inside. The dim sum is decent, but doesn't really stand out to me. The prices are reasonable, again not cheap but not too expensive. The service is average too.
author: Adrian L.

description: I live in Soma and when I'm too lazy to drive down the Peninsula or venture out to the Richmond for good dim sum, City View always hits the spot.  My friend made the perfect comment about this place - "This place is surprising good for being so clean."  Small dishes are $3, medium is $3.5 and large is $4.  Tea per person is $1.75.  I recommend sitting towards the back because a lot of items are hand carried by servers so you want to get them hot from the kitchen.
author: Jen C.

description: We've been here a couple time now for Dim Sum.  Both times on a Sunday around 11am.  I like the atmosphere of this place, it's one of the nicer Dim Sum places I've been to.  And we never have to wait for a table.  The food is fresh, tasty, and plentiful.  They have different options, like lettuce wraps and spring rolls.  It may be more of an "Americanized" type of dim sum, but I really like it.  The only reason for 4 stars instead of 5 stars is that it is a little pricier.  Between the 2 of us, our bill is around $30-$40.  I love the doughnuts here!!  order them for your dessert!
author: Autumn C.

description: I spent an hour or more fretting over where to take our out of town guest for her first Dim Sum experience - no need, because City View was the perfect spot. A little on the expensive side, but the cleanliness of the place and the quality dim sum made it worth it. All of the dishes we tried, including the buns were excellent, and the waiters were actually friendly and spoke to us in english. She loved it. We'll be back.
author: Bryan K.

description:
My family and I went here for Dim Sum on Saturday afternoon. This location is not your regular dim sum restaurant. It's upscale for a Chinese/dim sum restaurant. One thing I like about this restaurant is that they push carts around with the steamed bamboo containers in them. The ladies who push around the carts have earphones and a mic so if you make a request of something that they don't have, they "call it in" and try to get it to you soon. 

The food was decent. Dumplings came 3 to a container- lame. The shu mai pork dumplings were kind of small; they were average. I liked the skin of the shrimp har gao. It was doughy but very soft. If you order the Chinese broccoli, make sure to ask for more hoisin sauce. They are stringy in that department. My family really liked the Shanghai dumplings. The red vinegar sauce added great flavors to it.
author: Jennifer C.

description: For large-group dim summing, I like City View much better than Yank Sing.  The service was less manic, there were about the same amount of vegetarian options (some, not many), the food was just as tasty, and the bill was noteably smaller.  Yum Dim Sum!
author: Andi T.

description:
Today I went to City View for lunch since it got some good reviews from fellow reviewers and it was a major disappointment. Here is a list of what I had:
Shark Fin Gow
Shrimp Siu Mai
Fried spicy squid
Gau Choy Gau
BBQ Pork Cheung Fun

The Shark Fin Gow was not much better than your 3 for $1.70 ones a You's and Shrimp Siu Mai was a little bit better , but not worth the additional 2 bucks. the Spicy Squid was not spicy and really was kind of tasteless.  The Gau Choy Gau was good, but yet again not worth the extra money. The BBQ Cheung Fun was bad, the BBQ pork had some wierd taste. do they make their own BBQ pork?

All in all not worth the $30 including tips for 5 measley dishes. I felt ripped off. I am never going back here again.
author: Vincent P.

description:
Had the sesame chicken (must be ordered - not dim sum) and chicken lettuce cups, and a couple walnut shrimp.  Nothing too out there - but I'm a white boy.
Will go again for sure!
author: Mike A.

description:
food is good but a bit pricey, and customer service is horrible. 

I went with a table of 3 and we sat next to a larger table that received better customer service i.e a "how are you" and priority when the dim sum carts came by. 

Basically if you are going with many people this might be a good place for okey customer service and good food. But if it is very busy dont expect to get served right away, standing up to a large table.
author: lacou f.

description: Good place to go for dim sum.  Definitely make reservations before you go.  It's bustling at noon for lunch.  Service is fast. Pork buns were delicious.  It's been only 4 days since I've been there and nothing else jumps out as truly memorable.  I guess that says something.
author: Gail W.

description:
So far the best overall dimsum if you consider price as a factor.  I've been all over tasting the best in the valley and while Yank Sing has great variety it is way too expensive.  Same with Koi Palace.

I do like ABC Seafood and Mayflower in Milpitas, and Joy Luck Place (SM & Cupertino), but I be in the city now, so its all about city living!
author: Doug C.

description:
I had kind of shied away from dim sum for awhile after actually looking inside a wrapper at another restaurant.  Where the dish had been quite tasty, I found I had lost my appetite after looking inside.

However,  a friend brought me here a couple months ago and I was extremely pleased.  We were lucky to beat the lunch rush, entered at about 11:30 am.  By 12 the entire restaurant was packed.  We were visiting since we hadn't seen each other for awhile and the frequent stops by the servers did become a bit tiresome after we had reached our limit of food, but so goes the environment of a dim sum restaurant.  

The prices were higher than other dim sum restaurants I've tried in the past, but it's the financial district  - higher rent and higher paid expectant patrons equals higher charges. 

I enjoyed the food and never lost my appetite upon peering inside any of the dishes we ordered.  I will return.
author: Cristina S.

description:
Good food. 

Cheap food.

Clean.

Good location.

Unfortunately the sub par service brings this place down to three stars.
author: Pancake m.

description:
One of the hidden treasures near chinatown... Pretty pricey, but the food is alright... Even though chinese people call it "food used to trick whities".... i mean i wouldn't know.. i eat what tastes good to me and thats all i really care abut it... its got some nice paintings hanging around and it is pretty clean.. Too bad its only open during lunch time and its quite crowded

-x3 shells
author: Lily X.

description: Decent dim sum but pricey (not as much as Yank Sing though). The higher price is expected because of the convenient FiDi location.
author: L S.

description: Just went back a few weeks ago and the food was amazing (again) and the service rocked...seriously a stellar dim sum spot.
author: Taj A.

description: Portion sizing is small. Not much condiments and hostess was rude. Waiters and waitress' were nice. Some foods were good though some were not. Some of the dim sum street places are 10x better. Especially with price. We had a 75$ ticket for about 10 menu items which would normally be about 30-40 in Houston.
author: Steve V.

description: Pretty good dim sum right off of Kearny St.  They still do the push carts which is nice.  I like the quality of the dim sum but the pieces are kinda small and i never leave this place without spending at least $25 to a high of $45 once. The $45 was a freak incident of two people just eating way to much.  Sometimes there can be a wait but i've never had to wait too long here.
author: Ka C.

description: A great place to bring friends and family when they're visiting the city.. It maybe a LITTLE expensive by Chinatown-standards, but well, what can you do. This is my favorite Dim Sum place. It is tucked on a narrow street, . The food is always fresh ..To order, simply tell the server what you see that you like from the cart. My most favorite is the Pekin duck, the skin is thin like paper and just the right crunchiness, the bun is fresh. Yum..
author: Susie C.

description: Living in Atlanta, we have no Chinatown :( and if Dim Sum exists here, please...someone tell me about it! A frequent visitor to NYC, I always try to get Dim Sum in Chinatown there and generally have a good experience but am never wowed. City View came as a recommendation from our concierge at The Clift Hotel. Also a dim sum fan, she told us this was one of the best in the city and told us it was off an alley, hard to find for tourists. With those words, we were game! Arriving a few minutes before Noon the restaurant was about 1/2 full. By 12:15, there was a wait. Seeing locals on lunch breaks made us feel at ease that this is a local fav. The carts are plentiful, pass more than once (a pet peeve of mine in NYC, they only come by once) and if you want a specific cart to come around again, all you have to do is ask and they oblige. Larger shared dishes came out of the kitchen to several tables, no sure how we could have secured one of those (a separate menu perhaps?), but quite frankly, we were so full from our selections, we needed the big walk back up Commercial Alley and the streets of SanFran for the remainder of the day to work it off! This is wonderful, not to big, not to small of a dim sum restaurant and no, there is NO real City View, ha! But the food is worth it anyway.
author: Anne B.

description:
Good dim sum: four stars.
Reasonably priced: four stars
Wait staff are efficient & polite: four stars
Waiting to be seated- depends but usually within a reasonable time: four stars
Tea: 3 stars
Cleanliness: 5 stars
author: Ricardo O.

description: This is a go-to place for my friends and me when we crave dim sum. The wait is usually pretty short and they're good at dealing with small (four) and large (16) groups. It's very affordable. Definitely try their XLB. Remember they validate parking at the Portsmouth Square garage. Bring a Chinese speaker if you can.
author: Eric M.

description:
This is the best dim sum this side of the city that I've tried.  I haven't been to all that many, but I'd even go as far to say that this is my current favorite dim sum place.  The dishes are authentic(it doesn't come cheap of course if you compare with Chinatown pricing), and it's no wonder that both Chinese and non-Chinese pack this place well past the lunch hour even in the middle of the week.

They pass the test of quality on all sorts of dim sum:  basically, all the types that I've grown up eating and liking tasted as they should here, and they reminded me of why I like them.  Go here instead of Yank Sing.  It's way more authentic and a little cheaper too.  And they do it the traditional way via carts as well.  That's a must have.
author: Stephen N.

description: Mmmm, I really like this place. I had dim sum for the first time here. I was in food heaven. It's a lot of fun to have food brought to you like a king. "Sir, would you like another?" "Why yes. Yes, I would." The shrimp balls, the pot stickers, the warm buns, etc. Definitely was great experience. The service was great, the atmosphere was appealing and the prices weren't too bad.
author: Quantas G.

description: I have not eaten Dim Sum outside of San Francisco, so I can't claim to be a Dim Sum expert, but as someone who likes good food this place consistently passes the test.  I love eating here.  The restaurant is clean and has nice atmosphere.  The food is awesome- I love their pork buns, pot stickers, and all their desserts are amazing.  I have been going here for several years, and it never disappoints.   I do leave very full, though!
author: Susie H.

description: We had Dim Sum for lunch, came in a little late so we had to order from the menu. Overall very good, we come from the Pacific Northwest where there is a lot of great Dim Sum too. Choice of food was in line with other places I've been to. Quality was good. If you are in the mood for good Dim Sum in San Francisco, this should be near the top of your list.
author: Roberto R.

description:
after reading the sf chronicle's recent special guide to dim sum
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2009/01/28/FDGJ15D5ID.DTL
i found myself craving siu mai and egg custard tarts...

yank sing is my usual go to place for dim sum dining in the fidi during the work week, but city view is another good option.  the restaurant is large and bright, and it gets busy during the lunch hour - luckily they take reservations, even for a party of 2!

carts come regularly, along with servers carrying plates.  a pretty good assortment and had i brought the chronicle's pull out section picture guide, it would've felt a little bit like playing bingo!  

shanghai soup dumpling: piping hot and plentiful broth - i burned my mouth because i couldn't wait!
rice noodle rolls w/ shrimp - so slippery but tasty!
char sui bao: picked the baked version, nicely browned and slightly sweet/sticky rolls encasing yummy bbq pork
deep fried taro balls: tasty! nice textural contrast between the lacy outside, pasty inner layer and savory pork stuffing
har gau: took forever before a cart finally rolled by but worth the wait - nice chunks of sweet shrimp encased in a translucent wrapper that didn't fall apart when picked up or bitten into
siu mai: finally arrived on the same cart as the har gau and also tasty - nicely seasoned pork/shrimp mix, a little small in size
sesame balls: smaller than usual, thinner/crisper dough but still a good ratio to the bean paste filling (portion control's a good thing!)

we skipped the chicken feet, pea shoot dumplings, chive dumplings, sticky rice, chinese broccoli (which was a brilliant green), egg rolls, fried won tons, lettuce cups, peking duck, egg tarts - need something to come back to!

service was pretty good if not better than other dim sum joints - if carts didn't roll by w/ what you wanted, it was easy to let a waitress know and it would come out of the kitchen quickly.

major plus is that it seems a lot cheaper than yank sing, where it's easy to spend $30 per person for lunch - here, we got away w/ $40 for 2!
author: Jen P.

description: Great dim sum- the desserts are what I love best. Sticky pork buns are amazing, beef noodles and shrimp noodles are to die for. If you know what you're ordering- you get the best of the best dim sum. But you must love shrimp, pork, or shrimp and pork!
author: Annette K.

description:
They should get a 4 except that one of the "hot" entries was cold.  Relative;y fast service from the carts but you can wait 5-10 minutes depending on their route.  At lunch time they will push you out very quickly.
Better than some of the more expensive places but prices are closer to financial district than Chinatown places.
author: William R.

description:
i like this sort-of-hidden-from-the-rest-of-chinatown place for dimsum and i remember their har-gows are quite decent (shrimp dumplings being my standard test for a dimsum restaurant). i've only gone on weekdays, so i always remember it as one of the calmest dimsum places in the city. it probably gets way crazier on the weekends.

UPDATE 1/2008:
revisited on new year's day...granted, with an 11am reservation, so there was no crazy wait (the place did start filling up as we were leaving though). dimsum was quite excellent...even better than i remember. if i were you, i'd focus on the dimsum and skip the little plates of entree-like items they keep walking around with (e.g. walnut prawns, orange chicken) -- what the hell's up with that? not that i'm claiming they're trying to sell you leftovers or anything, but let's just say us chinese folks don't eat that stuff at dimsum.
author: Angi C.

description: My favorite dim sum in Chinatown. Lots of trays rolling through and friendly staff.
author: J P.

description: Went here for lunch today and we didn't carefully watch the servers (not that we should have to), we had 4 "extra" punches on our order card and of course they couldn't explain what they were, nor would they take them off. They ended up charging us $95 for dim sum!!!! That's with just three of us (two of them petite Japanese women). I've eaten there in the past and it took 6 of us to even come that close. They don't have listed prices and if you look at the dim sum menu they lump all "specials" onto the same page (so you would assume they are the same price), but nope they range from $5.35 to $8!!!! So they were saying 3 pieces of Siu Mai and a small plate of Honey Prawns was $16! Are you f#@*ing kidding me? I'm NEVER going to this place again, and if you decide you really want to do, I would ask them the price of each plate as you order and WATCH them as they mark your card. Buyer beware...
author: Scott C.

description: This is the cleanest dim sum place I've been to in Chinatown SF.  I mean they have white table cloths and napkins.  Not to worry, their food is pretty good too.  The flavors are good and well presented, so its pleasing to the eye and palette.
author: Bo T.

description: My solid place for dim sum in Chinatown. I like taking my coworkers here for dim sum.   The food comes out quickly with all the important staples of dim sum.  The shrimp dumpling, siu mai, BBQ buns and a few unique stuff.  If you don't see it. Ask them, they will usually bring it out for you.  Which is great because the faster you get your food. The faster you leave, better for them.   We're usually in and out within the hour and about a cost of 10-15 a person. Not bad at all.  Good service too!
author: Chris C.

description:
Looking for a delicious and clean dim sum place that wont break the bank? City View is it! 

My boyfriend and I used to live in the FiDi and City View was (and still is) a regular part of our Sundays. With a party of two, we NEVER have to wait. Also, I'm pretty particular about the type of hot chili sauce a dim sum place serves and this on is spot on! 

I would say our typical order is (don't judge, we like to eat): 

cheong fun- rice noodles stuffed with beef (2x) 
har gau - shrimp ball 
char siu baau- steamed pork bun 
crab claw ball- the boyfriends favorite 
spare ribs black bean sauce- guess that one is self explanatory 
taro dumpling- crunchy on the outside soft taro and meat on the inside 
shanghai dumplings - ginger and pork steamed dumpling with a little soup inside MY FAV (2x- at least....oops) 

= usually around $40...pretty good right!?!?! 

I would definitely recommend City View any day!
author: elyssa w.

description: Do not call it xiao long bao if there's no soup inside. Shame City View!
author: Wakako U.

description:
I don't know Dim Sum, but I know what I like. And I like City View. 

While I wouldn't say it is hard to find, it is a little hidden and that adds to the charm. It also helps I had a friendly face waiting for me inside =)

They serve all the dishes you would expect from Dim Sum in SF and everything I tried was very tasty. We came here on a Sunday at 1 pm. There was no wait and the place was not crowded. Give it a shot.
author: Matthew C.

description: I love the dim sum here and the restaurant itself is nice and clean. It's a great place for large groups, also, much cheaper than Yank Sing which I really don't think is all that!
author: Donna V.

description: Yum, yum, yum dim sum! Their Peking duck is unbelievably good, probably thee best Chinese dish I've ever had. In addition to the typical dim sum fare like the shumai and steamed pork buns, some other delectable dishes I recommend are the lettuce cups, stuffed crab claws and princess prawns. It is on the pricier side, running about $25 - $30 per person, but definitely worth every hard-earned penny.
author: Donna A.

description: This was a pretty good place! Never have had Dim Sum before, and this was a great experience! The service is great, especially since you pretty much sit down and choose what you want from the carts rolling by. The food was really good! Be careful, you might end up eating too much good food because you dont see how much you're getting!
author: Paisley P.

description: Went back again this weekend and was disappointed.  Service was okay, but they did not have very good variety.  On top of that, all the dumplings we ordered were too sticky, as if they  had let them sit for too long and the dough had started to congeal.  Not good.  I like that you can make a reservation, but I've had far better dim sum.
author: Michelle C.

description: One of my co-workers and I took another one of my co-workers here for his birthday lunch yesterday.  I'd never been because I guess I tend to frequent the smaller, non-white table cloth, not as clean, CHEAPER establishments.  I must say, it IS clean.  The dim sum isn't bad, but I thought it was a bit pricey!  Again, that might be because I tend to frequent the more inexpensive joints.  Most of the waitresses that come around with their carts and trays can, at least, say whatever it is on their tray in English.  They have to if they're catering to the financial district lunch crowd.  I even managed to bump into an old friend of mine on my way out the door.  What are the chances of that?
author: Kris L.

description:
I frequently take out of towners who want to eat in Chinatown here.  I love dim sum and feel that I need to spread the love - I'm like a Jehovah's Witness for dim sum.  This place is delicious but just as important - it's CLEAN!!!!  I cannot eat at a dirty restaurant.  I've seen mice in restaurants (several times in NY and once in SF).
Anyway everyone I've taken here has been impressed by the quality of the food and the presentation.  My only complaint is that some of the waitresses speak quietly and have very thick accents so it's difficult to tell what they are offering.
author: AngelaS F.

description: After going to Yank Sing, and pigging out on delicious (but pricey) veggie dim sum- this place just does not compare.  Perhaps it's better for meat-eating clients, but their vegetarian dim sum was lackluster.   I had to douse mine with soy sauce and red chili sauce to get any flavor out of it.
author: Sima S.

description: Today was my first and only time at City View. Not only is it overpriced, the food is not worth it at all.  I never knew you could have bad dim sum til today.
author: L M.

description: You know, I wouldn't have minded waiting 30 minutes past our reservation time if the food had been good.  Lousy selection, half the stuff was cold and too chewy, the broccoli was almost inedible, the shrimp and scallops didn't taste fresh.  The custards weren't crispy or fresh but stale and congealed.  Pretty bad stuff.  Sad part was that we were there Sunday at rush hour so I can only assume that this is as good as it gets.  I know Yank Sing and Ton Kiang are more expensive but the quality is MUCH better there.  Very disappointed...  I kept apologizing for this place to my out-of-town friends...
author: Erick Z.

description: Bad service (it took us forever to get tea), expensive (siumai is counted as a large dish?!?!), and the dumplings weren't stuffed very much. Still tastes good though when it's fresh, hot out of the kitchen. And I guess there really isn't any other dimsum restaurant in the FiDi. I'd rather go for the extra walk and eat at Chinatown next time. Also, not too many places serve good Shanghai dumplings - this is one of those restaurants.
author: Jonas T.

description: Was very pleased with my recent visit here for dim sum.  This place is much cleaner and quieter than most dim sum places, but the food is spot on.  The portion sizes are just right and everything is very fresh.  The har gau is perfect, the various forms of shu mai were great, the crab claws were VERY meaty and flavorful, and the thick slightly crispy noodle things (ok, I don't know the name damnit) were epic.  Sure it might not be the most authentic dim sum joint (the cart ladies even speak english) but if you're looking for a great weekend brunch for a pretty affordable price, you'd be hard pressed to find a better option than City View.
author: Joshua W.

description: Great food, even for vegetarians.  Dim sum is usually not a place for vegetarians, but I would recommend this.  Also for people who are allergic to shrimp, they can accommodate and have plenty of "green" dumplings without shrimp.  A clean restaurant that's on the edge of Chinatown, but feels classier than the ones in inner Chinatown.  Clean and dim sum rarely go together so this one is already a plus.  The dumplings are a good size and it hasn't been too overexposed by those zagat ratings yet, which means their prices are still normal and quality is still good.  Usually I find that an asian restaurant will lower their quality and raise the price once they've been "discovered."
author: Stacey C.

description: Excellent choices for dim sum.  Good prices.  I always felt the my local dim sum place, East Ocean Seafood Restaurant, in Alameda, was one of the best.  It still is, but this place is right up there with it in terms of choices, prices and ambiance.  Definitely go if you're in the area.
author: Greg R.

description:
from hong kong to taipei to shanghai to london to nyc chinatown to queens chinatown to seattle to vancouver to san diego to los angeles to every suburb in the bay area; i've eaten in at least one dim sum joint in each of those cities.

so why is it that my favorite dim sum place in SF is city view? they've got clean, fresh tasting seafood. their pork and meats have just enough fat. the steamed radish cake is immensely flavorful liike the ones i used to get in hong kong (and is also their best item). they've got more steamed and stir-fried options than most places. they've got a great tea selection and can combine leaves upon request (try chrysanthemum with xiang pian). they let you eat in a clean environment with sunny decor which is not typical of the sleazy/greasy/cheapy interiors of most dim sum places in SF. 

and my favorite reason: they make traditional BITE SIZE dim sum like how it's really done in guangdong. they don't skimp on quality and the rice skins are thin and break at the slightest tooth pressure. 

pricey, yes, but worth every single penny.
author: May T.

description: I figured I'd bring in the Lunar Year with a few friends today for brunch.  Although it was a packed house, it gradually got busier busier as our meal went by, it's very good dim sum, I was very pleased with the meal and the bill was equally pleasing.
author: Edward P.

description: nice place for lunch if you work in FiDi but don't go during rush hour, this place could get packed. The food is ok but what I like most about this place is the cleanliness, unlike your typical Chinatown dim sum place. Service is good but be prepared to be swamped by many dim sum ladies once you sit down. It's a bit pricey for dim sum but the atmosphere is better than your typical so you pay for what you get.
author: meL Z.

description: Food is just ok.  Price is OUTRAGEOUS.  My brother and I had to throw down $52 for 2 people for 11 dishes.  Every other dim sum place I've ever been to you can stuff yourself for ~$15/person.  You know how you can tell a Chinese place is crappy if they charge you for white steamed rice?  Yeah, well, this place charges $2.50 for tea.  A dim sum restaurant that charges for tea??  You gotta be kidding me.  Don't eat here.  It's a rip off.
author: Peter H.

description: Good food - I really enjoyed their shrimp dish with walnuts, it was very unusual and quite tasty. Their calamari special was pretty good too.  I wanted my fiance to experience the whole dim sum thing and it definitely fit the bill. But my Gosh that was expensive!!! We left a little more than $50 there for lunch which wasn't what I expected AT ALL. Wouldn't go back and yep, despite the name no city view except for the paintings on the wall....
author: Aurore L.

description:
I really like this place for dim sum.  They offer a wide variety, even some....non dim sum dishes, like...fried calamari, which my husband and I find hilarious.  But aside from that, the dim sum is good, hot and reasonably priced, considering we are in SF.  For other places in the Bay Area, I admit, it is expensive.  But for a good, clean place offering tasty dim sum in SF, it is quite good..

And the place is clean, which is important, to say the least.  

After noon, it gets a bit crowded, but still the wait it not too long (and worth it).
author: Coco L.

description:
Sorry guys, I can only give it 1 star and that's being generous because I'm giving it the star based on cleanliness. It's clean compared to most Chinese restaurants. The dim sum is between mediocre to poor and Chinatown being so close by, I'd much rather walk to Chinatown and pick some up there and get similar quality and pay half the price. Koi Palace I still find is the best - I occasionally get bad food there, but it's still the best on average. Here's my analysis:
- cleanliness +1
- no hostess at the door - I didn't even know what to do - just walk in and see a small barrier in front - should I seat myself? wasn't sure -1
- waiter asked if I wanted tea - didn't bother to ask what kind of tea ... just tea ... and brought a couple of cups and a pot. -1
- they all tried to speak English - this is good with non-Chinese speaking folks, but they didn't understand me in English! I asked for vinegar 3x! So I asked in Chinese.  -1
- shu mai - okay. was good compared to everything else. +1
- some good uncommon dishes - mostly fried, but they were good +1
- sand in my scallop gow (pretty common as it's hard to clean, but the scallop seemed to have been processed - didn't have the chewy texture  -1
- ha gow - bad texture - soft and now chewy -1
