- near the end of closing, a guy walked up and mumbled - I didn't know what he said (it was something in Chinese), so I just shook my head and he took the check and calculated it -1
 
My friend said this place was almost like Koi Palace. Sorry... food quality is not even close. Price is a bit high too - I think it may be around the same. 

This place wouldn't be my choice - ever.
author: Alton Y.

description: Clean and spacious without the usual hecticness of a dim sum place. The har chung was delicious cause the texture of the dough was  light and chewy. I would definitely recommend this place, but it isn't cheap. Then again, I prefer quality over quantity especially since obesity is on the rise. Overall, if you are looking for the usual greasy sloppy cheap dim sum, then don't stop here.
author: Sophie C.

description: This is the group spot for goodbye lunches at work.  Its ok - theres a lot of stuff that comes through and I'm always full when I leave.  It isn't something I crave, and I hate group bills- but its one of the better spots we go.
author: Catherine R.

description: This restaurant is cleaner and newer inside than most restaurants in chinatown but the food isn't very good.  They use too much sugar for most of the dishes I tried.  The chicken feet and lo mai gai was way too sweet and the dumplings were average.  I would go back if I was stuck in chinatown since it's about the only dim sum place in the area that is clean.
author: Luke T.

description: not the best dim sum, but also not the worst.  definitely hits the spot when you need your dim sum fix and cant afford to blow monthly wages on yank sing!!!!  lai wong bau is best!!!  especially when it is piping hot from the steamer basket!!!
author: Chris A.

description:
This place sucks ass!!  Its catered to white people.. I would give it zero stars if that was the option... 
I mean come on!! who serves sweet and sour chicken as dim sum?? The quality is horrible, and its expensive!  If you are looking for authentic chinese dim sum this is not the place!  There are much much better places in San Francisco.. Try Great Eastern, Mayflower, or Koi Palace for great dim sum..
author: Ethan C.

description:
City View has been my favorite dim sum in San Francisco now for many years.  I like it better than Yank Sing--where I always seem to have a hard time finding something that isn't fried or doesn't include pork.  Also, this place is actually clean! 

There was a dim sum cart woman with short hair that I remember from 1996 because she was so cute.  It seems she is long gone now, but at least I can experience nostalgia by returning here.
author: Richard P.

description: "More like 3.5 stars. Good quality dimsum in Chinatown. Great option if you don't want to go to Richmond or Sunset. Har Gou was good- 2 shrimps in each dumpling. My fave was the deep fried crab claws."
author: Jocelyn L.

description: Wow.. how have i grown up in the bay area and never been to City View.. Great clean spot for dim sum.    It's nice to get away from the crowded places like New Asia, Gold Mountain, and the over-priced Yank Sing.  This place is off the main streets in Chinatown and sure doesn't sound like a Chinese dim sum places.. but after seeing all the Cantonese workers and cooks, it's definitely a legit spot.   Very clean and parking wasn't so bad on a Sunday afternoon in that area.   The carts could have come around a bit more often but otherwise I would say this place was pretty good with service.   Their sticky rice which is one of my favorites was pretty good, and the shrimp dumplings and siu mai were solid.   I would definitely go back to this place for dim sum.
author: T M.

description: Good, expensive Dim Sum.  If you like high end dim sum you wont be disappointed.
author: Fatty A.

description: Average dim sum set in an average location.  We had all the usual contenders but nothing really stood out as great.  However, nothing was bad either.  I did like the fried taro a lot but that was pretty much it.  You won't go wrong here but I'm sure you can do better.
author: Simon L.

description: Great mid workday dimsum spot. ALWAYS busy, so make sure you either get there before 11:30 or after 1:30. Your bill will require many bills.
author: Annie T.

description: I always thought that dim sum would be out of reach to me as a vegetarian.  We had some friends visiting from DC who wanted dim sum, so I started the hunt for the most veggie-friendly dim sum place in town.  I came to City View, still not totally sure what I would find.  I was pleasantly surprised to be offered many, many dishes.  They not only had predictable things like veggie spring rolls, but they had excellent asparagus with a delicious sauce.  I expected to be sitting there hungry while everyone else was sitting there eating.  Nope.  We all left the place stuffed.  And it was totally affordable too.  I will definitely come back.
author: Squirrel L.

description: 3 stars for food and service, 1 star for price!  I'm not from the area, so I'm not sure what the accepted price for dim sum is, but seriously...$50 for 7 dishes?  In NY, the same exact dishes would have cost us half the price.  Off the top of my head, I remembered ordering ha churng, shark fin dumplings, scallop dumplings, hargow, one lettuce wrap, beef balls and pork and chive dumplings.  Portions at City View were also smaller than I'm used to (even my non Chinese boyfriend pointed this out), and the food wasn't spectacular enough to merit the huge bill.  Service here was better than what I expect from NY dim sum places, and the cart ladies were actually able to explain the dishes in English, even though I spoke Cantonese.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Dim Sum here is still as good as I remember! It's a hidden secret so there is no ridiculous wait and the food is delicious!
author: Michelle H.

description:
My daughter & I were impressed as this was our first time at City View.  We arrived about 11:30 and seated immediately.  The carts came around quickly, the food was delicious, and the restaurant was clean.

The walnut prawns, and the pork with peanuts were wonderful!  Can't wait to go back.  It's a little pricey but some of the best dim sum we have had.

Get there before 11:45 or noon.  By the we were ready to leave the place was packed and people were waiting for a table.
author: L. C.

description: I understand there are better Dim Sum places, but unless you speak Cantonese, this is as good as it gets. You get a really wide selection of dishes all of which are really delicious. No, they are not (each) made to order, but the quality and service is definitely there. It's a good choice for anglophones - that doesn't mean tourists.
author: Jim C.

description: Only come here when required by your boss during company lunches. Otherwise, there is no reason to get your dim sum here when you're practically in Chinatown and can have your pick of cheaper, more authentic fare. I've never seen a dim sum restaurant serve pot stickers as one of their items. Plates of sweet and sour pork don't count either. And while I'm on the subject, neither do wine glasses with lipstick marks still on them.
author: Philip W.

description: The decor is nice and clean and close to the financial district and away from the hustle and bustle of Chinatown.  Typical cart moving dim sum place.  I'm looking for some tasty fulfilling dim sum place and I don't feel this place is amazing except for the lines that it draws in.  I thought the plates were smaller in portion and smaller in quantity then the average dim sum plates that I've had in the past.  Also, the selection of dim sum plates were fewer then most places. I had tried numerous small plates and I thought it was mediocre.  For the price I'm paying for I'd prefer to go back for Yang Sing plates.
author: pengrin ..

description:
Dim sum continues to be  a big disappointment in SF chinatown.  City View keeps to that tradition of over MSG- laden dishes that leave you thirsty for hours  and a nice bitter after taste to boot.  To be fair, the decor is great, the restaurant is clean and well kept, and service above average.  But the dumplings come out with mushy skin, the meats under marinated, and the cooked food too salty.

The saving grace - baked goods.  The baked bbq pork buns and the pineapple buns with custard work out well.

All in all - it's a 2 star experience in the middle of chinatown.  People in Richmond are better off at Tong Kiang which has better food, less MSG, and better decor. If you are in downtown, for the price, decor, and selection, you are better off with more nuevo dim sum at Yank Sing which uses a bit less MSG.  In the south bay, Joy Luck Place or Mayflower are about in the same league.  On the peninsula, if you can tolerate the arrogance, HK Flower Lounge is not bad, though Fook Yuen has the better food.
author: R W.

description: Joined some friends here for dim sum today. Was really disappointed and felt bad because they were visiting from Seattle and were hoping for excellent dim sum. The place had an OK vibe and the service adequate, but food not-so-much. There was nothing exceptional or unique (and while I was somewhat relieved to not have to look at a chicken's foot first thing in the am -- it would have at least had some personality). Still searching for some yummy dim sum ...
author: Victoria Z.

description: I've eaten here many times, and it's a favorite.  Clean, good service and always tasty.  It's also become a favorite place to take out of towners - in 3 years I've taken probably 50 people here, and haven't heard one complaint yet.  Even my jewish mother from Long Island - who kvetches about everything was happy and asked to go back.
author: Chad K.

description:
I should have known that craving dim sum so badly I'd go alone at lunch on a Monday would mean my expectations would be too high. Really, though, my expectations weren't THAT high for the dim sum (I just wanted shu mai and those little football things). It was that walking into this restaurant, as everyone notes, you experience cleanliness, decor, all the things for which dim sum is not known. That should have been the omen.

Admittedly, there are white tablecloths. But if there is nothing tasty off of which to eat, then the table cloth is a non-issue. The main issues were as follows:

* The shu mai were bland, their flavor consisting mostly of salt and their appearance more a sushi caricature.
* The char siu pork pastries were fairly good, the pastry eggy, flaky and in good proportion to the pork.
* Shrimp with chives left everything to be desired.
* The sauce to accompany the flavorless pork buns were accompanied by a watered down sweet and sour sauce that made me wish I'd spent my calories elsewhere. (And I would have, except that when noon came, my patience couldn't last longer than five minutes of no carts or trays passing by.) 
* Little footballs (NO idea what their "real name" might be, but they're usually fried and filled with gravied goodness)? Non-existent.
* Also, can I mention the large number of tray carriers in proportion to cart people weirded me out? It did.

It should be noted that I ate all of the above. And yet, I left hungry--and disappointed. Little, though, left me as disappointed as my bill for $15.40. (For four plates, tea and water: $15.40. $15.40.) 

This is some dim sum I can go without.
author: Tina V.

description: The place is clean. 1 star, The service is good, another star. The food? The food is really not that great here. My younger sister took me here last year as a birthday treat. We spent about $63.00 and we left unhappy. The textures of the dumping wraps were horrible..... its like mush and it breaks apart. =(
author: A L.

description:
Came here for lunch with co-workers one day.  First off, I'd say that the place is very clean.  However, the food is a whole different story.  Tried their siu mai and they tasted very "rubbery" and I almost wanted to spit it back out.  Another dish we had was some eggplant/tofu, which made me question the freshness of the tofu since it tasted kind of sour.  Things I didn't know were dimsum were served to us.  Walnut Shrimp?  Never seen that as dim sum before.  The tea was very bland.  Don't even know why they asked us what kind of tea we wanted.  Overall, I thought it was way way too expensive for the quality/portions of food.  Someone mentioned earlier that their friend told them this place is like Koi Palace?  NO.  They don't compare.  Luckily, while I was at work my family went to Koi Palace and brought home left overs.  

I'd rather walk up 3-4 blocks up and buy dim sum from anywhere in Chinatown than eat here again on my own free will.
author: kenny w.

description: Really good dim sum. I recommend the asparagus, the stuffed mushrooms, any of the shrimp dishes. Feels a lot fresher and healthier than most of the dim sum places in Chinatown. You can actually taste the food rather than just the grease it's bathed in.
author: Leigh M.

description: Slightly above average dim sum on a cool street in the financial district.  Not as nicely decorated as the Yank Sing chain but not as expensive either.  If you have time to kill during your lunch hour, sneak a seat in the nearby city park and the adjacent Pacific museum which used to be a part of the Treasury.  These are good hideaways for your mid-day excursions.
author: Laurence H.

description: YUM. We were seated before 11am because dim sum is worth waking up early on Saturdays for, folks. We came with people who knew what they were doing (slash ordering), which always helps, since we then basically spent the following two hours simply opening our mouths and being fed a delicious variety of Chinese goodness. My only reservation was with the soup dumplings, which were just OK (Yank Sing has better!), but everything else was delightful and I practically had to be rolled home. Up the hill. No joke.
author: G. J.

description: Good place for large groups. We've hiked here several times from work and not been disappointed. You get a lot of good food for your money. Average price per person has been anywhere from $13-22. It really depends on the number of people. The larger your group the cheaper it is and you can get more variety. Ordering a noodle dish keeps the price down. Try the Cha Siu So, they are little triangles of pastry with roast pork inside. The fried meat dumplings are tasty and have a nice thin outside. All the dumplings are good here too. Make sure you bring your appetite.
author: Arlene C.

description: the most disappointed place in my south CA trip.. dim sum is normal and more other dim sum restaurants are much better than it. place is clean and service is good. price is really expensive !! 5 plates for $30 and we only have  2 persons and not full at all.
author: Samantha C.

description:
I'd give them 4 stars if it wasn't a bit pricey.  $47 for the two of us with one soda.

We had about 8 dishes.  All of them were tasty except for the pork buns which were small and not that great. The variety was nice and the service was decent.
author: Brian L.

description: This is my new favorite dim sum place in SF.  It's way better than Yank Sing.  I was extremely surprised how clean the restaurant was.  The tables weren't even greasy or dirty.  The food was excellent and not greasy either.  It gets crowded by 11:30am so I recommend you get there early.
author: Dan G.

description: Whoa, I can't belive it took me a couple years to find out about this place!  It's easily my favorite dim sum in downtown (the food's a lot fresher), though as with all the others the service is questionable when you want to order a drink or something that isn't being carted around.
author: Rego S.

description: Above average dim sum.... a great place to go if your in Chinatown... without the Chinatown crowds. Perfect place to go to on a lazy Sunday afternoon to eat with some buddies and not break the bank.
author: Alan N.

description: Sorry for the three stars, but I went here kind of late in the lunch hour and did not see a huge selection of my favorite dim sum items. I will update my review after another visit. Getting a seat did not take that long but it was a bit worrisome when I could not locate a hostess for a pretty good amount of time. I would prefer to give three and a half stars for my first visit.
author: Jen A.

description: My only qualification for dim sum was "No Yank Sing" But it was so good at City View! Reasonable too... for 5 of us we ate in less than $80 which included tip. The place was clean and nice... the dim sums kept coming and the servers couldn't understand us clearly. Perfection! Yummy steamed buns and greens and shrimp... Have started recommending this place to everyone I know.... so much so that I was able to convince a couple of guys from my office to hike up there Friday for lunch.
author: Pooja S.

description: Overall a good lunch spot. This was my first Dim Sum experience. I liked pretty much everything we got. The food was good (not great), the service was solid. Nothing really stands out as amazing with this place. I will probably go back eventually, but it is not going to be anytime soon.
author: Blake W.

description: This was my spot when I was still working in the Financial District! It's definately popular among the asian locals and those working in the financial district alike.  The food is always fresh and they carry a great selection.  I've tried other dim sum places actually in Chinatown, and I'd say this place wins overall .. prices are reasonable (between $2.50-$4 or so) and its clean.. not a scary place at all.  Best time to go for lunch is between 11:30-11:45 or after 12:30.  You will be waiting a good 15-20 min if not (the lady will always tell you 10 min tho, so be aware of the line). They take reservations.. so I'd recommend doing that  to make sure you don't get stuck in a low-traffic corner!
author: Lelly L.

description:
oh. my. gawd.

behold! there exists a dim sum restaurant that has carts. and carts teaming with hot har gow, shao mai, little bamboo bins of freshly steamed shrimp and leek dumplings... and this place is (tadaa!!) city view.

bf, friend and i had had an unlucky run of 3 dim sum restaurants that, well, sucked. no carts, bad service, and ordering forms. we thought we were doomed. i was ready never to eat dim sum in the bay area again. and then we found this place. not only is the dim sum sooo damn good, but the place is actually clean. and when i say clean, i mean clean in a way that most restaurants only dream of being. the fare is fresh and really well made, the carts frequent and the variety, excellent. a bit pricey, yes. but at least it won't ruin your dim sum craving for months to come (see my previous reviews).
author: monkey l.

description: I'm not really sure what to give City View. I enjoyed the dim sum, but it seamed that vegetarian and seafood dim sum was only available steamed. I was hoping for vegetarian pot stickers and maybe some deep fried shrimp. I wasn't blown away by anything, but the dumplings I did sample were quite good. It's hard to review since I'm a bit addicted to the Yank Sing sauce. It's just so damn good. Too bad it has MSG in it.
author: Alex L.

description: Great selection of foodstuffs, quick and attentive service. Totally filled up for lunch. We walked in no problem around 11:45, but after 30 mins the place was packed, so check it out early. I liked the BBQ pork buns and pretty much everything else we picked out (not sure what to call it all). One of the better dim sum places I've dined.
author: Brian G.

description: So I don't have dim sum very often but this place wasn't bad. I thought Tong Kiang was better because everything was fresh out of the kitchen and they had mango pudding. City view RAN out of mango pudding...that was really sad. Also, they don't have rice noodles here and those are really good. The wait was pretty long and you have to stay on top of where you are in line. When I was waiting, a couple just walked in and sat down right when they got inside.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Best dim sum place in the city EVER, especially since I've never been to any other dim sum place in SF.  Compared to places down in LA, this place is less hectic, better serviced, and right on par in terms of quality with Monterey Park-like dim sum hot spots.  Price points are def a step up.  Stray away from plates on trays and your meal will be LEGIT
author: JY J.

description: Let's make this clear from the get go, it's in the city, but there's no view. However, they have pretty good dim sum and it's a heck of a lot cheaper than Yank Sing.
author: melissa n.

description: One of the better dim sum restaurants I've been to in this city. The food seems to be less greasy, and more healthy, which is always a plus in my book. Now if only they could do something about the overabundance of overweight corporate dorks with their Blackberrys holstered to their belts (what is this, the Wild Friggin' West?)...
author: Chris B.

description: I enjoyed myself here. I am somewhat of a dim-sum rookie, and wanted to take my dad and brother somewhere "mild." The service was fine and the food was delicious. Besides losing control of a slippery dumpling into my soy sauce-splashing little brown drops of salty goodness EVERYWHERE...I had a great experience. Would take outta towners again for sure.
author: Jen G.

description: Good dim sum. On par with Yang Sing without the wait or sky high prices.
author: Scarlet S.

description: One of the better dim sum places in the city.  Went on Sunday around 11am and the food was delicious.  The prices are about 30-50% more expensive than other dim sum places I frequent in the city. My friend doesn't eat pork or shellfish and they had a good variety of beef and chicken dishes that most other dim sum restaurants don't offer.
author: Y C.

description: Believe it or not, this was my first Dim Sum experience!  I know, very rare for a person who eats out as much as I.  Enough about me...onto the food.  Fantastic.  Granted, I don't have anything to compare it to, but I went here for work and one of my asian co-workers was telling me all about the food and its origins, etc.  Pretty interesting.  And they have great choices, too.  I'd definitely go back.
author: Michelle L.

description: This place Frigging Rocks, Totally pigged out and had a beer with lunch...$22.24 and I ate a ton. Go early for lunch it fills up quick.
author: Tony P.

description:
food 4; service 4; value 3

Americanized dim sum but very tasty.  try their walnut shrimp or their baked bbq pork buns.
author: Stacy N.

description:
I went back for dim sum and i don't know what happened. The food was a major disappointment this time. I thought it was oily and not very flavorful. So this place is not very consistent. So i would give it a 3 stars this time.

=====================================================
I went here for some dim sum and OMG, it's delicious. I was ready to give up finding a good dim sum place. 

The food tasted fresh and not oily. A lot of dim sum places serve food that is too salty, greasy, or taste like everything is flavored with stock. 

It's clean too!

I'll be back for more!!
author: Babynorah T.

description: Yank Sing is a SF icon for Dim Sum. . .but for a really good Dim Sum meal without having sticker shock at the end of your meal, head down to City View. It's on a quaint alley across from Mercedes Restaurant (hair of the dog!). We heard that it gets really crowded by noon, and so it did exactly that. We arrived around 11:45 on Saturday (we were there for the Chinese New Year celebrations). Food is quick, hot and fresh. Very good for the money. Our party of four spent $80 and ate more than we should have. It was all very good! I have always gravitated to Mercedes for lunch, but will now look across the street to City View for a change in my menu.
author: Greg S.

description: I should correct this review only to say that the best dim sum in town is Yank Sing, but City View is best in terms of price and food quality and general deliciousness.
author: K N.

description:
Having Dim Sum at City View during the weekdays only.  Seems there are two different chef, because during the weekend, dim sum and noodles are completely different!  Not because it's stale dim sum, (some dishes are from the day before), but, the Chow Fun and Chow Mein don't taste the same. So, don't go there on a Saturday. 
Service is pleasant at all times, food comes out fast, I have to say this place is a 5.
author: Joanna Y.

description: Please don't be fooled by the name of the restaurant.  It's on Commerical Street in the Financial District.  Yes, when my group suggested we go there I thought it might actually have a view of something, call me whatever you like...  Service? meh, it's dim sum on carts.  Decor? none to speak of.  View?  hahaha.  And if you have to wait there's nowhere to wait but on the street.  We had a reso and we were seated right on time (go early in the lunchtime window if you can), ate our way through the usual dim sum suspects, were stuffed, and got out for under $20 each.   And that's a successful lunch, in my view.  Wish it were closer to my office.
author: Laura H.

description: The dumplings are really good and if I could remember all of the names, I'd rattle off my faves. It's all really tasty. I was a little put off initially by the fancy decor thinking that it was an Americanized chinese joint but after polling some Chinese SF natives, I was informed that this place was legit in the Chinese community.
author: Andy L.

description: Pretty good dim sum in a clean, white table restaurant. It get's packed in there for lunch so if you want a table get there just before noon otherwise you may have to wait. Be careful the bill can get rackes up pretty quickly - it's not cheap!
author: Stephanie I.

description:
this review is written with my coworker IAS in mind. ;) a short & sweet haiku.

*clears throat*

large choice of dim sum
end cravings for chinese yums
tum no longer glum.

*bows*
author: Diana L.

description: Not gonna lie, this place does have great dim sum. My only complaint would be the price. It still doesn't beat my favorite dim sum place, Lucky Fortune, in the Richmond, which has equally tasty and better priced dim sum (and my friends won't have to worry about running into their bosses on a weekend morning when they were supposed to be in the office.)
author: Lauren Y.

description: Not the greatest dim sum in the world, I think I've had better frozen dim sum from 99 Ranch. However, for the price I was very satisfied. As for the service; typically you wait until a server walks up to your table with a tray of dishes, hopefully there is one on there that you like. If you're a picky eater, it could take awhile. If your in a hurry, you can also request to just order something straight from their menu, for a more prompt delivery of food.
author: Marco M.

description: Supposedly the "best dim sum" in San Fran, but I wasn't blown away.  The food seemed average to me.  When busy, and you are not sitting near the beginning of the line, you don't get anything new and unique.  Disappointing.
author: Rachel P.

description: While shopping in Chinatown for the first time in San Fran I asked one of the store vendors where is a great place to eat dim sum.  She recommend City View, it was almost 2 pm so I knew the selection was limited.  So my BF and I  took a risk and went for it  Overall the dim sums were delicious and I only wished I came here earlier for more selections.
author: JAN I.

description: Not a fan of Dim Sum by any means, but I survived this place, and it was actually somewhat tasty  ;-)
author: C R.

description: I'm a big fan of Yank Sing, so I wasn't very excited about coming here. I had heard this place was less expensive (it is), and with the recession and all figured I could scale back and give it a shot. I'm glad I did. The Shrimp & Cilantro was my favorite, while the Pork & Ginger was also fantastic. Shrimp Hargao was good as well. The Shu Mai, unfortunately, was a bit sub-par; but not nearly as bad as some Chinatown excursions of mine (you know, the all you can eat Dim Sum for $5 variety).
author: Donald R.

description: The best quality dim sum near Chinatown that your stomach can trust!  They don't serve anything too crazy like frog legs or I don't believe I had bird's nest here either.  Nice clean location and prices are in line with better dim sum places.  They have a killer custard bun!  Crispy on top and creamy custard in the middle.  You get I think 3 per order.
author: Jason A.

description: Kind of pricey, but definitely the best Dim Sum in San Francisco.  I'm sure there are many hole in the wall places I have not tried that compare, but this place is nice and clean and has great Dim Sum.  I like how they don't hassle you as much as other Dim Sum places.  I do not like being asked every 2 minutes if I want something.  If you are up for some great quality Dim Sum then try this place out.
author: Christopher D.

description: Maybe some of the best Dim Sum I have ever had.  I tried City View a number of times and it was only OK.  In the last year, the food has improved by leaps and bounds.  Good for larger groups, this is the best lunch in the Financial District.
author: Anthony K.

description: My favorite dim sum place in SF.  The food is always fresh and fast to come around.  The shrimp dumplings, shrimp rice noodles and peking duck are at the top of my list.  Although Yank Sing may be just slightly better, City View is usually about 1/2 the cost.  I brought a large group from my office for lunch and even non-dim sum regulars were impressed and had a good time.
author: Michael E.

description: Up-scale dim sum in the heart of the Financial District and Chinatown. All the dishes are wonderful but be prepared to spend $$$!
author: La C.

description: Very decent dim sum in a clean dining room.
author: Mark C.

description: It is hard to find a place that is authentic yet classy or is fancy without being over-priced or faux authentic. This place is the perfect combo. When I arrived, I was pleased by the nice atmosphere -- on a cute block downtown, white table cloths, family oriented (but no screaming kids). The food was great. The wait staff was neither too aggressive nor too inattentive. The prices were great. I couldn't wait to get home and yelp it. Plus, they take reservations.
author: lindsey l.

description: Really high quality. I've eaten at most of the SF dim sum hole in the wall spots -- and I have to say you get what you pay for when you come here. I would pass on the snap peas, but everything else was delicious.
author: Jordan K.

description: Very nice interior and quick, friendly service. The dim sum is generally a bit on the greasy, undercooked side and quite expensive, but some dishes are really nice. I'd give it 2,5 if I could.
author: Dennis G.

description: The Dim Sum is really good here. The only reason why I wouldn't give this place five stars is because I came here on a weekend one day and the food wasn't up to the same standards as the weekdays. I usually go here during the weekdays during lunch and they very clean. The staff is not too nice, but that is my experience with most Chinese restaurants. They are quite reasonably priced too.
author: Christina O.

description: This is the best dim sum place in the financial district.  It's reasonably priced and has a large selection.  It gets crowded by 12 noon but if you show up at 11:50 am you can sit right now without a wait.  This place is much better than the overpriced Yank Sing or Harbor Village.  It's my go-to place to satisfy my weekday dim sum cravings.
author: L W.

description: Not my favorite dim sum restaurant. Honestly, I don't think I've been to enough to have a favorite yet. But, its conveniently located in the financial district, a block or two from my office. Its fresh. Its affordable. Its clean. They have a lot of tables, so you won't have to wait too long. Food is the usual Dim Sum fare, don't expect new culinary creations and you won't be disappointed. Thanks to Dianna B for the recommendation.
author: Johnny O.

description: Stumbled into this place 6 years ago, and have been frequenting it ever since.  Not the "most authentic" or "cheapest" but it's not the opposite either.  Always fresh, always tasty, and close to BART: this is a great place for effort free solid dim sum as well as a great place for dim sum newbies.
author: Dan S.

description: I really like this place - its a pain to find parking but once your there its usual all good. They have the BEST shrimp and chives pan fried dim sum i've had in a while.  They also have an excellent selection of other dim sums!!!
author: May A.

description: The dim sum here is ok if you don't wanna venture further into Chinatown.  The flavors are kinda muted and the bill can get kinda expensive.  If you wanna venture into Chinatown I'd suggest Gold Mountain.  If you wanna dine in FiDi stick to Yank Sing but be prepared to dish out skrill.
author: H Y.

description: Dee-leesh-ahhhs!!! Shrimp dumplings is where it's at!! The tea is pretty "eh" so minus one star for that. The place is clean too, which is surprising for dim sum--but you're probably paying a little more for the occasional vacuum and scrub-down.
author: Jeannie C.

description:
smart way to go in this hidden, i mean way hidden local spot, its yang sing level two at level two prices, this old chinese guy is okay with that ... attentive service, wear a tie guys and get the non-tourist level one service, what a good spot for fembots gazing ... oh, the food, hot, a tad underseasoned, creativity lacking, but hey, its dim in sum here!

later...............
author: tim y.

description:
I am not a huge fan of Chinese food, but every once in a blue moon I just get an irresistible craving for a certain type of greasy goodness that only Chinese cuisine can really satiate.  Today was one of those days...

My friend suggested this place for lunch. I would say the quality of the food was slightly higher than average.  Not the most amazing tasting dim sum but it didn't disappoint, maybe because I was so hungry.  We had fried chicken skewers (which were pretty tasty), sticky rice with some kind of mystery meat that comes wrapped in what looks like a banana leaf (yuck, didn't like it at all; pass on that one), shrimp on a slice of green pepper (not bad), steamed porkbun (just average), thick pan fried rice noodles (in a really good light sauce), and last but not least custard buns (deeeeelicious! I would go back just for those!)

Now for service and presentation....some of the servers coming around seem absolutely annoyed with having to keep repeating the same thing over and over and over to each and every table they walk by. I don't blame them, but hey that's your job, you don't need to bring me down too. I'm just trying to enjoy my lunch. The other criticism I would give is that there should be a way to signal to the servers that you are or are not ready for more food.  It can get a little annoying when you're trying to have a conversation and you get interrupted every 3 minutes by the servers offering you what just came out of the kitchen.  And I think that would take a lot of stress off of the servers as well to have some kind of signal system.  

As far as presentation, I found it a little annoying that everything comes out in 3's.  It's great if you're eating with 2 other people, but often times its just you and one other person, or even groups.  I don't enjoy fighting over the last piece of something, so I think it would be wiser if they prepared some things in 3's and some things in 4's to accomodate both odd and even parties.  

Well, that's my two cents on that.  Hope you enjoyed my honest input. 

;-)
author: L. Renee D.

description: This is my favorite dim sum joint in Chinatown. They have fresh dim sum that is always tasty and they often get a little creative with the standards with some fusion twists, which is fun. It's super clean and the waitstaff is usually pretty polite. But you pay a price for these little niceties, so the tab is usually a little higher than at your standard dim sum place.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Aside from this chick eating with her pink panties fully exposed to the restaurant patrons, it was good.  I mean, I let all the good carts pass me by because I was intrigued by the girl's low rise jeans that were half off her ass, but once I finally got food in front of me I was good.
author: Michael G.

description: if City View was located in Phoenix I don't think it would rate 4 stars. Great Wall is just so much better. However we're in SF and City View has a pretty good selection of dim sum including the rare baked BBQ pork bun! Their Shanghai dumplings are pretty tasty as well, and the restaurant itself is clean, conveniently located, and had no wait at noon on a Saturday. It had been a while since my last dim sum, so I have no complaints!
author: Will A.

description: This was the first dim sum place I ever ate at in San Francisco, a friend took me years ago. It was SO GOOD. It wasn't greasy and the portions weren't huge or anything, sure it's pricier but it's really clean  and fancy inside and the dim sum is super tasty. I've lived here forever and still haven't gone back but maybe I will this Xmas as a treat to myself.
author: Gina R.

description: Fun, clean place. The space is huge, though it seems like they only use the street level dining room. Food is good and they come around often enough so you can get all your choices.
author: Tom L.

description: my go to when i'm craving a dim sum lunch.  this place gets crowded during fidi lunch hour.  a bit more expensive than what i'd like to spend on dim sum, but with location and clientele, it's expected.
author: Helen T.

description: Sunday dim sum was ok. The dumplings were good, the chicken feet tasty. My favorite was the chive dumplings with shrimp. A bit pricy for dim sum, but then again, I'm used to dim sum at places were non Chinese patrons are a rarity.
author: tessie n.

description: Pretty good dim sum here. The usual offerings abound with most of it high quality. Get here before 12 to avoid the crowds.
author: Not M.

description: I brought a friend from NYC here.  We arrived towards the end and there were still plates being brought around (not carts like I'm used to).  We were starved and believe me we had plenty to eat.   I liked everything we had, shrimp shu mai, taro cakes, broccoli, pork buns, jasmine rice wrapped in some kind of leaf, and so much more.  It's clean, the staff are very nice and attentive.  It's a bit pricey for what it is, but I love Dim Sum and I don't have it often so don't mind paying a little extra for the cleanliness and good service.  I would come back again.
author: Magdalena ..

description: This place has grown on me over the last year or so. My real fave is Koi Palace, but downtown we usually go to Yank Sing. i know it's white-people dim sum, but it's good. However, it's pretty far from my office and really is obnoxiously expensive. City View is hardly cheap, but it's a little more reasonable, much closer to me and just about everything is good, if not blow-you-away fabulous. I've become a fan.
author: Erica W.

description: Not quite sure why they named this place City View, they're located in the middle of an alley with absolutely no view of the city.  But anyway, just went here for lunch and was quite pleased with my experience.  The ambiance is definitely more upscale which is reflected in the price, but not so much to make City View a rip-off.  They also understood my broken chinese order without making me feel like a fool in front of my co-worker.
author: Brent N.

description:
She Said (M), He Said (S):  We were brought here by a friend and couldn't have been happier.  M was skeptical b/c she grew up going to dim sum places in the heart of Chinatown.  With CV being "off the beaten path" (i.e. not in Chinatown) who knew what was to come... (Note:  We've only come here for dim sum)

Décor:   Very clean... cleanest dim sum place we've been to.  Modern.

Ambiance:  Can be noisy, but hey it's a good sign of a packed place.  Plenty of room for all the food carts to roll through without hitting you.

Food:  Always hot and fresh.   M's used to some larger sized dumplings but other than that good quality food.  Very addicting!

Price:  Although it's not Chinatown prices (i.e. cheaper), you pay a little bit more for ambiance and location.  

Service:  Very attentive to what you need, whether it's water, a refill on tea (tip: tilt the tea pot lid so they know you need more hot water), to order food off the menu, or to get food that you saw on a cart but can't seem to hunt down on.

FYI:  Get there early enough so you aren't waiting but not too early so that the food carts haven't even started going out.   11:30's a good time. 

Bon Appetite!
author: M and S.

description: So much better and cheaper than Yank Sing. Kind of slow service but totally worth it - weekday or weekend!
author: Kadotah S.

description: Dependable and reasonably priced. Can't say that about a lot of places.
author: Miki N.

description: Dim sum here is very good, and they have a lot of variety.  We've been here several times, and went again this weekend.  We had our traditional favorites of har gaw, siu mai, shrimp/rice roll, and several others.  Most were very good, the only disappointment was the siu mai.  It seemed to have been overcooked and dry, as well as a bit small.  At the end we were stuffed, although we were tempted as some new stuff came out.  A bit pricey, over $50 for 3 but still worth it.
author: Paul C.

description: We had a great dim sum breakfast here.  Our concierge recommended this place for cleanliness, and it was very clean and nice inside.  Courteous wait staff, lots of yummy dishes to try including steamed scallops, dumplings, sesame balls, chinese broccoli, shrimp egg roll things and great tea.   Reasonably priced, will return!
author: Aimee Z.

description: My prego friend was craving Dim Sum last night.....I have learned DO NOT mess with pregant lady cravings.....Heard City View was great, but we wouldn't know because it looks like it is closed?  Also, FYI apparantly ChinaTown does not believe in Dim Sum for lunch.  Who knew?
author: Kaley T.

description: I'm not a big dim sum fan since I don't eat meat, but I have to say, me likie this place.  The fried sesame balls are delicious, and their greens are crunchy and full of flavor.  I also like their vegetarian chow mein and har gaos.  Oh, and I get a kick out of the people pushing the carts - they will NOT stop asking you if you want the same pork buns!!  I mean, one lady asked me like 5 times.  Oh well, at least she said it with a smile.
author: Annie F.

description: Run of the mill dim sum --- 'cept it's CLEAN here.  That says everything about a Chinese establishment... plust it's expensive by dim sum standards.
author: BrasilPo P.

description: I don't know why I never thought about writing a review about City View since I came here for lunch so often???  I think this place is one of the best dim sum restaurants in SF.  Certainly it's the best in Chinatown in my opinion.  You know what your dishes look like as the staff pushes the carts with lots of different dishes through out the restaurant.  You don't need to know how to speak Cantonese or Mandarin to order your dishes here.  All you need to do is to point at the dishes and they are yours!  I love fried taro with ground pork.  They are the best.  You can order fried oysters if you like oysters.  It's not on the menu and not on the cart.  You just need to ask for the special fried oysters.  The price is pretty reasonable.  If you spend more then $20 per person on dim sum, then you are paying too much - a good benchmarking information to know!
author: Michelle H.

description: This restaurant is tucked away in an alley in Chinatown.  Aside from Yank Sing...I would say they have the best dim sum in Chinatown/downtown.  It's always packed on the weekends so if you have a big group I suggest you make a reservation in advance.
author: JenJen W.

description: Best clean dim sum place in the Financial District....MUCH better than the over-rated and WAY over-priced Yank (me) Sing. Save room for their coconut rice roll dessert....it is truly crack!
author: Brian B.

description: Since Yank Sing moved away, this is the best place to go to in Chinatown/Financial district area, for higher end dim-sum.  The food is very good, thin and translucent skins on most of their steamed dim-sum.  By the way, my friends went to Yank Sing in Rincon and swore never to go back after being charged $9 for don-tat (egg tarts).  The other great dim -sum place is Tong Kiang out in the avenues on Geary St.
author: Nancy H.

description: Outstanding upscale dim sum in the Financial District. I've never had a bad dish or experience here.  $$$.
author: Deno M.

description: Best dim sum in the city, if not the Bay Area. Fresh, flavorful, delicious. And the service is superb. Make sure you try the chow fun noodles with shrimp and egg. It is a casserole dish. We introduced my niece and nephew to dim sum here. Now they request it on every visit to San Francisco. Love it.
author: carina b.

description: Sometimes when I find a place I like, I forget to go to the rest.  Hence I've eaten at Yank Sing a hundred times, and somehow missed City View altogether until last week.  I'm jazzed to find a new upscale dim sum place with decent food.  Go for the specials - lots of different choices, as well as the old favorites.  I found most of the steamed dumplings to be a little thick-skinned which is not my preference, but the flavors were good.
author: Diana R.

description: Good dum sum.  Shrimp with chives...delicious...good chili sauce....
author: Pikachu P.

description: OK i went to City View with a little bit of trepidation from reading some of these reviews.  Hoping for the best I met my party there, both who are of Chinese decent. The dishes started coming. You know what happened? Despite what others have said negatively, we all enjoyed ourselves and will be back. Although many of the dishes were not typical dim sum, they were much healthier- less oil, fresh veggies, no heavy sauces, not salty, and cooked to perfection.   Service was great although we had to ask to refill our teapot and to get water. The restaurant was clean and I recommend this one to everyone.
author: Bob M.

description: Not your traditional chinatown restaurant. The food is sooooo delicious!!!
author: Efi S.

description: The Dim Sum is very good if it is fresh and hot.   Every item has met my approval as a restaurant to trust and go back.  Of course there are other Dim Sum places in the area, but if you are taking visitors or family to a clean, well lit, and good food,  this is the place. The price is moderate and not expensive like Yang Sing or Koi Place for that matter.
author: Kevinwdw C.

description:
I don't know where all the recent hating is coming from--is Yank Sing paying them?

Seriously, this is a fab place for dim sum.  It's quick, it's tasty, it doesn't break the bank, and it doesn't have attitude.  Great for groups, great for introducing people to dim sum (the servers know enough English to tell you if something is seafood, chicken, pork, or beef--try getting that kind of service in Oakland's Chinatown and see the results), and just all around tasty.  My favorite dish is the shrimp with cream sauce and walnuts.
author: Jay O.

description:
Cityview is my favorite dim sum in SF.  It's not necessarily the best, or the cheapest, but it's the best value hitting just the right happy medium for me.  The atmosphere is comfortable (read: clean), the people are relatively nice, it's a good mix of patrons, the dim sum is consistently solid, and the price ends up being acceptable.

I particularly like the Hong Kong dumplings.
author: Sam P.

description:
i never experienced dim sum before so i was excited t try it. the concierge at the hotel recommended this place to me and since i didn't know which restaurant was good or bad in the area, i just took his advice. 

i sat down during lunch and people started wheeling trays over to me and asking me if i wanted anything on it. it took be back a little bit because i have never had this style of served food before so i wasn't sure. anyway, i quickly got up to speed and realized you pick what you like off the serving trays and that's how you "order". the only thing is that there was no menu and it was difficult to understand how much each thing was. so either ask the person (language barrier sometimes if you speak English) or just pick something and hope it's cheap. i picked three things initially and all three were cold.  i sent one back and just kept the other two because I did not want to create a fuss. the one i sent back came back and it was hot. i realized after sitting there for a while that the secret is to get the FRESH TRAYS as soon as they are wheeled out. Since I sat down, I should have waited a bit to see if more trays were going to be wheeled out. They keep them coming back pretty fast so I would suggest if you are a first time goer, pass the first few trays that come your way and wait and watch when they bring new trays out of the kitchen. that way you get teh freshest and most hot food. When you first sit down, you have no idea how long they have been wheeling those trays around and your food could be cold. 

Once I got the hang of it, all my food was hot. I did not feel like the food was soooooo great. It was oik. but not anything so awesome that I never had anywhere else before. and since three of my plates were cold, it kinda took away from me liking the place. 

My total bill came to $30 and with a tip, i felt that I had really eaten very expensive Panda Express. Some of the dumplings were good though. I just think getting the cold food ruined it for me. I did see a lot of Asian people eating there so that is always a good sign. Maybe I just got the wrong things. 

I was just happy I was able to hold/use my chop sticks instead of a fork :)
author: Food C.

description: I have compared Yank Sing and City View and I believe City view is the winner.  Well actually yelp.com helped me decide as well.  I find the place to be grand and lovely.  Crowded, but good.  Affordable.....eh sort of but cheaper than Yank Sing.  Portions....they need to work on that to draw more customers.
author: nono C.

description:
a "nice," aka white linen tablecloths, dim sum place near chinatown to eat for lunch or to take family/out-of-towners.  more pricey than other local joints, but definitely provides consistent quality and variety of dishes.  

expect a wait during work week lunch times.
author: Kazuo L.

description: Ehhh. I still can'T get the experience I had at city view out of my head.  It was terrible, and I can still say that after its been a couple of months.  The service there was so bad.  I mean that's kindof what I've come to  expect at dim sum restaurants, but this was worse than most others.  They were simply not helpful.  There was this one woman there with dyed red hair whom I swear is like el diablito ur something.  She reminded me of some witch who was enticing me to eat city view's disgusting food.  (Disclaimer:I am not generally a fan of chinese food, in dim sum format or not).  The food itself reeked of acoupledays olditude and was simply not candastic or good.  I don't know, I'll stop before I start railing on city view even more or start making up more words,, but my one piece of advice which I wish to give is that you, my little dumpling, should AVOID this stinkin' place.
author: Kirk J.

description: When I was a youngster, my parents would take us to Chinatown for dim sum.  This place was never on our list of stops...probably because it hasn't been around that long.  It's actually kinda on the border of Chinatown and unless you frequented Commercial Street, you'd never have guessed there was a dim sum place here...and a rather nice place it is as well.  I arrived for a large gathering and was surprised to see the place was not even packed at 11am.  As the party gathered, it was evident that the ordering was going to go overboard.  They had all the usual dim sum favorites...chicken feet, tripe, fish eyes, etc.  I kid.  There was plenty of choices for the unadventurous as well as the dim sum connoisseur.  All were tasty.  Since it was a large group, it was hard to gauge just how much each dish cost.  By the end of the meal, it looked like the whole order card had been ticketed.  Brunch ended up being somewhere around $20 a person.  It's not bad if you're looking to get away from the crowded dim sum restaurants several blocks away.  Very clean and spacious.
author: JeFF T.

description: Came here for lunch on a Saturday afternoon (1 pm) with out of town guests and four kids ages 6-11.  Despite concerns of a long wait, we were seated right away (last large table in restaurant) and enjoyed the delicious dim sum.  My favorite was the shrimp and chive dumplings.  Service was polite and prompt.  Note that you can order things like fried rice or steamed rice for the finicky kid who won't eat any of the dim sum!  Only negative comment is that the women's restroom was a mess, and two of the three toilets were out of order.
author: Kay M.

description: i'm not sure how i feel about this place when compared to yank sing. it was a bit pricier than expected, yet the atmosphere wasn't quite up to par with YS. being located in chinatown, i felt that overall quality was OK and yet the cart ladies were much pushier and boisterous.  not sure i'll be back, i thnk i'd rather visit one of the local dives when i'm in this neighborhood.
author: Jesse W.

description: good food but not great.  big dining area but not great.  sub-par service.  my co-workers and i had a buttload of stuff and while we were all moderately satisfied, we weren't really blown away or really happy for that matter.  things seemed just standard fare.  sure the duck was aiight as was the shui mei but everyone wasn't overly thrilled w/ everything.  the mango pudding was a complete miss and after that i didn't even wanna try the sesame ball.  must find better dim sum that's a bit more affordable!
author: Swarup B.

description: Kind of pricey but pretty clean.  They don't have a good variety of dim sum and the service is only ok.
author: Mary L.

description: Service is horrible! Everyone does not understand English the food is average and the dim sum was horrible
author: T S.

description: i like it i like it!  it's clean, the food comes out fast and hot, and everybody speaks engrish!  portions are a bit small, but i forgive them because the prices are not so steep, and parking is bearable at the st mary's garage.  try it!
author: Josie M.

description: skip the lunch line at R&G Lounge, and come down the alley for a decent dim sum place.  clean atmosphere.  menu runs the gamut, is in english so easy for anyone to order, items are slightly smaller but still good.  easiest just to park in Portsmouth underground lot.
author: Rob C.

description: i must say .. i have had more than my fair share of dim sum in chinatown. this restaurant was pretty clean compared to other dim sum restaurants. however the quality of the food was the same as other places. this restaurant actually has a small menu to choose from. And the food is overpriced. OH and they charge $1.25 for tea! that is absurd!
author: Jen P.

description: So I used to be a big fan of Ton Kiang.  But then I went there too many times and I started getting bored.  I wanted the same flavorful, clean, high-quality dim sum - just different stuff!  So I went back to City View.  It's my current favorite dim sum place.  It's not your crazy loud bustling dim sum joint in chinatown - it's definitely much quieter - but it's soo good!  Everything is good there - high quality stuff.  Sure, it's a bit pricier than other places but you have to pay for quality.
author: Ming Y.

description: I was surprised to see that many people at the restaurant on a weekday lunch.  But I suppose it is near the financial district.  We were seated quickly, and like usual, was asked what kind of tea we want.  I ordered the chrysanthemum tea which was very watered down and had no taste of the chrysanthemum.  There weren't that many dim sum being pushed around, but for the few that we had, it was decent.  The steam pork bun was not as great because the bread wasn't very good.  It sort of sticks to the roof of the mouth when you chew it.  The good one doesn't.  Another surprising thing I saw that you normally wouldn't see at dim sum place is that they have many of their main dishes put into smaller dishes and trying to sell it as dim sum.  For instance, peking duck and pawns with walnut.  Those are your typical ordered main entrees.  But this might be a way the restaurant wants to cater to their non-chinese customers.
author: Crystal L.

description: Love this place. I have been going here forever. Everything is good. I LOVE the bbq pork buns and shanghi dumplings!!! You have to save room for the custurd dessert.
author: Katharine M.

description: If you like dim sum, you will like this place as their food is really good. The decor and vibe is pretty good as well. They do tend to run out of desert a bit too early in the day though and I had this happen more than once (- 1 star)... And I would definitely suggest making a reservation ahead of time as they get really busy more often than not.
author: Vanilla L.

description: hidden on Commercial between Montgomery and Kearny is this gem of a dim sum joint.  everything is amazing!  chicken lettuce cups, peking duck, perfect pork buns and shrimp in everyway bubba gump couldn't even imagine.  two suggestions to beat the lunch corwds: make reservations or show up before noon.
author: Chard M.

description: Best dim sum in the city. Forget the tourist traps over in the sunset, irving, judah areas. This place focuses on quality and not quantity, even though at times I prefer the latter. Its a bit pricey for dim sum, just bring a few friends and split the bill. In a big group one should expect to spend $10-$15 a person and get their fill. They are fairly busy on the weekends and there may be a long wait, but its well worth it. I use to see a lot of local folks but now I see more and more tourist/out of towners in this joint, please don't blow up the spot!!! The wait is already torturous when they roll the cart of fresh tsa tso bow, ha-gow, siu-mai, around the waiting area to give you that little tease before the feast. My suggestion, TRY EVERYTHING!!! This one of my top three dim sum joints of all time. No. 1 in the SF city. This spot is in a small alley like street so its hidden off the main road. It is cleaner than most establishments in chinatown, so don't worry about sticky tables and wiping down your chopsticks/teacups/plates before you eat.
author: Ron T.

description: Dim Sum gods were smiling down when we asked where to find a good place to get it.  We were told we were in luck, the best dim sum was only 2 blocks from our hotel.  Naturally we were skeptic that this particular restaurant had some kind of deal with our concierge.  The iPhone was broken out and Yelp was consulted.  A place that had a four star average with over 150 reviews was worth our time.  And boy was it.  There were five of us, three of us long time lovers of the dim sum, one of us who had spent the entire morning talking about how disgusting dim sum was and the two times he had eaten in LA were the worst moments of his life.  I wanted to smack him, nobody talks about my dim sum like that.  The fifth was a dim sum virgin, my beau's mother from Wisconsin who thinks just about everything is "too spicy."   Surprise, surprise, everyone loved their lunch.  We ate all of our favorites and some new stuff too.  The newbie and former hater couldn't stop raving.  Hits were the pork and ginger dumplings, the steamed sticky rice, anything with shrimp, ohhh the duck, yahhh.  We went back a second time with a bigger group and really partied with food.  Yes the prices were a little higher than what we were used to, but hey we kind of eat like ugly Americans so we expect to pay more.  My boss is going to SF on Thursday and I already gave him directions.
author: jamaica w.

description: I've been going here regularly for over three years, sometimes twice a week or more. Very good dim sum, with a mix of very authentic (chicken feet) to tasty crowd pleasers.  The soup dumplings are great, BBQ pork bun (both steamed and baked), as well as the Chinese broccoli and asparagus.  I've found that this is a god place to take people who have never had dim sum before.
author: Stu U.

description: Good enough food but very strange service. We were given a menu but then servers started bringing food around on trays. We had only chosen a few things when a server informed us that the last cart had just passed us by and if we wanted anything else we would have to order off the menu. I thought they must be ending their lunch service because it was a little late, around 2:00. But then we saw servers continue to walk around with trays and carts to the other tables, but not ours. Do you only get one shot to pick out what you want to eat? Also, the menu has no prices and you have no idea what kind of bill you're racking up until you get the bill. When we were in the middle of our meal, a server took away our menus and brought the check, eliminating the option to order more food or get dessert. Meanwhile, servers continued to pass trays of food to a nearby table. It was a very strange experience and I didn't feel welcome there. Most of the food was pretty good but it was nothing unique--I could have gotten it at another restaurant with better service. I would not recommend this place and I would not go back.
author: A. F.

description: My husband and I have been coming to this restaurant just about every Saturday morning for dim sum for the last year and a half or so.  We have enjoyed the dumplings and noodle dishes and one of our favorites is the shrimp egg roll- hot, deep-fried and crispy.  However in the last month or so they seem to have been experiencing some operational problems in the kitchen.  The food quality seems inconsistent - sometimes lukewarm food is served from their trays even though the servers have newly exited the kitchen door.  The time it takes for them to reach you also has been more considerable.  We waited for nearly 15 minutes before someone with a food cart came down our isle.  We have grown into the habit of asking for our orders rather than waiting for food carts to pass through.  Oh and by the way, if you're a "two-seater," try to avoid the 2-top tables in the middle row.  The food carts tend to avoid this isle and make their way first to the bigger tables (round tables of 8 or more) before they come down the middle isle.  We hope they will correct this problem because we do enjoy their food.  To finish, one great thing to say about this place is they validate parking at the Chinatown garage.
author: Denny L.

description:
good
- semi-hidden gem for dim sum -- good food, decent selection
- way better value and less crowded than the overhyped Yank Sing and Ton Kiang

bad
- not much...
author: Anthony W.

description: I used to go to this crappy place in china town.. food was good but it was just so dirty! This place is very clean and had tons of variety!
author: nit p.

description: if you want to go to a cleaner restaurant for dimsum in sf, you should come to city view.  it's a little pricier than some other places, but you can taste the fresher quality in its dimsum.  it's also not that crowded on the wknd, so you never have to wait for a table!
author: Helen T.

description: For amateurs and dim sum pros alike, there is something here for everyone.  The place is clean and can take reservations for groups.  The carts flow quickly through the restaurant stacked with plates and steamer baskets, including non-dim sum items, and you can grab the wait staff to order anything, dim sum or otherwise, to suit your mood.  With a group of 6+ people, the service seems to be more attentive.  While big shot dim sum eaters will be disappointed with certain liberties and short cuts some of the dumplings demonstrate (like the famous HK dumplings with soup inside them- which City View omits in their "version" of xiao long bao), but ok value and consistent options, some of which taste excellent, should make City View a place to grab dim sum for brunch with a group of friends or family on a Sunday without felling like you are spending a ridiculous amount, or full of greasy food.  Are there better dim sum places?  Sure, but if you just want to ensure consistent meals, or dim sum newbies are in from out of town, City View is your place.
author: Michael B.

description: excellent dim sum. the cream filled pastry things are tasty.
author: Dean E.

description: the restaurant was clean and you get all of the dishes you want for dim sum and more.  the food, like most chinese restaurants was on the greasy side.  the prices were definitely more expensive.  if you want a nice sit down dim sum experience, come here over yank sing.
author: Big e.

description: I love city view and it is the best dimsum in bay area. A lot of selections, the food and the price is better than yank sing or koi palace. The place is clean and you don't have to wait 1-2 hours like koi palace and the servers are nice, too.
author: sofie W.

description: I really liked this place.  It's a tiny bit pricey I thought---didn't really eat too much---went with 3 other people and it was still about $16 each.  But I guess that's really not too bad considering the quality of the food was excellent.  I will go back for sure!
author: Jo M.

description: City View was a very nice looking restaurant with the white table cloth and white napkins.  The food was expensive compared to the other places I've eaten at.  The har gow was really good but expensive(we paid $6.25 for one plat!).  I don't think I would go back since it seems too pricey for me.  Our check was $42 for 2 people before tips and we didn't order too much food.
author: Vivian R.

description: my friends and i love dim sum so we're always looking for places to eat. last sunday we went here instead of a more breakfasty brunch.  so, i'll answer what i look for in a dim sum place. yes, you sit at tables, yes, they bring carts around (i hate ordering it from a menu or counter), and yes there is fast service with enough food.  It was clean, the service was good, and they didn't rush us.  the food was pretty good too. my biggest complaint was the lack of variety.  they kept bringing over the same dishes there arent too many.  but things were fresh. the little dessert custards were hot, fresh from the oven!  there were 5 of us, we got there at 130 ish maybe and were seated right away.  i think we paid about a little less than $20 a person, including tip which is reasonable. and we eat A LOT.  i was a tad bit hungry after, as was at least one other person, but we wanted different food (if there had been more choices i'd have eaten more).  overall, pretty good.  not my favorite but better than some.
author: Merredith L.

description: i love this place. i try and go to this place at least once a week. the dim sum is great - far better than yank sing. also cheaper. it's also a non-scary dim sum place, unlike the ones you might find in chinatown. if you're looking to take people to dim sum for the first time i would suggest this place :)
author: Miss O.
